webTitle: New man in hot seat shocked by scale of crisis

fields.headline: New man in hot seat shocked by scale of crisis
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Gray faces a full in-tray at the ICC when he takes charge
fields.trailText: Mike Selvey incoming ICC president in waiting Malcolm Gray, who faces a full in-tray when he takes charge on June 24.
fields.body:
Malcolm Gray is 59 now but he reckons that, by the time his three years as president of the International Cricket Council are up, he will be at least 75.

The former chairman of the Australian Cricket Board, a post he held from 1986 to 1989, takes over the presidency from Jagmohan Dalmiya at the annual ICC meeting at Lord's on June 24 and, with the current debate on corruption showing no sign of abating, he looks like inheriting a seat so hot he will be parking his backside in a firebucket for a week. He is the man charged with picking up the pieces of the mess that has accumulated over the past decade and about which the governing body of international cricket has only just sprung into action.

Although he will not admit it, he knows that the next six weeks will involve the out-going administration treading water until the new incumbent arrives.

"Well, it's a task one would rather not have," Gray drawled drily yesterday. "I think we've done as best as we could over the past couple of days but it's going to be a long road. It's just coincidence that this meeting occurred so close to the changeover but we'll be on the job as quick as we can, although finding someone to head the anti-corruption investigation and getting it all in place will take some time."

Gray was stunned by the level of corruption that appears to exist in the game, a picture that unfolded itself to him during the days leading up to this week's meeting.

"I had no idea of the extent of it," he admitted, "I think all of us have been naive. There had been the odd story before but I don't think complacency came into it because there was no specific. But [Hansie] Cronje moved it on because here was a police involvement apparently with tapes and admissions.

"I've been in London for five days and even in that time my suspicions have grown. I thought it was terrible when I arrived and that, yes, there was a problem to sort out.

"But more came out over the weekend and it was then that personally I became a little despondent. You know we take the basic premise that the world and humanity is reasonably honest and we have an implicit trust in human nature. But we were wrong, there is no doubt about it, we were wrong and all we are doing is excusing our wrongness."

Gray's task will be to drive through the setting up of the investigation and to maintain the strength of purpose of his organisation during his term. At the moment, he recognises, there is an esprit de corps that comes from people uniting in times of trouble but he knows that it could dissipate if results are not forthcoming in the short term.

"As I came up in the lift last night I thought my task is to try and keep that joint spirit together. If they want to fight over money, then I want to be able to say: 'Look, chaps, can we have this as a separate fight?' Let the family squabble over money but let's keep the unity on the other issue. It is almost like being in the trenches at the moment. We have all been in a state of shock. But in the trenches, you pull together.

"What we have got to do is find the right person to run the investigation. We don't want an old and retired person doing it as a grace and favour but an energetic young person like a top criminal lawyer from the London Bar, for example, a forty-something that is driving a career - from whatever country because, I can promise, there is no political infighting over this one. And then we must fund and resource it as much as it needs and stay committed to that.

"Although it is independent and reports to the code of conduct commission, I suspect that events will prove it will come back to us. And, if we find a country is not co-operating, then we, or Lord Griffiths, who chairs the code of conduct committee, can suspend their membership of ICC. The thing is though, if it comes to it, we have got to have the guts to do it."

The ICC's firm line has been welcomed by the Australian cricket legend Greg Chappell.

"The dogs have been barking for a long time," said the former Australian captain.

"We'll look back on this and say that the Cronje affair was the watershed for cricket in regard to the current problem of bookmakers and match-fixing. I think the group in London appear to have taken some very strong steps the last couple of days and it's great for cricket."

webTitle: Whopper of a match for the burghers of Calais

fields.headline: Whopper of a match for the burghers of Calais
fields.standfirst: Amateurs from a run-down port will contest the French Cup final on Sunday
fields.trailText: Calais will be the first amateur side to play in a French Cup final when they face Nantes on Sunday. Jon Henley reports on how success for the put-upon town has led to broader criticisms of French First Division clubs' performances this season.
fields.body:
On Sunday at the Stade de France, under the eyes of 80,000 fans, they will contest the French Cup final. One team will be the holders, a successful first division side and no stranger to such occasions. The other will be a bunch of students, council workers and shelf-stackers who earn £300 a month from their football and play most of their matches in front of crowds of fewer than 300.

It is as if Dover were to take on Newcastle United at Wembley. When the players of Calais Racing Union FC take on FC Nantes Atlantique, the hopes of one of France's most down-and-out towns will be with them - and the hearts of France's professional footballers will be in their mouths.

Calais is a grey and gloomy place, all but destroyed in the war, rebuilt in the style of a Moscow suburb, a place to hurry through on your way to somewhere else. The only people who pause, generally, are the 30,000 Brits who cross the Channel each day to buy cheap wine, beer and a bite of Brie in the cash-and-carry warehouses lining the port.

Once dominated and enriched by the lacemaking industry, the town now suffers an unemployment rate of 17%. According to the town hall, just over a quarter of the town's 78,000 inhabitants live on less than £2,500 a year; just under half on less than £5,000. Calais hospital treats 60 suicide attempts every month.

So the historic success of their football club - the first amateur side to make it to the French Cup final - has been welcome in Calais. The flags are draped outside the cafes. Everyone sports a scarf or a badge or a hat. The club was allocated 17,000 tickets for the big match; it has received 50,000 applications.

"Let's all sing, let's all dance, we are in the Coupe de France," says José Demaret, quoting from the words he has written for the club's official song. "It's like a mad wind, this; it's blowing away all our worries. It's a magnificent adventure. It's beautiful that everyone's talking about our town."

Philippe Cozette, who works for Eurotunnel - he was the first to reach through a hole and shake hands with an Englishman, Graham Fagg, under the Channel in 1990 - says the town is transformed.

"It's like when we were building the tunnel," he said. "Everyone said: 'A tunnel under the sea? It's impossible. You'll never make it.' But that just made us madder. For a seaside town, building a tunnel under the sea is unthinkable - like a team of amateurs getting to the cup final."

But if the club's feat has blown a heady breeze through Calais, it has put the wind up France's professional footballers. To reach the semi- finals, Calais beat the second division sides Cannes and Lille and first division Strasbourg. To reach the final, they beat the league champions Bordeaux, 3-1 in extra time.

The Arsenal midfielder Emmanuel Petit found the polite way to express what French professional football thought about that. "Ça fait désordre," he said - it creates disorder.

Calais are not alone in upsetting the order of things. Gueugnon, a second division side in a town of 9,000, beat France's richest club, Paris St-Germain, to win the league cup. In all, French first division teams have lost 18 times this season in cup and league cup matches.

The public, and the national press, see in Calais's triumph a worrying failure. Even the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, complained at first division teams' performances during the league cup medal ceremony, and L'Equipe, the sports daily, did not mince its words.

"We have had enough of you wanting your cake and eating it, playing the stars in television commercials," it told French professionals. "Get back on to planet earth. It's the only chance for French football, which is inflated by self-importance and success."

For the national team coach Roger Lemerre, there is a simple explanation: the top 45 French footballers, he points out, pursue their careers abroad, dramatically reducing the gap between France's top sides and inspired amateurs.

The Calais coach Ladislas Lozano - who was so excited by the Bordeaux victory that he suffered a minor heart attack - sees things a bit differently. His side, he said, has brought to French football the key values of "commitment, ambition, hunger - and humility".

And their star striker Mickael Gérard, who scored against Bordeaux and works, along with the right-back Jocelyn Merlen, at the Pido Cash and Carry, has an even more heart-warming view.

"We could never match the big professionals for consistency," he said. "But we grew up together. And the thing is, we never forget where we come from. We play for our town."

fields.headline: Todd's £2m bonus
fields.trailText: Swindon's new manager Colin Todd has been promised around £2m to spend to ensure the club makes a quick return to the First Division.
fields.body:
Swindon's new manager Colin Todd has been promised around £2m to spend to ensure the club makes a quick return to the First Division.

Todd, who left Bolton eight months ago, has signed a three-year contract at the County Ground after Jimmy Quinn was sacked on Tuesday and will take charge of Swindon's final game of the season at Sheffield United tomorrow.

The former Middlesbrough manager has been brought in by the millionaire printer Terry Brady as he finalises a £3m takeover of the relegated debt-ridden club which was placed in administration in February and is losing around £25,000 a week.

The former Mansfield manager Andy King and one-time West Bromwich Albion coach Malcolm Crosby will be Todd's assistants.

Todd, who turned down a possible move to the Danish club AB Copenhagen, said: "I know this club has had a very difficult period but I'm very confident that we can now take it forward. This job is going to be very very tough but with the staff I have got in place and if everybody pulls together then we can really take this club places.

"It shows the kind of direction that Swindon want to go in for me to take this position and join this club. We're going to have to have some help to do that but there's potential for Swindon to come back stronger than before if a lot of hard work is put in."

The former Leicester chief executive Barrie Pierpoint, who left Filbert Street in controversial circumstances before Christmas, will return to football today when he is named Portsmouth's new chief executive.

Pierpoint left Leicester in December after failing in an attempt to overthrow the chairman John Elsom in a power struggle at the Premiership club. But he will be unveiled by Portsmouth's chairman Milan Mandaric as a successor to David Deacon this morning.

Sheffield Wednesday's defender Lee Briscoe is to leave the club this summer on a free transfer. The 24-year-old England Under-21 international, who has been with the club since he was 16, is the first Wednesday player to join an expected major exodus from Hillsborough.

 Argentine players have agreed to end a six-day strike in protest against increasing fan violence after the government said it would step up protection at stadiums.

fields.headline: Rebrov 'too good for Spurs'
fields.trailText: Arsenal defender Oleg Luzhny, showing an impeccable understanding of north London rivalry, announced yesterday that his fellow Ukraine international Sergei Rebrov should have joined a "better club" than Spurs.
fields.body:
Oleg Luzhny has struggled to establish himself as a hero at Highbury but that may have changed yesterday. Showing an impeccable understanding of north London rivalry, the Arsenal defender announced that his fellow Ukraine international Sergei Rebrov should have joined a "better club" than Spurs.

Rebrov expects to complete a £10m move from Dynamo Kiev to Tottenham in the next fortnight. The assessment of his close friend and former club-mate is unlikely to have him downing a celebratory vodka, though the thought of £25,000 a week might ease the pain.

"I think he could have chosen to go to a better club than Spurs," said Luzhny, who would be well advised to don a wig and dark glasses on his next visit to N17. "It may not have depended on him, of course. It might have been to do with the price. If it had been lower I suspect he would have gone to a better club."

Perhaps he had Arsenal in mind. Rebrov claims Arsène Wenger missed out by refusing to do business before the Uefa Cup final on May 17. Other Premiership teams and the Milan clubs are unlikely to have found the asking price prohibitive.

It is a surprise that Rebrov, who scored eight goals in 12 Champions League games this season, opted for a side who will not be in Europe next season. But he did not look to England without speaking to Luzhny - "I told him I liked it" - and comes highly recommended by his compatriot despite his alleged error of judgment.

"There will be no problems for him," Luzhny said. "I first saw him when he was 19 playing for Kiev. He's an all-round good player, very fast and with a good sense of where the goal is. We have known each other for eight years. He's a beautiful man and a character."

Tore Andre Flo's agent has claimed that Manchester United are interested in signing the Chelsea striker. "All the biggest clubs in Europe have been in touch with Chelsea, and Manchester United are among those clubs interested," said Gunnar Martin Ajenner. "Everyone has been told 'no' so far but now it looks as if they might offer him up for sale."

However Gianluca Vialli, the Chelsea manager, retorted: "I would let Tore go, but not for £8.5m. If [Ruud] van Nistelrooy is worth £18m then so is Tore. If somebody made us an offer, we couldn't turn it down."

Andy Cole should recover from his toe injury to be available for England's Euro 2000 campaign - if needed.

The Manchester United striker saw a specialist yesterday about the complaint, which has sidelined him for their last two games. The club's spokesman Ken Ramsden said: "He went to see a specialist but we don't know the results yet. However, the manager is hopeful that he will be available for Euro 2000."

Even if Cole, who has scored 22 goals for United this season, is fit, it looks unlikely that the England coach Kevin Keegan would name him in his squad.

Paul Ince was yesterday voted Middlesbrough's player of the season by fans. Boro's manager Bryan Robson, who signed the midfielder for £1m last summer, said: "I knew exactly what I was getting and he's been a great buy for us."

Robson moved in when Ince was shown the door by Gérard Houllier at Liverpool and early in the season appointed the 32-year-old as team captain.

"I know the games when Kevin [Keegan] has been watching us and Paul has played well every time," he added.

fields.headline: Our man in Chipping Norton
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited correspondent Derek Brown recounts his experience of standing as a Liberal Democrat candidate in the Chipping Norton council election in Oxfordshire
fields.trailText: 12am update: Guardian Unlimited correspondent Derek Brown recounts his experience of standing as a Liberal Democrat candidate in the Chipping Norton council election in Oxfordshire
fields.body:
The good news is that I came a very decent third. The slightly worse news is that there were only three candidates.

The other bit of good news is that the turnout was nearly 34% - pathetic, but not quite so pathetic as last time. Astonishingly, the Lib Dem vote more than doubled, to 156.

The surprise winner was Michael Howes, the Conservative candidate, with 850 votes. The surprise loser, in this staunch little pocket of radicalism, was Labour's Gina Burrows, with 546 votes. Is this a portent of Labour collapse in the English shires? Watch this space.

Mr Howes, our victor, was clearly flabbergasted by the result, and gave a very decent speech of thanks to the deputy returning officer for the district, Brian Rollaston. Like me, he was a virgin democrat and must have been bowled over by the sight of modest piles of ballot papers marked with a cross against his name. I know I was - though my pile was a good deal smaller.

The count was a pleasant ritual, capping a pleasant day of friendly banter with just a smidge of rivalry. In the biting cold of the town hall steps though, it didn't seem worthwhile for the tellers and candidates to get too ideologically combative.

When the polls closed at 9pm, the town hall doors were firmly shut, and candidates accompanied by their modest retinues (or alone in my case) made for the Fox Hotel. Fifteen minutes later, there was a signal from the steps and we all trooped inside to witness the ritual of the count.

It's a strangely satisfying business. The seals on the ballot boxes are snipped, and the contents strewn on to the table. The boxes are then shown to the candidates to verify that they are emptied, and the papers are counted into bundles of 25. The returning officer verifies that the total matches the number of papers issued during the day, and the main business commences.

In our case, there were just three spoiled papers. On one, a citizen had written, neatly enough, "A waste of time and money" in the boxes against our three names.

On another, a voter, who clearly had a crisis of conscience, had made marks against two names. On the third, a progressive spirit had marked 1 and 2 against two candidates, doubtless expressing a preference for proportional representation. All three papers were rejected.

In the end, the numbers added up. The five Labour supporters, four Tories and solitary Lib Dem agreed that all was in order. Councillor Howes - for such he now is - made his gracious little speech, and the party broke up. Democracy is safe in middle England.

In the biting cold of the town hall steps though, it didn't seem worthwhile for the tellers and candidates to get too ideologically combative. When the polls closed at 9pm, the town hall doors were firmly shut, and candidates accompanied by their modest retinues (or alone in my case) made for the Fox Hotel. Fifteen minutes later, there was a signal from the steps and we all trooped inside to witness the ritual of the count. It's a strangely satisfying business. The seals on the ballot boxes are snipped, and the contents strewn on to the table. The boxes are then shown to the candidates to verify that they are emptied, and the papers are counted into bundles of 25. The returning officer verifies that the total matches the number of papers issued during the day, and the main business commences. In our case, there were just three spoiled papers. On one, a citizen had written, neatly enough, "A waste of time and money" in the boxes against our three names. On another, a voter, who clearly had a crisis of conscience, had made marks against two names. On the third, a progressive spirit had marked 1 and 2 against two candidates, doubtless expressing a preference for proportional representation. All three papers were rejected. In the end, the numbers added up. The five Labour supporters, four Tories and solitary Lib Dem agreed that all was in order. Councillor Howes - for such he now is - made his gracious little speech, and the party broke up. Democracy is safe in middle England.

webTitle: Dons back down over final tickets

fields.headline: Dons back down over final tickets
fields.trailText: Aberdeen yesterday abandoned plans to take legal action against the Scottish Football Association in their attempt to secure an equal share of Scottish Cup final tickets.
fields.body:
Aberdeen yesterday abandoned plans to take legal action against the Scottish Football Association in their attempt to secure an equal share of Scottish Cup final tickets.

The Pittodrie chief executive Gordon Bennett revealed his club are turning their attention to ensuring that a 50-50 split is standard practice in future.

Aberdeen meet Rangers, who have been given 7,000 more tickets than the Dons, at Hampden Park on May 27 but the proximity of the date has prompted Aberdeen instead to try to ensure a similar situation never happens again.

Bennett said yesterday: "The club has exhausted procedures within the SFA. We have twice requested appeals and on both occasions our request for a hearing was turned down. We then asked the emergency committee to reconsider its original decision. We were informed late last night the emergency committee had reaffirmed its original decision.

"We have sought legal advice and have decided not to pursue the matter through a court of law."

Rangers have been given more tickets because of their higher average league gate but Bennett believes the final demands an equal allocation. He said: "We shall be rallying the rest of the Scottish football clubs to persuade the SFA to ensure that in future the Scottish Cup final is a truly national occasion.

"No team should have an advantage by having a dominant share of the support. Hampden must become the neutral venue it was always intended to be for such occasions.

"In taking the decision we are conscious of the fact we are members of the SFA. We are reluctant to take legal action against a body of which we are members."

Jim McCluskey will end his career at the top when he takes charge for the final. The Stewarton official is retiring at the end of the season after 16 years as a grade one referee.

Coincidentally, the 50-year-old McCluskey refereed the 1993 final between the same clubs, when Rangers won 2-1. McCluskey's linesmen will be Jim McBride and Joe McDowall.

Hamilton are set to return to the town next season after receiving planning permission from South Lanarkshire council for a new £6m stadium. They are currently sharing Partick Thistle's ground in Glasgow.

The club, which will start building work in the next three months, will learn today the SFA's verdict on the appeal against the 15-point deduction by the Scottish League after failing to fulfil a Second Division fixture against Stenhousemuir following strike action by the players.

If the 15-point penalty stands, Hamilton will be relegated. Their best hope is a reduced points deduction which would offer hope of avoiding the drop.

webTitle: Rate standstill reins in the pound's rise

fields.headline: Rate standstill reins in the pound's rise
fields.standfirst: City fears worst combination for sterling
fields.trailText: Sterling fell against all three main global currencies yesterday as the Bank of England sapped some of its strength by leaving interest rates on hold.
fields.body:
Sterling fell against all three main global currencies yesterday as the Bank of England sapped some of its strength by leaving interest rates on hold.

The unexpected move sent the pound crashing to a 3-year low against the dollar and shaved more than three yen off its value against the Japanese currency.

But a modest decline of just over a penny against Europe's single currency left manufacturers exposed to a severe competitive disadvantage in the euro zone, the destination for most of Britain's exports.

"At least half of the market expected a rate hike, so the reaction of sterling was justified," said Michael Metcalfe, currency strategist at NatWest GFM in London.

The Bank's monetary policy committee offered no explanation for its decision to leave its repo rate unchanged at 6% for the third month in a row.

But analysts concluded that borrowing costs were at or very near their peak.

With the prospect of US interest rates rising higher than the UK's in the months ahead, currency dealers sold sterling against the dollar, taking the exchange rate to $1.536, the lowest since May 1996.

Nick Parsons, chief currency strategist at Commerzbank, said sterling's weakness against the dollar could compound the problems for exporters.

"The problem is that a strong sterling against the euro and a weak sterling against the dollar is exactly the wrong sort of combination," Mr Parsons said.

"Nearly all our imported raw materials, including oil, are priced in dollars, which raises the cost for manufacturers. But a lot of manufacturers export to Europe where the strong pound means their goods are too expensive."

The MPC's "no change" decision, combined with rumours of intervention by the European Central Bank to stem the euro's decline, boosted the ailing single currency towards the 58p level.

"The central bank talk lifted the euro and it has found support for now," said Jane Foley, currency strategist at Barclays Capital in London.

The ECB, the Bundesbank, the Bank of Italy and the Bank of England all declined to comment on the reported central bank activity in the euro.

The euro also rallied against the dollar, climbing as high as $0.8973, having tumbled to a record low of $0.8848.

Traders said they saw central banks bidding for a small quantitiy of euros at between $0.8835 and $0.8850 on the Electronic Broking System.

"The euro has come down so far and so fast that people are inclined to take profits, but the sentiment remains negative for the euro and we could see new lows - we are not too far away," said Rob Hayward, economic adviser at Bank of America in London.

A trader at a Japanese bank in London said it was possible the euro had now found its absolute lows against sterling and the dollar. "The perception is now that sterling is so overvalued that at some stage it has got to correct itself and we are very close to that level.

"The euro is like a piece of elastic - the further it goes down, the greater the potential for a sharp correction."

Sterling's trade-weighted value has dropped nearly 2% from 14-year peaks set on Wednesday, but is still 2.5% above its close the day before last month's rate decision.

fields.headline: Just call me squidoffsky
fields.standfirst: An employment tribunal lawyer explains why her clients' enthusiasm for no win/no fee cases could be mis-plaice-d
fields.trailText: It's the end of the world as we know it. We've all known for some time it was coming. But in some part of ourselves, I think we each individually thought it might not happen to us.
fields.body:
It's the end of the world as we know it. We've all known for some time it was coming. But in some part of ourselves, I think we each individually thought it might not happen to us.

Yes, I was offered a "no win/no fee" case this week. I didn't take it because something else with a definite pay cheque attached presented itself. But I felt its cold breath on the back of my neck. And it roared its terrible roar and gnashed its terrible teeth.

Sitting in the tribunal waiting room with my sacked but previously well-paid city client (basic, plus car, plus bonus, plus pension, plus health scheme, etc.)and a bit stuck for chat, I hear myself bringing it up, like bad seafood: "Got offered my first no win/no fee case this week."

Client: "Seems like a good idea to me. Why should lawyers get paid for losing?"

Me: "Aah, I dunno. Maybe for the same reason that everyone else gets paid, you know, surgeons when the operation doesn't work, accountants when their clients have to pay loads of tax, people in the city"

Client: "Well, it seems to work in America"

Me: "Well, in America, people get awarded millions of dollars and then the lawyer is allowed to take some huge percentage of it. In America, no one expects you to go to Birmingham for a week at your own expense, then lose because the chair is insane, and earn no money."

Client is silent at this point and I realise I may have been somewhat over-emphatic about the Birmingham scenario, which has been haunting some of my more disturbing dreams.

Not that I'm really expecting anyone to be crying into their beer about lawyers and their fees.

Luckily I was able to go home at the end of this rather strained day and watch a new BBC drama called Fish, about the glamorous world of employment lawyers. This was hugely cheering.

The main character, Fish (short for Fishoffsky), got to go to a lovely garden-view tribunal which looked like it had been recently revamped by Lawrence Llewellyn Bowen. And the chair was a nice man who let Fish pace about the room in a To Kill a Mocking Bird manner when cross-examining and then read passages out of the Bible whilst staring meaningfully at the witness.

He never said "You have five minutes, Mr Fish" or "What chambers are you in, Mr Fish? I want to report you to the Bar Council."

I was, however, a bit concerned about how Fish was going to overhear bits of the other side's case, because his tribunal was based in the sort of building that looked like it had real walls between the waiting rooms rather than the usual skimpy partition things I have to put up with. But he did OK anyway, due to his natural brilliance, emerging from the chaos of his private life. He was so brilliant and dazzling generally that people just smiled fondly at him when he failed to turn up for meetings and appeared in fantasy tribunal with his pants on his head.

I imagine Fish would just laugh dazzlingly if someone offered him a no win/no fee case. No doubt he wins all of his cases anyway.

webTitle: What's left of that mutual feeling in life insurance

fields.headline: What's left of that mutual feeling in life insurance
fields.standfirst:
Standard Life
Equitable Life
Scottish Provident
Scottish Life
Wesleyan
fields.trailText: • Standard Life
fields.body:
 Standard Life

Europe's largest mutual life insurer, with £79bn assets under management. Has agreed to let policyholders vote on whether it should demutualise and pay windfalls estimated by some at £5,000-£6,000 to 2.3m members, though is opposing such a move.

 Equitable Life

Once-proud mutual hit by £1.5bn court case over its decision to allegedly renege on pension guarantees. UK's second largest member-owned life insurer, with assets of £22bn.

 Scottish Provident

Established as a mutual company in 1837. After recently coming under attack from carpetbaggers it has agreed to review its mutual status, with a decision expected by late summer. Some 430,000 members. Potential average windfall estimated at £3,000.

 Scottish Life

Founded as a mutual company in 1881. Assets of more than £6bn. Believed by some to be a possible takeover target - Abbey National is among those said to have shown an interest.

 Wesleyan

One of the smaller life companies, with assets of £2bn. Strong financial reserves, according to some analysts, though probably too small to float.

fields.headline: Lastminute maiden results surprise sceptics
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com yesterday quietened some of its critics when its much anticipated maiden first-quarter results turned out to be better than expected. Despite the announcement of mounting losses, analysts broadly welcomed a strong growth in revenue, subscriber and supplier numbers.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com yesterday quietened some of its critics when its much anticipated maiden first-quarter results turned out to be better than expected. Despite the announcement of mounting losses, analysts broadly welcomed a strong growth in revenue, subscriber and supplier numbers.

But they warned that the company still has a lot of work to do if its share price is to rise above its issue level again, and said the company is unlikely to break even until late 2003.

The shares rose 5% in early trading before slipping back to end the day up 8p at 245p. It remains 135p below the 380p set for March's flotation but 125p above the recent all-time low of 120p.

In the three months to March 31, total transaction value at Lastminute.com climbed by 68% to £7.162m compared to the previous period. Gross profit rose from £350,000 to £707,000.

However, heavy investment in a new version of the website - which is set to be relaunched in June - combined with in ternational expansion costs forced pre-tax losses up sharply from £6m to £11m, while the percentage of subscribers who actually buy goods from the website remained relatively stagnant at around 5%.

Analysts described the doubling of subscriber and supplier numbers as "encouraging". Lastminute now has 2,466 suppliers and 1.4m subscribers, of whom 65,387 have purchased goods from the company.

"This is clearly a good quarter, but the business is at an early stage and there is still a lot of work to do," said Nick Gregg, internet analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "The base of suppliers they are building up bodes well, and is key to liquidity in their exchange."

Goldman Sachs analyst Phil Clarke said: "These are pretty good results, and it looks as if the company is on track to become what it has talked about."

Chief executive Brent Hoberman warned that losses were likely to continue as Lastminute continues to build operations in Europe and possibly Asia and South America. "Our aim is to become a truly global marketplace."

Mr Hoberman predicted that techno logical advances and recent investment would shortly allow the company to offer "a personalised and more usable service across a variety of platforms".

"Our vision is to get to a stage where we can offer the sort of service where we send an alert to your mobile phone reminding you it's your anniversary, offer to book a table at a top restaurant that evening and guarantee you a table, even if it's fully booked, just as long as you promise to buy a bottle of champagne once you get there," he said. "We'll even arrange to pick up your wife in a limo with a gift on board."

A new agreement with Excite to provide a restaurant booking service through internet-enabled mobile phones would be the first step towards making that vision a reality, Mr Hoberman added.

His co-founder, Martha Lane Fox, conceded that Lastminute.com's flotation, co-ordinated by Morgan Stanley, could have been handled differently.

"It's very easy to speak with hindsight and say we would have done this and that differently, but our job has been to raise the maximum amount for the company and to keep running the business as best we could, and I think these figures show the business has not suffered," she said. "We've taken on board and listened to the criticisms levelled again us."

Morgan Stanley believes net stocks are likely to remain volatile. "There's going to be a lot of turbulence in the market as so many things are happening for the first time," said John Studzinski, head of European investment banking.

fields.headline: Safeway abandons loyalty card
fields.standfirst: Safeway
fields.trailText: Safeway staff will be dropping leaflets through customers' letterboxes instead of standing at checkouts as a result of the move by the supermarket to ditch its ABC loyalty card plan.
fields.body:
Safeway staff will be dropping leaflets through customers' letterboxes instead of standing at checkouts as a result of the move by the supermarket to ditch its ABC loyalty card plan.

The five-year-old loyalty scheme is to be stopped from June 1 and will be replaced by a "best deals ever" campaign which has already won Safeway 750,000 new customers - an 8% rise - since it was launched in October.

Simon Laffin, the group's finance director, said: "In the last 12 months customers have got bored with points and fed up with receiving vouchers.

"What they really appreciate are straightforward product offers at great prices."

He said Safeway staff would be sent out to leaflet customers directly.

The group is to extend its "best deals ever" campaign by £80m, taking the total cost to £110m, in a move which it expects to lead to annual savings worth £70 per household shopping in its stores.

Introduced by new chief executive Carlos Criado-Perez, the promotional scheme has produced a 6% increase in like for like sales and volume growth of some 10%.

The group admitted yesterday that its profits would still be down this year on last year's but predicted a pre-tax figure of £245m, which helped its shares rise by 22p to 208p because the estimate was higher than many analysts expected.

The chain is to end national advertising and instead target promotions locally. The items featured will change regularly at each store. Mr Laffin said the new approach to winning customers - its sales per square foot are lower than rivals' - was already proving more successful than loyalty cards.

Despite Mr Laffin's confidence, other supermarkets declined to follow his lead yesterday.

webTitle: iX sets timetable for selling itself

fields.headline: iX sets timetable for selling itself
fields.trailText: The merged London and Frankfurt stock exchange, iX, is likely to seek its own stock market listing next year, according to its chief executive designate, Werner Seifert.
fields.body:
The merged London and Frankfurt stock exchange, iX, is likely to seek its own stock market listing next year, according to its chief executive designate, Werner Seifert.

He told shareholders in Deutsche Börse that the Frankfurt exchange's plans for a listing would have to be called off in the light of the planned merger.

Speaking at the exchange's annual meeting, Mr Seifert said that because the creation of iX "a flotation in 2001 promises to be even more interesting".

He also gave more details of the savings to be gained, estimating that pre-tax synergies would be around €150m (£86m) a year, but warned that in the first years after the merger restructur ing costs would amount to around €100m a year.

Under the terms of the merger, trading in blue chip stocks will be centred on London while Frankfurt will provide the trading system and be the centre for dealings in growth stocks.

The merger still needs the approval of both sets of shareholders. A timetable for the proposals to be put to the shareholders has not been drawn up but executives from London and Frankfurt are likely to see the issue put to the vote before the end of June or early July if much of the work on integration is to be completed before the end of the year.

fields.headline: Friends Provident to float
fields.standfirst:
1.7m policyholders are promised windfall payments averaging £2,500
Friends Provident
fields.trailText: Mutual insurance group Friends Provident yesterday stunned the City by announcing plans to float on the stock market and pay windfalls averaging £2,500 to 1.7m policyholders.
fields.body:
Mutual insurance group Friends Provident yesterday stunned the City by announcing plans to float on the stock market and pay windfalls averaging £2,500 to 1.7m policyholders.

The insurer's surprise declaration that it intends to convert to a plc before the end of 2001 comes just days after it came under attack from an internet-based group of carpetbaggers seeking demutualisation payouts.

However, the company's board insisted that the decision to seek permission to convert had nothing to do with this campaign.

Analysts say that Friends Provident, the UK's third-largest mutual life insurer, could have a flotation value of £4bn-£4.5bn, which would mean average payouts of £2,300-£2,700 per qualifying policyholder. However, the 750,000 with-profits policy holders are likely to get significantly more than this, while it is thought the 1m eligible non-with-profits policyholders would get smaller payouts probably in the region of a few hundred pounds.

Friends Provident, based in Dorking, was founded by Quakers in 1832 and has more than 2m policies in force and £38bn of assets under management. It has long been considered a takeover target and just days ago there were reports that it would put itself up for auction rather than float, if the carpetbagger challenge succeeded.

Halifax, Abbey National and Prudential have been named as likely bidders. But a spokesman said the company was not up for sale and the board was "determined to take this business through to a listing".

The company said it had grown quickly in the past few years and the decision to recommend abandoning 168 years of mutuality "has not been taken lightly".

However, it had concluded that converting to a plc "would provide a more flexible corporate structure for Friends Provident to achieve its strategic goals in today's competitive marketplace and for members to gain the benefits of share ownership while continuing to enjoy the benefits of their policyholding".

A special meeting for members to vote on the plans will be held next year, with flotation set for the second half of 2001.

A spokesman said it was right that the with-profits policyholders - who include people with endowment policies, pensions and with-profits savings plans - should get larger windfalls because they have effectively provided the finance to expand the business over the years.

The company said that new policies dated May 4 or later would not be eligible for wind falls. Some observers expressed surprise that it did not close its doors to carpetbaggers as soon as the Friends Provident Vote Campaign action group announced last month that it would be attempting to force the insurer to ballot members on demutualising.

The group's spokesman, Gordon Hart, said he was "pleased but stunned by the announcement". He added: "The company was obviously well down the road towards flotation when we knocked on the door."

Yesterday's surprise announcement is a blow to fellow mutual insurer Standard Life, which a week ago decided to allow members to vote on whether it should demutualise but is determined to remain a mutual.

Friends Provident has made several acquisitions in recent years. In late 1997 it took over Scottish fund manager Ivory & Sime and it bought insurer London & Manchester for £750m the following year.

fields.headline: Back to the beginning
fields.standfirst:
Anne-Sophie Mutter
London Symphony Orchestra Kurt Masur Barbican Hall, London ***
fields.trailText:
Anne-Sophie Mutter
London Symphony Orchestra Kurt Masur Barbican Hall, London ***
fields.body:
The latest instalment of Anne-Sophie Mutter's massive Back to the Future series gave the impression that she might have bitten off more than she can chew. Her deeply personal retrospective of the 20th- century violin repertoire has passed from chamber music to concertos with surprisingly mixed results. The strengths and weaknesses of her playing, already apparent in two uneven but thrilling recitals, were, on this occasion, worryingly magnified.

With the LSO and Kurt Masur (on loan from the LPO), she essayed the Berg and Sibelius concertos back to back. The emotional trigger for Berg's masterpiece, written in 1935, was the death from polio of Manon Gropius, the 18-year-old daughter of Berg's friends Walter Gropius and Alma Mahler.

The opening cruelly exposed the flaw in Mutter's approach. She began with a bleached, vibrato-less tone, which she slowly weighted until the vibrato was full. The effect was aimed at giving the impression of gradually burgeoning life - but until she had strengthened the tone, her intonation was distressingly unsteady. Thereafter, she seemed oddly detached from the work until she reached the allegro, which depicts Manon's illness and death. Here Mutter briefly got into her stride, with those richocheting high notes sounding like shrieks of terrible pain. In the finale, however, a certain deliberation reigned once more. The concerto should leave you in bits. On this occasion I remained unmoved. Once past another vibrato-less, wonky opening, the Sibelius was much better, with a feistily dramatic first movement giving on to an Adagio which was immaculate.

Masur and the LSO were exemplary throughout, and the evening's true high point came, ironically, when Mutter was absent from the platform and they gave a performance of the Suite from Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet which was, by turns, electrifying, deeply sexual and tremendously moving. The task that Mutter has set herself is daunting, but I was left wondering whether she has been over-ambitious.

Anne-Sophie Mutter plays the Barbican, London EC2 (020-7638 8891), tonight and Sunday

webTitle: Creating value? It's all about investors' savvy

fields.headline: Creating value? It's all about investors' savvy
fields.standfirst: Net impact lies in lessons for shareholders
fields.trailText: One of the most common declarations about the impact of the internet on business life is that it will destroy more value than it creates.
fields.body:
One of the most common declarations about the impact of the internet on business life is that it will destroy more value than it creates.

Eight weeks ago on a wet Monday when Lastminute finally arrived on the market, it seemed that this young, effervescent company would prove the doomsayers correct.

As technology related stocks around the world went into free fall the dire predictions began to flow: overstretched investors would be bankrupted, venture capitalists would turn off the money tap, flotations would be shelved.

All of this has happened - but only in isolated pockets. Yes Television had to delay its 600m march on to the market, World Online in Belgium got into a real pickle and lost its founder, and just this week it has emerged that accident-prone online retailer Boo.com is now likely to be sold to an "old economy" competitor.

Countless amateur investors have discovered that shares in small, illiquid companies are easy to buy when they are going up and impossible to sell when the price is going down.

An unquantifiable number of start-up businesses, acqui sitions and hive-offs have been shelved, and quite a bit of value has been destroyed in double-quick time.

But something of value has also been created. Investors have become savvier, gravitating towards perceived technology "blue chips" rather than chasing any and every self-declared dot.com operation. Venture capitalists have begun to work harder, making more considered funding decisions - and internet companies themselves have begun to think harder, working at how they might make money rather than simply spending someone else's.

From here, everyone has their own theories about which eggs will hatch and who the real winners of the new economy will prove to be.

Last week business to business was all the rage. This week, judging by the flow of investment banking research, technology infrastructure and service providers are in vogue.

The Californian gold rush analogy is in circulation once again, with the advice of the 1850s to buy jeans, tents and picks replaced by website hosts, application service providers and virtual private network operators.

The business to consumer sector, where Lastminute.com resides, remains well out of fashion - as illustrated by the halfhearted bounce in Lastminute's share price yesterday, up 5.5p at 242.5p but still 36% below the price at which Morgan Stanley botched the March flotation. Lastminute.com still has much to prove.

fields.headline: Gems from an old friend
fields.standfirst:
Lou Barlow
Dingwalls, London ****
fields.trailText:
Lou Barlow
Dingwalls, London ****
fields.body:
When you have listened to someone's music for almost a decade, they weirdly but inevitably start to feel like an old friend. Hooking up again is a joyful, comforting experience, even if you haven't been in contact for a few months or years. An hour slips by catching up on the news and gauging the changes; then another, as shared memories resurface and favourite stories are uproariously, wistfully retold.

Lou Barlow's one-off gig - an exhausting yet exhilarating 35-odd song set ostensibly designed to promote the Folk Implosion albums but stretching to accommodate the Sebadoh back-catalogue - had exactly that structure, that heart-warming quality. The changes were startling: from being utterly incommunicative on stage, Barlow has transformed into the kind of affable, engaging performer who part- jokingly, part-lovingly asks: "How else can I serenade you, my fair audience?" and is then so unfazed by one prankster's ridiculous request for the Stone Roses' I Wanna Be Adored that he actually sings it, a cappella, beautifully.

Bearing in mind that Barlow is held as a founding father of scratchy, lo-fi guitar pop, it was a surprise to see him tinkering with bass-heavy backing tracks for the multi-layered songs from the Folk Implosion's latest album, One Part Lullaby. They weren't necessary; his simple guitar and cutting reflections on the selfishness, hurt and excitement of relationships are equally affecting unadorned - but he made an impressive job of precisely melding live and taped music without sounding slick. When he pushed away his guitar for My Ritual and began an avuncular shimmy so he could experience how it feels when bands perform on Top of the Pops without actually playing live, it was another delicious hint that he's not taking himself too seriously.

This new light-heartedness made revisiting the old Barlow, the "antique" Sebadoh songs, yet more thrilling. He played songs no one could have expected to hear: the scrappy fragment Punch in the Nose, released when Sebadoh were called Sentridoh; Gimme Indie Rock, a thrashy index of the late-80s alternative music scene that sounded hilarious banged out on an acoustic guitar; an eerily gentle Really Insane. Admittedly, there was an element of "He could fart and . . ." but that just added to the sense that this was one of those evenings when you pop to a friend's house for a spot of tea and find yourself still there at four in the morning, gibbering and deliriously happy.

webTitle: Brown accused of placing crony on MPC

fields.headline: Brown accused of placing crony on MPC
fields.trailText: The Treasury chose its moment well. Within hours of the Bank of England's decision to hold interest rates at 6% yesterday, Gordon Brown announced that his latest recruit to the Threadneedle Street's monetary policy committee would be Oxford don Chris Allsopp.
fields.body:
The Treasury chose its moment well. Within hours of the Bank of England's decision to hold interest rates at 6% yesterday, Gordon Brown announced that his latest recruit to the Threadneedle Street's monetary policy committee would be Oxford don Chris Allsopp.

Mr Allsopp, who has been a member of the Bank's court since 1997, has been named at a key time as the replacement for Charles Goodhart on the nine-strong committee.

With the Bank's actions under unprecedented scrutiny and both sides of industry screaming for action to reduce the level of the pound, the Treasury is expecting Mr Allsopp, 59, to use his expertise in macro-economics to ensure that the MPC gets the balance right between controlling inflation and nurturing growth.

Mr Allsopp barely had time yesterday to catch his breath before the brickbats started to come his way. Some said that his Labour party sympathies meant the appointment smacked of cronyism. Ian Peters, deputy director of the British Chambers of Commerce, said the chancellor should have plumped for someone who appreciated the pain being felt by manufacturers rather than an Oxbridge academic.

"We are disappointed that the chancellor has not sought to appoint an economist with a strong industry background, someone who understands fully the issues facing business on the ground," he said.

The economics profession was equally sniffy. "He's not really in the front rank," said one economist. "There are lots of better qualified people around. It feels like it's a political appointment."

While Mr Allsopp may not have written the highly theoretical articles that impress other economists, he has a track record as a globetrotting policy adviser and edits the Oxford Review of Economic Policy. Treasury sources said that Mr Allsopp was a progressive economist who brought an international dimension to the MPC.

In practical terms, the new appointment is thought likely to ally himself with the committee's other doves and could help tip the balance against the hawks pressing for higher interest rates. His predecessor, Professor Goodhart, was seen as the most hardline of the four outsiders on the MPC.

The Bank's no-change decision yesterday suggested that the latest round in the battle had gone to the faction which believes that the pound's strength is bearing down on inflation by cutting the cost of imports, as well as making life intolerably hard for exporters.

In the absence of any state ment by the Bank yesterday, a full explanation of the MPC's latest thinking will have to wait until the publication of its quarterly inflation report next Wednesday.

However, it is clear that the recent surge in the value of the pound has been weighing on the minds of committee members, and was viewed as more important than the acceleration in the rate of growth of earnings.

However, while the doves have won the latest battle it is by no means certain that they have won the war. Should the long-awaited fall in the pound materialise at a time when domestic demand remained strong, the hawks would again start to press for higher rates. Many analysts in the City believes that the cost of borrowing could still hit 7% by the end of the year, with the Bank's inaction over the past three months merely a hiatus in the progressive tightening of monetary policy.

The key to everything is how the pound behaves. Reflecting on the events of the early 1980s in an article written nine years ago, the new MPC member said: "A major reason for the severity of the recession and for its concentration on the manufacturing and traded sector was the behaviour of the exchange rate... There is still no fully adequate of the behaviour of sterling at that time."

A decade later this remains true, not just of the 1980s, but of the recent past.

As Mr Allsopp goes on to note: "Neglect of exchange rate policy [can] be highly dangerous."

webTitle: New freeze on interest rates halts pound's rise

fields.headline: New freeze on interest rates halts pound's rise
fields.trailText: Sterling's record-breaking surge on the foreign exchanges spared homeowners and industry from dearer borrowing yesterday when the Bank of England responded to the pain being felt by exporters and left interest rates on hold for the third month in a row.
fields.body:
Sterling's record-breaking surge on the foreign exchanges spared homeowners and industry from dearer borrowing yesterday when the Bank of England responded to the pain being felt by exporters and left interest rates on hold for the third month in a row.

On the day that the government faced its biggest political test since its landslide victory three years ago, the move gave ministers some respite from the barrage of attacks by business and trade unions over the threat to manufacturing.

However, there were calls last night from both sides of industry for the government to do more to bring down the level of the pound and avoid further factory closures.

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB general union, said the bank's decision would be no more than a "stay of execution" unless interest rates started to come down.

"British manufacturers and exporters are still sitting firmly on death row. Unless urgent action is taken to reduce rates, it is only a matter of time before the MPC (monetary policy committee) finally throws the switch on UK exporters," he said.

Martin Temple, director general of the Engineering Employers' Federation, said: "Thousands of skilled jobs remain at risk, whilst nobody is prepared to take responsibility for the urgent action needed to stem this tide, least of all the government, which seems to regard its role as nothing more than a innocent bystander."

The bank's decision to leave rates at 6% clipped sterling's wings on the foreign exchanges, taking more than a penny off its value against the ailing euro as dealers speculated that interest rates may have peaked. But the fall was too insignificant to restore industry's competitiveness in key European export markets.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the AEEU engineering and electrical union, said: "It's a relief rates haven't risen but will be cold comfort to many unless the pound begins to fall. Even the most productive companies like Nissan and Toshiba will continue to struggle. I hope this means that rates have peaked because manufacturing is facing a very rough ride."

However, Neil Parker, senior European economist at Royal Bank of Scotland, warned that further rate increases may be in the pipeline.

"We are certainly pleased to see the MPC has held off from raising rates and therefore not increased the pain manufacturers and farmers are in at the moment, but this may be a temporary reprieve," he said.

The bank's thinking on the outlook for rates will be detailed in its quarterly inflation report, published next Wednesday, but it is thought to remain concerned about accelerating earnings growth and the pace of growth of consumer spending - underlined by yesterday's news from the Halifax of a 0.8% rise in house prices in April.

David Walton, senior economist at Goldman Sachs, the US investment bank, said the future path of rates depended on the strength of sterling, which was currently offsetting the inflationary impact of domestic demand, allowing the bank to keep rates lower than they would otherwise need to be.

fields.headline: Royal mismatch
fields.standfirst:
The King and I
London Palladium **
fields.trailText:
The King and I
London Palladium **
fields.body:
I grant it looks wonderful. Designer Brian Thomson has festooned the proscenium arch and boxes with golden elephants and bronze buddhas. The king himself occupies a throne-room like a tiered wedding-cake. And the royal wives and courtiers sport glittering, bejewelled head-dresses that resemble gleaming towers.

Christopher Renshaw's production is a feast for the eye, but cannot still one's doubts about Rodgers and Hammerstein's quaintly patronising musical.

Anna Leonowens famously goes to Siam as governess to the royal children. What strikes one in a post-colonial age, however, is the one-way intellectual traffic. Though she unbends to the king, she remains an imperialist emblem: there is no suggestion she might learn something of the Siamese way of life.

This production also suffers from a mismatch in casting: at times, I felt it should have been called not The King and I, but The Prince and the Showgirl. The king, Jason Scott Lee, has authority, poise, muscular calves and pectorals, and a good voice. What he lacks is years, so that his fathering of 77 children seems improbable and his climactic death comes as a bolt from the blue.

And while Elaine Paige has many virtues, including the ability to project a number, she is not exactly my idea of an upper class military widow. The point of the story is that a tough governess confronts a testy autocrat: Ms Paige is so full of cheery grins and showbiz charm that battle between the two is never really joined. The best performance, in fact, comes from Taewon Yi Kim who - as the king's head wife - almost stops the show with her melting rendering of Something Wonderful.

Otherwise one is left to admire the spectacle, a glittering oriental kaleidscope, and the dancing: the interlude in which the royal household presents a ballet retains its irrelevant panache in Susan Kikuchi's reworking of Jerome Robbins's choreography. And the moment when Anna and the king break into the famous polka, Shall We Dance, briefly lifts the spirits.

But it remains a curiously old-fashioned, operetta-like musical, of the kind Rodgers and Hammerstein were meant to have banished with Oklahoma! And behind it lurks the belief that the Siamese are either despots, slaves or naive children who need a good dose of British enlightenment.

Today the show is a political embarrassment that not even Richard Rodgers's seductive songs can redeem.

Booking to next year. Box office: 020-7494 5020. This review appeared in some editions yesterday

fields.headline: Is that it?
fields.standfirst:
Match-fixers to face life bans
ICC decisions and punishments
Legal minefield awaits
fields.trailText: Frank Keating doubts the ICC has done enough to bring the game back on track.
fields.body:
Power inside the International Cricket Council may have been rudely wrested from the fuddy dominion's base at Lord's, but yesterday it at least managed a traditional British answer to a thorny problem - set up a committee to report back in the fullness of time.

Tell you what, no betting man would have got odds from his bookmaker on the ICC not setting up a committee of investigation. Well, what else could they do?

Quite a lot in fact. To be sure, it would be appalling if the inquiry limped along toothlessly and secretively before looking for a chance to fob off the mountains of cynical doubts and rumours.

Lord Griffiths, already chairman of the ICC's code of conduct committee, must play a blinder here as he has never remotely been seen to do before. Procrastination of the sort that he and his dozy ICC peers have been used to would have a brutally ruinous effect on a game already riddled with self-doubt and lack of leadership.

When, as well, is Lord MacLaurin actually going to show what he's made of? There is more to leadership than pronouncing sombre sentences to Radio 5 Live presenters.

One's confidence in this new committee of inquiry in sorting out the criminals - or even distancing cricket from them - took a dive with yesterday's further announcement that everyone concerned will be asked to sign a statement of integrity promising he is "clean".

Here's a piece of paper asking "Are you a crook?" Tick box "yes" or "no".

"No? Good boy. That's all right then."

Or: "Hansie, just put a tick in either of the boxes. No? Fine, you can captain South Africa this morning."

Such a bizarre and naive proposal makes one wonder if the 18 men around the table yesterday knew exactly why they had been summoned to sit there in the first place. Well, cricket is obviously a very honest game - see, we've got a host of signatures to prove it.

There was no announcement of any immediate reform of the one-day international fixture lists. A radical culling of all those worthless one-dayers, mostly played on the subcontinent, would have been my first act. In these corruption is a cinch - they are so meaningless and ubiquitous that nobody, even the morning after, can say who won or lost, or could care less. The players have no remote pride in playing them, and are careless about scoring a duck or a century.

Had yesterday's meeting come clean and admitted it, and announced a universal ongoing one-day world championship played for international kudos and prize money, the grubby barrage of meaningless fixtures would vanish like a shot. Is this the sort of thing Lord Griffiths has been charged to provide? I doubt it somehow.

The ICC's outgoing president Jagmohan Dalmiya will probably see yesterday as a triumph for negotiation and diplomacy. His three-year stewardship has been a disaster. High moral leadership, so desperately needed, has been non-existent.

Dalmiya seems to have survived seemingly wild allegations that he took kickbacks from television rights with ease, but he cannot escape the sober charge of complicity in the fatuous devaluation of cricket as a whole.

You desperately yearn for the days only a decade ago when the ICC was an almost unheard of adjunct of dear old MCC and its buffers at St John's Wood, who would hold amiable meetings over a couple of pink gins about the value of leg-byes or tinkering with the lbw law to allow leg-spinners a chance.

Dalmiya burst that all asunder when he saw his chance after the 1996 World Cup bidding had been put in the bag for England - when the chairman Colin Cowdrey languidly allowed South Africa to put in a bid simply to show their future intent. Dalmiya pounced - "what about us?" - and the 1996 tournament went east. Doubtless to the joy of its bookmakers.

The game - and for sure the certainty of its morals and ethics and innate goodness - has never been the same since. And yesterday seems to have done very little to alter that appalling indictment.

fields.headline: Legal minefield awaits new measures
fields.standfirst:
Match-fixers to face life bans
ICC decisions and punishments
Frank Keating
fields.trailText: In outlining a series of measures designed to root out corruption the ICC has entered a legal minefield which could leave it open to action in the courts and undermine its attempts to clean up the game.
fields.body:
In outlining a series of measures designed to root out corruption the ICC has entered a legal minefield which could leave it open to action in the courts and undermine its attempts to clean up the game.

Lawyers specialising in sports contracts agreed yesterday that the ICC's decision to introduce a declaration for those in cricket to state if they have been involved in corruption could prove one of the most problematic measures.

The ICC has also admitted that it needs to take further legal advice on several other aspects. It is not clear what disciplinary powers the anti-corruption team will have and whether it will have the legal right to hold inquiries into alleged match-fixing on foreign soil.

Under the law, cricketers currently under contract cannot be forced to sign any declaration. The only way this can be done is if the player and the relevant cricket board agree to a change in the contract, which could be amended to make signing the declaration compulsory.

Players who do not sign the declaration cannot be sacked, as this could leave the ICC or relevant national board open to a case of unfair dismissal.

A lawyer from one of the country's leading sports law firms said: "The declaration can be used in a court of law against any player who may have signed it. It would also make it easier to terminate that player's contract [if] a player knowingly lied. It is a powerful weapon but the problem is that players cannot be forced to sign it and there is no way of knowing if they are telling the truth or not."

Lawyers believe there are few problems with making the declaration retroactive but that one of the biggest problems is the ICC's wide definition of corruption.

Another sports lawyer, Joyti Manjdadria, said: "Many players will sign the declaration for practical reasons. But there is a very wide definition to corruption and this could cause more problems. What would happen if a player was corrupt but is not now? Can action still be taken against them?"

Problems are also likely to arise over the rule changes that have been implemented over the past few years by the ICC. Lawyers claim that a player cannot be charged with an offence that is against the rules now but was not five years ago, for example.

Many believe that players will sign declarations out of public pressure but that they would be on strong legal grounds if they refused.

Ultimately, the ICC will be able to prevent any player or country from taking part in international cricket if it feels that they are trying to cover up corruption or are not taking the matter seriously enough.

The ICC chief executive Dave Richards conceded yesterday that the organisation is relying on the goodwill of players to sign the declaration and weed out corruption. He was confident that all players would sign. It will also be up to players to reveal the details of any alleged corruption. They will face penalties if found guilty.

For critics of the organisation, however, the fact that lawyers are still being consulted over the legal implications of the new measures is a further sign that match-fixing is still not being tackled seriously enough.

Inderjit Singh Bindra, a former president of the Indian board of control, is to present a dossier on match-fixing to the ICC. He claims to have 100 pages of information relating to corruption among players and cricket administrators.

Bindra, who is currently in London, said yesterday: "I have named names where I can and have been preparing this document for a number of weeks. The ICC was supposed to discuss match-fixing but no specific allegations have been discussed.

"I am not sure whether these measures will be enough to tackle corruption and I was hoping that they would come out with something more concrete."

fields.headline: ICC decisions and punishments
fields.standfirst:
Match-fixers to face life bans
Legal minefield awaits
Frank Keating
fields.trailText:
Decisions
• The final report of match-fixing in Pakistan has to be made available within five weeks.
fields.body:
Decisions
 The final report of match-fixing in Pakistan has to be made available within five weeks.

 Every board to deal with evidence affecting players and others individuals within their jurisdiction.

 Fines and possible life bans for anyone found guilty of corruption.

 Suspension of any country failing to cooperate with the code of conduct commission.

 All international players and officials to sign a declaration stating they have not been involved in corruption.

 Independent anti-corruption investigation set up.

 Standard registration system listing unacceptable behaviour.

Punishments
 Life ban for anyone influencing or attempting to influence the result of a match.

 Life ban for anyone underperforming in any match owing to an arrangement relating to betting.

 Five-year ban or unlimited fine for a bet on any match in which a player or official took part.

 Five-year ban and unlimited fine for inducing and encouraging anyone to bet on any match.

 Five-year ban and unlimited fine for gambling on any match.

 Five-year ban for receiving money or other reward for providing information on weather, teams, state of the ground, status of, or outcome of a match

 Life ban and/or unlimited fine for receiving any money or other reward for bringing the game into disrepute.

fields.headline: Match-fixers to face life bans
fields.standfirst:
ICC announces swingeing penalties and plans for anti-corruption investigation
ICC decisions and punishments
Legal minefield awaits
Frank Keating
fields.trailText: The ICC yesterday demonstrated, in the strongest terms it can muster, its commitment to cleaning up the sport when it announced swingeing penalties and plans for anti-corruption investigation.
fields.body:
The International Cricket Council yesterday demonstrated, in the strongest terms it can muster, its commitment to cleaning up the sport by announcing a package of measures to counter corruption, including life bans for those found guilty of match-fixing in any form, and the setting up of an independent anti-corruption investigation. Inquiries could extend back almost seven years, to July 1 1993, and penalties can be retroactive.

Following the two-day emergency meeting of the ICC executive, there is also a firm agreement from all nine of the member countries that they will co-operate fully with any investigations, and failure to do so could result in suspension from the ICC.

However, plans to ask all current international players to sign a declaration, stating whether or not they have been involved in corrupt practice - although not whether they know of anyone else - seem a little optimistic with no incentive to be honest once the prospect of an amnesty was rejected as unworkable. They cannot seriously be expecting too many ticks in the "yes" box.

For a body as habitually slothful as the ICC, it represents massive progress, however, and the chairman of the England and Wales Cricket Board, Lord MacLaurin, upon whose initiative the meeting was assembled in the wake of the Hansie Cronje affair, admitted that the implementation of life bans will be the only way to restore public confidence in the game.

"We have got unanimity between all test-playing nations to root this out," he said. "But it is very difficult because there has been so much hearsay and innuendo. We have to find someone guilty, whoever it is, and make an example of them by kicking them out of the game for good."

The penalties for match- fixing, gambling and, for good measure, involvement in drugs are swingeing. Betting on matches involving one's own country or encouraging others to do so will bring five years and unlimited fines. Indulge in match-fixing, inducement, under-performing or contrivance and that is it for life.

Nailing the miscreants is going to be the big problem, however, and the anti-corruption investigation will be ongoing with wide-ranging powers within the game as a whole, covering not just players but umpires, team officials, referees, administrators and employees, although no sphere of influence beyond that.

It is to be totally independent of the ICC, is to be set up immediately and operational by the time of the full ICC meeting in July. According to the ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya, it will be headed by "a very senior experienced person of legal background or experienced in investigation, a QC or of that rank".

The appointment will be made in consultation with Lord Griffiths, QC, the chairman of the ICC's code of conduct commission, with he or his successors the only conduit to the ICC once the investigation is in place. "It will be totally resourced by [the] ICC," Dalmiya confirmed, "and its terms of reference drawn in consultation with Lord Griffiths." Despite the declarations of accord and the unanimity within the ICC, there is bound to be some controversy over Lord Griffiths' eventual choice to lead the investigation.

It is also vital, for the good of the game if nothing else, that any findings are not kept in-house. "We must be as transparent as possible," said MacLaurin. "Once an investigation has taken place its findings must be released."

One of its first tasks will be to focus on the Pakistan government-commissioned report into corruption, compiled by Justice Qayyum. It took two years to complete and was submitted nine months ago but has yet to see the light of day. One leak alleges that the report recommends life bans for Salim Malik, since retired, and Mushtaq Ahmed, but all will be revealed in five weeks' time when it will be handed over to the ICC.

The ICC investigation will also monitor closely the judicial inquiry into Cronjegate which is to begin in South Africa soon and those that have been or are being held in India, England and Australia. The name of the man to lead the South Africa inquiry is expected today or tomorrow.

The idea of an amnesty was always fanciful but might have offered a way out for potential whistle-blowers. However, it was deemed unworkable not least for legal reasons. "We could not put ourselves in a position where we were offering amnesty to people who had committed criminal offences. That is not within our jurisdiction," said the ICC chief executive David Richards.

Chris Lewis, whose revelations to a Sunday newspaper contributed to the match-fixing debate, said: "I haven't studied the full statement, but if the ICC is talking about life bans and long-term bans, then it is a definite beginning. They are showing people around the world that this won't be tolerated. All of us earn a living in cricket and if the game gets tarnished we are in the mire."
