Nailing the miscreants is going to be the big problem, however, and the anti-corruption investigation will be ongoing with wide-ranging powers within the game as a whole, covering not just players but umpires, team officials, referees, administrators and employees, although no sphere of influence beyond that. It is to be totally independent of the ICC, is to be set up immediately and operational by the time of the full ICC meeting in July. According to the ICC president Jagmohan Dalmiya, it will be headed by "a very senior experienced person of legal background or experienced in investigation, a QC or of that rank". The appointment will be made in consultation with Lord Griffiths, QC, the chairman of the ICC's code of conduct commission, with he or his successors the only conduit to the ICC once the investigation is in place. "It will be totally resourced by [the] ICC," Dalmiya confirmed, "and its terms of reference drawn in consultation with Lord Griffiths." Despite the declarations of accord and the unanimity within the ICC, there is bound to be some controversy over Lord Griffiths' eventual choice to lead the investigation. It is also vital, for the good of the game if nothing else, that any findings are not kept in-house. "We must be as transparent as possible," said MacLaurin. "Once an investigation has taken place its findings must be released." One of its first tasks will be to focus on the Pakistan government-commissioned report into corruption, compiled by Justice Qayyum. It took two years to complete and was submitted nine months ago but has yet to see the light of day. One leak alleges that the report recommends life bans for Salim Malik, since retired, and Mushtaq Ahmed, but all will be revealed in five weeks' time when it will be handed over to the ICC. The ICC investigation will also monitor closely the judicial inquiry into Cronjegate which is to begin in South Africa soon and those that have been or are being held in India, England and Australia. The name of the man to lead the South Africa inquiry is expected today or tomorrow. The idea of an amnesty was always fanciful but might have offered a way out for potential whistle-blowers. However, it was deemed unworkable not least for legal reasons. "We could not put ourselves in a position where we were offering amnesty to people who had committed criminal offences. That is not within our jurisdiction," said the ICC chief executive David Richards. Chris Lewis, whose revelations to a Sunday newspaper contributed to the match-fixing debate, said: "I haven't studied the full statement, but if the ICC is talking about life bans and long-term bans, then it is a definite beginning. They are showing people around the world that this won't be tolerated. All of us earn a living in cricket and if the game gets tarnished we are in the mire."

fields.headline: Warne in lookalike contest
fields.standfirst: Hampshire 232 Somerset 14-2
fields.trailText: Hampshire v Somerset
fields.body:
Those who came for Shane Warne's championship debut had mostly to make do with a lookalike instead. Somerset's Ian Blackwell has the same shock of blond hair and the same approach to the wicket.

A talented spinner, too, and his figures of 22-12-26-1 were rather Warne-like even though he is a left-armer. The real thing made his first appearance as a batsman and fell lbw to Andy Caddick for a three-ball duck.

When Hampshire took the field late on their captain Robin Smith appeared to sense the feeling of anti-climax in the crowd and introduced Warne to bowl the second over. But the two Somerset wickets to fall went to Shaun Udal .

The outstanding cricket, though, came from Hampshire's Derek Kenway. He should have been gripped by a terrible anxiety. Making his first-class wicketkeeping debut because of Adrian Aymes's cartilage problem, he is having to contend with Warne's sophisticated variety of twirls.

But this did not affect his batting. Dropped down the order from opener because of his new duties, he arrived at 69 for three and was unbeaten on 93 when Hampshire were all out for 232.

He batted for four hours, hit 16 fours and put on 109 for the last two wickets with Alex Mor ris and Simon Renshaw. Kenway has always had ability - last season he scored 1,055 runs at 42 - but Hampshire's new coach Jimmy Cook appears to have hardened his resolve.

This was an impressive performance against Caddick, bowling with his tail up to take five for 62, although Somerset's attack was weakened when Matt Bulbeck left the field with a sore back.

Hampshire had won the toss and were in little trouble reaching 50 in the first hour. But when Giles White was caught by the finer of the two gullies off Steffan Jones it prompted a collapse that saw seven wickets fall for 65 runs. Caddick had three lbw decisions in 16 deliveries for two runs.

webTitle: Martin has more cut in the same thrust

fields.headline: Martin has more cut in the same thrust
fields.standfirst: Leicestershire 263-9 v Lancashire
fields.trailText: Leicestershire v Lancashire
fields.body:
There remains a sense of under-achievement about Peter Martin. Twelve five-wicket hauls in the same number of summers suggest a career that has long become lodged in the solid rather than the spectacular.

Good days have tended to be hard won, with a weary satisfaction drawn from hours of genial foot-slogging and pleasure in a Lancashire victory.

At 31, he is not about to change his image. Eight tests and 20 one-day internationals might prove to be the limit of his England recognition. All the more reason, then, to draw special satisfaction from his six wickets on a frustrating launch to Lancashire's home championship season.

Martin's 31 overs were much in keeping with a labourer's reputation. The uncustomary bonus came after tea, in a spell of four for 18 in 12 overs as he tore through the lower middle order in a manner that has traditionally been the province of such as Wasim Akram and Muthiah Muralitharan.

It is Lancashire's shifting overseas emphasis this summer that demands that Martin develops more of a strike bowler's mentality. Chris Lewis, leg-before when working to leg in the first over after tea, and the trio of Vince Wells, Neil Burns and Phillip DeFreitas, all caught by wicketkeeper or slip, can vouch that yesterday he did just that.

Even then Lancashire's suspect cutting edge remained apparent. Leicestershire's last-wicket pair of Jimmy Ormond and Anil Kumble were allowed to complete the rescue, assembling an unbroken stand of 45, with Ormond so unperturbed by Chris Schofield's leg-spin that he launched him for six over midwicket within minutes of coming in.

Martin, like Lancashire's attack in general, lacked his usual consistency during the arctic preliminaries of the Benson & Hedges Cup. A cold morning had some Lancashire players covering their new-look fleeces with an extra sweater or two, but Martin warmed up in time to have had Aftab Habib leg-before just before lunch and later found some devastating swing to remove Trevor Ward's off-stump.

Leicestershire had lost four morning wickets. Darren Stevens dashed to 41 before becoming one of two victims for Andrew Flintoff. Darren Maddy failed again and has done nothing to tantalise England's selectors before the first test against Zimbabwe.

Leicestershire's sobriety, from that point, even encompassed Lewis, who was a model of deliberation. There was no repeat of the boos that greeted him on this ground during a Benson & Hedges tie last month. No one should be surprised about that. Championship crowds have always been more astute.

fields.headline: Kent expose tourists' shortcomings
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabweans 159
Kent 10-1
fields.trailText: The ice cream van lurking shamelessly inside the Old Dover Road entrance must have struck the tourists as something of a joke, and a cruelly mocking one at that. As if the poor chaps don't have enough to contend with, an outbreak of goosepimples was scarcely what the doctor ordered.
fields.body:
The ice cream van lurking shamelessly inside the Old Dover Road entrance must have struck the tourists as something of a joke, and a cruelly mocking one at that. As if the poor chaps don't have enough to contend with, an outbreak of goosepimples was scarcely what the doctor ordered.

Confronted by a Kent attack boasting just one first-choice specialist in Min Patel, the Zimbabweans will note that eight of their first nine men reached double figures but the encouragement stopped there. Nobody passed 24 and the two highest scorers, Heath Streak and Mluleki Nkala, were numbers eight and 10.

With Andy Flower unwell and Alistair Campbell deemed in decent enough fettle after a century against Hampshire, the lesser lights did not so much fizzle as short circuit.

Their chief inquisitor, making his first-class bow, was David Masters, a wiry, nippy seamer with a supple action as well as an unusually firm grasp of line and length. Four of the first five wickets were his: he deserved nothing less.

After Streak had elected to bat, an hour elapsed before the outfield had dried sufficiently to permit play, the first incision coming in the sixth over when Grant Flower nicked Masters to second slip where Rahul Dravid took a deft catch to his right. It was a wonder the Indian withdrew his hands from his pockets in time.

Trevor Gripper could have taught Geoff Boycott a thing or two about boring for his country, and the tourists' coach, a white-haired Jeff Thomson, soon beat a hasty retreat from the balcony, presumably unable to stomach such inertia, whereupon Masters pinned Gripper leg-before as he aimed across the line.

A similar fate befell Guy Whittall, and when the forthright Neil Johnson chipped Masters to mid-off with an apologetic air, three wickets had gone in six overs since lunch. James Golding, a dead ringer for Andrew Flintoff, had interrupted Masters' sequence by ejecting Murray Goodwin courtesy of a fine catch at midwicket by Ed Smith - an apt riposte to the colleagues who had stuck a donkey's tail on his back.

Dirk Viljoen, who shared a Zimbabwean all-wicket record of 330 playing for Mashonaland, failed to tarry, falling leg-before, the first of Patel's four victims. Darren Scott, Patel's lofty fellow twirler, was as shocked as anyone when his initial offering, a stratospheric full toss to Stuart Carlisle, was drilled to cover where Matthew Fleming plunged for a staggering one-handed catch. Further misfortune ensued when Streak was caught and bowled by Patel via silly point's heel.

Streak trapped Smith before stumps but the acting captain was left rueing a day in which his side's sole slice of luck was the ball from Patel that spun from the footmarks and, thanks to an errant throw and a stray helmet, yielded eight byes.

fields.headline: Katich leaves Surrey on ropes
fields.trailText: Durham v Surrey
fields.body:
The champions Surrey are facing a first defeat by Durham after two days of their First Division match at Chester-le-Street.

Durham's Australian batsman Simon Katich, with 43 not out, gave them a 251-run lead. Earlier Surrey were bowled out for 104, the lowest total ever made against Durham in the championship.

While Yorkshire will be happy with their first day of championship cricket, ending on 74 without loss in reply to Derbyshire's 239, Darren Gough will not be so chirpy. England's finest was distinctly off colour at Headingley where he went for 68 in 14 overs.

Nick Knight contributed to Warwickshire's first century opening stand since the season before last with an undefeated 127 against Glamorgan at Edgbaston. The promising Michael Powell made 73 as the hosts finished on 252 for two.

A second-wicket stand of 196 between the Middlesex captain Justin Langer (120) and his predecessor Mark Ramprakash (93) was the feature of the day at Lord's, where Northamptonshire finished on the wrong end of 282 for three.

Chelmsford was lit up by Stuart Law's magnificent century for Essex against Nottinghamshire. The Australian finished unbeaten on 120 out of a modest 216 for six.

fields.headline: Click and win
fields.standfirst: Reward cards are popular with high street retailers as a way of persuading customers to keep coming back. Now the online shops are getting in on the act. Lorraine Eames reports
fields.trailText: We are all familiar with the concept of loyalty cards. Pop down to the local supermarket for a loaf and a packet of teabags, and, along with your credit card, the cashier will ask you for your reward card; a quick swipe through the till, and the number of points each item is worth are added to your total.
fields.body:
We are all familiar with the concept of loyalty cards. Pop down to the local supermarket for a loaf and a packet of teabags, and, along with your credit card, the cashier will ask you for your reward card; a quick swipe through the till, and the number of points each item is worth are added to your total.

When you've built up a sufficient amount of points (which admittedly involves a substantial number of trips to the same store), you can offset them against the cost of your next big shop.

As a way of ensuring customer loyalty, the reward card appears to have met with the approval of virtually every high street shop - and now the online retailers are getting in on the act.

Specialist loyalty company WebRewards.co.uk, which launched this week, is creating partnerships with internet shops, such as Brandnewmusic.com, Easyshop.co.uk, and Carphone Warehouse, to maximise the choice of 'rewards' for its customers, with incentives ranging from air miles to MP3 players. There's even an island up for grabs (although you'll need to amass one million WebRewards to own it).

Customers, they say, will be rewarded for "virtually any online activity", including registering at sites, answering questions and recommending new members, as well as for buying online.

Gary Morrison, joint managing director of WebRewards, said: "Our members are active internet users, spending more time and money online than the average web consumer. By offering such compelling rewards for consumers, the programme is encouraging more and more people to use our partners - everybody wins."

webTitle: US identifies Aids as global threat to peace

fields.headline: US identifies Aids as global threat to peace
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration, convinced that the global spread of Aids is reaching catastrophic dimensions, has formally designated the disease as a threat to United States' national security. It fears that Aids could topple foreign governments, touch off ethnic wars and undo years of work in building free-market democracies abroad.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration, convinced that the global spread of Aids is reaching catastrophic dimensions, has formally designated the disease as a threat to United States' national security. It fears that Aids could topple foreign governments, touch off ethnic wars and undo years of work in building free-market democracies abroad.

The US national security council, which has never before been involved in combating an infectious disease, is directing a rapid reassessment of the Washington's efforts. The new push is reflected in the doubling of budget requests - to $254m - to combat Aids overseas. A White House group has been set up to "develop a series of expanded initiatives to drive the international efforts" to combat the disease. Top officials and some members of Congress contemplate much higher spending levels.

The new effort was spurred by US intelligence reports last year that looked at the broadest consequences of Aids for foreign governments and societies, particularly in Africa. Government analysts project that a quarter of southern Africa's population is likely to die of Aids and that the number of people dying of the disease will rise for a decade before there is much prospect of improvement. Based on current trends, that disastrous course could be repeated, perhaps exceeded, in South Asia and the former Soviet Union.

"At least some of the hardest-hit countries, initially in sub-Saharan Africa and later in other regions, will face a demographic catastrophe" over the next 20 years, according to a study in January. "This will further impoverish the poor and often the middle class, and produce a huge and impoverished orphan cohort unable to cope and vulnerable to exploitation and radicalisation."

Dramatic declines in life expectancy, the study said, are the strongest risk factor for "revolutionary wars, ethnic wars, genocides and disruptive regime transitions" in the developing world. Based on historical analysis of 75 factors that tend to destabilise governments, the authors said the social consequences of Aids appear to have "a particularly strong correlation with the likelihood of state failure in partial democracies".

US politics is another factor in mobilising attention. African American leaders have adopted the cause of Aids in Africa. Their interest is converging with that of Aids activists in the US and Europe, where the epidemic has been slowed by preventive efforts and anti-retroviral drugs. They are angry at policies that price those medicines beyond the reach of the developing world.

The US has endorsed the five-year goal of the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, to reduce the rate of new infections by 25%.

Twenty-three million people are infected in sub-Saharan Africa, with new infections coming at the rate of roughly 5,000 a day, according to World Health Organisation figures. Of 13m deaths to date, 11m have been in sub-Saharan Africa.

The intelligence estimate portrays the pandemic as the bad side of globalisation. Accelerating trade and travel are pushing much of Asia, and particularly India, toward "a dramatic increase in infectious disease deaths, largely driven by the spread of HIV-Aids," the intelligence report said. "By 2010 the region could surpass Africa in the number of HIV infections."

Senior administration officials said that the US government does not dispute estimates by the Joint United Nations Programme on HIV-Aids that it would take nearly $2bn to fund adequate prevention in Africa, and a like sum for treatment.

Pervading the recent US effort is a strong sense among participants of time misspent. "We saw it coming, and we didn't act as quickly as we could have," said Helene Gayle, a physician who directs Aids prevention at the Centres for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, Georgia. "I'm not sure what that says about how seriously we took it, how seriously we took lives in Africa." Washington Post

webTitle: Away wins a-plenty as race for places hots up

fields.headline: Away wins a-plenty as race for places hots up
fields.standfirst: Sam Delaney, our man with a perm and a placepot, points out the pick of the weekend's bets
fields.trailText: Sam Delaney, our man with a perm and a placepot, points out the pick of the weekend's bets.
fields.body:
A glance over this weekend's fixture list throws up a few more attractive bets than usual. Throw a selection of likely-looking away wins into an accumulator and you could be quids in come the close season.

There are numerous fixtures featuring the desperate versus the indifferent. Take Coventry versus Sheffield Wednesday. Coventry have already secured their usual finishing position - with their toes dangling millimetres from the relegation zone. Wednesday, on the other hand, have salvaged a tiny scrap of hope since Peter Shreeves took over from Danny Wilson. Their run of form has been stuttering - no sooner had they beaten Chelsea than they were being easily dismissed by Sunderland.

Everyone is assuming that just one out of Bradford and Wimbledon will go down but if Shreeves' men win both their remaining fixtures, they could send both their rivals down against the odds. Given this incentive, Highfield Road is hardly the most intimidating arena to commence an unlikely bid for survival.

Down in the First Division, there are a clutch of similar fixtures. With Birmingham looking pretty secure in the play-off zone, Huddersfield, Wolves and Bolton must contest the final place. With this fact in mind, Bolton and Wolves played out a titanic clash at the Reebok Stadium on Wednesday night, which was eventually won by the home side.

They can both be expected to win on Saturday against average (to put it politely) opposition. Bolton are at home to Norwich and Wolves are away to Port Vale. Huddersfield, of course, can render both results meaningless if they themselves gain a victory and maintain their position in sixth place. They travel to Fulham where Al Fayed's disappointing outfit are taking little interest in the tail-end of the season, more concerned as they are with Jean Tigana's future plans. For this reason, Huddersfield are certainly worth backing.

An exception to the prevailing trend will be Arsenal versus Chelsea. Arsenal are looking to finish in second place whereas Chelsea have rightly given up on qualifying for the Champions league. Nonetheless, Arsenal were frustrated for the best part of ninety minutes by an injury ravaged West Ham on Tuesday.

Only some highly-dubious refereeing denied the Hammers the result they deserved and Arsenal appeared to know it. When they face a far fitter Chelsea side on Saturday (fresh from an impressive victory over Liverpool) they are unlikely to be so lucky.

A first scorer worth backing before the season is out is Eric Bakke of Leeds United. The midfielder was an unknown this time last year but has done a remarkable job for David O'Leary's team. A combative player, he has shown an impressive knack of popping up in the box to score. He's 10-1 with Ladbrokes to score first against Everton at Elland Road on Monday night.

Recommended bets

Arsenal v Chelsea - away win

Coventry City v Sheffield Wednesday - away win

Fulham v Huddersfield Town - away win

Port Vale v Wolverhampton Wanderers - away win

webTitle: Demanding Doug Ellis, Kneecaps Keith McHat and John Craven

fields.headline: Demanding Doug Ellis, Kneecaps Keith McHat and John Craven
fields.trailText: FOOTBALL'S MR LOADED
fields.body:
FOOTBALL'S MR LOADED

Cast your minds back to February 1998, when Mark Hughes was still a Premiership player and Nicolas Anelka nothing but a surly teenager. In this cold and vicious month, a man stood outside Villa Park with nothing but a slicked back haircut, a sweater tucked into his trousers and a dream. This man was John Gregory, and his dream was to manage Aston Villa. Which was fortunate.

What a difference a couple of years and a few months make. Today, Football's Mr Longevity is one of the most respected (or maybe loudest) managers in the Premiership. So respected (loud) in fact, that he's just been awarded a new three-year contract by the most demanding chairman around - Demanding Doug Ellis. We just knew this would happen. Last week, Manchester United's attempt to snatch Greg van Rusedski from under the noses of Arsenal failed when the lumbering Dutch lummox fell over and knacked his knee. webTitle: Prisoner died after 'unlawful use of force'

fields.headline: Prisoner died after 'unlawful use of force'
fields.standfirst:
Sisters of black inmate are told there is 'clear evidence' in their case for judicial review

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Clear evidence existed showing that "unreasonable restraint" was used on a black remand prisoner who died in a privatised jail during a struggle with prison officers, the high court was told yesterday.
fields.body:
Clear evidence existed showing that "unreasonable restraint" was used on a black remand prisoner who died in a privatised jail during a struggle with prison officers, the high court was told yesterday.

Alton Manning, 33, from Birmingham, died as he was being carried away from a cell at Blakenhurst prison, Hereford and Worcester, on December 8 1995.

The incident happened when Manning was asked to squat naked for a strip search in "disputed circumstances", said Nicholas Blake QC, appearing for Manning's family.

They launched the high court challenge after David Calvert-Smith QC, the director of public prosecutions, decided not to prosecute any of the officers involved due to insufficient evidence.

Yesterday's hearing was the first challenge to the DPP's new policy on when to mount a prosecution when there has been a death in custody.

Manning's sisters, Patricia Manning and Elizabeth Melbourne, also from Birmingham, yesterday applied to Lord Bingham, the lord chief justice, sitting with Mr Justice Morison, for a judicial review following the refusal in 1996 of the DPP and crown prosecution service to bring manslaughter charges.

At the start of yesterday's hearing Lord Bingham described the case as a "matter of considerable public importance".

Mr Blake said: "There was clear evidence of restraint that was unreasonable and therefore unlawful being applied.

He added: "In cases where the state has a responsibility for investigating its own officers, the crown prosecution service has an obligation to either prosecute or explain why it is not going to prosecute."

He told the court there was a violent struggle involving six or seven prison officers and there was evidence from prisoners that one of the officers was holding Manning in a neck lock at the time he met his death from asphyxia at the prison run by the US-owned UK Detention Services.

Despite the DPP's decision in September 1996 not to prosecute any prison officers, an inquest jury returned a verdict that Manning had been unlawfully killed, after a three-week hearing at Kidderminster coroner's court, Hereford and Worcester, in March 1998.

Mr Blake said this "rational and lawful" verdict and the finding that the death was caused by asphyxia as a result of the neck hold resulted in the decision not to prosecute being reviewed.

He added: "A review note now suggests the prosecution was satisfied there was a prima facie case of unlawful act manslaughter against unit manager David Nicholson, the officer who had the responsibility for the head of Mr Manning when he was being restrained in circumstances when he was ordered to be strip searched."

Two other officers had gone to ground floor cell 26 on C wing of house block three to do a routine search of Manning, and he was taken to cell 35 for a strip search.

An altercation started when he was asked to squat naked for an inspection of his genital and anal area.

It was alleged that an assault by Manning on senior prison custody officer Peter Reynolds led to the alarm being sounded by prison custody officer David Brumby, and other officers coming into the cell.

Manning was then taken out of the cell headfirst and carried semi naked along a corridor towards the dining area, with Mr Nicholson at the head.

It was Mr Nicholson's claim that he was using an approved lock, said Mr Blake. But the evidence was that Manning had been unable to breathe by the time he was carried to the dining area. All efforts to revive him failed.

He was found to be bleeding from his ear and throat, but according to pathologists, this was consistent with pressure being applied to the neck, said Mr Blake.

He added that although it was now accepted there was a prima facie case of unlawful act manslaughter against Mr Nicholson, it was being suggested the death was the result of an accident, or an act of self-defence, justifying the use of force and the arm on the neck and there was "no realistic prospect of securing a conviction".

Mr Blake said in the light of all the evidence and the inquest jury's unlawful killing verdict, the latest DPP decision not to prosecute in February 1999 and reaffirmed that April, was manifestly perverse and irrational.

Failure to prosecute over three deaths in police custody prompted damning criticism of the last DPP, Dame Barbara Mills QC, who resigned before the end of her term of office.

The three deaths in custody prompted an inquiry under the retired judge, Gerald Butler QC, which led to an overhaul of procedures that required prosecution decisions in such cases to be referred to the attorney general.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Met calls in former boss of race body

fields.headline: Met calls in former boss of race body
fields.trailText: Sir Herman Ouseley, former head of the commission for racial equality, has been appointed to review and develop the Metropolitan police's anti-racist campaign.
fields.body:
Sir Herman Ouseley, former head of the commission for racial equality, has been appointed to review and develop the Metropolitan police's anti-racist campaign.

Sir Herman, who embarrassed the government last year by quitting the CRE claiming Jack Straw, the home secretary, had refused to listen to his calls for reform of the Race Relations Act, will advise the Met on its diversity strategy and the best way of continuing the "real progress being made in delivering a fair and effective service to all communities across London". He would also ensure equality and career development to police officers and civil staff, Scotland Yard said last night.

Sir Herman said policing the most ethnically diverse capital in the world was a "huge challenge" for the Met and it needed "as much support and help as it can attract".

"I look forward to making a helpful contribution as we seek to give all people who live, work and visit London a police service that is second to none," he said.

The Met's commissioner, Sir John Stevens, said: "We are delighted to have someone of Sir Herman's experience on board. The Met has come a long way in the past year and the way in which we handle diversity in external service delivery and internal staff relations has become a matter of professional excellence."

fields.headline: Youngest Asian QC appointed
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A man who took up the law after his chemistry teacher told him to steer clear of a career in science yesterday became England's youngest Asian QC.
fields.body:
A man who took up the law after his chemistry teacher told him to steer clear of a career in science yesterday became England's youngest Asian QC.

Manjit Singh Gill (above), a 39-year-old Sikh from Ealing, west London, said his appointment was important because it showed the Sikh community that "they can achieve, can be successful and do have good role models".

Mr Singh Gill, a barrister who specialises in human rights cases, was born in New Delhi, India. He arrived in Britain when he was six and settled in Birmingham.

He was called to the bar in 1989 and is among the 9% of ethnic minority lawyers out of the 10,000 barristers in England and Wales.

"I wanted to be a lawyer from about the age of 16," he said. "But that came about only because my chemistry teacher said I was not really good at that and maybe I should try the law."

He added: "The Asian community does need role models and people who will empathise with their problems and advise them."

fields.standfirst:
Four claim £1m for living hell

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Four black former remand prisoners who claim they suffered a "living hell" at the hands of white inmates and prison officers yesterday launched a damages claim in excess of £1m against the home secretary, Jack Straw.
fields.body:
Four black former remand prisoners who claim they suffered a "living hell" at the hands of white inmates and prison officers yesterday launched a damages claim in excess of £1m against the home secretary, Jack Straw.

The four say they were taunted and racially abused at Swansea prison from October to December 1994, culminating in an attack by 30 prisoners in the recreation area.

Marnon Thomas, Nigel Johnson, Hopeton Falconer and Patrick Campbell, all in their late 30s and from the Birmingham area, were on remand awaiting trial on false imprisonment charges which were later dropped.

They say that during their time in jail they suffered personal injury caused by the negligence of the home secretary in failing to protect them.

Harbinder Lally, representing the four, told Mr Justice Buckley at the high court in London that the four had been subjected to racial abuse in the presence of prison officers and that inmates had said Swansea was a "white man's prison".

He said they had been taken to magistrates court in a police dog van with no seats, their food contained spit and hair, and the lights in their cells were turned off and on to annoy them.

When the four complained, they were given forms to fill in which were torn up by prison officers, and when they asked to see the prison governor they were told by prison officers that he was too busy to see "blackies".

All four men were injured during an attack on December 11 when a snooker cue was broken over the head of one man and the others were punched and kicked and pelted with snooker balls.

All four remained in the hospital wing until their release three days later.

The case continues.

fields.headline: The racist hurdle
fields.standfirst:
Athletics is one of the few areas where black Britons are well represented. So why are the people who govern it mostly white? As two new allegations of racism turn the spotlight on the sport, Sally Weale investigates

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Athletics is one of the few areas where black Britons are well represented. So why are the people who govern it mostly white? As two new allegations of racism turn the spotlight on the sport,  Sally Weale  investigates
fields.body:
Lorna Boothe was 11 years old when she joined her local athletics club 30 years ago. She was one of two black athletes at the club and she always had problems getting into the teams, even when she was the fastest - but it only made her more determined to be the best so they had to select her.

Then, aged 18, she remembers having a row about who was running where in the relay. The coach yelled: "You black bitch! Why don't you get back where you came from?" She was so furious she beat the record for the 400m hurdles in her next race, then changed club. Boothe went on to win international medals for Britain between 1975 and 1984; and, when her competing career was over, she rose through the ranks of athletics administration to become the most senior black woman in athletics management.

Hers looked like a runaway success story. Then, in March, it emerged that Boothe, 45, was pursuing a claim for race and sex discrimination against UK Athletics, the sport's governing body, which appointed her Britain's athletics team manager for the Sydney Olympics. She was hoping to spill the beans on the "white male world of British athletics": after recent changes to the structure of the governing body, she claims her role as team manager has been diminished and she has been sidelined, a charge denied by UK Athletics. But her case was never heard because of a legal clause which disqualifies people who work regularly overseas. UK Athletics was accused of "wriggling out" of a proper hearing. Boothe and her lawyers are now lobbying for a change in the law, with the support of the Commission for Racial Equality.

This comes at a tricky time for UK Athletics. In a few months, British athletes will make their way to the Sydney Olympics. For most, an Olympic medal is the ultimate prize in a career - the contest only comes round once every four years; the majority of competitors will have only one or two chances for Olympic glory in their career. Few outside the sport can understand the sort of gargantuan effort that goes into preparations for such a competition.

Ashia Hansen is one of those gifted few chasing the Olympic dream. A world record-holding triple jumper, she is one of Britain's best hopes for a gold. In March, however, Hansen and her boyfriend, Chris Cotter, both 28, found themselves the targets of a terrifying race hate campaign which could have killed Cotter and was designed to strike fear in the heart of Hansen and every other black athlete hoping to make it to Sydney.

It was late one Tuesday evening. Cotter was due to meet Ashia Hansen at her Birmingham house. Hansen was due to fly to the US for warm-weather training, and Cotter was to have dinner at her house that night. Shortly before 10.30pm, he was making his way to her front door when a man - 6ft 5in with a nasty line in racist abuse - accosted him. He grabbed Cotter's arm and marched him towards Hansen's house, whispering horrible, racist things about Hansen. He wanted to get into the house.

Cotter tried to back off but other men joined in the attack. They swore at him, calling him a nigger-lover. He felt punches to his back, then before they ran off, the big man who first grabbed him slashed Cotter across the forehead. "We warned you not to mix with niggers," one of the gang hissed.

They drove off, leaving Cotter with three stab wounds to the back and blood pouring from his head. He lost four pints of blood. The next morning Hansen found a letter in her porch, composed of letters cut out from newspapers and magazines. "You were lucky last time," it said. "We won't make the same mistake again."

The incident sent a shiver of fear, anger and revulsion through the world of international athletics, and beyond. Then the racists followed their attack on Cotter with a series of racist hate letters. So far, three high profile black athletes have received them. Others may find them on their doormat when they return from training abroad. The message? We don't want your kind representing Britain in the Olympics.

The police are carrying out forensic tests on the letters; other mail sent to leading athletes c/o UK Olympics (until now it has all been forwarded to those named on the envelope and regarded as fan mail) is being screened, and all leading athletes have been warned to be vigilant.

It's not the first time such attacks have happened against high profile black sportspeople, particularly those in mixed marriages. Sharron Davies, Olympic swimmer-turned-TV star, and her former husband, retired athlete Derek Redmond, were targeted by the extreme right group Combat 18; four years ago police intercepted a parcel bomb addressed to their house. Earlier this month, a new, neo-nazi CD surfaced in which more threats are made against Davies.

Talk to people within the sport and what emerges is not only widespread horror at the racist attacks launched on athletes from outside athletics, but also a strong undercurrent of dissatisfaction about what's going on inside the sport. It's one thing to be attacked and abused by racist thugs; it's another to feel that your own organisation is discriminating against you.

The trials which decide who goes to the Olympics are to be held in Birmingham in August amid tight security. The chief concern is that, while nearly half of British team is likely to be black, the management, selection, coaching and administration of athletics is still predominantly white. Black competitors may have proved themselves on the track and field but they still aren't making the transition to other areas of the sport, unlike their white counterparts. "At the end of the day in this country," says one leading black figure in athletics, "it's jobs for the boys, and I ain't part of that boys' system. I'm not the right colour."

Boothe is one of the few successful black athletes who would appear to have made that transition successfully: "The response to what happened to Ashia has been [a feeling that] these thugs have brought racism into our sport. But it's been there for a long time. I've had racism all the time. I certainly suffered it as a youngster. If you look at how many black administrators there are at top level, how many managers, how many coaches - what barriers are keeping us back? We've got no black officials. It's like a clique, white and mainly male. They say there's no racism, there are lots of black competitors."

Keith Connor, another successful British Olympic athlete, would have liked to coach in Britain, but when he found there was nothing for him, he looked elsewhere. He now works in Australia and watches with disbelief the way British black talent is being wasted. He says many of Britain's leading black athletes who retire and become top personal coaches - producing winning performances from others - are still being overlooked by the athletics establishment for work with the national team. "I don't think anything has improved," he says. "If anything, it's more depressing because the new regime in charge of athletics should know better. It's not as if they've not been around black people. I hear some of these guys talking about athletes in track and field as if they've just come out of the trees."

Last month it also emerged - outside the narrow confines of the world of athletics - that Geoff Thompson, five times former world karate champion and one of Britain's leading black sports figures, is considering taking a job in South Africa, feeling he has been marginalised and denied opportunities in the world of sports administration in this country. The problem is clearly widespread.

Max Jones, performance director of UK Athletics, rejects any suggestion of discrimination in his sport, however. He puts the lack of black coaches, managers and administrators down to a generational gap. In 1969, for example, there were just two black members of the British team who took part in the European championships, he says. A number of the athletes in that squad, once retired, went on to work in different areas of the sport - including David Hemery who is now president of UK Athletics. But there weren't enough black athletes at that stage to have made a significant mark in the running of the sport. Black athletes, according to Jones, only began to come through in the late 70s and 80s.

"I think we've seen encouraging signs," he says. "Over the past 10 to 15 years, there's been a huge increase in the number of black coaches. In each of the major games recently there's been a black coach. I reject any suggestion of discrimination. It is an issue we should look at, and encourage black athletes to participate in the sport after they've retired. We are setting up high performance centres across the country using lottery funding, and are looking at ways of fast-tracking today's athletes into coaching and administration. We are looking for black coaches and administrators to take part in teams. But I can only take eight coaches to the Olympics."

Of the eight team coaches already selected for Sydney, one is black; of the five managers, two are black; and the rest of the 22-strong support squad - medical staff, physiotherapists, sports psychologists - are likely to be white. Selection panels are exclusively white (Boothe and another manager were removed in a reorganisation) but Jones says he doesn't believe that's a problem as selection is purely performance-based. Of a six or seven strong panel that is responsible for picking both male and female teams, there is just one woman.

So how does all this fit in with Ashia Hansen and Chris Cotter? Does it fit in at all? "Lorna's case raises very serious questions about what is happening at the top of one of the most integrated sports," says Courtney Hay of the Northern Complainants Aid Fund which has backed her case along with the CRE. "She's the most senior woman in athletics in this country, and the most senior black person. She's making very serious allegations. They need to be investigated. If they are committed to race equality, they should be taking her concerns seriously."

Senior figures in athletics point to the racial equality charter for sport signed by seven national governing bodies, including athletics, as evidence of their commitment to equality. Other moves include research into low participation by Asians in the sport, scholarships to attract more black coaches, and the appointment of black tutors to bring more ethnic groups into administration and coaching. But the impact of such moves is yet to filter through to many, such as this black former athlete who says of racism in athletics: "It's a taboo. It's not seen as an issue. It's touched on around the edges, but they don't want to go to the heart of it. We need to slap a few people and say wake up."

Athletics may have woken up to racism from outside - the sort that sees a white man stabbed for going out with a black woman. Whether it is fully aware of the sort of discrimination that allows it to trade on the competitive success of its black members then deny them top jobs in running the sport remains to be seen. Boothe is determined to see change. She is one of the few who has made it to the top. She plans to be there at the Olympics with Ashia Hansen and all the other athletes, black and white. "I'm there to do a job. I'm not going to be pushed. I'm there till Sydney."

webTitle: We can work it out, says MP3

fields.headline: We can work it out, says MP3
fields.standfirst:
Music sites face 'download or die' copyright rulings

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: What do Elton John, Lou Reed and Metallica have in common? The answer is that they are all fighting in a campaign that has brought together more artists than Live Aid - the legal battle against online music piracy.
fields.body:
What do Elton John, Lou Reed and Metallica have in common? The answer is that they are all fighting in a campaign that has brought together more artists than Live Aid - the legal battle against online music piracy.

Court cases brought against MP3.com and Napster, two online music companies, are set to reawaken the debate over copyright and online music in the US, where internet downloading of recorded music has soared in recent years.

Any day now, a judge in California will rule on a case brought against Napster, a popular song-swap service, by the Recording Industry Association of America, the trade body for the world's largest record labels.

The ruling follows last week's judgment in a separate case that MP3.com was liable for copyright infringement. At issue was My.MP3.com, a service launched in January which allows users to access tracks from the company's database of 80,000 albums provided they already own a copy of the CD. The recording association successfully argued that the creation of the database alone violated copyright law.

Analysts believe that MP3 has been trying to reach a settlement with the association before the judge publishes his detailed ruling. Neither the company nor the association would comment on reports yesterday that they had failed to agree a proposed $100m (£64m) settlement.

The recording association is believed to be unlikely to accept such a payment, especially if tied to an agreement on future licensing fees. Under the lawsuit, it asked for up to $6bn in damages from MP3.com, almost half of the more than $14bn-worth of recordings sold in the United States last year.

Lise Buyer, internet analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, believes that San Diego-based MP3.com is trying to reach a settlement with the labels. In a note to investors this week, she wrote that it was in the interests of the recording industry to "work out a solution as the MP3 genie cannot be put back into the bottle". The interests for MP3.com include avoiding potential damages that "range from inconsequential to fatal".

Following the ruling, Michael Robertson, chief executive of MP3.com, said: "This is not a victory for the record labels - it's a loss. New technologies for delivering music are here to stay and the technology trend is moving in only one direction - forward." Rather than harming the industry, he argues that the service provided by MP3.com - which does not own the compression technology behind MP3 - helped music sales increase 8% in the first quarter of this year compared with 1999. He said the decision to attack MP3.com was misguided and would lead to copyright chaos because the company insisted on users at least buying a CD "as opposed to other services like Napster".

Silicon Valley-based Napster allows users to download music from the hard drives of other people using its technology. Its failure to insist that any music is bought first has prompted attacks on many fronts, including from groups like Metallica that own the rights to their recordings. Napster, which declined to comment before the judgment, is claiming immunity under the digital millennium copyright act, a largely untested American law that allows internet service providers to escape penalties for copyright abuse.

International artists have supported the legal action. On the association's website, Elton John wrote: "I am excited about the opportunities presented by the internet. But the bottom line must always be respect and compensation for creative work."

Lou Reed said: "Artists, like anyone else, should be paid for their work."

A few musicians have supported Napster and other internet companies, such as Myplay.com, believe that internet companies and recording labels should work together to take advantage of the explosion in online music.

Forrester Research estimates that 25% of all music revenue in 2004 will be generated from internet downloads, up from a fraction today. Even after last week's decision, the jury is still out on who will benefit from such a change.

webTitle: How much can you pay for....

fields.headline: How much can you pay for....
fields.standfirst: ...a razor?
fields.trailText: ...a razor?
fields.body:
Gentlemen, what better a way to start the day than watching yourself drag a sterling silver museum piece across your face?If the idea grabs, why not try the Peretti razor from Tiffany & Co.

Its fat-ended shape is the trademark of Elsa Peretti, Italian model and ski instructor turned designer for the US jewellery house. Peretti has based her razor on "sculptural interpretations of forms found in nature, such as bones, tear drops and vegetable matter." It looks great but might nip your chin. Tiffany personal shoppers warn that it's "quite stiff" and doesn't "flex with your face". At £250 it is a case of form over function. For an extra £160 you can prime your face with the sterling silver Peretti shaving brush. At Tiffany you are, of course, paying for a lesson in refinement.

fields.headline: Just a spoonful of sugar?
fields.standfirst: A Which? report has found that most baby food contains high levels of sugar and starch. But do parents really need to worry?  Helen Hague  reports
fields.trailText: A Which? report has found that most baby food contains high levels of sugar and starch. But do parents really need to worry? Helen Hague reports
fields.body:
Supermarket and corner shop shelves are awash with baby products reassuringly described as specially formulated and containing wholesome ingredients. These prepared foods may be convenient for parents too busy (or too lazy) to make their own, but do they live up to their boasts? And could they actually be bad for babies?

According to yesterday's Which? survey, many of the well-known brands contain high levels of added sugar, fruit juice and starch. Which? checked 420 foods and found 40% contained sugar or fruit juice, or both, 40% contained starch additives (to bulk out or texturise the food) and just under half the desserts contained some form of added sugar. Cow & Gate sage and turkey casserole, for example, contains more maltodextrin, a complex carbohydrate, than actual turkey and Sainsbury's Sunshine Banana has more maltodextrin and sugar than plain old banana.

Tim Laing, professor of food policy at Thames Valley University, is not surprised. "Babyfood manufacturers play a very brilliant and sophisticated game of taking regulations to the maximum, rather than listening to the will of the people, let alone the most progressive elements of nutritional thinking," he says. "Infant foods are a very emotive subject, not just because of a child's nutrition, but to build up brand loyalty with the parents, from the moment a child is born, encouraging brand loyalty.

"It may be perfectly legal to include sugars and fats in baby foods, but that does not mean it is desirable. Nutritionally, or from a long-term public health perspective."

Which? says the "tick boxes" on the front of most products, allegedly to help parents choose, are particularily worthless. For example, "no added sugar" does not cover fruit juice, which is high in natural sugars (and can also rot little teeth), and "no added salt" means next to nothing as salt levels are already strictly controlled by law. The same goes for a boast of "no preservatives" as, apart from vitamin C and other anti-oxidants to stop food going off, these are outlawed. The "no artificial colours" claim only tells you that the product is not breaking the law - artificial colours are banned in all baby foods.

So how does the industry defend adding these ingredients to products? "If you wiped all the prepared baby foods off the shelves tomorrow, a lot of people would not make their own and adult foods are not nutritionally suitable," says Heather Page, spokesperson for the Infant and Dietetic Foods Association, which represents some of the baby food manufacturers. She says the report ignores how well controlled the industry is. Baby foods, says Page, are nutritionally appropriate and convenient. And babies simply cannot cope with adult diets. Infant foods are tightly governed by law and strictly regulated when it comes to sugar and salt.

But parents need to be able to make an informed choice, rather than running scared, argues Sara Stanner, a nutritionist from the British Nutrition Foundation. She advises parents to find out what the information on labels actually means.

"Low amounts of sugar is not a problem. But people don't realise all those words that end in ose - maltose, dextrose and so on - are sugar derivatives. It's very difficult. People should be better informed about what to look for but products won't be on the shelves unless they conform to strict regulations. Look on the back, not the front. It's all there, but people sometimes don't know what it means."

Sucrose, glucose, dextrose, syrup and honey, fruit syrups and fruit juice concentrates are all types of sugar to look out for on labels. You will find them on the backs of products, not flagged up on the front, unlike the seductive yet meaningless phases designed to catch parent's eyes.

Stanner offers some comfort: "I wouldn't like people to think that the only way to feed young children healthily is by buying organic products or preparing their own food."

The National Childbirth Trust, a zealous advocate of breastfeeding for the first six months, agrees. It urges parents to "check, check and check again" if worried about the contents of prepared infant foods. "If you make it yourself, you know what's in it - and you'll save money," says Janice Muir, NCT spokeswoman. "But we understand that people face a lot of time pressure when they have got a young baby and would not want to land a load of guilt on them if they don't make up food themselves."

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Lucas does a u-turn over DVDs, Tony Scott's directorship of Take Down confirmed, and Rick Baker signs on for Apes remake
fields.body:
 George Lucas has performed a u-turn on his initial decision not to release Star Wars Episode One: The Phantom Menace on DVD. The change of heart has been caused in part by pressure from a series of fan websites which were outraged at the film's appearance last month in VHS format only. "Absolutely," a Lucasfilm spokesman said when asked if website pressure had had an effect. "We're listening and George is listening."

 Tony Scott has been confirmed as the director of Take Down, a big-budget thriller backed by Disney and produced by the ubiquitous Jerry Bruckheimer. The picture will follow the fortunes of a bunch of US marshals on the trail of a killer and is based on the book by Carsten Stroud, Deadly Force: In the Streets with the US Marshal Service. Tony Scott (brother of Ridley) is regarded by Hollywood as a sure hand on the tiller after a string of box-office successes including Top Gun and Enemy of the State. More recently, he was responsible for directing the reviled Barclay's Bank advert which purports to chart a typical "big" day in the life of actor Anthony Hopkins (see our recent news story).

 Simian whiz Rick Baker has been signed on to supervise the make-up on the Planet of the Apes remake directed by Tim Burton. Baker has enjoyed a long acquaintance with all things ape-ish, mastering the make-up on such films as Gorillas in the Mist and Greystoke, as well as winning plaudits for his lupine techniques on An American Werewolf in London. But his appointment appears to slip a banana skin under the feet of veteran special-effects man Stan Winston, who finds himself abruptly sidelined by Baker's arrival.

webTitle: Mel Gibson eyes generation gap role

fields.headline: Mel Gibson eyes generation gap role
fields.trailText: Mel Gibson has been approached to take on an ambitious double-role in a fledgling sci-fi project currently in development with Disney subsidiary, Touchstone Pictures
fields.body:
Mel Gibson has been approached to take on an ambitious double role in a fledgling sci-fi project currently in development with Disney subsidiary, Touchstone Pictures. The Oscar-winning Aussie would play an ageing hitman who is being hounded by a clone of his younger self. Gibson would tackle both roles.

Scripted by Darren Lemke, the film - Gemini - centres around an all-powerful genetics conglomerate in the America of 2020 and has been put on a fast-track development schedule with a view to filming towards the end of the year. The Hollywood Reporter claims that Walt Disney Studios chairman Peter Sneider is keen to secure Gibson, but is considering Harrison Ford as second choice.

The means of cutting between the two Gibson incarnations remains a big stumbling block. Sneider has apparently been experimenting with cross-cutting between footage from both Gibson's 1999 picture Payback and his 1982 Australian drama The Year of Living Dangerously to gain a sense of how the actor has aged. Whether Gemini's success will depend on digital conjury, heavy make-up or just plain good acting, however, remains to be seen.

webTitle: People of Lockerbie recall rain of fire

fields.headline: People of Lockerbie recall rain of fire
fields.standfirst: Witnesses tell Camp Zeist court of  the awful scenes that followed the destruction of PanAm 103
fields.trailText: Lockerbie residents today described the night in 1988 when PanAm 103 exploded over their town, as they gave evidence on the second day of the trial of the two  Libyans accused of blowing up the plane and killing 270 people
fields.body:
Lockerbie residents today described the night in 1988 when PanAm 103 exploded over their town, as they gave evidence on the second day of the trial of the two Libyans accused of blowing up the plane and killing 270 people

One witness, Jasmine Bell, told the hearing at a special Scottish court in Camp Zeist in the Netherlands that she had to dodge flames and burning debris as she called at her brother's home in Sherwood Park, Lockerbie, on 21 December 1988.

Mrs Bell said she and her brother were standing outside the house when they heard a "distant noise" which got louder and louder. She looked up into the sky as her brother yelled: "It's a plane, get down." Visibly distressed, Mrs Bell told the court: "I looked up and saw what I imagined was a small plane just going over my head. I ducked down and covered my head.

"I ducked down and my brother had dived into the garage. There was fire all around me, there were burning objects and the fire was falling down from the sky and as it landed on the ground I was stepping backwards to avoid the fire and I stepped back and back until my back was against the wall of the house and I couldn't go any further." Then her brother, who had entered his home through the garage, pulled her into the house. Mrs Bell said: "Everything was burning, the driveway, the lawn, the hedges, the rooftops." She said she and her brother later went into the street and had to jump over small "campfires" everywhere. Many houses were on fire, and she said she and her brother helped several people escape from burning homes. Later she stumbled over an object which she later realised was part of a human body.

She added: "I recalled later seeing in my brother's garden and he had put white cloths around and there were parts of bodies and he had covered them."

The two accused men, Abdelbaset Ali Mohmed Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, were also present in court. They both deny conspiracy to murder, murder and a breach of the 1982 Aviation Security Act.

Another witness, Roland Stevenson, was collecting his daughter from Lockerbie railway station when he saw the explosion. He said he shouted to people to run for cover as debris from the aircraft rained down.

"My first thought was that the train was over-revving its engines. It got progressively louder and became thunderous. I got out of the car. The noise appeared to be coming from the north.

"I saw an object coming from the north. It was a black mass showing some form of lights. A small flame. Enough for me to see the dark shape and the passage of the object. It was coming down on what I would call a glide path. It was coming down at a shallow angle," he said.

"The whole of the wing was descending vertically straight down... A rolling ball of fire was descending rapidly from the sky. In the ball of flame I could see objects descending. After the wing had crashed down I saw a door panel which came down shimmering down in the night sky, silver, very clearly visible."

Mr Stevenson went on: "People came out of the nearby public house. I shouted to them to get under cover because there were objects falling from the sky. I knew what it was - a big Boeing or a jumbo."

Ian Wood was a resident of Lockerbie at the time of the disaster. He said he was at home when he heard a "big bang".

"I went to the front door. I saw balls of flame. It looked like an atomic bomb, pure red, and like mushrooms flaring up. I could feel the heat. Shortly after that a grey-blue object just fell from the sky on top of two houses virtually in front of my house. The impact was so fierce that I had to push on my front door to try and close it.

"Then I went back outside. All I could smell was fuel. I thought it was a fighter jet or a small plane of some sort. There were no street lights on. Nothing at all. It was raining glass, small fragments of glass. I started walking up the road. There was a body."

The trial continues.

webTitle: Free McManaman with a free role

fields.headline: Free McManaman with a free role
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman can make the difference between England crashing out of Euro 2000 in the first round and winning the entire tournament. All he needs is the chance to prove it.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman can make the difference between England crashing out of Euro 2000 in the first round and winning the entire tournament. All he needs is the chance to prove it.

He really is that good.

But despite his scintillating performances for Real Madrid in Europe this season, and the small matter of him being one of England's most creative players in the past decade, McManaman might not even make the squad.

That, if it happens, would be shameful. Because McManaman shouldn't just be in the squad - he should be in the first eleven and given a free role with it.

That's not an argument you'll hear very often, but there are myriad reasons why Kevin Keegan should pick him.

First off, England under Keegan have been all passion and no performance. In almost every game they've been plodding and predictable, and if they lack the ingenuity and spark to regularly prise open sides like Poland, Bulgaria and Sweden, how do you think they'll fare in Euro 2000?

McManaman, operating in a free role, would change all that by sniffing out space, constantly making himself available and dragging defenders out of position. As a result the stifling rigidity we've come to expect from recent England performances would be shattered.

Another reason why McManaman must start is that in the well-organised world of international football, players that can dribble are as precious as water in the desert. In Euro 96, England had four players who could take on their markers and beat them - Shearer in his prime, a dazzling McManaman and also Paul Gascoigne and Darren Anderton. Who out of Keegan's first eleven possesses the kind of Redondo-like trickery that can turn a game?

Not Shearer, who at international level is a shadow of his former self. Not Beckham either, who despite his brilliant crossing ability takes on a full back approximately once a season. The only player that does it on a regular basis is Michael Owen - and he's not certain to be in the starting line-up.

That's where McManaman comes in. As recent games have shown once again, he is a big-time player with big-match temperament. And he's able to take defenders on and beat them.

So how should Keegan accommodate him? I would try out a 4-3-1-2 formation in one of the remaining friendlies, with McManaman providing the link between a midfield three of Scholes, Wise and Beckham and the forward line. That would leave him free to forage, rather than being clamped ineffectually to the left wing.

But not everyone shares this view. In fact the vast majority of football fans would have some sympathy for view that McManaman is inconsistent, only plays when he feels like it and never does it for England.

So let's look at those ropey arguments one by one.

It's true that McManaman can be inconsistent, but so can Rivaldo and Beckham - yet the charge is never made against them. For some reason people seem to put the bar much higher when it's McManaman, even though anyone who has seen him play over last few weeks knows he can produce on the big stage.

People also forget how consistent McManaman actually is. This current run of good form isn't a flash in the pan. Contrary to popular belief he started well at Madrid - and for the first couple of months he was in Marca's team of the season. It was only after injury that his form dipped. Furthermore, everyone seems to forget that between 1994-1997 he was game after game, season after season, one of the Premiership's best players.

Some critics will give him that, but claim "he never does it for England". But that view is also wrong, as it airbrushes out of history McManaman's sparkling performance in Euro 96, when he was given more freedom by Terry Venables and became one of our best players.

At the moment McManaman is almost certainly one of Keegan's eight possibles, from which he will choose four the final four members of his squad. If he doesn't go it will be a crime. If he goes and doesn't play it will be a terrible waste.

But even at this stage it's not too late for Keegan to change things.

McManaman is much more a Scouse scally with shaggy haircut who plays well when feels like it. Given a free role he will certainly make England less predictable, and may even turn out to be their saviour. All it needs now is for Keegan to realise it.

Furthermore, everyone seems to forget that between 1994-1997 he was game after game, season after season, one of the Premiership's best players. Some critics will give him that, but claim "he never does it for England". But that view is also wrong, as it airbrushes out of history McManaman's sparkling performance in Euro 96, when he was given more freedom by Terry Venables and became one of our best players. At the moment McManaman is almost certainly one of Keegan's eight possibles, from which he will choose four the final four members of his squad. If he doesn't go it will be a crime. If he goes and doesn't play it will be a terrible waste. But even at this stage it's not too late for Keegan to change things. McManaman is much more a Scouse scally with shaggy haircut who plays well when feels like it. Given a free role he will certainly make England less predictable, and may even turn out to be their saviour. All it needs now is for Keegan to realise it. sean.ingle@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Virtual poll records Livingstone victory
fields.standfirst:
Play Vote Monkey
Guardian Unlimited mayor special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has won the Guardian Unlimited contest to find a virtual London mayor with a 50% clear lead over his nearest rival.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has won the Guardian Unlimited contest to find a virtual London mayor with a 50% clear lead over his nearest rival.

VoteMonkey, an interactive opinion poll carried out in conjunction with Freeserve and Austrian web provider sysis, invited readers to answer a series of detailed questions about what they expect from the mayor's policies and personality - Vote Monkey then chooses the most appropriate candidate.

The former GLC leader polled 63% in a vote that would see Mr Livingstone become mayor without the need to count second preferences if it was repeated at the ballot box. Green candidate Darren Johnson came second with 11.6% of the vote. Close behind him was Labour's Frank Dobson on 11.2%, while Steve Norris and Susan Kramer languished with just 6.5% and 5.9% respectively.

The online voters were largely under-25, two-thirds female and in employment. They were looking for a charismatic, trustworthy politician to be mayor. On the tube, 70% said they would prefer it to stay public and 65% want congestion charges introduced for driving into central London.

According to the poll the mayor should concentrate on sorting out London's transport problems, cleaning up the environment, shaping up London's schools and cracking down on crime.

The voters supported the legalisation of cannabis and supported a teacher's right to speak freely about homosexuality in the classroom. Their liberal-left leanings were reflected with 0.1% support for both the UK Independence and BNP candidates.

Independent candidate Aswin Tanna recorded 0.7%, Christian People's Alliance hopeful Ram Giddomal 0.1% and Geoffrey Ben-Nathan (Pro-Motorist and Small Shop) exactly zero.

Vote Monkey recorded 1875 votes.

webTitle: Alan Rusbridger: Why we chose not to make a choice

fields.headline: Alan Rusbridger: Why we chose not to make a choice
fields.standfirst: The editor of the Guardian explains how the paper reached its decision not to endorse any mayoral candidate
fields.trailText: The editor of the Guardian explains how the paper reached its decision not to endorse any mayoral candidate
fields.body:
It is curious how media myths grow and spread. In the last two days I have read two separate accounts of the supposed fury, division and recriminations within the Guardian over whether the paper should endorse a mayoral candidate for today's London elections, and, if so, whom?

The fury is alleged to have erupted at a passing remark I made to an interviewer some weeks back that the paper might consider supporting Steve Norris. Deputations are reported to have beaten their way to my desk. The Hard Left were ready to organise and storm the Leader Writers' Citadel. They would take no prisoners. CP Scott was reliably reported by Private Eye to be revolving in his grave.

If he was spinning, it would not be for the first time. He would, on this account, have revolved in October 1951, when the Manchester Guardian advised: "For the next few years a Churchill government is, it seems to us, the lesser evil." And he would apparently have spun once more in 1955 when the paper reluctantly concluded that a Conservative government would be better for the country.

But, of course, Scott would not have spun then or now. Not that he had any need to in May 2000. The Guardian did not endorse Norris. It did not endorse anyone. We gave reasons why people might genuinely wish to support any of the four main candidates - together with reasons why they might wish to withhold their support. But we held back from supporting any candidate ourselves.

That position was arrived at after much discussion, argument and inquiry. All four main candidates - and Glenda Jackson, too - came to lunch at the paper over the past few months. All journalists on the staff had the opportunity to come along, question them and judge for themselves.

We also staged a debate at Church House, chaired by our policy editor, Jonathan Freedland, and had an open internal meeting for anyone on the staff to come along and contribute to the discussion before the final leader was written.

It was apparent that there was no clear consensus among the staff. Few spoke up full-throatedly for Ken Livingstone. Some spoke vehemently against him. There was some sympathy, but little support, for Frank Dobson. There was respect for, but not overwhelming confidence in, Susan Kramer. Norris was admired by some, while others felt that his record on transport while in government was patchy and that his views on such issues as abortion and hanging disqualified him from the support of a progressive paper such as the Guardian. All the discussions we had were calm, grown-up and, I thought, impressive.

In the end it is the editor and the leader writers who set the leader line - though, of course, those discussions among the wider constituency of Guardian journalists do become the mulch out of which the editorials grow. The eventual decision that we did not want to endorse any candidate was arrived at fairly quickly and painlessly.

Other papers seem to have been going through a similar process. The Mirror - traditionally a rock-solid Labour paper - came out for Norris. The Independent was reported to be edging towards an endorsement for Livingstone until the editor asked his staff if any of them would be voting for him. Their leader this morning stops short of an endorsement. Only the Observer actually supported Livingstone - though even its support was hedged with numerous qualifications. Norris picked up such widespread support that I'm sure he can live without the Guardian's endorsement. And CPS can rest quietly in his grave.
