fields.headline: Zimbabwe selection is all relative
fields.standfirst: Have you any cricketing questions? Email asksteven@guardian.co.uk with your query.
fields.trailText: Have two pairs of brothers ever appeared in the same Test side? asks Melanie Myers
fields.body:
Have two pairs of brothers ever appeared in the same Test side? asks Melanie Myers

Actually the record is three - Andy and Grant Flower, Gavin and John Rennie, and Paul and Bryan Strang for Zimbabwe v New Zealand at Harare in September 1997. Zimbabwe's 12 for that Test also included Guy and Andy Whittall, who are cousins, but Andy was made 12th man. The various Flowers and Strangs have all played in the same Test 12 times now. Other occasions when two pairs of brothers have been in the same Test side were in 1913-14 (Herbie and Dan Taylor and Philip and Reginald Hands for South Africa), 1933-34 (CK and CS Nayudu and Nazir and Wazir Ali for India), 1963-64 (Peter and Graeme Pollock and David and Tony Pithey for South Africa) and 1976-77 (Geoff and Hedley Howarth and Dayle and Richard Hadlee for New Zealand). The Waugh twins (Steve and Mark) and the Lee brothers (Shane and Brett) featured in Australia's one-day teams this winter.

Can you please tell me what has become of Paul Strang? asks Paul McCann

Strang has been out of the Zimbabwean side for a while because he has been struggling with injury. First he hurt his arm just before last year's World Cup, then when he tried a comeback in Zimbabwe recently he injured his knee, and announced that he wouldn't be fit to tour England - a blow for Zimbabwe, because he would have brought much-needed experience after his two useful county seasons with Kent and Nottinghamshire. It's not all bad news for the Strang family, though: brother Bryan recently returned to the national side, and he is part of the squad in England. Cricinfo recently carried an interesting interview with Paul Strang - you can find it here

I am researching my family tree and have discovered that Wilfrid Timms, who played for Northamptonshire in the 1920s, was my grandfather's cousin. Do you have any more information about him? asks Kate Prinsep

Wilfrid Walter Timms played 99 matches for Northants between 1921 and 1932, scoring 4083 runs at 22.55. He was still at Northampton School when he first played for them, and scored an amazing 154 not out in only his second match, against Essex at Northampton, after which he was chaired from the field by his schoolmates. Later that season he found himself captaining Northants even though he was still a schoolboy - he was the only amateur available to play, and it was traditional in those days that an amateur should lead the side. Timms died on Sept 30, 1986, two days after his 84th birthday. A long article on him appeared in the February 1986 edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly, and his obituary appeared in that year's November issue.

I was looking at the list of Wisden's Five Cricketers of the Century and noticed that Godfrey Evans and Geoff Boycott were not styled as 'Sir'. I thought they had both been knighted: is that right? asks SJ Rose

Neither has been knighted, although Boycott is often referred to jokingly as 'Sir Geoffrey'. He is an OBE though. And Evans, who died last year, was a CBE.

What has happened to Dominic Cork? He used to be my favourite England player and now rarely seems to get a mention anywhere asks Julia Gillen

Although he has been out of favour with England since the 1998-99 tour of Australia, Dominic Cork is still playing for Derbyshire, where he is now captain. Last season he led them to ninth in the County Championship, which means they are in the first division this year. He is bowling well again now, and last weekend the Daily Telegraph argued that he should replace the injured Dean Headley as England's third seamer for the first Test against Zimbabwe, which starts at Lord's on May 18.

Please could you tell me where the Campbell Park ground is? asks Anna Brickman

It's in Milton Keynes, in Buckinghamshire, and will stage this season's match between a First-Class Counties XI and the New Zealand A tourists (July 7-10).

Are there any trophies, like the Ashes, at stake for England's forthcoming series against Zimbabwe and West Indies? asks John Peacock

You've come to the right place, at least for the second part of your query: since 1963 England and West Indies have competed for the Wisden Trophy. England haven't had their hands on it since 1969, when Ray Illingworth's side won a short series 2-0. The trophy was instituted in 1963 to mark the 100th edition of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack, first published in 1864. As yet there isn't a special trophy for England-Zimbabwe Tests, although Cornhill Insurance, the sponsors, will probably be providing a cup of their own.

What is the most picturesque Test ground, and what is the smallest international venue in the world? asks Dhanush from Sri Lanka

It's arguable. Adelaide, in Australia, has its admirers, but I think the ground at St Vincent, in the West Indies, is probably the most picturesque. It is on a fairly small island and the ground is right next to the sea. Some of the other grounds in West Indies aren't very big, but the smallest one I've actually been to is Queen's Club in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe - apart from a few seats in front of the pavilion, and one bit of grass terracing, there is very little permanent seating. The ground could probably accommodate 2000 people at a squeeze.

Steven Lynch is managing editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

We regret that not all questions can be answered and that personal correspondence can only sometimes be entered into

webTitle: Polls open on Blair's big day

fields.headline: Polls open on Blair's big day
fields.trailText: Voting is under way in what is likely to be the most important register of public opinion until the next general election.
fields.body:
Voting is under way in what is likely to be the most important register of public opinion until the next general election.

Polls for 152 local authorities across England, the Romsey byelection and the London mayoral contest will provide a snapshot of local opinion and an indication of the fortunes of Tony Blair's government three years after it won power.

Londoners also have the chance to elect the first members of the Greater London Assembly. In total, 20m people out of a 43m-strong electorate in Britain are eligible to vote today.

However, voters trickled to the polls in London, suggesting the final turnout might be less than a third. In Streatham, south London, 85 people made it to the polling booths in the first three hours.

Independent candidate Ken Livingstone attacked the "vile" campaign against him as he cast his vote in Cricklewood, north London. "It has been a negative campaign and I don't think Londoners will want another like this," he said. He added that the vote would be much closer than opinion polls suggested and predicted it would run into a count of second preferences.

The capital's first directly elected mayor will be decided with a supplementary vote system in which each voter is entitled to mark their first and second choice candidates on the ballot paper. If one candidate wins more than 50% of the first preferences he or she is declared the winner.

If no candidate gets half the vote all but the top two are eliminated and the second choice votes of those who opted for the eliminated candidates are taken into account. Whichever of the two remaining candidates has more votes is declared the winner. The result is expected early tomorrow morning.

Conservative candidate Steve Norris said that Mr Livingstone's bubble had burst as he stepped out of his Jaguar to vote in Clapham, south London. "Londoners are voting today for action over politics. They want a safer, cleaner, fairer London," he said.

And Labour's Frank Dobson attracted a last minute supporter as he cast his vote in Drury Lane, central London. A 45-year-old environmental activist from Totnes, Devon ran after his car with a placard reading "Dobbo for the Jobbo".

"He's got a nice hairy beard, and he's furry like me, that's why I am supporting him," he said.

Outside London, polling stations are open for the Romsey byelection precipitated by the death of the Conservative MP Michael Colvin in a fire at his home. In the local elections 3,000 seats are being contested by 9,000 candidates. These seats were last up for election in 1996 when the then Conservative government suffered a crushing defeat. Polls close in all elections at 9pm.

London mayor candidates

Geoffrey Ben-Nathan, pro-motorist and small shop

Geoffrey Clements, Natural Law party

Frank Dobson, Labour

Ram Gidoomal, Christian People's Alliance

Damian Hockney, UK Independence Party

Darren Johnson, Green

Susan Kramer, Liberal Democrat

Ken Livingstone, independent

Michael Newland, British National Party

Steve Norris, Conservative

Ashwin Tanna, independent

Romsey byelection

Sandra Gidley, Liberal Democrat

Andrew Howard, Labour

Thomas Lamont, independent

Derrick Large, Legalise Cannabis Alliance

Timothy Palmer, Conservative

Garry Rankin-Moore, UK Independence party

fields.headline: Voting for change
fields.standfirst: The public today is being offered an electoral box of tricks. Martin Wainwright, northern editor, celebrates a spirit of change that could breathe life into our jaded polling system.
fields.trailText: The public today is being offered an electoral box of tricks. Martin Wainwright, northern editor, celebrates a spirit of change that could breathe life into our jaded polling system.
fields.body:
"Vote early, vote often" was the cynical slogan in corrupt electoral times, but today we can use it in pure celebration. The local government polls are the most innovative and experimental since 18-year-olds won the vote in 1969. Novel ways to refresh and invigorate democracy are breaking out all over the country.

Londoners reading this may well have voted up to three days ago. To jack up the turnout - the point of all today's electoral pilot schemes - polling stations in many parts of the capital have been open since Monday. It is perhaps a shame for the clever Ken Livingstone campaigners who devised the slogan Ken-4MAY-or, but the dismal percentages which so often mar non-parliamentary elections are long overdue for such action.

Action is what they are getting. Similar extra voting days are being tested in Sunderland, Coventry and a dozen other districts. Parallel trials including electronic voting, all-postal ballots and mobile polling stations are designed to bring the suffrage mountain to the reluctantly voting Mohammed. The entitlement to a postal vote has been broadened in Gloucester and Milton Keynes, freepost ballot papers have been issued in Watford, voting hours have been extended in Leeds and Mole Valley and there will be computerised counting tonight in Salford, Stratford-upon-Avon and London.

These technical innovations go hand in hand with other common sense changes in the Representation of the People Act 2000, which became law in March. You can now add your name to the voters' register at any time of the year, instead of all at one time (which the forgetful and disorganised often miss). You can have your name removed from the public register - the equivalent to going ex-directory to avoid junk mail - without losing the right to vote. Registration has been made easier for homeless people, remand prisoners and many in mental institutions.

The ethos which drives the initiative is a hugely welcome reversal of the British tradition that voting must somehow be stately, ponderous and - yes - require a bit of an effort from the punter. Older generations still associate polling day with trudging to an inconvenient, draughty hall, usually in the rain. The attitude was based on the long and tremendous struggle for universal suffrage - the feeling that something so very hard-won (women did not get equal voting rights until 1928) should not be easy.

The other brake on imaginative reforms - soon expected to include mobile polling stations stopping at schools to Hoover up sixth form votes - is security. This bedevils the democrat's holy grail of voting by phone or email. But the United States is holding its first electronic election this year in part of Colorado, and we notoriously follow in Uncle Sam's wake. So far, the people of Colorado are happy with the way things have gone. For instance, fears that those without computers would be disadvantaged have been quelled by an e-drive among black voters which has seen their electoral registration rate rise by over 50%.

The first proof of the British reform pudding will come tomorrow when we know the turnouts, although the Home Office is sensibly reserving judgment until voters have had a few goes at the new-fangled ways. Meanwhile, other democrats will be studying the effect of the preferential vote in London, where electors can pick a first and second choice. But that is heavy duty electoral reform with momentous party-political implications. And that is another story Useful links
Representation of the People Act
Working Party report on Electoral Procedures

You can now add your name to the voters' register at any time of the year, instead of all at one time (which the forgetful and disorganised often miss). You can have your name removed from the public register - the equivalent to going ex-directory to avoid junk mail - without losing the right to vote. Registration has been made easier for homeless people, remand prisoners and many in mental institutions. The ethos which drives the initiative is a hugely welcome reversal of the British tradition that voting must somehow be stately, ponderous and - yes - require a bit of an effort from the punter. Older generations still associate polling day with trudging to an inconvenient, draughty hall, usually in the rain. The attitude was based on the long and tremendous struggle for universal suffrage - the feeling that something so very hard-won (women did not get equal voting rights until 1928) should not be easy. The other brake on imaginative reforms - soon expected to include mobile polling stations stopping at schools to Hoover up sixth form votes - is security. This bedevils the democrat's holy grail of voting by phone or email. But the United States is holding its first electronic election this year in part of Colorado, and we notoriously follow in Uncle Sam's wake. So far, the people of Colorado are happy with the way things have gone. For instance, fears that those without computers would be disadvantaged have been quelled by an e-drive among black voters which has seen their electoral registration rate rise by over 50%. The first proof of the British reform pudding will come tomorrow when we know the turnouts, although the Home Office is sensibly reserving judgment until voters have had a few goes at the new-fangled ways. Meanwhile, other democrats will be studying the effect of the preferential vote in London, where electors can pick a first and second choice. But that is heavy duty electoral reform with momentous party-political implications. And that is another story Useful links Representation of the People Act Working Party report on Electoral Procedures

fields.headline: Bank leaves interest rates unchanged
fields.trailText: The Bank of England has announced that interest rates will remain unchanged this month.
fields.body:
The Bank of England has announced that interest rates will remain unchanged this month.

The decision to leave rates at 6.00% is welcome news to British manufacturers, who have long complained that the soaring value of the pound is threatening to destroy their industry by making their exports more expensive.

It is also a respite for the faltering euro, which has hit new record lows this week and would certainly have fallen even further against the pound if UK base rates had risen.

This is the third consecutive time that the bank's Monetary Policy Committee has decided to leave rates unchanged. Many believe further rate rises are inevitable in the near future to curb rapid growth in the British economy, fuelled by consumer spending and the expansion of "new economy" companies.

Trade union leaders welcomed the committee's decision, but warned that rates must begin to fall or manufacturing jobs would be lost.

Roger Lyons, general secretary of the Manufacturing Science and Finance union, said: "We are relieved, not pleased. The MPC must start cutting rates if manufacturers are to stop cutting jobs."

John Edmonds, general secretary of the GMB union, said: "This is merely a stay of execution. British manufacturers and exporters are still sitting firmly on death row. Unless urgent action is taken to reduce rates, it is only a matter of time before the MPC finally throws the switch on UK exporters."

Business leaders were more positive about the decision, but still warned against future rises.

Ian Peters, deputy director-general of the British Chambers of Commerce, said: "Business will give the bank credit for recognising the untold damage that the strong pound is doing to UK business competitiveness."

Kate Barker, the chief economist of the Confederation of British Industry, said: "This was the right decision and should bolster long-term economic growth.

"Firms are now making investment decisions that will come to fruition over the next two years. With sterling rising to new peaks, a further rate rise would have hit these plans hard."

However, one City economist warned that interest rates were likely to rise again.

"We are certainly pleased to see the MPC has held off from raising rates and therefore not increased the pain manufacturers and farmers are in at the moment, but this may be a temporary reprieve," said Neil Parker of Royal Bank of England.

fields.headline: Have you entered yet?
fields.trailText: Reality Cricket 2000 is the fourth edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly magazine's popular game Ü more fun and less effort than any fantasy league, plus it gives you a chance of winning a winter holiday in Barbados.
fields.body:
Reality Cricket 2000 is the fourth edition of Wisden Cricket Monthly magazine's popular game Ü more fun and less effort than any fantasy league, plus it gives you a chance of winning a winter holiday in Barbados.

All you have to do is buy the May issue of WCM (complete with a free calendar of all the summer's fixtures), spend a few minutes filling in the Reality Cricket form and send it in by Friday, May 12.

There are 40 questions, ranging from "How many runs will players named Flower score in the first Test at Lord's?" to "How many different players will play for England in the seven Tests during the season?". Answering them is easy; it's getting them right that's more difficult.

Regular updates will be given at wisden.com as well as in the magazine. There is a prize for each month's winner, kindly provided by the PCA, and an overall prize of a holiday for two in Barbados, courtesy of Blade Sport. The charity that will benefit is the Primary Club, which provides sports facilities for the visually impaired.

May's Wisden Cricket Monthly is out now at all major newsagents. For subscription details, click here.

fields.headline: The Murdochs
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the Murdoch media dynasty on the net
fields.trailText: 1. Managing director of Sky TV Elisabeth Murdoch yesterday announced she was leaving the company and her father's business empire
fields.body:
1. Managing director of Sky TV Elisabeth Murdoch yesterday announced she was leaving the company and her father's business empire

2. Ms Murdoch, who pioneered original content on the channel, including soccer soap, Dream Team and the saucy Majorca-based game show Prickly Heat, is stepping down to set up her own production company.

3. She is the third generation of Murdochs in the media business. Her grandfather, Sir Keith Murdoch, made his name reporting in Gallipoli in the first world war.

4. In later years he owned the Adelaide News. Under Sir Keith it was the town's sleepy second paper.

5. His son Rupert, Elisabeth's father, took over the paper in 1952 and used it as a springboard for interests in books (HarperCollins), television (Sky, Fox), newspapers (New York Post, The Times) and film (20th Century Fox).

6. Many dislike the head of the Murdoch clan. He alienated Manchester United supporters in 1999 because he tried to buy their club. Others simply believe he has too much power.

7. Want to be like him? Well, Rupert has plenty of words of wisdom for aspiring media moguls with an eye to the future.

8. Don't be a traditional conservative. Instead, start off by putting topless models in a daily paper (The Sun) and then fall over backwards to help the communist regime in China.

9. Follow this up by creating a 'respectable' image. Admire the Australian university named after great uncle Walter and finally, endow a chair in your own image at Oxford.

10. Elisabeth appears to have chosen not to follow in her father's footsteps, and her departure leaves the Murdoch succession in question. One thing is clear, the next generation of Murdoch's is secure with news of Elisabeth's pregnancy. The expectant father is PR man Matthew Freud.

fields.headline: Populist, moi?
fields.standfirst: The critics say he's turning the National into the home of bland, crowd-pleasing theatre. So why is Trevor Nunn's team winning so many awards? He talks to Fiachra Gibbons
fields.trailText: The critics say he's turning the National into the home of bland, crowd-pleasing theatre. So why is Trevor Nunn's team winning so many awards? He talks to Fiachra Gibbons
fields.body:
Trevor Nunn looks a lot like Charles I. He's regal even dressed in denim. But while Charles lost his head by ignoring criticism, Nunn, less than halfway through his five-year term as head of the National Theatre, seems determined to hang on to his.

One of the best post-war interpreters of Shakespeare and the man who brought us Les Misérables and Cats, Nunn was the safe choice to replace Richard Eyre. He had run the Royal Shakespeare Company for 18 years, opened the Donmar Warehouse and amassed a £30m fortune in his "spare time" through projects in the West End and on Broadway. But almost as soon as he was installed, Nunn was accused of being too cautious and populist. Muttering began about whether he should be allowed a second term.

It is only fair to admit that the Guardian's theatre critic, Michael Billington, thought his appointment a bad idea. He said so, as Nunn ruefully testifies: "He heard a rumour that I would get it, and said it was a still worse idea when it became a reality."

Nunn, 60, has strong views on his old sparring partner, dating back to Billington's attack on his eight-and-a- half-hour staging of Nicholas Nickleby in 1980, which, Nunn delights in explaining, was "subsequently held up as one of the theatrical events of the decade". Billington, however, insists he is not pursuing a vendetta, but simply reflecting widely held views in the theatre that the National is now being run as "Trevor's club".

Nunn disputes this, but the National's stages have found little room for the younger generation of directors led by Stephen Daldry, Deborah Warner and Declan Donnellan.

Last month in these pages Billington again laid into the Nunn regime, attacking what he perceived to be its blandness and reliance on musicals, describing his latest, The Villains' Opera, as "dire". Since the show was Nunn's baby, it hurt all the more.

Nunn robustly defends The Villains' Opera as a perfectly valid vehicle for the National's award-winning ensemble, a company led by Simon Russell Beale and Henry Goodman that cleaned up at this year's Olivier theatre awards. "Between 1999 and the end of 2000 there will have been 43 productions in our theatres, five of which will have contained music.

"Honk! [a musical for young people based on The Ugly Duckling, described by Billington as "mediocre"] was written by two youngish British writers, and beat Spend, Spend, Spend and even The Lion King to the best new musical of the year [Olivier] award. Yet critics write that it should never have been put on."

Critics, Nunn says, have always tried to put him in a "mainstream, populist box" because he once worked for Andrew Lloyd Webber. "I am totally unrepentant about doing Oklahoma. I think of it as one of the seminal works of the popular theatre of the 20th century. It was an epoch-forming work that changed the genre."

He is also proud of bringing back an ensemble to the National "after decades" - without doubt the greatest achievement so far of his regime - and of squeezing more money from government. But he has clearly been stung by claims that he hasn't had an eye for new talent, and is adamant that playwrights are prospering under him. "People forget that it was I who opened the Donmar as a home of new writing. I don't know if you remember Educating Rita?"

Last week three National productions opened in New York: Copenhagen, Our Lady of Sligo and Rose. "We are keeping Broadway in new plays," he declares. "If there really have been problems for three years, as they say, what about Closer, Amy's View and Cleo, Camping, Emmanuelle and Dick, described only last week in the Guardian as one of the best plays of the 90s? Look at Joe Penhall's Blue/Orange, another new play, which has West End managements queueing up to transfer it.

"Of course there are a number of plays that occupy a middle position. Billington says our only policy is to do the worst play of any given author, but Nick Darke's The Riot proves that is not so. Don't go for the snapshot - you have to look at the broader picture."

Nunn maintains he does not feel under siege and has had much praise from his peers. "I would love to know how many directors of the first rank have attacked me. There will be aspirant directors and writers who are impatient - I understand that. But with an organisation of this complexity it takes a year just to learn what is going on. Things are changing now."

He has doubled touring, to bring "the National to the nation", and believes the institution should also be a showcase for the best of regional theatre. "I apologise that West Yorkshire Playhouse's Singing in the Rain [opening in the summer] is a musical. But this is what people got so excited about in Leeds, and which work do you think they want to bring to London? What should I say? 'Oh no, why don't you bring something that you're not so keen on?'

"The money that comes to us is from across the board. That is why the National has to be a theatre for everybody. Some of its work has got to be ground-breaking, but not all."

Nunn nevertheless admits it is "high time" the National had the wherewithal to present plays developed at its own studio on its main stages, and hopes to bring three new works through shortly. But where are the big plays, like David Hare's trilogy (Racing Demon, Murmuring Judges and The Absence of War), which defined the upheavals of Thatcher's Britain? "It's not so long ago that 'state of the nation' was a term of abuse," Nunn retorts. "I have approached many writers on the subject of the big play, and its extraordinary how so many of them are saying, 'I want to go small'. It will come. The determination to commission work, receive work, find work and encourage work is unswerving."

So is Nunn digging in for a second term? "I am not going to have such words put into my mouth. There is never a point when you achieve all you want. However, it is vital that departure is connected with succession. I am interested in building genuine associate directorships with people who are broadly in agreement with the aims of this building. There is no sense in trying to create cohesion from a group of people who keep saying no to everything you try to do."

It is clear, however, that Nunn wants to go on working with the National's "fantastic family" as long as he can. But with all that money in the bank, isn't it tempting to just opt for an easier life? "I promise you this," he says with even greater gravitas than usual, "I shall still be here when Billington [who is 60] has retired." And then, for the first time in an hour, he allows himself a grin.

webTitle: The end of an era, not the end of the road

fields.headline: The end of an era, not the end of the road
fields.standfirst: The Premiership needs Wimbledon more than they need it, argues WSC
fields.trailText: The tide of popular opinion, as well as results on the field, seems to be swinging against Wimbledon. After last Sunday's defeat at Bradford, there are more than a few who are willing to write their obituary as a Premiership team, and even as a club at all.
fields.body:
The tide of popular opinion, as well as results on the field, seems to be swinging against Wimbledon. After last Sunday's defeat at Bradford, there are more than a few who are willing to write their obituary as a Premiership team, and even as a club at all.

That includes the club's former owner, Sam Hammam, who last week reiterated what has become a common theme, particularly since Wimbledon's move to Selhurst Park. "If we ever go to the First Division we will lose between £7m and £11m a year," he said. "In two years the club will have no players, no money and would probably be in the Second or Third Division, heading nowhere."

For all Hammam's undoubted qualities, this is frankly bullshit. Wimbledon's situation if they went down would be little different from that of other clubs of similar size. In fact it would be much better than that of the likes of Barnsley or Charlton, because of the accumulated wealth Wimbledon have accrued by being members of the Premiership since it began.

Since the recent trend has been for clubs who drop out of the Premiership to bounce back, there seems little good reason for the likes of Crewe, Stockport or Grimsby to rub their hands in anticipation at falling on a weakened Wimbledon. God knows that the Dons could hardly be in a worse position than their co-tenants Crystal Palace - and they survived relegation this season with a surprising degree of comfort.

Yet even if Wimbledon did find First Division life relatively stable, there are still good reasons for wishing they would stay in the top division. That may seem harsh on Bradford, who have fully earned their chance of a reprieve (albeit almost certainly with a record low points total), but there certainly would be an unwelcome symbolic finality about the Dons' relegation.

The 'crazy gang' image may have become a tedious parody of itself, but it cannot mask the truly incredible achievement of the club since it began its rise through the divisions. For a club to rise and then stay at the top level for such a stretch was all but unheard of in pre-Premiership days (as Northampton, Orient, Notts County, Carlisle, Swansea and others would all testify), but to do so at this point in football's history is phenomenal.

Whatever you may think of Vinnie Jones and his fellow footballing gangsters, Wimbledon represent something which helps to keep the game going in the lower divisions - the idea that if they can do it, others can too. It's probably not true, of course. But if Wimbledon cannot defy logic any more, then it seems futile for anyone else to dream that they can.

fields.trailText: As queen of romance Maeve Binchy pens her last, is it time to kiss Mr Right goodbye?  Joan Smith asks what modern women want between the covers

Is the romantic novel dead? Maeve Binchy, the undisputed queen of the genre, has just announced her retirement from a world in which women fall madly in love and steamy sex is left to the reader's imagination. Scarlet Feather, due out in August, will be her final novel because she does not want to remain on the "treadmill" of writing books for the mass market. It is a highly unusual move from an author whose books have put her in the top 10 of Britain's most popular writers.

But is there still a market for novels in which women dream about meeting Mr Right and accompanying him to church in 15 yards of white satin? Kate Saunders, bestselling author of family sagas, dismisses the very idea. "It's a pathetic fantasy to get yourself dressed up in net curtains and go down the aisle." Romantic fiction is for readers who "go for books coloured like sweets - something that goes in with the cat litter in the supermarket".

Yet Binchy's success here and in the US, where Tara Road was a bestseller and Circle of Friends has been made into a movie with Minnie Driver, suggests there are plenty of women whose fantasy is to "go mad in a meringue". This Life creator Amy Jenkins' much-anticipated first novel goes one better, with a heroine facing turmoil after meeting an old flame on her honeymoon. So does Bridget Jones's Diary, which puts a modern gloss on the angst of young(ish) women who've not yet got their man.

It seems unlikely, though, that Helen Fielding's novel appeals to the same readers who snap up the latest Binchy. And while Fielding has inspired plenty of thirtysomething imitators, there are also signs that suggest the market for light romantic fiction is fragmenting. There are currently lots of novels about girls in their 20s sharing flats, referred to in publishing as Bridget Jones's younger sisters. Then there are novels about women in their late 30s/early 40s - Bridget's older sisters. "The mission is trying to set a new agenda for women of the 21st century through light popular fiction," says Shyama Perera, whose third novel, not yet published, falls into this category. "Love isn't the antidote to life's stings."

There are even novels, like surprise 90s hit The Bridges of Madison County, which offer a couple of romantic fantasies, late-blossoming love and the power of renunciation, to older women unlikely to experience it for themselves. These books recognise the limitations of their readers' lifestyles and offer a romance that is theoretically possible, if not very likely.

What all of this looks like is a calculated piece of niche marketing: identify your audience and give them what they want. But it could also reflect the fact that today's romantic authors are writing almost exclusively about their own experience. "Women are reflecting their own lives," agrees Victoria Routledge, whose latest novel charts the life of a twentysomething newly arrived in London. She predicts the successor to zany four-girls-in-a-flat novels will be fiction about friends opening restaurants. A case of killing two niches with one stone - romantic fiction meets the Naked Chef, or Bridget Jones's menus.

Celia Brayfield, author of Pearls and definitely not, she says, a romantic novelist, thinks publishers must bear some of the blame for the state of romantic fiction. "Women's fiction is starting to change, but not as fast as women's lives," she says. She points out that we have had 25 years of the pill and decades of feminism - facts not always reflected in popular fiction. "I am irritated," she says, "with the assumption that women still want the same old stuff. If Sebastian Faulks were a woman, he'd be told to take out the boring world war one rubbish."

Perera's experience with her second novel suggests this is not far off the mark. Her publishers were worried because the characters in Bitter Sweet Symphony belonged to a different age group from those in her first book, Haven't Stopped Dancing Yet, a coming-of-age novel. Perera compromised by bringing a couple of characters from the first novel into the second, thus ensuring continuity.

Her novels are, she agrees, semi-autobiographical. She wrote the second after her marriage broke up and regards it as an "empowerment novel". She also admits cheerfully: "I can only write what I've experienced. I'll never be one of those great writers who can write 200 years of history and geography."

Does this matter? It is clear that Bridget Jones's Diary appealed to women who recognised themselves in its anxious heroine, who felt better about their own failings after reading of a woman who smoked too much and worried about being single. There were novels in the 19th century that reflected the preoccupations of Victorian women, though our view is distorted by the fact that only the very best survived. Who now reads Marie Corelli or Mrs Humphry Ward, two of the bestsellers of their day?

Even Charlotte Brontë incorporated elements of romance and contemporary anxieties into her work. In her novel Shirley, the heroine's governess, "Mrs Pryor", turns out to be the mother of her best friend, Caroline Helstone, in disguise; her revelation of her true identity comes just in time to save Caroline from anorexic decline.

This theme, of mothers separated from their children by a legal system that recognised only fathers, recurs in Victorian fiction - an ancestor of the Hollywood movie Mrs Doubtfire, in which Robin Williams dresses up in drag and takes a job as a nanny to get access to his children. "Dead! And never called me mother," laments Lady Isabel Vane, in disguise at her son's deathbed in the stage version of Mrs Henry Wood's 1861 tear-jerker, East Lynne.

If popular novels based on real experience are nothing new, why are so many readers and authors hostile to romantic fiction? One answer lies in the expectation that fiction should do more than confirm what we already know. This is especially true of the kind of fiction most likely to be read by women, many of whom are trying to escape from traditional feminine anxieties about weight and status.

The other objection stems not so much from the books themselves as from their marketing. Slight, forgettable novels are hyped to a point at which other publishers, chasing sales, actively seek writers who can produce near-replicas. Bookshops groan under the weight of novels that repeat a successful formula, however trivial, while more sophisticated, demanding authors barely get a look-in.

Maeve Binchy is famous now, but will she still be read in 50 years? The telling thing about her decision to stop writing novels is that she will be 60 later this month, the traditional age for women to retire. It is as though she has been doing a conventional, if unusually lucrative, job all these years and is looking forward to a change. Perhaps that says something about romantic fiction, as opposed to its literary relative, which publishers tend to forget. Its appeal lies in its ability to capture a moment and when that moment is gone, it dates as quickly as last season's must-have shoes.

webTitle: If at first you don't succeed

fields.headline: If at first you don't succeed
fields.standfirst: No matter the outcome of today's local elections, the important thing is the taking part, writes Guardian Unlimited correspondent Derek Brown, who is standing as a Liberal Democrat candidate in Chipping Norton
fields.trailText: If, by any chance, you are reading this in the Chipping Norton ward of West  Oxfordshire, please stop right now and go to vote. More precisely, please  vote for your Liberal Democrat candidate for the district council. Me.
fields.body:
If, by any chance, you are reading this in the Chipping Norton ward of West Oxfordshire, please stop right now and go to vote. More precisely, please vote for your Liberal Democrat candidate for the district council. Me.

It's an odd business, this. As a Guardian correspondent, I have covered elections in at least a dozen countries. I've seen shameless rigging, wild public fervour, enormous landslides and huge upsets. I have predicted outcomes with middling success, and I've even voted a couple of dozen times, almost invariably for a losing candidate. Now I'm a candidate myself.

I wish I could report that this came about by a duly democratic selection process reflecting the will of the local party. To be perfectly candid, it came about in the public bar of The Chequers, down the road, where I was collared by the LibDems' indefatigable local organiser, Gareth Epps.

We need a candidate, he said. We need to fly the flag, give people a LibDem choice. You won't have to do anything. It won't take much time. There isn't a chance of winning. Persuasive young charmer, is Epps.

I've been a Liberal all my adult life. I have never been persuaded by the widespread view that journalists should be strictly and visibly non-political. We are, like everyone else, citizens and taxpayers. We should claim neither privilege nor exemption from civic duty. In short, I was a bit of a soft touch for the Epps approach.

There is no organised LibDem presence in our area - yet. Lacking a branch, we had to scurry round known supporters and sympathisers in the town to scrape together the ten required signatures on the nomination form. We made it, just, and my candidacy was duly acknowledged by the district council.

The tireless Epps next produced, seemingly out of the air, an A4 campaign leaflet in the 'focus' format beloved of Liberal door steppers everywhere. A half-dozen or so party loyalists readily agreed to help distribute them. The leaflet included a party application form, and, within a couple of days, we had recruited a new member, roughly representing a 12.5 per cent increase in our total strength. .

At the beginning of this week, Epps turned up with another focus sheet, this time it was A3-sized, in vivid orange, setting out the district party and yours truly's, manifestos for change.

Tramping round with a satchel of hastily folded photocopied leaflets is conducive to reflection - not least on the Epps pledge that the election would take up none of my time. And there were other leafleting thoughts. Yappy little dogs should be banned. Householders who install impenetrable draught excluders on their letter boxes should be severely punished. Terraced houses without front gardens are an estimable benefit to the democratic process.

It would be good to record more profound experiences from the campaign trail. But in truth the most sobering aspect of it was the almost complete absence of response. Voters I met on the doorstep were unfailingly courteous, and completely non-committal. Not one expressed a hint of hostility, or an iota of enthusiasm.

We could not consider a proper canvass, given our scant resources. If we had, I believe the results would have been dispiriting, and not just in the partisan sense. The fact is that Chippy folk are not, it seems, greatly moved by local government. They lost their own council in the ill-fated 1974 reorganisation and now, like so many middle-sized towns, there is little sense of identity with the amorphous, artificial district system. For a start, the council is based far away (20 miles anyway) in Witney, and it's hard to say which town is more fed up with the other - Chipping Norton because Witney ignores it, or Witney because Chipping Norton keeps bleating about being ignored.

There are local issues of burning importance to be addressed, not least the scandalous shortage of affordable housing, and the dire state of public transport. And yet for all the daily importance of such matters, local voters seem to have decided that local votes don't much count. The turnout last time was 30 per cent. I'll be pleasantly surprised if we get that today.

It doesn't help that the main party organisations, my own included, are so patronisingly dismissive of local government. Their party political broadcasts, devoted entirely to cheap national-level point scoring, were disgraceful.

Chipping Norton has deep-seated, radical, nonconformist instincts. It remains loyal to Labour while the rest of the county is deep-dyed Conservative. As an added curiosity, we now have a Labour MP, the Tory defector Shaun Woodward, who lives in non-proletarian splendour in a mighty mansion down the road.

There is nothing immutable about the dominance of the two big parties: LibDems have made great inroads in other parts of the district where they have got their act together. And that, in a sense, is what this election is all about: identifying support, and putting together the framework of a permanent, campaigning organisation which can win elections and, more importantly, improve the way we are governed. Only next time, God willing, there will be another - more worthy - candidate.

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.body:
Junk and disorderly
We are all familiar with junk mail which is annoying enough, but worse when the addressee is a) someone you've never heard of or b) a long-dead relative. John Gill's lament from East Sussex gives an insight into how this happens.

He runs a small mail-order company and uses addresses rented from list brokers for many of his mailshots. He recently rented 40,000 addresses, from one such broker, organised a mailshot, and has received nearly 3,000 of his catalogues back marked "gone away". Hundreds of those on the list had signed up with the mail preference service and should never have been contacted and several addressees had died years previously. The Direct Marketing Association (DMA), which governs the sale and use of data by its members, is, he claims, uninterested in taking up his complaint. "The carelessness of the [data] industry runs from top to bottom," he says, "and the consumer is rightly irritated by the mindless proliferation of junk."

 The DMA insists that there are strict regulations to prevent such slip-ups. The Data Protection Act requires brokers to ensure information is up to date and the DMA's own code of practice insists householders' details are amended within 30 days of death or within 60 days of changing address. Each broker has to sign a warranty guaranteeing that its lists abide by the rules. "We haven't had a case involving breached warranties before and will be investigating, even though the broker in this case isn't a member," says a spokeswoman.

Floored by Halifax
Kevin Healy of Leeds sought help from Consumer last year w hen his mortgage lender, the Halifax, helped itself to payments for an insurance policy he had never requested. Consumer managed to effect a reconciliation; now the Halifax has slipped again.

For 28 years Healy has paid his buildings insurance premiums as part of his mortgage arrangement and the policy has always been renewed automatically. Next year his mortgage will be paid off, so last year the Halifax explained that it had switched him to a new, more appropriate, policy. Several months later Healy found that a shower leak had damaged the walls and floorboards in his bathroom. Halifax, however, told him that whereas his previous policy had covered damage to floorboards, his new one did not. "I feel that the company has promoted an inferior policy which substantially weakened our cover," he says.

 Halifax admits that its service has been unacceptable. "Our insurance policies are not designed to cater for damage resulting from wet or dry rot," says a spokeswoman. "However, where the outbreak can be clearly linked to an insured event, consideration will be given to the cost of these repairs." Healy is to receive new flooring at Halifax's expense.

Plagued by gas
Last week R Wallis of London took three days off work to wait in for British Gas engineers and on each occasion the appointment was broken without notice or apology. A dozen phone calls and several letters later she was promised a goodwill voucher which was never sent. British Gas failed to reply to most of the letters, but did manage to drop her a line demanding payment of her gas bill.

 British Gas blames "poor communications" between departments and "lack of attention" on the part of its engineers. "The appointments were broken in the depths of winter when we are under more pressure," says a spokeswoman. "If an emergency arises our engineers get diverted to deal with it and they have a mobile to warn waiting customers of this. Maybe we didn't have Mrs Williams's number." The company has now agreed to pay her a sum to compensate for her wasted time and energy.

Straight to the top
Liz Eburne and Mark Crudgington are rejoicing. After seven months, they have finally had their Cable&Wireless telephone installed. "We ordered it in September but the installation was constantly delayed. We've had to put up with abuse from staff and lack of response from customer services."

Eburn and Crudgington hit on the bright idea of writing to the chief executive of C&W and received a reply within two weeks. They were put through on a direct line to a helpful human being and even given a date for installation. Their advice to people who have suffered similarly? "May we suggest other frustrated readers do the same as the results were refreshingly fast and it's a comfort to have a name to sort out future problems."

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER; email consumer@theguardian.com

fields.headline: My crown of thorns
fields.standfirst:
The history of the dome was beset by ministers who got involved, pushy sponsors and inept designers

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: It is reasonable to ask what those of us who made the heroic leap into the executive role for the Millennium Dome project thought we were doing. We were responding to the requirements of our employers and we had the tacit support of the politicians. We were also motivated by a desire to see progress made on a big idea, which had wallowed in the water for many months.
fields.body:
It is reasonable to ask what those of us who made the heroic leap into the executive role for the Millennium Dome project thought we were doing. We were responding to the requirements of our employers and we had the tacit support of the politicians. We were also motivated by a desire to see progress made on a big idea, which had wallowed in the water for many months.

We risked our immediate employment futures, since cancellation was a real prospect. According to one Bechtel consultant, if we survived that, then none the less I, as chief executive of a time-limited political project, was likely to end up walking out, sacked, dead or mad.

I reflected on those words every day of the next three years, until they came true.

The real driving force was the chance to achieve an exemplary shift in the standards of what is offered to the public in terms of public places in general and visitor experiences in particular.

There was a general belief that an incoming Labour government would reshape or reject the exhibition; this meant hold-ups. Yet we had to make rapid progress on hundreds of fronts at once.

The people prepared to join the company were almost by definition brave, flexible and innovative. Many were young and unused to large projects. Others, who were very experienced, had worked for themselves. Few had extended experience of working with public sector regulations.

We had very quickly to earn respect from our stakeholders, while struggling with the fact that we could not satisfy all their requirements. The sponsor representatives and the millennium commission staff and the politicians and civil servants made up a wider circle of essential participants. At times, the different business cultures could get in the way.

All contracts had to be let within public sector constraints, and hundreds referred for approvals. It was hard to convince a wardrobe mistress, buying materials for costumes for 84 aerial performers, that the procurement of fringes for skirts was something on which the commission should be allowed a view.

We struggled to balance the overall coherence of the dome while each area and sponsor kept their individuality and got value for money. We obviously did not satisfy everyone all the time. Increasingly, sponsors began to act together to exert pressure on the company.

The workload was immense. The shareholder minister and commission had weekly meetings with me and with other members of the team. Simultaneously, the company was in discussion with many, many bodies - the charitable world, the educational sector, the faith communities, the environmental agencies, the broadcast authorities (principally about opening night), the local planning authority, transport bodies and so on. The rush meant working with more uncertainty than was comfortable.

The exhibition needed to unite big picture ideas with what sponsors could in due course be persuaded to finance. The environment theme might have attracted any energy producer, from an oil company to the nuclear industry. In the event, no industry was able to match its own environmental record with its current commercial interests sufficiently well to make them comfortable to provide backing. Probably for that reason, it was one of the most consistent in design, and first to be finished.

Some designers did not at first produce practical, affordable and indeed buildable designs. Others could not adapt easily to changing requirements created by the search for sponsors: still others encountered real technical problems. The amount of innovation in the dome contents and structures is considerable. The desire to use environmentally sound materials was new for many design teams.

We had to have what seemed like an endless series of meetings. Sponsor chairmen and chief executives were seeing ministers in the course of their normal business, and quite reasonably could use these opportunities for lobbying for special interests. From time to time, individual ministers would also need to be involved in content on education, transport and science.

The scale and novelty of the dome meant that no one person could be asked to take on the final responsibility. The creative review group provided a high-powered feature of the management of the designers. Like all committees with no executive responsibility, it occasionally took off into the stratosphere, but its influence was generally benign and it was very brave in its backing of some ideas. To the charge that this may have produced too many cooks, I have to reply that we needed these many hands, to get through the work and to provide a broad church, appropriate to the very broad based market at which the dome is targeted.

Everywhere in the dome, we fought for the principles of good design, allied with accessibility and sustainability. Internationally, it is already admired for the achievement it represents and for the quality of the experience. And, as the Mori polls show, visitors enjoy their day at the dome and express satisfaction with the contents.

fields.headline: Ex-dome chief breaks silence
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The sacked chief executive of the Millennium Dome, Jennie Page, last night broke her four-month silence on her departure by confessing that she had been warned she would probably end up "walking out, sacked, dead or mad".
fields.body:
The sacked chief executive of the Millennium Dome, Jennie Page, last night broke her four-month silence on her departure by confessing that she had been warned she would probably end up "walking out, sacked, dead or mad".

Her admission came in a speech to the Royal Society of Arts in London, where she told how a consultant had hammered home the dangers of working on such a politically sensitive project. "I reflected on those words every day of the succeeding three years until they came true," she said.

Ms Page was asked to resign after the dome's attendance figures flopped in its first month, and she also took the blame for the disastrous opening night celebrations when thousands of guests were left waiting for hours at Stratford station. Friends said she had been made a scapegoat and pointed to how she had delivered the £790m project on time and on budget.

Ms Page said uncertainly about whether the dome would be built after the Conservative defeat in the 1997 election unsettled the scheme from the beginning. "There was a general belief that an incoming Labour government would reshape or reject the exhibition; this meant hold-ups in two key areas - discussions with sponsors and recruitment of staff - until the outcome of the election and the subsequent review became clear."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All the news that's fit to reprint
fields.trailText: Flo, Hasselbaink, Viduka, Trezeguet, Barthez, Guardiola and Enrique. Could they be playing for your team next season? Find out here.
fields.body:
Tore Andre Flo is a £18m target for Manchester United. Chelsea manager Gianluca Vialli will use any funds to bid for Liverpool's Robbie Fowler.

The Mirror claims Chelsea are the latest club to join the chase for Celtic's £7m striker Mark Viduka. Spurs and Leeds are also interested.

George Graham wants Atletico Madrid's Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink to partner new Tottenham striker Sergei Rebrov next season, reports the Sun. The Dutch striker played under Graham at Leeds and would love to work with the Spurs boss again. Hasselbaink would cost £15m.

Manchester United's latest goalkeeping target is £10m French World Cup-winner Fabien Barthez, according to the Daily Mail. Barthez has asked to leave Monaco after being accused by coach Claude Puel of throwing a game against his old club Marseille.

Meanwhile, Monaco striker David Trezeguet has said he will snub a £12m move to AC Milan if United made a bid to sign him - although Teamtalk report that Jean Tigana's Fulham are ready to make an audacious bid.

Spurs have made a concrete £2m bid for Hibernian prospect Kenny Miller. Leeds have also been tracking the Scotland Under-21 midfielder.

Bobby Robson has been given £15m to spend plus whatever he can generate from sales. His top targets, says the Daily Mail, are Pep Guardiola and Luis Enrique from Barcelona.

Fernebahce have claimed they have agreed a £3m deal with Chelsea for Gianfranco Zola.

fields.headline: Better than the real thing
fields.standfirst: When Ridley Scott wanted to recreate the Colosseum for his film Gladiator he stayed well clear of Rome.  Rory Carroll asked the director why
fields.trailText: When Ridley Scott wanted to recreate the Colosseum for his film Gladiator he stayed well clear of Rome. Rory Carroll asked the director why
fields.body:
Antiquity's most famous arena, the Colosseum, still hulks over Rome. Millions of sightseers flock to it every year, sit on the same seats as the baying mobs of 2,000 years ago, wander the dungeons where wild beasts were caged, and lapse into an awed silence. Ridley Scott is struck by its majesty and scale every time he visits.

In the 8th century AD, Bede wrote: "While the Colosseum stands, Rome shall stand, but when the Colosseum falls, Rome shall fall - and when Rome falls, the world will end,"

Well, the Colosseum is still standing. And when Steven Spielberg's DreamWorks studio commissioned a £120m epic about gladiators, Scott's pulse quickened. No director in a generation had been offered the opportunity to recreate imperial Rome. It was not enough merely to evoke the Colosseum's atmosphere and scale. No other monument better embodies man's ingenuity and brutality, and the director of Blade Runner and Thelma and Louise wanted the set of a lifetime. Everything had to be viscerally real. The actors and audience had to see, hear and smell the arena. Scott went to Malta.

The real Colosseum - all of Rome in fact - he left to the tourists. He preferred to build from scratch on an empty parade ground, using less bricks and mortar than Romulus and Remus on a slow day. The result? A triumph. Scott gallops the audience through a sprawling metropolis of winding streets, markets, temples, palaces, avenues and arches before depositing it, breathless, at the Colosseum.

The camera climbs up its three tiers, tips over the retractable canvas roof then plunges into the 50,000 spectators screaming for blood. Seconds later it is swooping into the bowels, where pulleys hoist cages of gladiators to the surface. The grilles lift, the fighters sprint into the sunlit arena and the games begin.

It is one of cinema's most ambitious, and successful, recreations of imperial Rome - achieved without setting foot in the city. For this, hail computer graphic imaging. British technicians built a fragment of the Colosseum's first tier; 16m (52ft) high and a third of the original circumference, enough to fit 2,000 extras. Computers filled in the second and third tiers and the statues, pasting images of real extras on to the virtual seating.

Not all scenes were filmed in Malta. A battle in Germania between a barbarian army and Roman legions was shot in Bourne Woods in Farnham, Surrey. A provincial gladiator school and arena were built in Morocco.

Just outside Rome lies the huge, underused sets of Cinecitta, the studio where Cleopatra, Ben Hur and War and Peace were made. Attempts are under way to revive it, and with it the golden age of Italian cinema. Martin Scorsese and Leonardo DiCaprio will film the £50m Gangs of New York there this summer, but Scott was not tempted. The only bit of real Rome in his film is the lead characters' footwear, made by hand and shipped to Malta.

Call it cheeky, call it postmodern, but the film's publicists staged photocalls and interviews in the Eternal City. In a hotel lobby two stones' throws from the Colosseum, Scott guffaws at the suggestion of having filmed here. "I love the Colosseum, but it's full of pockmarks - it's wrecked. We did look at another coliseum in France, but in the end it was simpler to build one."

Sitting beside him is Russell Crowe, whose character, General Maximus, wreaks havoc in the arena after becoming a gladiator. Did he share the attitude of Ewan McGregor, who was bored and bothered by acting in an empty blue space for The Phantom Menace? Not at all. "When 2,000 extras are screaming at you, it doesn't feel like you're acting in a void. It's real."

Filming a battle scene in the depths of a Surrey winter did not require much imagination, either. "It was snowing, we had horses, we had fires, it was like two real armies. Those weren't computers."

Crowe, a New Zealander best known for LA Confidential and The Insider, is keen to reassure Italians that he does value their history. The writings of Marcus Aurelius, the real emperor and father figure to his character, deepened his understanding. "I've been to Rome three times before and each time I've visited the Colosseum. It's incredible. To think that it's been there for 2,500 years."

He's overstating the case by about 600 years, but no one corrects him, for even the Romans do not mind being spurned in favour of Malta and computers. Advance press coverage of Gladiator has been uniformly positive. Their ancestors' glory has been re-created, and they are grateful.

 Gladiator opens on May 12.

fields.headline: Yasujiro Ozu:Tokyo Story
fields.trailText: Ozu shoots his story with as little movement of the camera as possible. We view scenes almost always from the floor, lower than the eye level of a seated character. He insisted that no actor was to dominate a scene
fields.body:
Those brought up on the energetic diet of American cinema may find it hard to appreciate the quietist art of the great Japanese director Yasujiro Ozu. He has been called the poet of family life, capable of taking the seemingly trivial and making great drama of it. Nothing was too small to be significant.

Ozu steadfastly peers into the hearts and minds of his characters until we feel we know them intimately. And the loyalty of those who love his work is as absolute as his own conviction. The number of film-makers who have made pilgrimages to his grave (marked simply by the Japanese word for nothing) runs into dozens.

Ozu started making films in 1927 and was one of the last to forsake the silent cinema. Much of this early work has been lost or destroyed. But we know from examples that he wasn't always as calmly contemplative as he was in his late work, which reached the west only in the 60s. He could make boisterous comedies and earthy chronicles of family life, containing outrageous sight gags. In the last stretch of his life, however, he had refined his art so much that it hardly seemed like art at all.

His most famous film, and certainly one of his masterpieces, is Tokyo Story. In it an elderly couple are taken to visit their grown-up children in Tokyo. Too busy to entertain them, the children pack them off to a noisy resort. Returning to Tokyo, the old woman visits the widow of another son, who treats her better, while the old man gets drunk with some old companions. They seem to realise they are a burden, and simply try to smooth things over as best they can. By now the children have, albeit guiltily, given up on them; even when their mother is taken ill and dies, they rush back to Tokyo after attending the funeral. A simple proverb expresses their failure: "Be kind to your parents while they are alive. Filial piety cannot reach beyond the grave." The last sequence is of the old man alone in his seaside home, followed by an outside shot of the rooftops of the town and a boat passing by on the water. Life goes on.

The film condemns no one and its sense of inevitability carries with it only a certain resigned sadness. "Isn't life disappointing," someone says at one point. Yet the simple observations are so acute that you feel that no other film could express its subject matter much better.

Ozu shoots his story with as little movement of the camera as possible. We view scenes almost always from the floor, lower than the eye level of a seated character. He insisted that no actor was to dominate a scene. The balance of every scene had to be perfect. Chishu Ryu, who often played the father in Ozu's films about family life, once had to complete two dozen devoted to raising a tea cup.

Tokyo Story was followed by eight other films, all of them as masterful, and a group named after the seasons, including Early Spring and An Autumn Afternoon. Each was about the problems of ordinary family life. While their conservative nature made younger more polemical Japanese directors, such as Imamura and Oshima, impatient, their universality has come to be recognised the world over. Ozu was the most Japanese of film-makers, but his work can still cross most cultural barriers.

CREDITS

Director Yasujiro Ozu

Writers Yasujiro Ozu, Kogo Noda

Starring Chishu Ryu, Chieko Higashiyama

Japan,1953, 136 minutes

webTitle: Ice Cube in line to play Iceberg Slim

fields.headline: Ice Cube in line to play Iceberg Slim
fields.trailText: Rapper turned actor Ice Cube is reported to be in final talks to take the role of Iceberg Slim in a film based on the Harlem icon's autobiography
fields.body:
Rapper turned actor Ice Cube is reported to be in final talks to take the role of Iceberg Slim in a film based on the Harlem icon's autobiography. Slim (real name Robert Beck) was a notorious pimp in the New York of the 40s and 50s before turning his hand to true-crimes fiction based on his own experiences in the underworld. His 1969 autobiography, Pimp: The Story of My Life, has been adapted by practised Hollywood script men Rob Weiss and Bruce Rubenstein and black director Bill Duke (Hoodlum) has been pencilled in to direct. The film - entitled Pimp - will begin shooting this autumn.

Where Iceberg Slim made himself legit through turning from pimping to prose, Ice Cube has taken a subtler route into the mainstream: shifting from the wild stylings of gangsta rap to a profitable niche in the Hollywood establishment. The former NWA frontman won acclaim earlier this year for his support slot as a disgruntled serviceman in David O. Russell's biting Gulf War satire Three Kings and is currently preparing to shoot a starring role in John Carpenter's Ghosts of Mars opposite Courtney Love - another musical wild child turned actor.

Not that the Cube has entirely let the rapping slide however. He is currently planning a short Monsters of Rap-style tour alongside heavyweight performers Snoop Dogg, Dr. Dre and Eminen, which kicks off on June 15 in San Diego. Clearly you can take the boy out of Compton, but you can't take Compton out of the boy.

He is currently planning a short Monsters of Rap-style tour alongside heavyweight performers Snoop Dogg, Dr. Dre and Eminen, which kicks off on June 15 in San Diego. Clearly you can take the boy out of Compton, but you can't take Compton out of the boy.

fields.headline: Lastminute loses £17 million
fields.standfirst:
lastminute.com
Follow lastminute.com's share price on Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com, the online travel supplier, has announced it lost £17 million pounds in the last six months.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com, the online travel supplier, has announced it lost £17 million pounds in the last six months.

The bulk of the pre-tax losses - £11 million - were made during the second quarter, during which time the business also doubled its spending on advertising to £4.8 million.

The results were the first announced by the internet start-up, which floated on the stock exchange in March at 380 pence per share, only to see its value tumble in what many saw as the first sign of the "dot-com bubble" bursting. Last night, lastminute's shares closed at 237 pence, but rose by 10 pence following this morning's results.

The company sold a total of £11.4 million worth of goods and services during the period, from which it earned £1.25 million in commission. Although the majority of the company's business is still in travel - mostly discounted airline tickets - lastminute said that travel only accounted for 55% of its sales.

The company insisted the results were positive, pointing out during the same period last year, it had sales of only £300,000. It also claimed to have increased its number of suppliers to 2,466, and its registered users to 1.4 million. However, only 68,000 people - less than 5% of registered users - actually bought anything using the site.

Lastminute's founders, Martha Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman, today said that the company's future was bright, despite the losses. Mr Hoberman, the company's chief executive, said lastminute's high profile among consumers would help it see off competition from a range of similar businesses, and eventually make a profit.

Ms Lane Fox also denied that the fall in share price had not meant the company was in trouble. Rather, she said, the company's stock had fallen as part of a market-wide fall affecting new technology companies.

Lastminute also announced today it was launching Britain's first restaurant booking service available through internet-enabled mobile phones. "We will continue to concentrate on the provision of last minute solutions over the Internet via a variety of platforms - personal computers, mobile, interactive digital television and personal digital assistants," the company said in a statement.

fields.headline: The mouse that conjugated
fields.standfirst: Meet Minimus, the rodent who has inspired a Latin renaissance in our primary schools. But is there any point in learning a dead language? Charlotte Higgins says yes - and gives 10 reason whyEducation Unlimited
fields.trailText: Meet Minimus, the rodent who has inspired a Latin renaissance in our primary schools. But is there any point in learning a dead language? Charlotte Higgins says yes - and gives 10 reason why
fields.body:
Latin is not a dead language. Minimus, a Latin course aimed at primary school pupils, is proving so popular that its author, Barbara Bell, is appealing nationwide for Latinists to emerge from their cobweb-strewn, Horace-bedecked libraries, brush off their Kennedy's Shorter Latin Primers (or Shortbread Latin Primers, as the dog-eared classroom copies always used to end up) and help set up Latin clubs in schools.

In fact, Minimus is far from dusty. In my day we had prissy Cornelia (Cornelia est in horto is a phrase engraved on my heart), Marcus her boring brother and the slightly naughty Sextus (that was ever such a funny name when you were 11). We hated them.

Minimus, on the other hand, is a cutesome little mouseykins who lives at the Roman settlement of Vindolanda, on Hadrian's Wall. He is a cheeky soul, always trying to snaffle morsels from the laden dining tables of the humans. He is also, we are given to believe, a native Briton and therefore a conquered, colonised mouse. In his spare time from being pursued by the cat Vibrissa, he doles out helpful advice to modern schoolchildren on Latin grammar.

It is witty, characterful and uses original everyday documents found near Hadrian's Wall to add immediacy to the whole thing (sadly these do look like boring grey smudges when reproduced in the book). But what's the point of it all?

What made Bell write the book, she says, was that she was concerned about children's understanding of English. "It is through Latin that I learned about the English language, and learned so many English words derived from Latin. Knowing Latin gives a wonderful general language awareness that is ideal when children come on to learn other languages like German, Spanish and Italian." And, she says, children love it (they must make children of very stern stuff these days). "Latin is beautifully structured," she enthuses, "and children like rules. They can see patterns in the language that they find extremely satisfying."

Still, you can sweeten the pill as much as you like, but when push comes to shove, you still have to learn your hic haec hoc. One mother, an ex-Oxford classicist, whose daughter is learning Latin from Minimus, says that her child started out all enthusiastic "but now she hates it just as much as we used to, and I have to bully her into doing it. I have a very weird sense of cycles of abuse... still, if you do Latin it gives you an understanding of English and an understanding of how to use language. Why we can't seem to teach English grammar in English I don't know. "

To find out whether ex-Latin students find their skills a useful aid for the rigours of modern life, I questioned a number of university classics graduates. Every single one of them did say that their increased grasp of the structure of language was a definite advantage in adult life. And so, with their help, I offer you 10 reasons to pursue a classical education:

1 One respondent claims that he reads Latin poetry when heartbroken. He has even made his own translation of Catullus's wonderful two-line poem, Odi et amo (I hate and I love) to repeat to himself when feeling down. He also tries to live by, he says, two epigrammatic quotes from Virgil, which have, in translation, entered the English language: "fortune favours the brave" and "never trust Greeks bearing gifts". I'm not sure what he has against Greeks.

2 A books editor says that the raunchy Latin poetry she read in school has "helped her shed her convent-school naivete". (That was Ovid's Amores, if any convent-school teenagers want to know).

3 It helps with the Guardian crossword.

4 A producer of drama for ITV says that he is sure that a good 5% of questions on Who Wants to Be a Millionaire are easier if you have a classical education.

5 Lots of people cite problem solving-skills as a benefit - whether because you have to learn patience to get through the horrible difficulties of translation, or because you have to be logical, calm and rational in the face of apparent gibberish.

6 An accountant says that every times she gives a presentation, she thinks about what the great orator Cicero would have said.

7 It helps you appreciate all kinds of western art and literature. Someone also talks about metaphors in Tolstoy being clearer after she'd read Virgil.

8 Another says that they never let lawyers and their long Latinate jargon words scare them.

9 The last two are mine: I once earned very good money finding or inventing Latin tags to go on Roman-themed gifts for the historical gift shop, Past Times. Libens, Volens, Potens T-shirt, anybody?

10 I am the only person in my patch of the Guardian who knows where to use "may" instead of "might" and understands the difference between a gerund and a gerundive. So there.

fields.headline: Love bug shuts down computers
fields.trailText: A computer virus spread by email messages titled ILOVEYOU has infected computers across the world today and forced the House of Commons to shut down its communication system.
fields.body:
A computer virus spread by email messages titled ILOVEYOU has infected computers across the world today and forced the House of Commons to shut down its communication system.

The virus, which is thought to have originated in the Philippines capital, Manila, spread through Asia before it reached Europe. A computer is contaminated once a user opens one of the emails, which appears to be a love letter from someone you know.

About 10% of UK businesses are thought to be affected by the bug. The leader of the Commons, Margaret Beckett, confirmed that the virus had hit Westminster's internal communications and told MPs that no member could send or receive emails.

"I don't know whether to say I am sorry or pleased that as far as I'm aware I have not received an email saying I love you," Mrs Beckett said.

The virus works by gaining entry to an email address book and sending out messages at five minute intervals. It is activated when a computer user opens a file attachment called LOVE-LETTER-FOR-YOU.txt.vbs and replicates itself so widely that it generates an enormous amount of network traffic, paralysing servers the world over. The virus can also damage the computer's hard drive and cause web browsers to malfunction.

Many users may not realise that the attachment carries a virus since it looks like a normal text file.

Virus experts are battling to find an antidote to the problem, which is thought to be targeting Microsoft's Outlook email software. Other packages such as Outlook Express, Eudora and Lotus Notes are not immediately at risk.

First sightings of the virus were in Hong Kong. Financial markets in Asia were hit, with the Dow Jones Newswires and the Asian Wall Street Journal among the early victims. The Danish parliament was among the first casualties reported in Europe, while the banking giant Credit Suisse First Boston issued a global email memo to employees warning them not to open the messages.

The United States, which was waking up as the world became aware of the virus, is expected to be hit less hard.

Who writes the viruses?
