fields.headline: Exchange merger raises euro hackles
fields.standfirst:
Executives duck tough questions

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: 'Subject to market conditions and consultation, the aim is for all equity trading ultimately to be undertaken in euros.' This was the statement yesterday with formal details of the proposed merger between the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges.
fields.body:
'Subject to market conditions and consultation, the aim is for all equity trading ultimately to be undertaken in euros.' This was the statement yesterday with formal details of the proposed merger between the London and Frankfurt stock exchanges.

True to form, the executives involved in yesterday's presentation proceeded to spend much of their time ducking questions about the use of the euro. Maybe they noticed that there are - er, certain political sensitivities here.

But their insistence that the use of the single currency will be up to the market to decide, and that the merged exchange has no influence on British government policy on the euro appears a trifle disingenuous.

If the merger does work and if it does form the nucleus of a pan-European trading network then much of Europe's share trading, wherever the deals originate, will inevitably gravitate to the euro. This is not because it is the currency of choice - just look at yesterday's events on the foreign exchanges - but because it is the currency of convenience. That, after all, is its raison d'etre.

Institutions seeking to simplify the ways they trade in shares are not going to run two sets of accounts, one in euros and the other in sterling, just to pander to British sensitivities on the issue. Nor would it make sense for institutions in the 11 countries which have adopted the euro to switch to the pound for equity trading for the same reason.

The long-term implication must be that the euro will become the de facto currency of an important part of the British economy - the wholesale financial services industry - before the rest of Britain has had a chance to express a formal view.

Sound advice

Meanwhile, it used to be said in the City that nobody ever got sacked for selling sterling - and for some 50 years it was sound advice.

Not today, however, when the nostrum drummed into the heads of every tyro George Soros is that nobody ever gets sacked for selling the euro.

At every point on its way, down to last night's close of just over 89 cents against the dollar, the expert commentators have been predicting a rally in the single currency. It was thought, for instance, that parity against the dollar was such a big psychological number that it would prove to be a floor from which the euro would bounce.

Instead, it went through the floorboards, and may carry on falling unless something is done to reverse its decline.

What we are witnessing threatens to exacerbate the glaring imbalances in the global economy that were highlighted by the International Monetary Fund last month.

The counterpart to the weak single currency is an excessively strong dollar, which judging by the falls in US exports over the past two months is already putting the squeeze on American competitiveness.

Closer to home, the pound is at levels not seen since Michael Heseltine walked out of Margaret Thatcher's cabinet over Westland.

There are two ways of looking at all this. One is that the level of currencies says something about the relative strengths of economies, so that the capital flows out of the eurozone and into the US and Britain is an endorsement of sound policies and the right sort of economic management.

If that is true, the Pontius Pilate approach would be correct.

The alternative view is that currencies are wildly out of kilter and that the euro's near-30% fall in 16 months is a classic overshoot. Capital flows into the US - the argument runs - are only to be expected in the very last stages of a bubble as investors seek to maximise their returns.

If this is what is happening, the failure of central banks to intervene now is simply building up even bigger trouble further down the road.

But with a US presidential election looming and a weak currency boosting euroland's exports, don't hold your breath.

Doubling up

Having trundled along for seven months without a chief executive, Alliance & Leicester has decided to ditch the position entirely. Instead we get a new group managing director, Peter McNamara, who will have responsibility for the day to day running of the group alongside executive chairman John Windeler, who will keep his focus on overall group strategy.

A&L says this all fits with the corporate governance codes designed to prevent power going the heads of senior executives. It also claims the new title simply fits Mr McNamara's job better.

But on the surface the title switch raises suspicions that Mr Windeler, formerly a non-executive, is simply avoiding giving up the double-barrelled role he enjoyed in the aftermath of Peter White's acrimonious departure.

fields.headline: Heseltine warns of euro damage
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Heseltine yesterday launched a powerful attack on Tony Blair, declaring that the prime minister's failure to join the European single currency was devastating Britain's manufacturing industry as exporters struggle with the high level of the pound.
fields.body:
Michael Heseltine yesterday launched a powerful attack on Tony Blair, declaring that the prime minister's failure to join the European single currency was devastating Britain's manufacturing industry as exporters struggle with the high level of the pound.

As the euro hit another record low against sterling, the former deputy prime minister warned that Britain would pay a heavy price if the government delayed its decision on the euro any longer.

"In Longbridge and in Dagenham one can see just the tip of an iceberg of what that price will actually be," Mr Heseltine said, in reference to the complaints by Rover and Ford that their exports have been severely damaged by the strength of the pound. "The longer it goes on the more damaging it will become."

Mr Heseltine, speaking for the first time since his announcement last week that he will stand down as an MP at the next election, said the prime minister should issue a firm declaration that he wants to join the euro.

At the moment, Mr Blair will only say that he would like to join the euro in principle and that he will make a decision on whether to hold a referendum on the issue after the general election if a series of economic tests have been met.

The former Tory deputy prime minister dismissed the government's position, claiming that Mr Blair's refusal to adopt a firm position was creating the conditions which has led the pound to reach ever higher levels against the euro. Against the dollar yesterday the euro fell below 90 cents for the first time since its launch last year.

"The process of going in has now to begin," Mr Heseltine said at a press conference organised by the pro-European Britain in Europe pressure group.

"The tests, which the government is perfectly capable of interpreting any way it wants, are simply a political smokescreen. Britain is going to join the euro. The question is when and at what rate. The principle should now be dealt with and at the earliest possible moment."

Mr Heseltine called on the prime minister to reinforce a declaration on the euro with a pledge to join the currency at a lower level of sterling than the current high rate.

His intervention underlined the growing strains within the cross-party Britain in Europe group, launched by Mr Heseltine and Mr Blair last year.

The Tory pro-European "big beasts", who also include the former chancellor Kenneth Clarke, are increasingly frustrated with the government's refusal to give a firmer commitment on joining the euro.

webTitle: Old trouper Hezza, and his hair, keep their gloss

fields.headline: Old trouper Hezza, and his hair, keep their gloss
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: A voice throbbing with excitement announced "He's just coming!" and into the room walked Michael Heseltine. It was a press conference for the Britain in Europe movement.
fields.body:
A voice throbbing with excitement announced "He's just coming!" and into the room walked Michael Heseltine. It was a press conference for the Britain in Europe movement.

Normally Euro affairs are so dull that you would rather watch eight editions of Classic Supermarket Sweep back-to-back on cable TV than sit through 10 minutes of someone banging on about their "tremendous friend, Hans Tietertotter, of the committee on administrative affairs, who's doing such marvellous work in the parliamentary liaison group on inter-regional funding _ Do have another of these mini-boeufs-en-croutes!"

But we were there to see the old trouper, the Donald Wolfit of the political stage, making his first farewell appearance since announcing last week his imminent retirement from politics.

He looked remarkably fit for someone who might have been Tory leader if it had not been for his heart. He could probably still go to the mat with William Hague and might even win. The hair is as bouncy as ever, and if it is no longer bushy enough to shelter small woodland creatures, it has lost none of its gloss. He could sell it to the makers of My Little Pony.

He began with the familiar halting delivery with long pauses between the phrases. In the past this was meant to indicate Hezza holding his emotions under strict control, and was generally the prelude to a stupendous rant against socialism.

fields.headline: London's voting system
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Mayor
fields.body:
Mayor

 London's 5m-strong electorate have two votes, for a first and second choice, under the supplementary voting system.

 If one candidate wins more than 50% of the first preference votes he or she is immediately elected as mayor.

 If nobody wins 50%, the two candidates with the highest number of votes will remain in the contest while all others are eliminated. The votes of the losers will be distributed to the two remaining candidates.

 The candidate with the highest number of first and second preference votes will be elected mayor.

 Votes will be counted electronically by a machine which processes two ballot papers a second. Voters will feed their ballot papers into a special box with instructions not to fold them.

The calculations

 Ken Livingstone, who looks certain to win, is hoping to secure more than 50% of first preference votes to strengthen his hand in negotiations with the government.

 If he fails to win 50% of the vote there is an outside chance that another candidate, probably Steve Norris, could beat Mr Livingstone with the help of second preference votes. This is highly unlikely, however, and Mr Norris would be happy with a strong second place. If he wins more than 20% of first preference votes he will have done well.

Assembly elections

 Londoners will have two votes to elect the 25-seat assembly.

 In the first vote, Londoners will choose one candidate in their local constituency. The winner will be elected on a first-past-the-post basis. London is to be divided into 14 constituencies, consisting of two to three boroughs.

 In the second vote Londoners will select the 11 remaining members of the assembly from a London-wide list. Voters will cast a vote for a party or an independent candidate.

 The 11 seats will be distributed in proportion to the votes received.

fields.headline: Clinton bows to food producers
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: The Clinton administration bowed to food manufacturers yesterday by refusing to compel them to label products that contain genetically-modified ingredients.
fields.body:
The Clinton administration bowed to food manufacturers yesterday by refusing to compel them to label products that contain genetically-modified ingredients.

Instead, it outlined a plan to provide more scrutiny of genetically altered crops, set standards for labelling food claiming to be free of biotech products and involve the agriculture department in tests to establish whether foods included gene-altered substances.

"The Food and Drug Administration's [FDA] scientific review continues to show that all bio-engineered foods sold in the United States today are as safe as their non-bioengineered counterparts," commissioner Jane Henney said. "We believe our proposed initiatives will provide the public with greater confidence in the safety of these foods."

The food industry welcomed the initiative. "We think this is a good step to make sure that this process is open and transparent," said Brian Sansori, a spokesman for the Grocery Manufacturers of America.

But consumer groups which have insisted that genetically-modified foods should be labelled as such rejected the plan. "Talking is not testing," said Andrew Kimbrell, director of the centre for food safety in Washington.

Carol Tucker Foreman, director of the consumer federation of the food policy institute, said: "It has yet to be seen whether the details of a mandatory pre-market approval process will meet the public's need for assurance of safety."

Foods free of genetically-altered elements are expected to carry an FDA statement that they are not necessarily any safer. "That means that the very people who are advertising that they don't have this stuff in their food are forced to advertise the supposed safety of engineered products," said Mardi Mellon of the Union of Concerned Scientists.

The governors of 13 states, including Missouri and Delaware, home to the leading biotech companies Monsanto and DuPont, are joining the industry's attempt to convince the public that the crops are safe. "It makes sense to say this isn't just the big bad chemical companies trying to engineer something to jam down your throats," said Ed Schafer, co-chairman of the Governors Biotechnology Partnership.

fields.headline: 'Britain will not decide our destiny'
fields.standfirst:
Mugabe vows to continue his land redistribution agenda as Zimbabwean elections draw near

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: President Robert Mugabe promised yesterday that "hostile British neo-colonialism" would not force him to backtrack on his plans to redistribute about half the white-owned farmland in Zimbabwe to poor blacks.
fields.body:
President Robert Mugabe promised yesterday that "hostile British neo-colonialism" would not force him to backtrack on his plans to redistribute about half the white-owned farmland in Zimbabwe to poor blacks.

He launched his Zanu-PF party's parliamentary election manifesto by portraying the land crisis as lying at the heart of a continuing struggle against British imperialism. And he offered his backing to the veterans of the independence war who have led the occupation of about 1,000 farms, saying that he would not order them off the land.

Speaking to an audience of boisterous veterans and party supporters - and attentive British diplomats - he denounced white Zimbabweans as "diehard Rhodesian settlers" who were welcome to leave the country if they did not like his policies. But his primary target was the British government's criticism of the farm invasions and the rising political violence.

"We won't allow [Britain] to determine our destiny. We determine it ourselves, the people of Zimbabwe," he said.

"Not from Downing Street. Not from the British parliament. And let those who are pretending that they can determine our future realise we fought for it. We can still fight for it.

"The British government says it has no further colonial responsibility for Zimbabwe, but every day they are talking about Zimbabwe and want to direct our affairs. No sanction of whatever nature can make us desist from our quest for land. Never, never."

The government still has to announce a date for the elections, which it originally said would be held last month. It can legally delay them until August.

Mr Mugabe rejected British and Commonwealth calls for him to ensure that the vote is held on time. "We don't need a Mr Blair or a Mr Robin Cook to tell us when to hold elections. We know when to hold them," he said.

But it is clear that the campaign is already under way. Zanu-PF's election slogans focus on the farm crisis: "Land is the economy and the economy is land," and "Lest they forget, land belongs to the people."

Mr Mugabe promised a "humane" approach to land redistribution; whites who own more than one farm, or whose property abuts existing communal lands, are to be the first targets for seizures. But he warned the farmers against rejecting redistribution.

"If there is going to be resistance, then we might go much further and say you don't acknowledge the justice of our cause. And if you do not, then, from every angle, you are not fit to be one of us," he said.

"The 20,000 that the British want to leave the country are free to leave and we will assist them by showing them the various ways out of the country."

At times he broadened his attack on a "very vicious international campaign against Zimbabwe", although he did not directly criticise the Commonwealth ministerial action group for its condemnation of his government on Tuesday.

He blamed the Movement for Democratic Change, which the government parodies as the "Movement for Destroying the Country", for spreading political violence and added: "They got more than they bargained for".

He regretted the killing of at least 15 people, including the murder of two white farmers - David Stevens and Martin Olds - but accused journalists of over-emphasising their deaths.

"We are sorry that there have been some deaths; and those deaths are not just of Stevens and Olds, there have been some blacks. But the CNN and the BBC is only interested in projecting the deaths of the whites. We don't die. Only the whites die. They have a greater life than us. More sacred."

He criticised the financial policies imposed on Zimbabwe by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, saying they had made capitalists richer but had done nothing for the poor.

Zanu-PF's election manifesto promises that both these organisations, and foreign donors, will be "removed from having any direct or indirect role in managing and controlling our country's fiscal policy".

But always he returned to his verbal assault on the UK.

He criticised Britain for failing to put together a high-powered delegation to meet the three Zimbabwean cabinet ministers who flew to London for talks last week.

He said they had expected to meet the government's economic experts to discuss funding the land redistribution, but all they got was the foreign secretary.

"It was Mr Robin Cook, who wanted to use the meeting for propaganda purposes," he said. "It was sad, very sad."

fields.headline: Purple pimpernel prepares for government
fields.standfirst:
In the last of our series on the leading contenders, Matthew Engel tracks down the strangely elusive frontrunner, Ken Livingstone

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: In the last of our series on the leading contenders, Matthew Engel tracks down the strangely elusive frontrunner, Ken Livingstone
fields.body:
The strangest election campaign Britain has ever seen came to a suitably bizarre conclusion yesterday when Ken Livingstone, the overwhelming favourite to become mayor of London, spent the last available day doing no electioneering whatever.

Steve Norris took the Tory battle bus to Sutton; Frank Dobson was improbably being smothered by kisses in Walworth; Susan Kramer, the Lib Dem, did one of her high street walks in Richmond. The mayor-apparent did his utmost to avoid being seen doing or saying anything. Not a baby kissed; not a dog stroked; not a promise made.

At first it was said Mr Livingstone would probably go on to his purple/lilac Ken4London bus "if it didn't rain", a notion conveying a splendidly relaxed fair-weather form of politics, probably last seen during the Earl of Rosebery's administration. It didn't rain; he still didn't go on the bus. The candidate, said an aide, would instead be having "private meetings" all day.

Suddenly, at lunchtime, the Purple Pimpernel broke cover. He was spotted boarding a Tube, alone, at Oxford Circus. He emerged at Westminster, and made the already familiar walk to Romney House, HQ of the Greater London Authority - his fifth visit since the campaign started - and went in to talk to officials about his plans for events after his assumed elevation to the mayoralty tomorrow. He was wearing the same jacket, tie and trousers (the jury is out on the shirt) he had on when he was last there five days earlier

All his meetings, he said, were about transition. "There's going to be a real scrum on Friday, and I want to be fully prepared if I'm mayor. There's nothing else we can do about being elected. It's been a seven-month campaign, and there's real voter fatigue. Short of gliding over the streets of London in a balloon, there are no stunts left to pull."

Mr Livingstone's refusal to play the customary political game of lastminute.con seems to be based on a number of factors: strategy; reality (he admitted envy of Labour's ability to turn out a million personal letters from Tony Blair); a dash of statesmanship perhaps; and his own impish perverseness. Plus a touch of hubris, and incompetence within his campaign team. The exact mix is a matter of debate. There is also a fear of the press, which has turned sharply against him. "The coverage has been a disgrace, as I knew it would be. If Rupert Murdoch came out and said I was a good guy, my support would probably melt away."

Some of his aides may have feared that, given a platform, Mr Livingstone might have goaded his opponents by announcing a mayorally-sponsored contest for best graffito on the Cenotaph, proceeds to Gay Fenian Asylum Seekers. His bus, meanwhile, went south of the river without its conductor. It appeared suddenly from behind a 355 in Tooting Broadway. "One people, one London, one mayor," the man on the microphone was declaiming, rather chillingly. The volunteers, in their lilac fleeces, were still loyal, if a little ragged. The response seemed more tepid than it has been.

Only a couple of drivers obeyed the injunction Hoot4Ken, and they may well have been simply irritated: the usual reason for hooting in Tooting. This fitted with Mr Livingstone's perception of voter fatigue, and the sense of slight slippage in his overwhelming lead. But none of his opponents have emerged as a credible al ternative focus: Dobson is still tainted, Kramer is still too obscure, Norris is still a Tory.

The raven-haired Ken-ite in the beret who looked like a 70s hijacker turned out to be a nice and apparently law-abiding TV freelance called Rebecca Goff. She has now been persuaded to swap the beret for a less terrifying natty blue number she bought at a craft fair in Devon. With her was the one bus regular who ignores the uniform, Sinna Mani, an old Labour hand and a former mayor of Lewisham.

"Ken's not a doer," he said. "I'm under no illusions about that. But he is an enabler. When the froth dies down, he'll appoint the best people and get the best out of them." At that moment, an elderly passerby shouted: "You must be mad. Don't you remember how he effed up London last time?"

Then the bus trundled off, looking like a prop in a film about a fictional candidate standing in a fictional election for a fictional office. We're in the last reel of a film that has lurched from storyline to storyline (remember Jeffrey Archer?), and still the electorate's disbelief in Ken remains largely suspended. Next comes The Sequel. That's when people usually get fed up with the whole concept - and the star.

fields.headline: Rebrov ready to join Spurs
fields.trailText: One of the biggest transfer coups of recent years looked a step closer to completion yesterday when Ukranian international striker Sergei Rebrov declared his willingness to join Tottenham Hotspur.
fields.body:
One of the biggest transfer coups of recent years looked a step closer to completion yesterday when Ukranian international striker Sergei Rebrov declared his willingness to join Tottenham Hotspur.

The 26-year-old, who scored eight goals in this season's Champions League, had been expected to move to either AC Milan or neighbours Internazionale, with Inter chasing him as a replacement for the injured Ronaldo. But Rebrov revealed today that he has agreed personal terms with Spurs and that a deal "should be done within a couple of weeks."

"They managed to find a common language with me," Rebrov said of his dealings with the North London club. "I am looking forward to playing in England. I like it better than Italian football, although I can't explain why."

Rebrov, who is likely to command a transfer fee of £11m, had also been in talks with Arsenal. But it seems a personal liking for George Graham (as well as a veto on any transfer moves at Highbury until after the Uefa Cup final) swayed his decision. "At a club like Tottenham there's a trainer [Graham] who gets the strikers to run and get the ball," he said. "I am used to that. I have played like that all the time."

Rebrov's arrival at White Hart Lane would go some way to allaying criticism of Spurs' lack of activity in the transfer market. Chairman Alan Sugar has frequently been accused by fans of failing to put his hands in his pockets during his time in charge of the club.

Furthermore, the signing of a major world star will also help the club as they seek to persuade Sol Campbell and Steffen Iversen to sign new contracts at White Hart Lane.

I like it better than Italian football, although I can't explain why." Rebrov, who is likely to command a transfer fee of £11m, had also been in talks with Arsenal. But it seems a personal liking for George Graham (as well as a veto on any transfer moves at Highbury until after the Uefa Cup final) swayed his decision. "At a club like Tottenham there's a trainer [Graham] who gets the strikers to run and get the ball," he said. "I am used to that. I have played like that all the time." Rebrov's arrival at White Hart Lane would go some way to allaying criticism of Spurs' lack of activity in the transfer market. Chairman Alan Sugar has frequently been accused by fans of failing to put his hands in his pockets during his time in charge of the club. Furthermore, the signing of a major world star will also help the club as they seek to persuade Sol Campbell and Steffen Iversen to sign new contracts at White Hart Lane.

fields.headline: Foe faces a lengthy ban
fields.trailText: West Ham's Marc-Vivien Foe faces a four-match ban after being charged with misconduct by the Football Association for allegedly pushing the referee at the end of Tuesday's controversial game at Arsenal.
fields.body:
West Ham's Marc-Vivien Foe faces a four-match ban after being charged with misconduct by the Football Association for allegedly pushing the referee at the end of Tuesday's controversial game at Arsenal.

The decision coincided with a warning from the FA's new chief executive Adam Crozier that the governing body will continue to get tough with intimidation on the pitch following a spate of recent incidents.

The Foe episode is not deemed as serious as the infamous occasion when his Hammers team-mate Paolo di Canio pushed over the referee Paul Alcock while playing for Sheffield Wednesday, also against Arsenal.

But the Cameroon international can still expect to be banned for at least a month if found guilty of manhandling Durkin as various West Ham players protested at his decision to allow Emmanuel Petit's injury-time winner despite suspicions of handball. Foe's team-mate John Moncur was also charged with misconduct for comments made to Durkin.

West Ham's manager Harry Redknapp escaped a misconduct charge despite making scathing post-match comments about Durkin's refereeing ability and the club as a whole escaped a misconduct charge for failing to control their players.

Instead the club will receive a written FA warning that they are responsible for their players' behaviour after picking up one red card and seven yellows on Tuesday night. Trevor Sinclair was sent off in injury-time for a foul having minutes earlier been cautioned for protesting the handball decision.

The FA is now considering introducing an automatic fine for clubs who pick up more than six cautions in a game.

Meanwhile, Arsenal yesterday moved to close the financial gap between themselves and their wealthy rivals Manchester United by appointing a heavy-hitting City businessman as managing director.

Keith Edelman, who until recently was the chief executive of Storehouse, the stock-market listed owner of Mothercare, is to take over from Ken Friar who is stepping down at the end of this month after 50 years in the post.

Edelman's arrival will reignite speculation that Arsenal are considering a money-raising flotation of their own or partnering a media company.

Prior to working for Storehouse, the 48-year-old held a senior position at Carlton Communications, the media company which in 1998 tried to buy Arsenal. Friar will remain at the club to oversee the move to a new stadium at Ashburton Grove.

webTitle: Warning for Hague as Lib Dems claim Romsey poll will be close-run fight

fields.headline: Warning for Hague as Lib Dems claim Romsey poll will be close-run fight
fields.standfirst:
The other elections Tories hope to make 400 local council gains

Special report: Elections 2000
fields.trailText: Today's byelection in Romsey will produce a photo-finish, Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy predicted yesterday as he claimed significant slippage in the Tory vote could leave William Hague's party in "terminal trouble".
fields.body:
Today's byelection in Romsey will produce a photo-finish, Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy predicted yesterday as he claimed significant slippage in the Tory vote could leave William Hague's party in "terminal trouble".

In a final push before today's poll, both Lib Dems and Tories flooded the traditionally true blue Hampshire seat with MPs and activists to maintain momentum in a race both sides acknowledge could depend on turn-out.

With 3,300 council seats at stake as well, all three party leaders clashed at Commons question time.

Mr Hague again played the law and order card while Mr Kennedy joined forces with Tony Blair to condemn the Tory leader for stirring up the asylum issue in search of votes.

Unembarrassed by a British National party claim that he had "pinched our campaign" on asylum seekers and the euro, Mr Hague hammered Labour's "wretched weakness" on crime, including Monday's anti-capitalist riot in London.

Mr Blair defended Labour's record and pointedly told MPs that Mr Hague had not dared run his anti-asylum scare tactics in the Commons itself.

Accusing Mr Hague of "leaping on any passing bandwagon" he told one MP that the Tory leader's "desperation is rather bigger than his judgement."

While Mr Kennedy, buoyed by a 600-strong party rally and frenetic campaign, talked tough in an eve-of-poll press conference, the Conservatives fielded shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe in the leafy, Conservative-voting, north of the sprawling Romsey constituency.

The Tories are confident their Eton-educated candidate, Dorset farmer Tim Palmer, will hold the seat made vacant after the death of sitting MP Michael Colvin in a house fire in February.

The Lib Dems, pushing the local credentials of Romsey pharmacist Sandra Gidley, publicly claim the seat is within their grasp and privately believe they can at least whittle the Tories' 8,585 majority down to within 1,000 votes.

Doing so would require Mr Kennedy's party to win over substantial numbers of Labour voters in housing estates on the Southampton fringes, banking on a combination of disillusion with Tony Blair's government and a measure of tactical voting to keep out a Tory MP.

Labour's search for votes saw the party field cabinet members, David Blunkett and Alan Milburn, to warn voters that the Tories would threaten improvements in education and health - not least by forcing elderly people to pay £2,000 for a cataract operation outside the NHS.

Lib Dem campaign chief Lord Rennard, who has consistently talked up his party's chances in Romsey, yesterday claimed half of Labour supporters canvassed indicated they were planning to vote Lib Dem, together with a third of wavering Conservatives. Estimates of Labour converts are strongly rejected by the party's candidate Andrew Howard, who insists Labour is "fighting for every vote".

Talk of a shock result in such a solidly Tory constituency, the 50th safest Conservative seat in the UK, is bold. Lib Dems acknowledge that a swing large enough to win them Romsey by just one vote would translate at a general election into 103 Lib Dem parliamentary seats and 70 Tory ones.

But even taking a significant bite out of the Conservatives' share of the vote would constitute a confidence boosting achievement for the Lib Dems. Mr Kennedy said yesterday: "If the Conservatives, in what should be, historically, one of the safest seats in the country, experience any loss of support in our direction when they are not in government, then they really are in potentially terminal trouble."

The Tories, running a less effervescent campaign which has nevertheless seen three visits by Mr Hague, deny Lib Dem suggestions they are rattled.

The euro and asylum seekers are key concerns on the doorstep, they claim. One source said: "The Lib Dems have played it very parochially - it's all cycle paths and broken paving stones."

Miss Widdecombe, striding up Stockbridge's quaint high street, used her visit to announce new proposals for "cops in shops" - basing neighbourhood bobbies in local shops or pubs to increase public accessibility and deter criminals.

In the local elections there are 3,360 seats up for grabs in 153 councils. Labour is bracing itself for losses because it is defending seats won in 1996 at the height of John Major's unpopularity. For the Tories, more than 400 gains will be a good performance, and anything less than 200 gains will privately alarm party strategists. Any Lib Dem gains will come as a relief to Charles Kennedy. More than 100 losses will cause him concern.

webTitle: Vote for Norris, Mirror tells readers

fields.headline: Vote for Norris, Mirror tells readers
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The Mirror newspaper, traditionally a staunch supporter of Labour, made the surprise move yesterday of advising its readers to vote Tory.
fields.body:
The Mirror newspaper, traditionally a staunch supporter of Labour, made the surprise move yesterday of advising its readers to vote Tory.

Along with the Express, which has a shorter history of supporting Tony Blair, the newspaper endorsed the Conservative candidate for mayor of London, Steve Norris.

"To vote Dobson is pointless. To vote Livingstone is unthinkable. And the Lib Dem candidate Susan Kramer is clearly out of her depth."

That left only one "unbelievable" alternative, the Mirror said in its editorial column.

The Express described Frank Dobson as "decent", but said he had been "shoe-horned" into the job. Ms Kramer was a serious, dedicated politician, but had no chance of winning. Mr Livingstone would be a disaster. The paper concluded that Mr Norris, while not perfect, but was "sensible".

Mr Norris was delighted at the newspapers' stands. "These endorsements show two things. Firstly, that nobody trusts Ken Livingstone to run London, and secondly, this really is a new kind of politics in which people from all constituencies - media and voters - recognise the need for action before party politics," he said.

The Livingstone camp was sanguine. A source said: "It is amazing that Tony Blair has presided over a situation which has led the Mirror to advocate voting Tory."

The Mirror had not endorsed Mr Livingstone, in order not to antagonise the government, the source said.

Sources at the Mirror said yesterday that editor Piers Morgan had taken the decision with his deputy, Tina Weaver, against the advice of other staff, in order to fire a shot across the bows of the prime minister. It is thought that Mr Morgan was angered at Mr Blair's recent decision to send a handwritten defence of the government's record to the Sun, the Mirror's tabloid rival.

fields.headline: Prodi clears out tainted officials
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: Three of the most powerful jobs in the European Commission will change hands in a shake-up designed to strengthen the hand of its president, Romano Prodi, after months of media criticism have badly damaged his reputation.
fields.body:
Three of the most powerful jobs in the European Commission will change hands in a shake-up designed to strengthen the hand of its president, Romano Prodi, after months of media criticism have badly damaged his reputation.

Victims of the surprise reshuffle include Mr Prodi's spokesman and friend, Ricardo Levi, and the commission's most senior civil servant, Dutchman Carlo Trojan, whose links to the disgraced Jacques Santer commission were becoming an embarrassment.

But a stern-faced Mr Prodi denied yesterday that constant media sniping about his erratic leadership style and poor communications strategy had forced his hand. "It is not my habit to take decisions because of pressure," he said. "If I acted on pressure all the time, I'd be making changes every day."

In an address peppered with euphemisms and praise for officials who have effectively been demoted, Mr Prodi said a reshuffle was needed to make the commission more efficient. But he doggedly denied that Mr Levi or Mr Trojan had committed any big errors.

One of Mr Prodi's advisers offered this explanation for the changes: "If you're a prime minister and you go through a rough period, you have a shake-up partly to clear the air, partly to consolidate your position and partly to promote some good people. And if you have a shake-up, you have a big one - it's a learning curve."

The reshuffle will see British lawyer Jonathan Faull replace Mr Levi as the commission's most senior spin doctor. Irishman David O'Sullivan, previously in charge of Mr Prodi's team of policy advisers, takes up the prestigious job of secretary general, overseeing some 18,000 officials.

webTitle: Hague and Blair clash over riots

fields.headline: Hague and Blair clash over riots
fields.standfirst:
PM rejects 'weak on crime' jibe

May 2K: special report

Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague seized on the controversy over the handling of the May Day protest in central London to launch a direct attack on Tony Blair last night, lambasting the prime minister for "wretched weakness" on law and order.
fields.body:
William Hague seized on the controversy over the handling of the May Day protest in central London to launch a direct attack on Tony Blair last night, lambasting the prime minister for "wretched weakness" on law and order.

In bitter Commons exchanges, the Tory leader told him: "You are the one that went out to the Cenotaph yesterday, peeled an onion and said it can never happen again. We want to know what you are going to do to make sure that it never happens again."

Mr Blair retorted by accusing the Tory leader for "leaping on any passing bandwagon" and added: "Your capacity to exploit any situation is absolutely unlimited."

Though some have praised the Metropolitan police for tactful treatment of the "guerrilla gardening" event in Parliament Square, Mr Hague reflected those who have accused the authorities of being too soft on a protest which, as both police and organisers had anticipated, led to violent clashes.

With an eye on today's mayoral election, Mr Hague said that perpetrators were the same groups which wrecked the City on June 18 last year. "On Monday the same groups defaced the Cenotaph and dishonoured our war dead.

"You have said this kind of thing cannot happen again. So will you now abandon this government's wretched weakness on law and order and will you support the call of the [Tory] mayoral candidate Steve Norris to do all in your power to see this annual display of violence banned next year?"

Later he accused Mr Blair of being "soft on crime and soft on the causes of crime".

Mr Blair said ministers would do what they could to prevent such "appalling" scenes" recurring. "It is not, unfortunately, the first time that riots have occurred in London.

"Some people remember in the 1980s and 1990s a few of those happening. But of course we have to sit down sensibly with the police and other authorities to make sure these disgraceful scenes do not happen again."

He accused the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, of attacking the police's handling of the protest.

"It is the police we should be supporting in this situation and we will take no lessons on law and order from a Conservative party that doubled crime and, when you [Mr Hague] were in the cabinet, cut police numbers too."

At Horseferry magistrates court, central London, yesterday, a man accused of violent disorder during the May Day protest said he was called Keith Blakelock, the same name as that of the policeman murdered during the Tottenham riots in 1985.

The man betrayed his "contempt" for the police and authorities, said the prosecutor, Alun Milford, who said the man's real name was Kevin Charles Townsend, unemployed, of Stoke Newington, north London. He denies ripping up paving slabs and throwing missiles at police.

But his solicitor, Ms Hirani - who declined to give her first name - said her client's name really was Keith Charles Blakelock on his birth certificate. The man was remanded in custody for seven days.

Ashley Warder, 20, was remanded in custody for a week, accused of violent disorder. The court heard that Warder threw a bottle at police officers.

webTitle: UK freezes arms sales to Mugabe

fields.headline: UK freezes arms sales to Mugabe
fields.standfirst:
Zimbabwe leader vows defiance
Zimbabwe: special report
Labour's ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: Britain last night stepped up its campaign to curb government attacks on white farmers and opposition parties in Zimbabwe by announcing the suspension of all new export licences for arms and military equipment to Robert Mugabe's regime.
fields.byline: Michael White in London and Chris McGreal in Harare
fields.body:
Britain last night stepped up its campaign to curb government attacks on white farmers and opposition parties in Zimbabwe by announcing the suspension of all new export licences for arms and military equipment to Robert Mugabe's regime.

In a move that reflects growing despair in Whitehall that President Mugabe is not going to respond to Commonwealth pressure for "constructive engagement", the remaining supply of 450 Land Rovers to the Zimbabwean police has also been halted - "until there is a clear determination to restore the rule of law".

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, made the announcement in a Commons statement after hearing reports of what he called Mr Mugabe's inflammatory speech made earlier yesterday, in which he renewed his "anti-imperalist" rhetoric against Britain.

In a scathing attack, Mr Mugabe launched his election platform with a pledge that "hostile British neo-colonialism" would not force him to backtrack on plans to redistribute about half the white-owned farmland in Zimbabwe to poor black peasants.

"We won't allow them to determine our destiny. We determine it ourselves, the people of Zimbabwe. Not from Downing Street, not from the British parliament. And let those who are pretending that they can determine our future realise we fought for it. We can still fight for it," he said.

"The British government says it has no further colonial responsibility for Zimbabwe, but every day they are talking about Zimbabwe and want to direct our affairs. No sanction of whatever nature can make us desist from our quest for land."

Mr Mugabe's rhetoric prompted Whitehall to send a clear but limited signal to Harare. But the Zimbabwean opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, was quick to admit that it would have "minimal" effect", and would enable Mr Mugabe to claim that he was once more a victim of colonial manipulation.

Mr Cook told MPs: "In the present circumstances of spreading violence, we have resolved that from today Britain will refuse all new export licence applications for arms and military equipment to Zimbabwe. This will include all licences for spare parts in connection with previous contracts such as Hawk aircraft."

The Tories and Liberal Democrats backed the decision. Mr Cook is treading a tightrope between calls from some Conservative MPs for tougher action, including wider sanctions, and the more conciliatory approach of the Commonwealth ministerial action group (CMAG).

"All Britain's concerns have now been supported by a body representing all the Commonwealth," Mr Cook said. Their "united message" was to the majority in Zimbabwe who wanted to live in a free democracy under the rule of law - a claim that Mr Mugabe derided because no such conditions had existed under colonial rule, he said.

Yet there were signs last night that the Foreign Office's claims that this week's CMAG meeting endorsed the UK position went further than Don McKinnon, the secretary general - who is to carry the message to Mr Mugabe in person - would have wished.

The Commonwealth seeks constructive engagement and free credible elections to ease Zimbabwe through a difficult time, officials stressed. But sanctions are not on its agenda. Nor was Zimbabwe officially part of CMAG's remit this week, they added.

Both Mr Cook and Tony Blair want "fair elections without violence" too. Mr Mugabe has until August to call a parliamentary election under the constitutional timetable, and Whitehall wants to avoid giving him any excuse to cancel the ballot.

Yesterday ministers repeatedly stressed their willingness to support land reform in Zimbabwe, but only if it was linked to the restoration of the rule of law, a fair price paid for expropriated farms and a "genuine" programme that eases the plight of the landless rural poor - a coded phrase to distinguish real reform from handouts to Mugabe allies.

Amid cheers from MPs, Mr Cook said that Mr Mugabe's speech suggested that his government's interest in land reform was merely "to create a condition of crisis in which he can secure its re-election" after 20 years in power and deepening economic malaise.

"Opposition campaigners have been ambushed and beaten up. Commercial companies who display opposition posters have had their properties fire-bombed. Rural communities have been threatened that it will be known which ballot box came from their village.

By the end of the past month of election campaigning, 14 political activists had been murdered, all of them supporters of the opposition," Mr Cook said.

Mr Tsvangirai has urged Britain not to impose economic sanctions. Last night he questioned the value of yesterday's military restrictions, saying that it would have been better coming from international organisations. He also said that the effect would be minimal, mainly felt by the air force which would not be able to obtain spare parts for its Hawk trainers.

"We won't allow them to determine our destiny. We determine it ourselves, the people of Zimbabwe. Not from Downing Street, not from the British parliament. And let those who are pretending that they can determine our future realise we fought for it. We can still fight for it," he said. "The British government says it has no further colonial responsibility for Zimbabwe, but every day they are talking about Zimbabwe and want to direct our affairs. No sanction of whatever nature can make us desist from our quest for land." Mr Mugabe's rhetoric prompted Whitehall to send a clear but limited signal to Harare. But the Zimbabwean opposition leader, Morgan Tsvangirai, was quick to admit that it would have "minimal" effect", and would enable Mr Mugabe to claim that he was once more a victim of colonial manipulation. Mr Cook told MPs: "In the present circumstances of spreading violence, we have resolved that from today Britain will refuse all new export licence applications for arms and military equipment to Zimbabwe. This will include all licences for spare parts in connection with previous contracts such as Hawk aircraft." The Tories and Liberal Democrats backed the decision. Mr Cook is treading a tightrope between calls from some Conservative MPs for tougher action, including wider sanctions, and the more conciliatory approach of the Commonwealth ministerial action group (CMAG). "All Britain's concerns have now been supported by a body representing all the Commonwealth," Mr Cook said. Their "united message" was to the majority in Zimbabwe who wanted to live in a free democracy under the rule of law - a claim that Mr Mugabe derided because no such conditions had existed under colonial rule, he said. Yet there were signs last night that the Foreign Office's claims that this week's CMAG meeting endorsed the UK position went further than Don McKinnon, the secretary general - who is to carry the message to Mr Mugabe in person - would have wished. The Commonwealth seeks constructive engagement and free credible elections to ease Zimbabwe through a difficult time, officials stressed. But sanctions are not on its agenda. Nor was Zimbabwe officially part of CMAG's remit this week, they added. Both Mr Cook and Tony Blair want "fair elections without violence" too. Mr Mugabe has until August to call a parliamentary election under the constitutional timetable, and Whitehall wants to avoid giving him any excuse to cancel the ballot. Yesterday ministers repeatedly stressed their willingness to support land reform in Zimbabwe, but only if it was linked to the restoration of the rule of law, a fair price paid for expropriated farms and a "genuine" programme that eases the plight of the landless rural poor - a coded phrase to distinguish real reform from handouts to Mugabe allies. Amid cheers from MPs, Mr Cook said that Mr Mugabe's speech suggested that his government's interest in land reform was merely "to create a condition of crisis in which he can secure its re-election" after 20 years in power and deepening economic malaise. "Opposition campaigners have been ambushed and beaten up. Commercial companies who display opposition posters have had their properties fire-bombed. Rural communities have been threatened that it will be known which ballot box came from their village. By the end of the past month of election campaigning, 14 political activists had been murdered, all of them supporters of the opposition," Mr Cook said. Mr Tsvangirai has urged Britain not to impose economic sanctions. Last night he questioned the value of yesterday's military restrictions, saying that it would have been better coming from international organisations. He also said that the effect would be minimal, mainly felt by the air force which would not be able to obtain spare parts for its Hawk trainers.

webTitle: BT may float network building offshoot

fields.headline: BT may float network building offshoot
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: British Telecommunications is considering a flotation of its UK network construction business after announcing a review of the division yesterday.
fields.body:
British Telecommunications is considering a flotation of its UK network construction business after announcing a review of the division yesterday.

BT said it was considering separating Networkbuild from its network operations either by flotation, a joint venture or management buyout. If a public listing of the division was undertaken it would be in addition to the planned float of Yell, the online yellow pages, by BT before the end of the year.

The City has brought pressure on BT to hive off various divisions to crystallise the value of the company which has not been reflected in its flagging share price.

BT refused to rule out a float of shares to fund the growth of its Dutch mobile unit, Telfort.

Paul Reynolds, BT's managing director of networks and information services, said the move could "unleash the tremendous growth locked up within the network construction business," given the grown in mobile, internet and data services markets.

Networkbuild builds the infrastructure for voice, data, mobile and IP traffic for BT. It has won external contracts and has work in hand of £400m annually. Networkbuild employs about 10,000 people.

The areas where it is expected to capitalise on the booming growth are in the rollout of an asymmetric digital subscriber line, that delivers services such as high-speed internet and video on demand, and third generation telecom networks.

Dave Mowbray, general manager of Networkbuild, said: "This is a huge opportunity for us to grow in a thriving sector. We have the resources, skills and track record to compete successfully in a vigorous and demanding market.

"Network construction is growing fast. Some exciting and very tangible business opportunities exist."

fields.headline: Let's pay our local councillors
fields.standfirst:
Then we would be sure they regarded it as a job, not a hobby

Special report: Elections 2000
fields.trailText: The thousands of councillors we will elect today might look like a pretty fair cross section of society. But one thing will distinguish them from most of the rest of us: they will all be people with time on their hands. Because most councillors are unpaid, the "property qualification" which once excluded all but a handful of British people from standing for parliament is mirrored in local government by a leisure qualification. It is unfair, divisive and disastrous for democracy.
fields.body:
The thousands of councillors we will elect today might look like a pretty fair cross section of society. But one thing will distinguish them from most of the rest of us: they will all be people with time on their hands. Because most councillors are unpaid, the "property qualification" which once excluded all but a handful of British people from standing for parliament is mirrored in local government by a leisure qualification. It is unfair, divisive and disastrous for democracy.

The government acknowledges that the current system is flawed. Executive mayors and their cabinets will be working full-time and can't be expected to do it for nothing. The practice of giving councillors "allowances" for attending meetings simply encourages more meetings. So the white paper on local government proposes that mayors and some senior councillors should receive "pensionable salaries", while the local government bill will set up independent panels to review council allowances.

These proposals, unfortunately, do little to expand the range of people who will be able to stand. Apart from their tiny "basic allowance", backbench councillors will still receive no regular income. One of the most important jobs in Britain is treated as if it were a hobby.

Defenders of the system argue that it reflects the great British tradition of voluntarism. It ensures that we elect self-sacrificing people, who put the welfare of the community ahead of personal advancement. At first sight, these are laudable aims, but they soon run into trouble.

The most obvious problem is that millions of British people are shut out, as self-sacrifice of this kind is a luxury beyond their means. It is almost impossible for members to take their responsibilities seriously unless they are wealthy, retired, working part-time or living on benefits. As councillors acquire more responsibilities, fewer people will be able to stand. The commitment to voluntarism is a commitment to exclusivity.

Moreover, the allowance system, built around a largely fictitious recompense for "out-of-pocket expenses", rewards corruption. As many voters know to their cost, bogus mileage claims and illegible lunch receipts can lead swiftly to more serious graft.

But perhaps the most important problem is what biologists call the "life-dinner principle". When a fox chases a rabbit, the rabbit runs harder than the fox, because if the fox loses it forfeits its dinner, while if the rabbit loses it forfeits its life.

This principle governs the relationship between councillors and the businesses they are supposed to regulate. Professional property developers and waste companies, for example, survive only if they can obtain planning consents or disposal contracts, and will spare no effort to secure them. Councillors, by contrast, want to minimise the work they do, in order to return to their real lives as quickly as possible. As a result, the rabbits win, even when the holes they will dig will undermine the neighbourhood.

The same problem applies to the relationship between members and officers, who often end up controlling our elected representatives even more effectively than civil servants control ministers. Far from being too expensive to pay councillors, years of disastrous decision-making suggest that it is too expensive not to.

In January, following an allowances scandal at Cardiff County Council, the Welsh assembly suggested a fixed rate for councillors, based on the average Welsh wage. It is an excellent idea, but the assembly's report fudged the issue of salaries. It insisted that any money councillors are paid should still be classed as "allowances". While senior councillors could receive much more, the hourly rate for backbenchers should be a third less than the average wage, "to reflect the voluntary nature of their work".

Not only has it ensured, in other words, that councillors are still regarded as amateurs; it has also sustained the fiction that sitting on committees entails more valuable work than helping constituents. It would surely be fairer simply to divide the average district wage by 40, then multiply it by the number of hours each member is expected to work. Councillors would not be lavishly paid, but they would be engaged in a job rather than a hobby.

The great British tradition of voluntarism is as flawed as the great British tradition of philanthropy. It is a tea-and-sympathy approach to government, incapable of defending us from professional profiteers.

I don't want to entrust the key decisions about my neighbourhood to amateurs. I want to be represented by professionals. comment@theguardian.com

fields.headline: RUC informer on murder charge
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A man accused of murdering Belfast defence lawyer Pat Finucane more than a decade ago was yesterday charged with a second killing dating back 13 years.
fields.body:
A man accused of murdering Belfast defence lawyer Pat Finucane more than a decade ago was yesterday charged with a second killing dating back 13 years.

William Stobie, 49, an RUC informer, who had won bail on the Finucane shooting, was held in custody after he was charged with the murder of Adam Lambert, 19, in November 1987. But he won an emergency application at the high court in Belfast, and, despite crown objections, was freed.

Campaigners seeking a public inquiry into claims of security force involvement in the Ulster Defence Association's execution of Finucane in February 1989 said the new charge was designed to delay an independent investigation.

They said evidence against Stobie was available last June, when he was charged with the Finucane killing.

Scotland Yard, heading the investigations, said it was determined to get to the bottom of allegations of state collusion.

The surprise move came as Norfolk police, leading the investigation into last year's loyalist killing of Rosemary Nelson, also a Catholic lawyer, in a car bomb at her home in Lurgan, Co Armagh, arrested a 31-year-old woman and her 28-year-old partner.

Adam Lambert was shot the day after the IRA blew up 11 people at Enniskillen in November 1987.

webTitle: MoD too slow and costly over flood aid, say MPs

fields.headline: MoD too slow and costly over flood aid, say MPs
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday rebuked the Ministry of Defence over its response to the Mozambique flood disaster, accusing it of being too slow in providing help and charging too much for aircraft for rescue missions.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday rebuked the Ministry of Defence over its response to the Mozambique flood disaster, accusing it of being too slow in providing help and charging too much for aircraft for rescue missions.

The criticism by the international development committee came amid a furious attack on the government by backbench MPs for holding an important defence debate today when most of them will be away from Westminster.

Ten of the 11 members of the Commons defence committee signed a motion deploring the decision to hold the debate on the day of the English local elections.

Iain Duncan-Smith, shadow defence secretary, accused the government of "shamefully running away" from a debate at a time when grave concerns were being expressed about the state of Britain's armed forces".

Responding to the public row between Clare Short, international development secretary, and the MoD over the cost of supplying helicopters, the international development committee accused the MoD of tending to offer a "Rolls - Royce" service with too many support staff "at the expense of flexibility and speedy deployment".

The MoD initially charged £2.3m for the hire of four Puma helicopters, two Hovercraft, air transporters and 170 support staff.

Ms Short decided instead to charter five helicopters locally for £870,000. She subsequently agreed to send four Pumas to Mozambique after the MoD cut the bill to £1m. She told the committee that while there were 100 staff servicing the MoD's Pumas, there were only 10 looking after the locally chartered helicopters.

Geoff Hoon, defence secretary, said: "The MoD is looking at the lessons arising from our assistance to Mozambique to make sure we can do even better in the future."

webTitle: Prescott fights to convince air traffic sell-off rebels

fields.headline: Prescott fights to convince air traffic sell-off rebels
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Labour rebel MPs claimed last night that John Prescott had failed to dissaude as many as 70 backbenchers from rebelling over his plans to part privatise the national air traffic service next week.
fields.body:
Labour rebel MPs claimed last night that John Prescott had failed to dissaude as many as 70 backbenchers from rebelling over his plans to part privatise the national air traffic service next week.

At a lengthy meeting of the Parliamentary Labour Party, the deputy prime minister sought to stave off a rebellion next Tuesday by pointing out that his own political career had been dedicated to increasing transport safety.

Tony Blair at prime minister's questions also sought to reassure Scottish MPs that he would retain the second air traffic control centre at Prestwick. At least six of the 12 rebel speakers yesterday were from Scotland where the Scottish Nationalists have run Labour ragged on the issue.

However, the former transport minister, Gavin Strang, and MP for Reading West, Martin Salter, are expected to publish an amendment tomorrow insisting that NATS should be run by a government controlled trust, a policy already adopted by the Canadian government and now supported by the IPMS trade union.

Mr Prescott told Labour MPs: "I will not compromise on a lifetime's commitment to improving safety. This is a chance for Britain to get ahead." Mr Prescott is planning to hold further one to one meetings.

Mr Prescott claimed yesterday the sell-off of a 51% stake would raise £500m, and ensure a private sector company would invest a further £1bn.

Mr Strang said: "Many MPs are still deeply unhappy and are desperately hoping that the government will change its plans. If the proposals comes to the floor of the House in their current form, then many MPs will be unable to support the government."

Mr Salter, a former Heathrow shop steward, added: "When the airline pilots themselves and the air traffic controllers express reservations, politicians have a duty to listen." The government's plans for NATS was "a privatisation too far". He added: "I hope, even at this eleventh hour, that common sense will prevail and enough people will support a compromise." Mr Salter pointed out the Canadian model had been supported by the Labour-controlled transport select committee in a report in February.

Mr Salter's aides continued to insist that as many as 70 to 80 Labour MPs were in the mood to rebel in one form or another. Labour whips said the task now was to peel off the soft rebels, so reducing the political impact. Some MPs claim Mr Prescott offered only bluster yesterday and did little to convince any sceptic.

However, at one point Tam Dayell, the Labour MP for Llinthgow, appealed to Mr Prescott to listen to the Parliamentary Labour at which point Mr Prescott replied he would listen to the majority of Labour MPs, if rebels like Mr Dayell did the same.

Mr Prescott claims the 51% sell-off of the service would allow managers to raise more money to modernise the system, handle growth of air traffic and help the government controlled Nats to win stakes in the rapidly rationalising foreign air traffic services.

However, the independent accountants Chantrey Vellacott claimed the government was being disingenuous in claiming part privatisation was the only way in which the extra £1bn investment could be levered into NATS.

The public finances set out in the March 2000 budget red book indicated that over the next five years the Treasury could easily borrow an extra £60bn over current plans to invest in additional public sector assets.

fields.headline: Lockerbie blame shifted
fields.standfirst:
Lockerbie blame shifted as trial starts

Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: Two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing yesterday blamed Palestinian terrorists for murdering 270 people in the December 1988 disaster.
fields.body:
Two Libyans accused of the Lockerbie bombing yesterday blamed Palestinian terrorists for murdering 270 people in the December 1988 disaster.

As the long-awaited trial got under way at a specially constituted Scottish court in the Netherlands, the alleged intelligence agents repeated that they were not guilty of bombing Pan Am flight 103.

In a statement read out by the clerk of the court at Camp Zeist, the defence claimed that members of two Syrian-backed Palestinian groups -one a prosecution witness - planted the device.

A second crown witness, Parviz Taheri, was also named as being involved in the alleged crimes of murder, conspiracy to murder and breaches of the Aviation Security Act.

The submission of a special defence of incrimination, a Scottish legal peculiarity, came moments after Lord Sutherland, the presiding judge, opened proceedings against Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifah Fhimah, who surrendered for trial last year.

The defence named Mohammed Abu Talb, a Palestinian serving a life sentence in Sweden for earlier bombings in Denmark and the Netherlands, as one of 10 other alleged conspirators.

Abu Talb was an early suspect in the case, but investigators abandoned that line of inquiry before the two Libyans were indicted in 1991. He is listed as one of more than 1,000 witnesses due to give evidence for the prosecution.

Seven other named Arab men were described as members of the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front, a small and now, in effect, defunct organisation founded with Syrian support in 1969, which has never before been mentioned in connection with Lockerbie.

The seven, whose whereabouts are unknown, were also described as formerly directors of the Miska Bakery in Malta, where the suitcase containing the bomb that destroyed Pan Am 103 was allegedly loaded onto a feeder flight to Frankfurt, and thence to London.

The defence statement referred also to unnamed members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command, a larger group based in Damascus.

No details were available about Mr Taheri, though his name is evidently Iranian.

In an interview broadcast shortly before the trial began, the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, dismissed a suggestion that the two accused acted under his direct orders. "It is an absurd question that should not have been asked," he told Sky Television. "Ever since 1977, I have no political or administrative responsibility, because I have handed over the authority to the people. And it is unreasonable that a person would give orders like that for such an act. This would be not reasonable."

Col Gadafy said the court would try the two Libyans only, and they alone would bear responsibility for the bombing if they were found guilty.

The Libyan leader, now enjoying international rehabilitation after last year's handover of the accused triggered the lifting of UN sanctions, said he was "sympathetic" to all the relatives of the Lockerbie dead, along with the relatives of victims of the 1986 US-British attack on Libya, as well as victims from Iran, Palestine and Lebanon. "I have confidence that the problems of Lockerbie will come to an end and will be finished so that we will be turning over a chapter which has been with us ever since the cold war."

The first witnesses to appear for the prosecution, in a trial expected to last for well over a year, were air traffic controllers who described how they tracked the doomed aircraft - call sign Clipper 103 - from Heathrow until it disappeared from radar screens at 19.03 on the evening of December 21 1988.

Alan Topp, who was in contact with the plane from Prestwick air traffic control, told the court how the fateful explosion looked on his radar screen. "I had never seen anything like this happen before. Nobody had," he said.

The indictment, which took 20 minutes to read, states: "You did conspire together and with others to further the purposes of the Libyan intelligence services by criminal means, mainly the use of explosive devices in the commission of acts of terrorism directed against nationals and the interests of other countries and in particular the destruction of a civil passenger aircraft and murder of its occupants."

If convicted of murder or endangering the safety of a commercial aircraft, Megrahi and Fhimah face a mandatory life sentence in a Scottish prison.

The defence named Mohammed Abu Talb, a Palestinian serving a life sentence in Sweden for earlier bombings in Denmark and the Netherlands, as one of 10 other alleged conspirators. Abu Talb was an early suspect in the case, but investigators abandoned that line of inquiry before the two Libyans were indicted in 1991. He is listed as one of more than 1,000 witnesses due to give evidence for the prosecution. Seven other named Arab men were described as members of the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front, a small and now, in effect, defunct organisation founded with Syrian support in 1969, which has never before been mentioned in connection with Lockerbie. The seven, whose whereabouts are unknown, were also described as formerly directors of the Miska Bakery in Malta, where the suitcase containing the bomb that destroyed Pan Am 103 was allegedly loaded onto a feeder flight to Frankfurt, and thence to London. The defence statement referred also to unnamed members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command, a larger group based in Damascus. No details were available about Mr Taheri, though his name is evidently Iranian. In an interview broadcast shortly before the trial began, the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, dismissed a suggestion that the two accused acted under his direct orders. "It is an absurd question that should not have been asked," he told Sky Television. "Ever since 1977, I have no political or administrative responsibility, because I have handed over the authority to the people. And it is unreasonable that a person would give orders like that for such an act. This would be not reasonable." Col Gadafy said the court would try the two Libyans only, and they alone would bear responsibility for the bombing if they were found guilty. The Libyan leader, now enjoying international rehabilitation after last year's handover of the accused triggered the lifting of UN sanctions, said he was "sympathetic" to all the relatives of the Lockerbie dead, along with the relatives of victims of the 1986 US-British attack on Libya, as well as victims from Iran, Palestine and Lebanon. "I have confidence that the problems of Lockerbie will come to an end and will be finished so that we will be turning over a chapter which has been with us ever since the cold war." The first witnesses to appear for the prosecution, in a trial expected to last for well over a year, were air traffic controllers who described how they tracked the doomed aircraft - call sign Clipper 103 - from Heathrow until it disappeared from radar screens at 19.03 on the evening of December 21 1988. Alan Topp, who was in contact with the plane from Prestwick air traffic control, told the court how the fateful explosion looked on his radar screen. "I had never seen anything like this happen before. Nobody had," he said. The indictment, which took 20 minutes to read, states: "You did conspire together and with others to further the purposes of the Libyan intelligence services by criminal means, mainly the use of explosive devices in the commission of acts of terrorism directed against nationals and the interests of other countries and in particular the destruction of a civil passenger aircraft and murder of its occupants." If convicted of murder or endangering the safety of a commercial aircraft, Megrahi and Fhimah face a mandatory life sentence in a Scottish prison. webTitle: Church quits new deal job scheme

fields.headline: Church quits new deal job scheme
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A Church of England diocese has dropped out of the government's new deal programme because it was "too bureaucratic", it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
A Church of England diocese has dropped out of the government's new deal programme because it was "too bureaucratic", it emerged yesterday.

Church leaders in Liverpool decided to sever links with the scheme aimed at helping young jobless people secure work.

They blamed their decision on "the many obstacles and difficulties" encountered during their involvement with the programme.

The move was made after the church carried out a review of its dealings with the scheme, the findings of which were sent to the Department for Education and Employment.

Since joining, 14 people have passed through the scheme and were employed in a variety of posts, including administrative and nursery work.

A Liverpool diocesan spokesman, Ultan Russell, said: "The decision was really taken on the grounds that the bureaucracy of it meant that at a practical level, it cost us more to run the scheme than we got back from central government.

"We were dealing with something centrally which may be dealt with better locally. The bureaucracy was like something out of a Kafka novel."

Other problems encountered by the church included the lack of specialist support and advisers overburdened with casework while some trainees were referred to unsuitable placements.

"The poor souls hadn't got anything like the support we anticipated. We had a situation where one girl told us that she didn't want to work in a nursery and we were told that they would try to force her," added Mr Russell.

He said it was a pity as "something that has such potential in it could really develop if efforts were made".

A spokesman for the Department for Education and Employment said that it welcomed the Church of England's comments and would respond to them in detail.

"We are sorry that the diocese of Liverpool have now withdrawn from their subcontract," he said.

He added: "The new deal has proven to be a considerable success because of the contribution of a wide variety of organisations and more than 199,000 young people have already been placed into work.

"However, we are always looking to improve the new deal, and we welcome their comments which we will respond to in detail."
