fields.headline: Violent disagreements
fields.trailText: It will take far more than the mindless smashing of a few corporate shop windows in Seattle or Westminster to remedy the endemic ecological destruction and social injustices perpetuated by those wrong-headed political and business elites who currently rule the world (Blair vents outrage at rioters, May 4). Violent protest is the dictatorship of the individual. It begets the tyranny of the state.
fields.body:
It will take far more than the mindless smashing of a few corporate shop windows in Seattle or Westminster to remedy the endemic ecological destruction and social injustices perpetuated by those wrong-headed political and business elites who currently rule the world (Blair vents outrage at rioters, May 4). Violent protest is the dictatorship of the individual. It begets the tyranny of the state. Confronted by violent citizens, government introduces more restrictive law, and tougher military policing, which the media and silent majority approve. The underlying issues are ignored and public debate refocuses around points of law and order. Democracy narrows and the rights and opportunities of aware and active citizens shrink. This law of revolutionary consequence happens as easily in mature, as in fledgling, democracies.

Witness Britain's various public order and criminal justice acts, brought in in response to the poll tax riots and the violent (not the peaceful) anti-roads objectors. These illiberal laws block much significant democratic challenge to government and companies. I bet Jack Straw just loves those merry May Day mobsters - the perfect justification for his draconian Anti-Terrorist Bill, which threatens to make criminals of anyone who dares to publicly oppose official authority.

What the hot-heads have to understand is that you don't need violence to win, at least not in a democratic, regulated market economy. Companies do not make products that consumers ignore. No bad company practice can withstand the challenge of media expose, preventative laws or tax regimes, or shareholders dumping stock in protest. Witness Monsanto, or Shell, or many other examples.

The initial challenge for campaigners is to get the right information to the right people in the right way at the right time. Information is the first step to democratically exercising power. The second is to act upon it effectively. That means creating cam paign opportunities for citizens to use that knowledge - as voters, consumers, shareholders, investors, taxpayers - to shape what happens next. The third step is to peacefully organise and mobilise that activism toward government and company decision-makers so that transformation occurs.
Charles Secrett
Director, Friends of the Earth

 Violence is grotesque, but even the limited democracy we have is borne of it. Parliament itself is a result of the violent struggles of the English civil war. The forces of capitalism and the state employ violent methods to retain the status quo: we can't wish it away. There have been enough failed earth summits and abandoned parliamentary reforms.

The answer lies in a fresh and radical approach that learns the lessons of the past and that is what the pre-May Day conference was all about (Letters, May 3). It does not lie in policies presented to governments bought off by the Fossil Fuel Lobby (US) or corporations subsidising host state armies (South America). The inevitability of violence will be determined by the reaction of those in control of the current system to the demands for change.
Daniel Neville London

 In 1894, 200-300 young rowdies smashed a screen that was erected to separated the audience in the Empire Music Hall from the bar and its prostitutes. They paraded in triumph around Leicester Square and were addressed by their ringleader. Winston Churchill. A bit of paint? I'm sure he'd understand.
Trevor Hopper
Brighton

fields.headline: London fog
fields.trailText: London gets its first shot at an elected mayor and the Guardian stays silent rather than endorse the egomaniacal breakaway independent or the bearded, reluctant lapdog of New Labour. Your mealy-mouthed leader (April 29) never made clear a preference. Pathetic.
fields.body:
London gets its first shot at an elected mayor and the Guardian stays silent rather than endorse the egomaniacal breakaway independent or the bearded, reluctant lapdog of New Labour. Your mealy-mouthed leader (April 29) never made clear a preference. Pathetic. Although this is an American-style election, many voters won't abandon lockstep party affiliations and judge the candidate rather than the party. If ability was the case, we'd be waking up to a Norris or Kramer London tomorrow. Your refusal is another sad indication of how the left avoids tough choices.
David Ellis
London
David.Ellis@dowjones.com

 Polly Toynbee (Comment, May 3) chides all those naughty children voting for Ken Livingstone today for their "frivolity". Could it not be that, perhaps, some of them are genuinely, seriously, way to the left of New Labour - just like Toynbee admits she was, 25 years ago?
Francis King
Wymondham, Norfolk

 There is a sixth face of Ken Livingstone (Charlotte Raven: Brothers under the skin, G2, May 2) which should secure a chunk of votes in the mayoral elections. Ken represents - at least for me, and I suspect for many other as-yet-unreconstructed lefties - the opportunity for (a minor and insufficient) retributive justice against Thatcher's destruction of the GLC. Oh, how I would love to hear that woman's heart palpitations when Ken is declared the winner.
Adam Roberts
University of Sussex
a.j.j.roberts@sussex.ac.uk

 No, Charlotte Raven, the people still supporting Labour are not "the toadies" - just people who realise that political change involves more than skipping in the sunshine. We were there before the butterflies fluttered in and remain now they have flittered off in search of their next ephemeral enthusiasm.
Rosemary Chamberlin
Bristol

 So it's congratulations and condolences to the winners and losers in the race to be the first London Mayor. The winner is clear - the press and TV for stifling all the other excellent independent voices and candidates, by focussing solely upon whom you decided were the "main contenders". The losers are us Londoners who had no idea of the wide variety of choice being presented, because you decided we did not need to know.
Andrew Hough
London
email@wfyfc.free-online.co.uk

fields.headline: Fishy figures
fields.trailText: Stephen Pollock-Hill's remarks (Letters, May 1) were a ragbag of cod economics, factual errors, misunderstanding of the currency markets and misinterpretation of our most recent representative survey on the euro.
fields.body:
Stephen Pollock-Hill's remarks (Letters, May 1) were a ragbag of cod economics, factual errors, misunderstanding of the currency markets and misinterpretation of our most recent representative survey on the euro.

The NOP-conducted survey showed that 55% ruled out euro membership - "for the foreseeable future" (25%) or "never or probably never" (30%), while 43% wished the UK to join either "as soon as possible" or "in the foreseeable future". The balance supporting our official position of "not for the foreseeable future" or stronger was 12%.

Our members also opposed handing interest rates over to the ECB, restrictions on fiscal policy, the pooling of the gold and foreign exchange reserves, further tax and labour market harmonisation and EU political integration. Hardly a resounding endorsement of the euro.

Ruth Lea
Head of the policy unit, Institute of Directors

fields.headline: Shakespeare: reading between the lines
fields.trailText: There is a straightforward answer to John Sutherland's question "Why is Portia still a virgin?" at the end of The Merchant of Venice (From Bard to worse, G2, May 3). Portia herself makes quite clear what the marriage arrangements are to be.
fields.body:
There is a straightforward answer to John Sutherland's question "Why is Portia still a virgin?" at the end of The Merchant of Venice (From Bard to worse, G2, May 3). Portia herself makes quite clear what the marriage arrangements are to be.

Before the trial, Portia tells Bassanio to go to Venice and pay off his debt with her money, so saving Antonio's life. They will go through the outward form of marriage but not go to bed together until Bassanio's debt of honour is paid. As soon as they return from Venice - where Portia, not Bassanio has saved Antonio - they head for bed.

It's not to do with Queer Theory. There is nothing in the text to suggest that Bassanio is "really in love with Antonio", though there is plenty that suggests Antonio is gay and isn't happy about it. Bassanio is very happy to take his troubled admirer's money, and Portia is keen that he should repay it soon.

Feminist theory is on firmer ground. The very moment Portia is released from the restrictions of her father's will, she takes charge of her own - and Bassanio's life - in a most resourceful manner, part of the process of civilising him she undertakes. She can only clear up the mess the men have got themselves into by disguising herself as a man.
Ellen Dryden & Don Taylor,
Banham, Norfolk
firstwrites@cwcom.net

 Carol Vorderman may indeed be wrong when she labels Shakespeare's plays dull as ditchwater. But the teaching, as described by John Sutherland, certainly is dull. In years of reading The Merchant of Venice, he'd never noticed Bassanio's failure to consummate his marriage and linked it to his "regard" for Antonio. Hardly a revelation. But it does reveal a dismissive attitude to female characters and women students. No wonder Carol ditched Shakespeare.
Sarah Morgan,
London

 If Shakespeare is "boring" why wasn't I bored when I saw Much Ado about Nothing? I thought it was witty and exciting. It made me want to watch all the Shakespeare films. I bet I could put up letters on Countdown just as well as Carol Vorderman.
Amy Cullen (Aged 10),
London

fields.headline: Aircraft orders 'waste of cash'
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence has been castigated by the Treasury for planning to "waste" up to £1bn on aircraft and missile orders for the RAF in the run-up to the comprehensive spending review in July.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence has been castigated by the Treasury for planning to "waste" up to £1bn on aircraft and missile orders for the RAF in the run-up to the comprehensive spending review in July.

Andrew Smith, chief secretary to the Treasury, is at loggerheads with Geoff Hoon, defence secretary, over three orders that Treasury mandarins see as "dumb procurement". Yesterday they summoned Mr Hoon's close advisers to tell them to think again about the orders, or face an even tougher spending squeeze in July.

At the centre of the row is Mr Hoon's determination to order Boeing C17 heavy lift aircraft in preference to leasing more Ukrainian-built Antonovs. The Boeing carries half the payload and will cost an extra £400m over seven years. The Treasury and the No 10 policy unit see it as too advanced for the job.

The Treasury is also critical of Mr Hoon's inclination to order European Meteor missiles in preference to the tried and tested Raytheon missile, for an additional £400m. Officials fear fresh equipment problems for the armed forces.

The third Treasury concern is over Mr Hoon's decision not to back the military version of the European Airbus. This could mean Britain having to order US jets in years to come, at an extra minimum cost of £200m.

webTitle: New crime of sexual abuse within families likely in overhaul of act

fields.headline: New crime of sexual abuse within families likely in overhaul of act
fields.trailText: A new crime of sexual abuse within families is expected to be proposed by the home secretary, Jack Straw, next month as part of the first major overhaul of the law on sexual offences in England and Wales for nearly 50 years.
fields.body:
A new crime of sexual abuse within families is expected to be proposed by the home secretary, Jack Straw, next month as part of the first major overhaul of the law on sexual offences in England and Wales for nearly 50 years.

Ministers hope that the new offence will finally kill off any lingering "keep it in the family" belief among the public, the police and the courts and emphasise that the law protects the victims of sexual crimes that take place in the family home.

The new offence of "sexual abuse within families" would bring together existing crimes such as incest, rape and indecent assault but at the same time would make clear that the law no longer regarded such crimes as private matters.

Indeed, ministers are keen to stress that they regard crimes committed in the home or within a relationship as a breach of trust, which the criminal justice system should recognise as an aggravating and more serious factor.

The first major overhaul of the law since the 1956 Sexual Offences Act, to be published next month, is also expected to redefine the boundary between rape and indecent assault so that serious sex attacks that stop short of attempted rape attract much heavier penalties than the law currently allows.

At present, the maximum sentence for indecent assault stands at 10 years but a change in the law could mean that life imprisonment becomes an option to a judge sentencing in a case involving a very serious violation.

Home Office ministers are nervous about the public reaction to the proposed changes, fearing that they could prove as controversial as the current debate over the repeal of section 28 on the alleged promotion of homosexuality.

The Whitehall review was set up in 1998 after concerns that the criminal law was not delivering effective protection to victims, children and mentally incapacitated people and that abusers were not being appropriately punished.

Among its more startling findings is the conclusion that 75% of the sex workers in Soho brothels come from abroad - particularly the Balkans - and that they work in an industry that is worth £12m a year.

The review is also expected to recommend that a new offence is created to protect vulnerable people from abuse by their carers and to replace the current law which, in outdated language, bans "sexual intercourse with mental defectives".

The Home Office review team whose report has recently gone to ministers found that many mentally impaired people regarded sexual abuse as a normal part of their lives.

The wide-ranging review of sex offences is also expected to lead to a more consistent approach in the law to the different treatment of child victims of different ages. In some cases it is illegal to engage in certain sexual practices with a child under 18, although the age of consent has been equalised at 16, while the penalties facing abusers of children under 13 are much more punitive than for offences against those aged 13 to 16.

The review team, which has been studying the problem for two years, is also expected to recommend the creation of a new offence of necrophilia -having sex with the dead - which curiously has never been an offence under English law.

Changes that highlight the need to define and clarify the meaning of consent in rape cases have already been trailed, as have moves to extend the definition of rape to include forced oral sex. Ministers hope that the new offence will finally kill off any lingering "keep it in the family" belief among the public, the police and the courts and emphasise that the law protects the victims of sexual crimes that take place in the family home. The new offence of "sexual abuse within families" would bring together existing crimes such as incest, rape and indecent assault but at the same time would make clear that the law no longer regarded such crimes as private matters. Indeed, ministers are keen to stress that they regard crimes committed in the home or within a relationship as a breach of trust, which the criminal justice system should recognise as an aggravating and more serious factor. The first major overhaul of the law since the 1956 Sexual Offences Act, to be published next month, is also expected to redefine the boundary between rape and indecent assault so that serious sex attacks that stop short of attempted rape attract much heavier penalties than the law currently allows. At present, the maximum sentence for indecent assault stands at 10 years but a change in the law could mean that life imprisonment becomes an option to a judge sentencing in a case involving a very serious violation. Home Office ministers are nervous about the public reaction to the proposed changes, fearing that they could prove as controversial as the current debate over the repeal of section 28 on the alleged promotion of homosexuality. The Whitehall review was set up in 1998 after concerns that the criminal law was not delivering effective protection to victims, children and mentally incapacitated people and that abusers were not being appropriately punished. Among its more startling findings is the conclusion that 75% of the sex workers in Soho brothels come from abroad - particularly the Balkans - and that they work in an industry that is worth £12m a year. The review is also expected to recommend that a new offence is created to protect vulnerable people from abuse by their carers and to replace the current law which, in outdated language, bans "sexual intercourse with mental defectives". The wide-ranging review of sex offences is also expected to lead to a more consistent approach in the law to the different treatment of child victims of different ages. In some cases it is illegal to engage in certain sexual practices with a child under 18, although the age of consent has been equalised at 16, while the penalties facing abusers of children under 13 are much more punitive than for offences against those aged 13 to 16. fields.headline: MacKenzie talks up radio station
fields.trailText: Kelvin MacKenzie, the former editor of the Sun, yesterday said he expected the recently relaunched TalkSport radio station to break even within three years after detailing plans for the £200m stock market flotation of the parent Wireless Group.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie, the former editor of the Sun, yesterday said he expected the recently relaunched TalkSport radio station to break even within three years after detailing plans for the £200m stock market flotation of the parent Wireless Group.

Mr MacKenzie said the relaunch of the station, one of only three national commercial licences, as a pure sports station from Talk Radio 12 weeks ago had caused a shift in audience but added that overall numbers were flat at 2.2m. "To me that is pretty incredible given the change in format and the fact that radio is pretty much a heritage business," he said.

Last year the station made an operating loss of £12.1m.

Wireless Group is the fourth largest commercial radio group in Britain after acquiring two regional radio companies in little over a year. It also holds the second London digital multiplex which will carry eight stations.

The company is raising up to £40m from the issuance of new shares accounting for 25% of the business. The cash is being raised to fund future acquisitions in radio although the company is also likely to use its shares as currency to pay for further deals.

"We still felt that there were a lot of acquisitions for us to do and we clearly can't keep going back to our investors and asking for a handout," Mr Mackenzie said.

He cited the acquisition of Border Television which was recently bought by Capital for around 10 times revenues. "It was still a bloody bargain and had we been a public company we might have looked very closely at it." He also detailed plans to build a series of local internet portals.

Group managing director Jonathan Goodwin said: "We want to be predator rather than prey. There are six major radio groups and I expect there to be three before long. We would like to be one of those three. We will have to move very quickly."

Mr MacKenzie, who avowedly put £1.5m into the business, has a 7% stake which will be worth up to £14m. Other sizeable shareholders in the group include News Corporation which has 20% and Liberty Media with 29.9%.

fields.standfirst: BSkyB's Windies catch
fields.trailText: Yesterday BSkyB signed an agreement to manage the international broadcasting and internet rights for the West Indies Cricket Board in a further tightening of the company's grip over sporting rights. The deal makes BSkyB the West Indies' media partner on the internet with immediate effect, and from 2004 it will become the official host broadcaster of the cricket board and manage all broadcast rights.
fields.body:
Yesterday BSkyB signed an agreement to manage the international broadcasting and internet rights for the West Indies Cricket Board in a further tightening of the company's grip over sporting rights. The deal makes BSkyB the West Indies' media partner on the internet with immediate effect, and from 2004 it will become the official host broadcaster of the cricket board and manage all broadcast rights.

Sky will produce all the coverage of international cricket in the West Indies for five seasons. It will also manage the sale of sponsorship and advertising rights. Matches, including a test series with England in 2004, will be screened on Sky Sports. Sky holds rights to England's domestic one-day internationals and live Test matches in Pakistan, South Africa and Australia.

The bigger prize for BSkyB will be on offer on Wednesday, when the deadline falls for bids to broadcast the Premiership. The company has been taking stakes in clubs, adopting the role of media agent.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Treasury in tax back-down
fields.body:
Treasury in tax back-down

The government yesterday bowed to pressure from multinationals by announcing a year-long delay to plans for tighter tax rules on overseas profits. While sticking to the principle of stamping out abuse of double taxation relief, the inland revenue said companies would have until March 31, 2001 before arrangements outlined in the Budget took effect. The measures are designed to counter attempts by multinationals to minimise the amount of tax paid on profits from overseas operations. The move, announced in the Commons by Treasury minister Dawn Primarolo, received a qualified welcome from the Confederation of British Industry, which has been lobbying on behalf of its members against the changes.

Davies warns on hedge funds

Hedge funds could face direct regulation if progress is not made on recently recommended guidelines for their risk management, transparency and investment conduct, Financial Services Authority chairman Howard Davies warned yesterday. "I hope there is progress on the recommendations. If there is not and there is another market destabilising collapse, then we might find ourselves developing a closer and more formal relationship with the hedge fund industry," he said.

He said the near collapse in 1998 of the US hedge fund Long Term Capital Management, "a wholly unregulated institution", had threatened to create systemic risk on a destablising scale in markets worldwide.

CWS big stores are hit

The Co-operative Wholesale Society blamed the "Wal-Mart effect" for falling sales in its superstores which reined in a buoyant performance of its other retail outlets. The Co-op, which is slowly closing its superstores and concentrating on town supermarkets and convenience stores, said that overall profits of its food operations in the year to January 8, rose 16% to £43m. Sales rose 2% to £1.12bn while like-for-like sales grew 1.2%. The CWS completed its merger with the Co-operative Retail Society last month; it is expected to deliver cost savings in the food division with the convergence to one head office, the integration of technology systems and 329 job losses. The 470 CRS stores will be brought under the CWS banner, including the convenience stores which now bear the Welcome brand.

Generators act against Ofgem

Two electricity generators were referred to the competition commission yesterday after refusing to agree to a new condition in their licences. The condition, which bans market abuse by the generators, has been agreed by six electricity companies. But AES and British Energy have refused to accept the clause, arguing that it is too broad and gives the regulator unnecessary catch-all powers.

webTitle: Healthy market for the safer jab

fields.headline: Healthy market for the safer jab
fields.trailText: Accidental jabs with syringes cause 600,000 injuries among US health care workers each year and with concerns growing about the risk of contracting viruses such as HIV, the race is on to find safer ways of injecting drugs.
fields.body:
Accidental jabs with syringes cause 600,000 injuries among US health care workers each year and with concerns growing about the risk of contracting viruses such as HIV, the race is on to find safer ways of injecting drugs.

The latest company to come up with an idea is Weston Medical, a Peterborough firm which yesterday announced that it will be valued at £210m in an imminent flotation.

The company's founder, Terry Weston, has invented a kind of high-speed water pistol called Intraject, which fires liquid medicines through the skin. Mr Weston styles himself as a freelance inventor - among his other creations are certain snap closures for food packaging.

He has an 10.7% stake in Weston Medical, worth a tidy £22m, but it may not all be plain sailing - there is plenty of competition out there.

Weston's best known British rival is Powderject Pharmaceuticals, which has a similar technology but reformulates medicines into powder before delivering them.

Weston believes its advantage is on the regulatory side. Because Powderject turns drugs into powder it needs to go through arduous clinical trials for each one. Weston can take existing liquid drugs and put them into its devices, as long as it can prove "bioequivalence" - that the process is comparable to using a traditional syringe.

Both technologies cost about £1 a time, so they are only suitable for more expensive drugs. Weston has tie-ups with Glaxo Wellcome, which wants to use Intraject for its migraine drugs, and with Roche, which wants it for a hepatitis C therapy.

Powderject's lead products target erectile disfunction and osteoporosis. It claims more "added value", arguing that its powder gun delivers particles more accurately to specific cells within the skin, and therefore actually makes medicines work better. Powderject also claims its method is more painless, though Weston disputes this.

There is an enormous market out there for injection devices - it is estimated that between 8bn and 12bn injections are given worldwide each year.

Five states in America have passed laws requiring syringes to be avoided where possible, and legislation is pending in another 26 states.

Two UK-quoted companies, NMT and Medisys are developing retractable syringes with needles that snap back into plastic cases to avoid accidental jabs. These will target "mass market" drugs.

With the shares priced by broker Goldman Sachs at 170p, Weston is raising £52.4m of new cash. That is slightly below initial expectations, but not bad in current market conditions for a company unlikely to make profits for at least three years.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Economists remain divided over the fate of short term interest rates, but the 16 who earlier this week argued a rise was inevitable when the monetary policy committee meets today appeared to be in sympathy with the markets.
fields.body:
Economists remain divided over the fate of short term interest rates, but the 16 who earlier this week argued a rise was inevitable when the monetary policy committee meets today appeared to be in sympathy with the markets.

The FTSE 100 suffered its biggest one-day points loss in more than 12 months yesterday, as interest rate worries sapped sentiment across the board. Telecom stocks took a special drubbing on both sides of the Atlantic following a miserable set of first quarter results from AT&T and a disappointing outlook for the coming year for the US long distance carrier.

The news hit UK heavyweights Vodafone and British Telecom, helping to send the blue chip index down 188.6 points or 3% lower at 6,184.8.

Only a handful of stocks bucked the trend. Diageo said a cost cutting program had turned it into the most efficient drinks group in the world. True or not, the market bought the tale and sent the shares up 7.5p to 522.5p. Rio Tinto edged higher 10.5p to £10.72 despite reports that environmental activists had garnered a sizable chunk of votes ahead of the firm's annual shareholders' meeting with a view to causing maximum embarrassment.

Cadbury joined the risers early in the day when it reported strong soft drinks sales in the US, but the shares eventually closed unchanged at 439p.

Most retailers and industrial concerns, however, saw their values slip. "What people have detected is that we might be on the edge of a bear market," said one senior equity salesman.

"Confidence has gone and people are nervous," he added, "some clients are sitting on loss positions and looking for opportunities to get out ... it's looking like a long, hard summer."

Losses in Vodafone (down from 288p to 270p) and BT (slipping 50p to £11.22) between them contributed some 70 points of downside to the FTSE, or almost half its total decline.

Other telecom stocks also declined, with Colt Telecom off 269p at £26.69. In the same sector, Thus slumped 43p to 340p, after in-line results showing a pre-tax loss of £63.1m - after a £43.5m exceptional charge.

Tech stocks such as handheld computer maker Psion , down from £44.61 to £40.04, also bore the brunt of the downturn.

Elsewhere, the day's biggest casualties included household products company Unilever , down from 385p to 349p, as investors reacted cautiously to the company's $18.4bn cash bid for US firm Bestfoods.

fields.headline: Arcadia
fields.trailText: There seems to be little let-up in the woes of Arcadia, the struggling retailer which sells 10% of Britain's womenswear.
fields.body:
There seems to be little let-up in the woes of Arcadia, the struggling retailer which sells 10% of Britain's womenswear.

It owns a string of retail brands including Top Shop, Principles, Miss Selfridge and Dorothy Perkins but nothing has gone right over the last year. Generally sluggish trading, unimaginative merchandising and the advent of "dress-down" policies have combined to turn it into a shadow of its former self. John Hoerner, the group's beleaguered chief executive, revealed an action plan last month with the trendy name BrandMAX which was actually a slash and burn programme involving the closure of 400 shops, at a cost of £90m and with the loss of 3,500 jobs. Principles for Men and Richards were the big casualties, both facing closure.

Including costs related to the integration of Sears' womenswear businesses (for which Arcadia overpaid last summer), analysts reckon the company will take more than £120m of exceptional charges this year. Interim losses were £7.3m and the underlying full-year deficit is likely to top £11m.

There are signs of hope in recent trading. Between January and March like-for-like figures were up, but this was achieved through price cuts, hitting profit margins. Arcadia is approaching its riskiest period, when closure and disruptions will peak. The shares, down 1.5p to 40p yesterday, are close to their all-time low.

It would be easy to argue that the market capitalisation of £76m is laughably low for a business sitting on prime sites such as Top Shop's Oxford Circus store - worth perhaps £150m on its own.

However, the prospects are mixed for the short and long term. Retailers have yet to experience the full impact of the internet, and high street trading remains unremittingly bleak.

In a research note this week, stockbroker Teather & Greenwood concludes that "shareholder value destruction continues apace". Life for Mr Hoerner is likely to remain very difficult.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: £3m for ousted NatWest chief
fields.body:
£3m for ousted NatWest chief

Derek Wanless, ousted as chief executive of NatWest after a hostile takeover last year, received a £3m payoff, including £601,000 in "liquidated damages" and pension benefits.

NatWest's annual report and accounts, issued yesterday, also showed that Martin Gray, the former head of retail banking, received "liquidated damages" of £339,000, taking his final pay cheque, including pension benefits, to £1.9m.

Ron Sandler, who was paracuted in as chief operating officer after the Bank of Scotland bid, received £226,000 for his first three months' work. He later left the bank after Royal Bank of Scotland's counter-bid was successful, with an estimated £1m payoff.

CBI warns on interest rates

High Street sales rose strongly last month but the increase should not be used as an excuse by the Bank of England to raise interest rates, the CBI said yesterday. Retailers enjoying a pick-up in business compared to a year ago outnumbered those suffering a decline by 33%, up from 23% in April, according to the CBI's monthly distributive trades survey.

Alastair Eperon, chairman of the CBI's distributive trades panel, said: "With little sign of inflation in most parts of the economy, an interest rate rise would tip the economic scales further in the wrong direction."

AstraZeneca profits rise

Strong sales of agrochemicals, including products for genetically modified crops, helped AstraZeneca increase its first-quarter pre-tax profits by 17% to $1.12bn (£720m).

Agrochemicals profits leapt 30%, which the company attributed to good weather, particularly in the United States. However, the shares fell 69p to £26.03 because growth was slower on the healthcare side, where profits rose 14%. Ulcer drug Losec fared well but overall sales fell in Britain, which AstraZeneca blamed on price cuts and a surge in cheap imports.

New voice for M&S

Marks & Spencer has appointed a director of communications in an attempt to improve its battered public image.

Cheri Lofland, 42, an American who is a former public relations executive at Reckitt & Colman and Nutrasweet, pledged to make M&S's communications more open, admitting: "It will be a challenge. I've never been interested in easy jobs." The company has created the position after a year in which profits and shares have fallen

Deadline set

Anglo-Dutch food and consumer goods group Unilever gave US target Bestfoods until tonight to reconsider its $18.4bn (£11.8bn) bid.

fields.headline: Blue Circle beats off bid
fields.standfirst: Investors reject £3.65bn Lafarge offer
fields.trailText: Cement maker Blue Circle last night beat off the hostile £3.65bn bid from Lafarge, the French-owned construction materials group.
fields.body:
Cement maker Blue Circle last night beat off the hostile £3.65bn bid from Lafarge, the French-owned construction materials group.

Lafarge admitted defeat, announcing that its cash offer, at 450p a share, had attracted support from the holders of 44.52% of Blue Circle shares - including 20% held by the French group.

Bertrand Collomb, the chairman and chief executive of Lafarge, acknowledged his disappointment with the outcome of the bid battle but said the group would press on with its expansion programme.

Blue Circle executives were understandably gratified by the outcome.

Chief executive Rick Haythornthwaite, who led the fight to fend off Lafarge, said: "Blue Circle is delighted to have retained its independence. We have argued all along that Lafarge's offer undervalued our company and our shareholders have shown they agree."

Blue Circle was Lafarge's second foray into the UK takeover market in recent times.

Two years ago it snapped up Redland for £1.8bn, and when it launched its Blue Circle bid at the beginning of February the French group was seen as having a good chance of winning though its its initial 420p a share bid was always regarded as too low by the City.

However, Blue Circle put up a strong defence, and when Lafarge came back with an offer of 450p - launching a dawn raid on the stock market alongside the higher offer - the City had reassessed its view of the UK cement maker.

"It was a combination of a stronger defence and people did think the Lafarge bid was a bit short of the mark," said Matt Unsworth, a construction and building materials sector analyst at Commerzbank in London. "I think Blue Circle's management won a great deal of credibility during the course of the defence."

Lafarge criticised Blue Circle for its policy of concentrating on heating and bathroom products in the 1980s which had had to be reversed and claimed the cement maker was having to pursue an aggressive acquisition strategy to try to make up lost ground.

It said the firms were a natural fit, forming the world's largest producer, and that it had the management strength and global presence to get the best out of the merged group.

Key points in the Blue Circle defence were the focus on cost savings, a strong recovery in Asian markets and proposals to return £800m to shareholders. Blue Circle chairman Lord Tugendhat said: "This sends an important message to those who try to buy good businesses in this market on the cheap. They cannot and should not take the value embedded in companies like Blue Circle for granted."

But Mr Collomb said: "Lafarge remains committed to expanding by acquisition as and when suitable opportunities are available, and where such acquisitions can be executed in a way that creates value for Lafarge."

He acknowledged that Lafarge may have failed to explain its intentions but said price was the main reason for Lafarge's failure in the bid.

fields.headline: Smugglers net £2bn for tobacco
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: Tobacco smuggling is now second only to drugs in terms of consumer spending on illegal activities, according to a report published yesterday.
fields.body:
Tobacco smuggling is now second only to drugs in terms of consumer spending on illegal activities, according to a report published yesterday.

The Tobacco Manufacturers' Association, which commissioned the report, described as "breathtaking" the scale of criminal activity and the government's failure to deal with it.

The study, carried out by the independent consultants DTZ Pieda, claims that 16.6bn black market cigarettes, or over 830m packets, were sold illegally in the United Kingdom last year.

"At an average street price of £2.50 a pack, this equates to over £2bn in revenue for the smugglers and estimated untaxed profits of £415m," the report said.

"Add further profits of £123m from the £430m illegal sales of hand-rolling tobacco and it is not hard to see why organised crime has moved in on this lucrative and relatively risk-free business."

And the report predicted that if cigarette smuggling expanded to the level of hand-rolling tobacco, revenue losses could rise to over £11bn by 2005.

"With estimated sales of £2.5bn a year, tobacco smuggling is now second only to drugs in terms of consumer spending on illegal activities," the report said.

It also claimed that customs and excise managed to seize only a small proportion of all tobacco smuggled into the UK from Belgium and elsewhere.

It concluded that if the government was to stamp out this black market it must:

 Reduce the tobacco tax differential between Britain and the rest of Europe;

 Restrict the quantity of cigarettes that can be legally imported for personal use; and

 Make stiffer penalties for tobacco smugglers.

Sir Donald Mackay, chairman of DTZ Pieda, said: "Most people are aware that a black market in tobacco exists, but this is the first time it has been so thoroughly and independently investigated.

"The results are alarming and depressing, and should be required reading for all policy-makers."

David Swan, chief executive of the Tobacco Manufacturers' Association, said: "If anyone still believes tobacco smuggling is a harmless activity practised by cross-channel transit van weekenders out to make a bit of extra pin money, they should study this report.

"The scale of criminal activity and the government's failure to deal with it is breathtaking."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: •Like any good wine vinegar, my old friend Gerald Kaufman just gets better with each day that passes. Bless his heart, Gerald was on cracking form in the Commons on Tuesday, treating members to a burst of the acid humour that has made him Westminster's most glittering wit since the electors of Harlow dispensed with Jerry Hayes. An indulgent, twinkly-eyed Madam Speaker asked Gerald to withdraw his remark when he described Ken Livingstone as - wait for it - a "smarmy charlatan". As a last minute boost to Ken's campaign this seems superfluous. I suppose Gerald could have gone further (he might have called Ken "a slimy, sibilant sycophant"), but not very much. Enchanted by this, we ring Gerald at the Commons and on his mobile to say well done, but he doesn't answer or return the message. A pity. All we wanted to say was that there are so few politicians of Gerald's age who can make fun of themselves.
fields.body:
Like any good wine vinegar, my old friend Gerald Kaufman just gets better with each day that passes. Bless his heart, Gerald was on cracking form in the Commons on Tuesday, treating members to a burst of the acid humour that has made him Westminster's most glittering wit since the electors of Harlow dispensed with Jerry Hayes. An indulgent, twinkly-eyed Madam Speaker asked Gerald to withdraw his remark when he described Ken Livingstone as - wait for it - a "smarmy charlatan". As a last minute boost to Ken's campaign this seems superfluous. I suppose Gerald could have gone further (he might have called Ken "a slimy, sibilant sycophant"), but not very much. Enchanted by this, we ring Gerald at the Commons and on his mobile to say well done, but he doesn't answer or return the message. A pity. All we wanted to say was that there are so few politicians of Gerald's age who can make fun of themselves.

Competition winner Joseph M Brogan III emails us following yesterday's picture of himself wearing an Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirt, arm-in-arm with Dobbo. "Saw the pic and the article! I have bought loads of copies to show to people back in little ol' New York City," he writes, "thanks again." No, Joe, thank you. The cheque's in the post. Sort of.

From from the Jordanian capital Amman, Labour MP George Galloway has bizarre mayoral news. George is over there for an inter-parliamentary union meeting about the peace process in the Middle East, and reports that all the talk is of the Guardian's imminent declaration of support for Shagger Norris. First of all a Blairite peer, Lord Faulkner of Worcester, gave George the shock news, which was later adamantly confirmed by a senior official at the British embassy - who, when told that people at the Guardian knew nothing of this, muttered: "I think we know something they don't, then." Very odd. They must be confusing us with the Mirror. Please God our chaps in Jordan are better informed about the peace process than events here in the Farringdon Road.

Speaking of the Mirror and its pro-Shagger line (not quite as shocking as the Guardian backing the Tories in 1955, but still a surprise), news of this led the Cabinet Office to access its website yesterday morning to read more. This was fine, but when they tried to check on the rival Sun's angle, a message informed them they were barred from accessing the site because the Sun is deemed "inappropriate". Whether this is on political or bare breast grounds, if I was alopecian Sun editor David Yelland, I'd take a very dim view of this indeed.

Given Mr Tony's alleged obsession with schooling, it's a bit baffling that British elections are still held on Thursdays, costing children a day at school, and not on weekends as in France, Germany and Italy and other first world countries. Resisting the change, we gather, is Jack Straw, who is concerned on the traditional twin fronts of God and mammon. He doesn't want to pay overtime to the policemen, who hang around polling stations looking bored. And he doesn't want to distress the Sunday lobby, which is odd (he never worries about offending the rest of us) but touching all the same.

Good luck, finally, to all candidates, but especially to Dobbo. Rumour reaches us that the old boy has been canvassed himself this week. Apparently, he was having his afternoon nap when the doorbell rang, and he opened it to find a young woman wearing thick spectacles and a Lib Dem rosette. "I'm very sorry to trouble you, sir," she said, "but I was wondering how you were planning to vote." "Oooh, I'm not quite sure yet," Dobbo allegedly replied. "If it's fair, I'll probably stroll over to the polling station after breakfast with Mrs Dobson. Then again, if it's raining I may catch the bus from outside the library"

fields.headline: Emergency! My sausage is mouldy
fields.trailText: When Alison Mckenzie telephoned an emergency 24-hour environmental health helpline to complain about a chorizo sausage she had bought from her local supermarket, she was more than a little surprised by the size of the response.
fields.body:
When Alison Mckenzie telephoned an emergency 24-hour environmental health helpline to complain about a chorizo sausage she had bought from her local supermarket, she was more than a little surprised by the size of the response.

The mother of two from Aberdeenshire was besieged with calls from police forces up and down the country, asking exactly how they were supposed to help, after a glitch in a British Telecom system transmitted her message to police headquarters from Land's End to John o' Groats.

But Ms Mckenzie's problems did not end there. Bemused doctors, nurses, carers and businessmen then phoned, after the glitch forwarded her complaint, which carried her address and phone number, to every BT pager beginning with the number 01426.

Hampshire police eventually tracked the source of the trouble to BT, which brought in engineers to try to erase the message from their system after police attempts failed.

Ms Mckenzie, 40, of Peterhead, said: "Two weeks ago I bought this sausage for £1.75 and when I took it home it was green, so I called environmental health to complain. I had forgotten about it until I started getting calls from people all over the country."

"My husband, Derek, said someone was having a laugh, but when I found out what had happened I couldn't believe it. The police told me that my complaint about the sausage is on their voicebank, which informs the press of everything from rapes and murders to road accidents.

"Then I discovered BT accidently sent my message to every number beginning with 01426, which meant hundreds of thousands of pagers received it. I have had calls from 20-year-olds and people in their 70s, I had so many that in the end I had to put my answer machine on because my line was being inundated.

"Safeways must be going crazy because now everyone thinks they sell bad sausages."

A Hampshire police spokeswoman, Susan Rollings, said: "We were astonished when people began reporting this alien message on our voicebank. We had no idea where it came from and tried to erase it without success.

"We then discovered that other forces across the country had also been invaded and couldn't do anything about it either.

"It's bizarre - nothing like this has happened before."

A BT spokesman said: "We have had technical problems with part of our voicebank service and we are working urgently to correct the faults."

webTitle: Fee-paying pupils up for fifth year running

fields.headline: Fee-paying pupils up for fifth year running
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Independent schools have reported an increase in the number of their pupils for the fifth year in succession.
fields.body:
Independent schools have reported an increase in the number of their pupils for the fifth year in succession.

Figures from the Independent Schools Information Service published yesterday showed a rise last year of 3,812 pupils, or 0.8%, to a total of more than 484,000.

The growth at the 1,280 fee-paying schools that belong to the Independent Schools Council was across all age ranges - except for the sixth form, where numbers fell by 2%; this was attributed to a "blip" caused by weak recruitment in the mid 1990s.

Independent schools attract 7% of all schoolchildren in England, and 10% in London.

The overall growth was achieved despite a second year without a fresh intake receiving financial assistance under the assisted places scheme, to replace the 6,800 pupils who left in 1999.

The last significant down turn in overall pupil numbers was recorded in the early 1980s, as a direct result of the economic recession. David Woodhead, director of the information service, said the strong economy had given parents confidence to invest in their children's education.

"Independent schools go from strength to strength. Growth has been achieved through all the main pre-school, junior and secondary ages," he said.

"For schools which have lost thousands of students from the assisted places scheme to increase the size of their new intake and their total pupil numbers is a remarkable achievement."

The schools said the scrapping of the scheme (implemented by the government as a manifesto pledge) had had a worrying effect on the socioeconomic composition of schools, depriving them of many bright pupils whose parents could not afford the fees.

The survey also showed a further collapse in the number of regular boarders, a fall of 2.6%, although there was a 76% leap in the proportion of day pupils opting for occasional boarding in "sleepovers".

The schools warned that their fees would rise sharply in September, to take account for teachers' performance-related pay, which is to be adopted by some independent schools as well as by the state sector.

Last year fees rose an average 6.3%, having risen 5.7% the previous year, though there was a 4.6% increase last year in the number of pupils receiving assistance from their schools in paying fees.

The survey shows that the average pupil/teacher ratio in the independent sector remains at 1:10.6, much lower than the 1:18.6 ratio in the state sector, although actual class sizes are considerably higher for all schools.

Capital investment by independent schools rose 17.4% in 1999, one of the largest annual increases recorded; the amount was £369m - an average of £767 a pupil as against £658 the previous year.

Further education colleges in England were making progress in their financial management but there remained 56 colleges struggling to balance their books, the national audit office reported yesterday.

Colleges experiencing financial difficulty "grew rapidly" between 1993 and 1997, Whitehall's spending watchdog reported. It warned: "More recently the proportion has started to decline but still stands at about 13%."

The office urged the worst performing colleges to adopt best practice from better managed institutions.

There are 429 FE colleges in England with a combined income of £4bn a year. The comptroller and auditor general, Sir John Bourn, said: "The financial state of the sector is improving, but there are still too many colleges in poor financial health."
fields.bodyText: Independent schools have reported an increase in the number of their pupils for the fifth year in succession. Figures from the Independent Schools Information Service published yesterday showed a rise last year of 3,812 pupils, or 0.8%, to a total of more than 484,000. The growth at the 1,280 fee-paying schools that belong to the Independent Schools Council was across all age ranges - except for the sixth form, where numbers fell by 2%; this was attributed to a "blip" caused by weak recruitment in the mid 1990s. Independent schools attract 7% of all schoolchildren in England, and 10% in London. The overall growth was achieved despite a second year without a fresh intake receiving financial assistance under the assisted places scheme, to replace the 6,800 pupils who left in 1999. The last significant down turn in overall pupil numbers was recorded in the early 1980s, as a direct result of the economic recession. David Woodhead, director of the information service, said the strong economy had given parents confidence to invest in their children's education. "Independent schools go from strength to strength. Growth has been achieved through all the main pre-school, junior and secondary ages," he said. "For schools which have lost thousands of students from the assisted places scheme to increase the size of their new intake and their total pupil numbers is a remarkable achievement." The schools said the scrapping of the scheme (implemented by the government as a manifesto pledge) had had a worrying effect on the socioeconomic composition of schools, depriving them of many bright pupils whose parents could not afford the fees. The survey also showed a further collapse in the number of regular boarders, a fall of 2.6%, although there was a 76% leap in the proportion of day pupils opting for occasional boarding in "sleepovers". The schools warned that their fees would rise sharply in September, to take account for teachers' performance-related pay, which is to be adopted by some independent schools as well as by the state sector. Last year fees rose an average 6.3%, having risen 5.7% the previous year, though there was a 4.6% increase last year in the number of pupils receiving assistance from their schools in paying fees. The survey shows that the average pupil/teacher ratio in the independent sector remains at 1:10.6, much lower than the 1:18.6 ratio in the state sector, although actual class sizes are considerably higher for all schools. Capital investment by independent schools rose 17.4% in 1999, one of the largest annual increases recorded; the amount was £369m - an average of £767 a pupil as against £658 the previous year. Further education colleges in England were making progress in their financial management but there remained 56 colleges struggling to balance their books, the national audit office reported yesterday. Colleges experiencing financial difficulty "grew rapidly" between 1993 and 1997, Whitehall's spending watchdog reported. It warned: "More recently the proportion has started to decline but still stands at about 13%." The office urged the worst performing colleges to adopt best practice from better managed institutions. There are 429 FE colleges in England with a combined income of £4bn a year. The comptroller and auditor general, Sir John Bourn, said: "The financial state of the sector is improving, but there are still too many colleges in poor financial health."

webTitle: Dairy forces farmers to abandon GM crop trial

fields.headline: Dairy forces farmers to abandon GM crop trial
fields.standfirst: GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Government-backed trials of genetically modified crops were in more trouble last night after a cooperative of dairy farmers forced colleagues to drop out of the experiment for fear it would damage their milk sales.
fields.body:
Government-backed trials of genetically modified crops were in more trouble last night after a cooperative of dairy farmers forced colleagues to drop out of the experiment for fear it would damage their milk sales.

Seven proposed sites have been abandoned in recent weeks, and so far only 50 sites have been confirmed for planting this year - up to 30 fewer than the target set by ministers in March; it appears that the biotech industry itself is now settling for a total of 60.

The latest body blow to the three-year programme of farm scale evaluations of GM seeds came with the decision by a farming couple in Cornwall to pull out of a trial for modified maize. Scimac, the industry umbrella group supervising the trials, has also abandoned a site for oil seed rape in St Osyth, near Clacton in Essex. The farmer concerned had already promised to abide by the decision of a parish referendum on the planting to be held today.

The government wants an average of 75 trials a year for three years to monitor the effects of GM crops on the environment and wildlife. This year it wanted 30 sites for sugar beet or fodder beet for animals, 25 for maize, and 25 for oilseed rape, much of which should either already have been planted or be in the ground within a few weeks.

Barry and Mary Symons, of West Portholland on the Roseland peninsula in Cornwall, dropped out under pressure from Peninsula Milk, a cooperative that buys their produce and sells it on to supermarkets. Mrs Symons said: "Our milk buyer put us under pressure, saying they would not collect from us if we took part, and we didn't have any choice but to withdraw."

She said the cows would not have gone anywhere near the crops but "milk is the most important part of our farm, so we have to listen to our buyers". There had not been much other local pressure: "Only two people have expressed concern about the trials, and one is a beekeeper."

Geoff Lawrence, managing director of Peninsula Milk, said: "We know there is resistance to GM foods from our consumers. We are not judging GM foods one way or the other, but if the customer doesn't want it, then the rights and wrongs don't matter." The company hoped soon to be free of milk from cows fed on GM feed.

Ian Johnson, spokesman for the National Farmers' Union in the south-west, said "inappropriate pressure" had been put on Mr and Mrs Symons. "GM crops are here now, and I think people will become more amenable to the idea when they see vaccines and other medical uses," he said.

The Cabinet Office's GM unit insisted that the steering committee monitoring the trials has set a maximum of 80 and minimum of 44 trial sites this year, even though the environment minister, Michael Meacher, has said there would be at least 66 and possibly 80 sites. A spokeswoman for the unit said: "This is not something we are concerned about at the moment. The goalposts have not changed."

No one from Scimac was available to comment.

webTitle: Rugby Gladiators thrown to the Romanian lions

fields.headline: Rugby Gladiators thrown to the Romanian lions
fields.trailText: Dorchester Gladiators over-40s rugby team recently found themselves appearing in front of thousands of spectators after a translation error saw them take on a team containing international stars.
fields.body:
Dorchester Gladiators over-40s rugby team recently found themselves appearing in front of thousands of spectators after a translation error saw them take on a team containing international stars.

The Gladiators, who boast a 50-year-old as oldest player, were expecting to take on a similarly mature side from the lower ranks of Romania's top club Steaua Bucharest. But due to a language mix-up the Romanians thought they were playing a top English side. The match was played in a packed stadium, while recorded highlights featured on Romania's television news.

Nigel Jones, 43, who plays in the second row, said: "We did our pre-match match build-up in the bar and didn't get in until 4am. The match began at 11am. We tried to convince them we were not any good but they thought we were trying to wind them up."

The match ended 61-17 after the Romanians eased off when they realised the mistake.

webTitle: Police action at Tibet rally unlawful

fields.headline: Police action at Tibet rally unlawful
fields.standfirst: Met forced into climbdown over treatment of protesters
fields.trailText: The treatment of demonstrators by the police during the controversial state visit of the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, last year was unlawful, the Metropolitan force admitted in the high court yesterday.
fields.body:
The treatment of demonstrators by the police during the controversial state visit of the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, last year was unlawful, the Metropolitan force admitted in the high court yesterday.

The Free Tibet Campaign said the Met had been forced into a humiliating climbdown after it agreed, before Mr Justice Burton, that "it was unlawful for individual officers to remove banners and flags from people solely on the basis that they were protesting against the Chinese regime on October 19".

The force has also agreed to a carefully worded declaration that "it would be unlawful to position police vans in front of the protesters if the reason for doing so was to suppress free speech".

The police took away Tibetan flags and pro-democracy banners from protesters but left Union flags and Chinese flags untouched. The Met continues to argue that vans were used to prevent public disorder, and not to hide demonstrators, outside Buckingham palace on October 19 and outside the Chinese embassy on October 21.

The judge was told that while there was still substantial factual dispute between the two sides, the police have agreed to the granting of the two declarations.

Lawyers for the Free Tibet Campaign, seeking judicial review, argued that the police's handling of the protests in the Mall, widely criticised by opposition parties, contravened the common law right to peaceful protest and articles 10, 11 and 14 of the European convention on human rights, which deal with freedom of expression, freedom of peaceful assembly, and discrimination. Although the Human Rights Act, which adopts the convention, does not become law until October, courts are already anticipating its effects in Britain.

In an internal review, published on March 17 - condemned by the Free Tibet Campaign as a whitewash - the Met refers to the police applying a "restrictive policy". But the agreement announced yesterday refers to mistakes by individual officers, rather than to a policy.

Alison Reynolds, director of the Free Tibet Campaign, yesterday called on Sir John Stevens, the Metropolitan police commissioner, to explain how the internal review "came to defend as policy what the police now admit was unlawful". She said: "It stretches credibility to ask us to believe that all the officers in the Mall spontaneously made the same mistake by removing flags. Senior officers did nothing to correct this and the Met's own review defended the action."

Ian Johnston, an assistant commissioner at the Met, said this was "a tricky area" for colleagues to deal with. "We didn't get it entirely right. We accept absolutely the blame for that ... On the day, our officers on the ground - because we didn't support them properly with decent briefings for the event over the complexity of the bylaws and the Vienna convention - individuals made decisions which we accept entirely were not right and we have apologised for that."

But Mike Bennett, a former Metropolitan police federation chairman, told BBC Radio 4's World at One programme: "Police officers today are very wary of their actions and the actions that were taken at the time would not have been taken unless the instruction came from above." The Foreign Office repeated its denial that it had put pressure on the Met to curb demonstrations, although in a Commons written answer, John Battle, the Foreign Office minister, admitted that officials and the Met had discussed the concerns of the Chinese about "the possible impact of demonstrations on the visit".

Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, said last night: "It has been clear all along that the Foreign Office's first priority was to prevent the Chinese president being embarrassed. It must come clean on its precise role in [the] policing arrangements."

Ann Widdecombe, the shadow home secretary, on Tuesday contrasted the treatment of protesters during the state visit with what she said was the more lax attitude to participants in the anti-capitalism protest on May Day.

A Free Tibet Campaign spokeswoman said that the group was delighted with the Met's admission - the first time the police had declared that its handling of a protest was unlawful - but that without a full court case the truth about police decision-making during the visit might never come out.

fields.headline: Tunnel vision
fields.standfirst: Tyne landmark given protection
fields.trailText: Britain's longest foot tunnel was yesterday awarded Grade II listed status. The 900ft pedestrian tunnel under the river Tyne between Wallsend and Jarrow was built between 1947 and 1951, with a cycle tunnel running alongside.
fields.body:
Britain's longest foot tunnel was yesterday awarded Grade II listed status. The 900ft pedestrian tunnel under the river Tyne between Wallsend and Jarrow was built between 1947 and 1951, with a cycle tunnel running alongside.

In their heyday, more than 18,000 people, many of them shipyard workers, used the crossings daily. The cycle tunnel is now part of the national cycle network.

Alan Howarth, the arts minister, announcing the award of Grade II status, said: "For nearly 50 years the Tyne tunnels have had a special place in the affections of local people and visitors alike.

"They are fine examples of municipal architecture and civil engineering with virtually all of the original fabric and machinery still intact."

The foot tunnel has a 200ft wooden tread escalator which is believed to have been one of the longest in the world when it was constructed.

The tunnel itself was the longest in the world until superseded by one in Hong Kong.

fields.headline: Keeping up with the Joneses
fields.trailText: Plain John Smith is not as plain a name as most people thought. Well, not as plain as David Jones or David Smith, according to lists published yesterday by the office for national statistics.
fields.body:
Plain John Smith is not as plain a name as most people thought. Well, not as plain as David Jones or David Smith, according to lists published yesterday by the office for national statistics.

At the top of the top 100 most common male names in England and Wales sits David Jones, a moniker shared by 14,341 other David Joneses, including the former Monkee and David Bowie, who changed his name from Jones.

Robbie Williams's music and stage persona may be unique but his name certainly is not. Robert Williams is the 50th most common name and 4,628 men are so called.

Other famous singing names which make an appearance are James Brown, James Taylor, Thomas (Tom) Jones, and Paul Jones.

Top of the list of women's names is Margaret Smith, a name shared by the actor Dame Maggie Smith and 7,639 others. Margaret Jones is second most common followed by Susan Smith, Susan Jones and Mary Smith.

The survey shows that women tend to have a wider range of names than men: the most popular boys' forenames are used more often than the most popular girls' names. David appears 22 times whereas Margaret gets 11 mentions.

The ONS compiled the list from the national health service central register, which comprises everyone who is registered with a GP.

Mohammed Khan is the only Asian origin full name to make it into the top 100 male names, while none make it into the women's list.

Khan, Ali, Singh, Begum and Hussain all make it in to the list of top 100 surnames.

In this list, Smith is the most popular, followed by Jones, Williams, Taylor and Brown.

The top forename for men is John and is followed by David, Michael, James and Robert.

Margaret is the most common woman's name with Mary coming second, followed by Susan, Elizabeth and Sarah.

fields.headline: The danger of overkill
fields.standfirst:
Order matters, but so do our freedoms

May 2K: special report
fields.trailText: On the Richter scale of riot, Monday's demonstrations in the centre of London rank low. They caused £500,000 of damage: small change compared to the repair bills generated by, say, last year's protests against the world trade talks in Seattle. Still, they found two targets certain to grab attention: the Cenotaph and a statue of Winston Churchill.
fields.body:
On the Richter scale of riot, Monday's demonstrations in the centre of London rank low. They caused £500,000 of damage: small change compared to the repair bills generated by, say, last year's protests against the world trade talks in Seattle. Still, they found two targets certain to grab attention: the Cenotaph and a statue of Winston Churchill. The handful of vandals responsible succeeded in drowning out the cause which had brought the rest on to the streets - and allowed our more hysterical newspapers to warn of a mindless mob threatening the British way of life. Joining that chorus, regrettably, has been the prime minister himself. His comments, coming on the eve of today's elections in London and across England, have opened up a debate which stretches far beyond the concerns of the guerrilla gardeners and their friends.

For Tony Blair said the government would now reconsider its entire approach to demonstrations: "This kind of thing cannot happen again," he warned. One does not have to be a pierced, tattooed marcher with Reclaim the Streets to be chilled by that remark. In a democratic society, freedom of assembly is a basic right. It does not have to be "reconsidered", even if a handful of anarchists use that right for a cheap stunt on a couple of monuments. No, the prime minister should not have tried to catch up with the nation's hysterics but cooled them down, calmly noting that real freedom allows scope for unpopular individuals to say and do ugly things.

Unfortunately, the government seems to have a tin ear for such fundamental notions of liberty. A sharp reminder of that came yesterday, when the Metropolitan Police admitted that some of its officers broke the law in their heavy-handed treatment of protesters against the Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, during his visit last October. The images of police stripping demonstrators of flags and banners which posed no threat to anyone, was a jolt to all those who had believed the British right to peaceful protest was inviolate.

The defence offered at the time was that the conduct of those officers was a matter for the Metropolitan Police, not the politicians. Few believed that: it seemed impossible that the Met would not have received clear instructions from on high on how to handle Mr Jiang's visit. Luckily, this previously confused matter is about to be cleared up. Today Londoners will elect not only a mayor, but the other part of the new Greater London Authority: the assembly. It may have received less airtime, but this new body will share powers with the mayor - including a say on policing. The new Metropolitan Police Authority will have to answer for displays like the ones we saw last October and on Monday.

That means Londoners' votes for the assembly will matter. They will have two: one for their constituency, where the normal first-past-the-post rules apply, and a second which will run on a London-wide, proportional basis. Voters may well want to mix and match: perhaps backing Labour in the constituencies where minor parties will struggle, but using their second vote to ensure a pluralist mix in the assembly - with Greens and Lib Dems more healthily represented. In the rest of England, there is an even more basic need than pluralism: participation. Local turnouts have been depressingly low in recent years. Making Britain a less centralised country means giving local government itself a vote of confidence. English voters can do that today, using the democratic right for which those war dead gave their lives.

fields.headline: A marriage of money
fields.standfirst: How can this new world be regulated?
fields.trailText: International capitalism yesterday showed itself to be in fine fettle, despite May Day's demonstrators. The merger of the London Stock Exchange and the German Bourse opens the door to further restructuring of equity markets. And companies.
fields.body:
International capitalism yesterday showed itself to be in fine fettle, despite May Day's demonstrators. The merger of the London Stock Exchange and the German Bourse opens the door to further restructuring of equity markets. And companies. By cutting transaction costs and making ownership more transparent the move must accelerate "Anglo-American" pursuit of shareholder value; shaken-out employees may regret it. Next, Madrid and Milan are to join International Exchanges (iX). Then Nasdaq will create with iX a new exchange for technology and growth stocks. Discussions with Euronext, the united Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam bourses, start at once. Around the corner lies continent-wide trading, within a single clearing and settlements system. Where politicians fear to tread - French finance minister Laurent Fabius yesterday bemoaned lack of movement on the pan-European front - profit-seekers pile in. Here is evidence of business remaking the world in its own image. Will regulators and public authorities be able to keep up?

Although iX will trade more than half Europe's stocks, its turnover falls beneath the European Union competition threshold, so Brussels said it was unlikely to get involved. Protecting the public interest falls to the Financial Services Authority and the Federal Securities Supervisory Office. But while German and British minds may meet, can ad hoc arrangements work if the Spanish and Italians join? Who is to oversee the German-based, American-oriented exchange that will emerge after Nasdaq's European entry? On it the supply of capital for e-enterprise may depend. Capitalist competition, history shows, is usually only as productive as the framework of enforceable rules put around it by government. The slow-moving, hydra-headed bureaucracies of the EU do not look fit for the purpose here. Don Cruickshank, iX's chairman, may be a good chap who took the consumers' part against the banks but even saints cannot be trusted to regulate themselves.

No one yesterday seemed concerned about the euro, which will probably be used to list iX prices - surprising on a day when dealers declared their lack of confidence in Greece's accession. Here is a paradox. The value of the euro falls, but countries queue up to join: Stockholm was avidly signalling its intention yesterday. In wait-and-see London nothing was deemed to have changed.

fields.headline: Hostages die in Philippine gunfights
fields.standfirst:
Sabah Ministry of Tourism Development
Institute for Counter-Terrorism: Abu Sayyaf
fields.trailText: Four Filipino hostages were killed and five others, including children, were wounded yesterday when Philippine troops clashed with Muslim rebels on the southern island of Basilan, officials said.
fields.body:
Four Filipino hostages were killed and five others, including children, were wounded yesterday when Philippine troops clashed with Muslim rebels on the southern island of Basilan, officials said.

In separate incidents elsewhere in the Philippines, it was reported that Moro Islamic Liberation Front (Milf) guerrillas seized more than 100 hostages and launched grenades at an airport near the city of Cotabato, on the island of Mindanao; bombs at General Santos, also on Mindanao, killed four people; and at least two men were wounded in a five-hour gun battle between their Abu Sayyaf rebel captors and troops on Tuesday night.

A spokesman for the Abu Sayyaf militia had earlier told television stations that a white male hostage was killed by a stray bullet and a white woman died of a heart attack during the fighting on Jolo island. He did not identify them.

But a local government official on the island, 600 miles south of Manila, said all 21 hostages were alive.

The defence secretary, Orlando Mercado, said 10 Filipino hostages, including seven children, from a group of at least 27 were rescued unhurt after clashes between their captors and troops on the nearby island of Basilan.

At least four hostages were killed and five, including three children, were wounded, he said, denying earlier reports that 10 hostages might have been killed.

"The troops are still looking for the other hostages," he said.

The children were among scores of people abducted by Abu Sayyaf rebels in raids on two secondary schools on Basilan on March 20. The army attacked the camp about 10 days ago after the Abu Sayyaf guerrillas said they had executed two male adults. Troops took control of the camp on Sunday but said many rebels escaped with the hostages.

The news of the hostage deaths does not bode well for the mostly foreign captives held on Jolo.

Their governments have appealed to Manila to ensure that the army is not asked to attack the guerrillas camp.

The 21 hostages snatched by Abu Sayyaf from the Malaysian diving resort of Sipadan on Easter Sunday comprise 10 Malaysians, three Germans, two French nationals, two South Africans, two Finns, one Lebanese and a Filipina.

About 2,000 troops have surrounded the rebel base and gun battles erupted in the area on Tuesday night. Journalists were barred from going near the camp yesterday.

The violence racking the southern Philippines is the worst in the country since Muslim separatists agreed a peace deal with the government in 1996.

Abu Sayyaf and Milf rejected the agreement and have continued their decades-long fight for Muslim self-rule in the south of the mainly Roman Catholic country.

Mindanao island, the scene of the latest hostage-taking and bomb attacks reported by officials and army officers, is home to most of the 5m Muslims in the country's 74m population.

It was not known if yesterday's explosions were linked to the Milf-led fighting, but officials in General Santos said they were convinced that they were the handiwork of the group.

Philippine Airlines said it was cancelling today's flights to Cotabato and General Santos because of the violence and was not sure when they would resume.

Milf pulled out of peace talks last week after claiming that troops had violated the shaky ceasefire.

About 130 people have been killed since then in fighting between troops and Milf rebels. Reuters
