webTitle: French court throws out Boycott appeal

fields.headline: French court throws out Boycott appeal
fields.standfirst: We are dealing with a cad, says lawyer for cricketer's assaulted ex-lover
fields.trailText: A French appeal court yesterday upheld Geoffrey Boycott's conviction for beating his former lover after a hearing in which the former England cricketer was referred to as a "bounder".
fields.body:
A French appeal court yesterday upheld Geoffrey Boycott's conviction for beating his former lover after a hearing in which the former England cricketer was referred to as a "bounder".

Saying he was disappointed and frustrated by the decision, a stoical Boycott, 59, denied he had ever hit Margaret Moore at a Riviera hotel nearly four years ago, adding that he would be consulting his lawyers about whether he would take the case to the French high court.

"I've done my best," he said after the 90-minute hearing in Aix-en-Provence. "I didn't have great hopes because of the French system and culture, which are different from ours. But I had to try. I never hit her."

The presiding judge, Jean-Claude Vuillemin, confirmed the November 1998 verdict of a district court in nearby Grasse, which convicted Boycott of assault, sentencing him to a three-month suspended jail sentence and a fine of nearly £5,000. He was also ordered to pay a symbolic one franc in compensation to Ms Moore.

Ms Moore said she was pleased that justice had been done. Asked what her feelings for Boycott were now, she said: "We all make mistakes in life. Looking back on it, I don't know what I saw in him."

The case centred on a violent row between the couple at the Hotel du Cap in Antibes on October 2 1996. Boycott claimed that the heavy bruising Ms Moore suffered about the face and eyes was the result of a fall during the argument, which he said flared up after he turned down her request for marriage.

Ms Moore, who ran a computer consultancy in Monaco and was Mr Boycott's lover for four years, said the former Yorkshire captain, who now works as a cricket commentator and columnist, had thrown her to the floor, held her down with his knee, and hit her 20 times after a dispute about how much money she had made for him.

Boycott, who is believed to have spent some £400,000 mounting his defence - including flying in 13 different witnesses during November's hearings to testify to his good character - again insisted Ms Moore's bruises were merely accidental.

"If I had hit her 20 times, she would have had a busted nose, cut lip and grazes," he said. "I am a strong man physically."

During exchanges that on several occasions reduced a packed courtroom to giggles, both parties agreed on one point: the struggle started when Ms Moore returned to their room and found Boycott packing to leave. In a fury, she threw several pieces of his clothing and toiletries out of the window.

Judge Vuillemin - who made no effort to conceal his laughter - said that must have made an engaging spectacle. "It is not usual in a hotel of this quality for luggage to be brought down through the front windows," he commented.

While denying his client had ever hit Ms Moore, Boycott's French lawyer, Jean-Luc Cardona, tried to argue that it was not surprising the Yorkshireman had lost his temper.

"She tried to throw his trousers out of the window," he said. "Everyone knows that the trousers are the most sensitive part of the male wardrobe."

Contrary to Mr Cardona's claims, Judge Vuillemin expressed doubts as to whether a simple fall to the floor of the Hotel du Cap could have produced such bruising. "Such injuries are surely not consistent with a fall in such a plush hotel, where one can assume the carpet to be soft," he said.

Boycott, in a final statement, said: "My job as a cricketer has been one of controlled emotion and patience for over 25 years. I'm not a fool. I've always had to be aware of my actions."

He continued: "I come here for one reason today. Mrs Moore has put a stain on my name, and I have come here to try to remove it.

"It is about my honour. Was it in Richard II that Shakespeare wrote, 'Mine honour is my life. Take away honour and my life is finished.' "

The public prosecutor, Jean-Yves Duval, said Boycott's arguments did not withstand examination. "The medical evidence is damning," he said. "The wounds suffered by Ms Moore are absolutely incompatible with an accident. What we have heard today are lamentable lies."

Ms Moore's lawyer, Stephane Choukroun, was even more forthright. "All this is being done so that Mr Boycott can recreate a virginal image for himself in Britain," he said.

"He wants to be able to go back to Britain and be able to say that French justice is a French farce, a Mickey Mouse court. I think we are dealing with a bounder and a cad."

webTitle: Mother executed for killing her children

fields.headline: Mother executed for killing her children
fields.standfirst: Guilt-ridden, Christina Riggs wanted to die
fields.trailText: A former nurse became the first woman to be executed in Arkansas for more than 150 years on Tuesday night, put to death by lethal injection for killing her two children in 1997.
fields.body:
A former nurse became the first woman to be executed in Arkansas for more than 150 years on Tuesday night, put to death by lethal injection for killing her two children in 1997.

Christina Marie Riggs' last words were directed to the five-year-old son and two-year-old daughter she murdered. "I love you, my babies," she said as a lethal mix of chemicals was injected into her wrist at a prison in Varner.

Riggs' mother and lawyer initially argued that she had been suffering from post-traumatic stress from her work as a nurse treating victims of the terrorist bombing of a government building in Oklahoma City.

But Riggs, 28, waived her right to appeal and prevented her lawyer from applying for clemency, saying that she could not live with the guilt of the murders and wanted to be reunited with her children in heaven.

"There is no way words can express how sorry I am for taking the lives of my babies," she said before the execution. "Now I can be with my babies, as I always intended."

Human rights activists said her desire to die confirmed her mental instability, and asked for the execution to be stopped on the grounds that it would amount to state-assisted suicide. But the Arkansas governor, Mike Huckabee, turned down their appeal.

Yesterday Riggs' lawyer, John Wesley Hall, said: "It started out as a suicide and ended as a suicide."

Riggs told the police that in November 1997 she gave her son, Justin, and daughter, Shelby, some anti-depressants in a cup of water to sedate them.

She then injected a large dose of potassium chloride into her son's neck with the aim of putting him to sleep. When he woke up and started crying, she injected him with morphine and smothered him with a pillow. She also smothered her daughter.

She laid the two dead children on her bed, before injecting herself with potassium chloride and swallowing 28 anti-depressants.

She left a suicide note for Shelby's father saying: "I can't live like this any more, and I couldn't bear to leave my children behind to be a burden on you or to be separated and raised apart from their fathers and live knowing their mother killed herself."

The prosecution portrayed her as a cold-blooded killer to whom her children were an "inconvenience".

She was accused of leaving them locked in their room for hours while she went out at night to karaoke bars.

Doctors testifying for her said she had been severely depressed as a result of sexual abuse as a child, a series of failed relationships with men, lack of money, and lack of self-esteem because of her obesity.

She went to her death weighing 122kg (270lb). She agreed to the execution needles being put in her wrists when her executioners were unable to find a vein in her arm.

Denying that her misfortunes excused her acts, the county prosecutor, Larry Jegley, said: "She claims she was horribly depressed, she was overweight and she was a single mom, and she didn't have enough money.

"My response to that is 'welcome to America'. Plenty of folks are in far worse situations than she was."

Women put to death in America

A total of 560 women have been executed in the US, 3% of the convicts put to death. Five have been executed since 1976, when the death penalty was reinstated after a brief moratorium:

Velma Barfield By lethal injection in North Carolina on November 2 1984 for killing four people, including her mother and fiance, with ant poison. The sunday school teacher confessed and went to her death in pink pajamas after a meal of Cheez Doodles, a popular snack

Karla Faye Tucker By lethal injection in Texas on February 3 1998 for hacking two people to death with a pickaxe. She claimed to have undergone a religious conversion in prison and appealed unsuccessfully to the state governor, George W Bush, for clemency

Judy Buenoano By electric chair in Florida on March 30 1998 for poisoning her husband with arsenic. She was also convicted of drowning her son, who used a wheelchair

Betty Lou Beets By lethal injection in Texas on February 24 2000 for shooting her fifth husband and burying his body in her garden. The 62-year-old grandmother had been charged with, but not convicted of, shooting dead her fourth husband, whose body was also found in the garden, and was convicted of shooting and wounding her second husband. She claimed that she had been the victim of physical abuse by her successive spouses, but her appeal for clemency was turned down by Mr Bush

Christina Marie Riggs By lethal injection in Arkansas on May 2 2000 for the murder of her two children. She waived her right to appeal and forbade her lawyer to apply for clemency

webTitle: 'We have the angels and the hand of Allah'

fields.headline: 'We have the angels and the hand of Allah'
fields.standfirst:
Sabah Ministry of Tourism Development
Institute for Counter-Terrorism: Abu Sayyaf
fields.trailText: Abu Sayyaf, the militant group which brought terror to an idyllic Malaysian diving resort, is a distant splinter of the resurgent Islamic extremism erupting in the Middle East.
fields.body:
Abu Sayyaf, the militant group which brought terror to an idyllic Malaysian diving resort, is a distant splinter of the resurgent Islamic extremism erupting in the Middle East.

Its founder, Abdurajak Abubakar Janjalani, found his calling while studying in Saudi Arabia.

He received military training in Libya and fought alongside the mojahedin holy warriors against Soviet forces in Afghanistan - a breeding ground for Islamic militancy.

There he is thought to have established contact with such extremist gurus as Osama Bin Laden, the Saudi alleged to have masterminded the 1998 bombing of the US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.

He adopted the name Abu Sayyaf, "bearer of the sword", and applied it to the small group of followers he attracted when he returned to the Philippines.

His aim was to instil a "pure" form of Islam, under which he would ban television, dancing and even laughing with bared teeth. His supporters were mainly young Muslims, impatient with the moderate strategy of the older separatist leaders seeking an independent Muslim state in Mindanao.

The new group proclaimed its arrival by bombing a port in the southern city of Zamboanga, aimed at a boat operating as a floating Christian bookshop.

That was followed by attacks on the city's airport and a number of churches.

Abu Sayyaf's founding principle was to target only soldiers, but the killing soon got out of hand.

In 1993 he rolled grenades down the aisle of a Roman Catholic cathedral, killing seven worshippers. In 1995 his group moved into the small Christian town of Ipil and killed 53 soldiers and civilians before burning the settlement to the ground.

In 1998 Janjalani was killed in an exchange of fire with the police, triggering a power struggle in Abu Sayyaf eventually won four months later by Janjalani's brother Khadaffy, an expert in the use of explosives.

Abu Sayyaf is thought to retain links with its roots, receiving funding from the Middle East. Reports that the group was visited by Mr Bin Laden have never been confirmed, however.

There are conspiracy theories circulating in the region that the Philippines army has encouraged the group, to discredit the separatist cause and sow divisions in the Muslim community.

Its strength is estimated at about 200 armed men and a roughly equal number of unarmed sympathisers, based on the islands of Basilan, Sulu and Tawi-Tawi at the southernmost tip of the Philippines.

"We may be small in number, but we have plenty fighting with us - the angels and the hand of Allah," Khadaffy Janjalani recently told journalists.

"We dream of an entire Islamic world, and we will achieve it."

Twelve civilians, including a two-month-old baby, were wounded yesterday when Israeli forces fired rockets at the house of a leader of the pro-Syrian Amal guerrilla group in southern Lebanon.

Six children were injured during the attack in Haboush, a village inside the border zone occupied by Israeli forces and their allies, witnesses said. Reuters, Nabatiyeh, Lebanon

Red Brigades link examined

Italian police are investigating six suspects they say were arrested with a stash of automatic weapons on Tuesday in Milan. The authorities believe they could be connected with the militant Red Brigades.

The arrests took place after police monitored phone calls allegedly connecting them to members of faction. The suspects are believed to have been planning to rob armoured delivery trucks and a post office. Milan, AP

webTitle: Italy sees pasta give way to present

fields.headline: Italy sees pasta give way to present
fields.standfirst: Burger chains make mincemeat of tradition with big offensive in the land of mamma's cooking
fields.trailText: McDonald's and Burger King have breached Italy's final frontier: pasta, pizza and mamma's cooking are succumbing to foreign fast food.
fields.body:
McDonald's and Burger King have breached Italy's final frontier: pasta, pizza and mamma's cooking are succumbing to foreign fast food.

Decades of resistance by family-owned bars, pizzerias and restaurants look like ending in defeat with the announcement that the two chains are about to transform Italy's high streets by doubling their number of outlets.

A massive investment is under way based on evidence that Italians are ready to abandon traditional eating habits once considered immutable.

Gourmets yesterday bewailed the "triumph of the hamburger" and drew up plans for a counter-attack.

US-owned McDonald's and British-owned Burger King - for years ghettoised at 5% of the market - are determined to bring Italy up to the European average of 25%. Within two years, McDonald's intends to open 200 restaurants, most of them in the centre and south of the country, which were considered heartlands of the Mediterranean diet. Its rival, which until last year did not have a single franchise, plans to open more than 100.

The two companies expect to expand not at the expense of each other, but of traditional restaurants.

According to McDonald's, turnover at its existing 243 restaurants jumped by almost a fifth last year.

That is just scratching the surface, said Felice Invernizzi, marketing director of McDonald's Italia. Two months ago the chain launched its first pizza in Italy, called Pizza Mia. Sold by the slice, it has been a hit, despite purists' anguish.

Burger King is bullish after cutting a deal with the pizza chain Spizzico, which can tap into a network of restaurants owned by its parent company, Autogrill.

"It is the globalisation of the palate," mourned La Repubblica yesterday. It published graphics showing how long it took to serve a Big Mac (90 seconds) and eat it (10 minutes). Breakdowns of ingredients and calorie count (610) were accompanied by warnings from leading gourmets.

Edoardo Raspelli was sent on a field trip to McDonald's and Burger King in Milan. Having seen the future, he declared that it did not work: "It takes a big effort to imagine this food as healthy." The ambience was mechanical, the chips like cardboard and the bread poor, he said. "I found it alienating and vulgar."

Mr Raspelli appealed for diners to respect skill and effort in cooking. "To eat is to give birth," he said.

Laura Mantovano, an editor of the food magazine Gambero Rosso, urged traditional restaurants to keep their nerve and continue serving simple Mediterranean dishes based around pasta. "That has taste, vitamins and protein. And you consume it in 20 minutes, faster if you want. But in Italy it is an effort to convince the restaurants to drive out fast food with what is already there."

Encouragement came from a survey done for Salute Naturale, a health magazine, which found that 70% of Italians felt unable to do without their pasta. A third said they became nervous if deprived.

Yet traditional bars, cafes and restaurants continue to disappear. A survey by the Permanent Observatory on young people and alcohol in Rome found that 42% of young Italians consume all their drink in British or Irish-style pubs. While consumption of wine has dropped, demand for beer and spirits has shot up.

Rome's Cafe de Paris, one of the few great bars on the celebrated Via Veneto, which attracted Marcello Mastroianni, Rita Hayworth and Frank Sinatra, has been turned into a burger bar. The new managers were pilloried for adding the words "The cafe of the Dolce Vita" to its old sign.

fields.headline: Mohammad Abdur Rob
fields.standfirst: Parent power in the East End
fields.trailText: In the late 1980s, Mohammad Abdur Rob, who has died of cancer aged 57, realised that few Bangladeshi parents in London's East End were becoming school governors. So he co-founded the collective of Bangladeshi school governors. Thus were hundreds of Bangladeshi parents trained and appointed to the governing bodies of Tower Hamlets schools.
fields.body:
In the late 1980s, Mohammad Abdur Rob, who has died of cancer aged 57, realised that few Bangladeshi parents in London's East End were becoming school governors. So he co-founded the collective of Bangladeshi school governors. Thus were hundreds of Bangladeshi parents trained and appointed to the governing bodies of Tower Hamlets schools. He also founded the Chicks and Estate supplementary school, which has taught hundreds of Whitechapel children Bangla and Arabic, and the Tower Hamlets parents' centre.

Rob was part of the new East End, one of that generation of Bangladeshi immigrants who arrived in the early 1960s. He recognised that British children whose parents were from Bangladesh would need to work twice as hard and be encouraged twice as much by their teachers if they were to be successful. He also recognised the central role that the East London Mosque should play in binding the local Muslim community together.

Rob was born in Borni district, Moulvi Bazar, and studied at Sylhet College, from where he gained a teaching post, and went on to become a headmaster in his homeland. Since his teacher's qualifications were not recognised in Britain, he opened a small tailoring business here. In the early 1980s he gained British teaching qualifications and taught for a while, before becoming an estates officer.

In 1981, with his own children entering the education system, and responding to a call by the Inner London Education Authority to Bangladeshi parents, he became a governor of Thomas Buxton primary school, and later Stepney Green boys' secondary school. He served both for more than 17 years. He and other such governors successfully campaigned for trousers and hijab for girls, for a halal diet and for the Eid holiday. They also fought alongside the local authority for more school funds and against cuts.

Tower Hamlets schools have improved dramatically during the past 10 years - and Stepney Green now has the best GCSE results of any boys' secondary school in the borough. This improvement is due to a committed teaching staff, an effective local authority - and the efforts and passion of community leaders such as Rob, a quiet and gentle man whose anger with injustice was tempered by religion and humanity.

He is survived by his wife Jahanara Khanam, whom he married in 1971, three sons and two daughters.

Mohammad Abdur Rob, educationalist and community leader, born April 1 1943; died April 19 2000

fields.headline: London's new wonder
fields.standfirst: The Bankside Tate is a triumph
fields.trailText: They are polishing the floors and touching up the paintwork in the Tate Modern, Bankside, as a series of events launches this new London landmark on the world. With nearly twice the exhibition space of the old Millbank site, it is likely to become one of the capital's biggest tourist attractions.
fields.body:
They are polishing the floors and touching up the paintwork in the Tate Modern, Bankside, as a series of events launches this new London landmark on the world. With nearly twice the exhibition space of the old Millbank site, it is likely to become one of the capital's biggest tourist attractions. For the director, Nicholas Serota, it is a remarkable achievement. More than £130m has been raised; it has been completed on time, within budget, and with little of the bad publicity which dogged the Royal Opera House.

The result justifies London's claim to have become the most vibrant city for the visual arts in the world. Tate Modern will reap praise for its astonishing juxtaposition of familiar favourites like Monet, and Matisse with contemporary works, and for the striking Louise Bourgeois spider dominating the main hall. The spin-offs from its brave reinterpretation of modern art are evident all over London, as commercial galleries, such as the Lisson and White Cube2, compete to catch the eye of the world's museum curators, due to arrive in the next few days for the opening - and, not to be outdone, the Royal Academy announces its follow up to Sensations, to open in September.

None of these will come close to matching Bankside's new authority as one of the world's great art museums. Yet its gravitas is not intimidating, with terraces, cafes and riverside garden destined to teem with people. The effect of this international collection, housed in a majestic, British-designed building in a remarkable site, is breathtaking: from its galleries, the eye can roam from canvas to barges on the Thames, Wren's dome on St Paul's, the thatch of the Globe Theatre, the City and back. This is a powerful, optimistic statement about the capital - which has found sadly no reflection in the campaign culminating in today's mayoral election. It symbolises at the start of the new millennium the historical symbiosis of London's artistic creativity and its money-making.

webTitle: Who wants to live for ever?

fields.headline: Who wants to live for ever?
fields.standfirst: Scientists appear to have slowed ageing in a group of cloned calves.  Ben Rogers  assesses the implications for humankind
fields.trailText: Scientists appear to have slowed ageing in a group of cloned calves. Ben Rogers assesses the implications for humankind
fields.body:
Life expectancy in the west has increased to the extent that most of us expect to live longer than our parents, and certainly our grandparents. Yet until now we have never seriously expected to exceed what we still consider to be life's natural parameters, the limit of 80 or 90 years that was recognised as achievable but unsurpassable except by a very few.

The news last week, however, that US scientists had cloned six calves with chromosomes which appear, for reasons not quite understood, to be ageing more slowly than is normal, seems to open up the possibility of extending life beyond natural limits.

The breakthrough may at least make it possible to replace old or faulty organs and tissues with new ones that will age more slowly. Beyond that, the technology might offer ways of slowing the rate at which our bodies age.

This is likely to leave us feeling a little uncertain. The revelation that scientists in Scotland had cloned a sheep created a furore, but the ethical significance was, perhaps, a little exaggerated. Nature, after all, already produces clones in the plant world: strawberries, for example.

This latest development, however, conjures up weird possibilities: octogenarians with the bodies of Olympic athletes; generations in which someone's children and great grandchildren grow up together.

In fact, our attitude to the idea of eternal, or at least greatly extended, life has long been ambivalent. Many religions and perhaps the majority of philosophers have promised it, and some of us still appear to long for it, especially if it means not having to lose people we love.

Yet the Daily Mail was merely echoing a long tradition of religious and secular moralists when it warned last week of hubris in trying to achieve immortality here on earth. (Oscar Wilde's The Picture of Dorian Gray is, in part, a cautionary tale on just this theme). And some religions, such as Buddhism, and a few philosophers, such as Schopenhauer, have viewed death as a fate devoutly to be wished for.

There is, of course, a great difference between something becoming practical and actually practised. Most people who can afford face-lifts and nose-jobs still don't have them. Nevertheless, while it's hard to imagine that the practice of cloning oneself will ever become widespread, the enticement of a prolonged youth might prove hard to resist. Nor, contra the Mail, would the decision to extend one's life, or that of one's children, necessarily convict one of immaturity, narcissism or hubris.

It is true that such a life would be less "natural", but there might be something a little life-denying in refusing to extend life at all. We go to extraordinary lengths to safeguard human life, but if existence is so valuable why not prolong it? Most of us complain of the pressures of modern life - of not having enough time to work and bring up the children, or work and play - so why not avail oneself of a little extra time?

Perhaps we will witness a gradual extension of life's "natural" length, from generation to generation, as each finds it likes it enough, or thinks it important enough, to want it to go on just a few years more.

Yet one thing seems certain. It is unlikely that any but a mad minority would want to go on living endlessly. Life without the prospect of death would lose its intensity, its shape, its meaning. Eternal life would, if you think about it, be a pretty pointless, empty thing. Nothing would seem important. Last week's news has profound implications. It might even teach us to recognise more clearly the value of death.

 Ben Rogers' AJ Ayer, A Life, published by Vintage at £8.99, is out in paperback this week.

fields.headline: Henry Daniels
fields.standfirst: The maths of textiles and timekeeping
fields.trailText: Henry Daniels, who has died aged 87, was a key figure in the development of statistical theory, practice and teaching in this country. He was an independent thinker with a natural mathematical and physical bent, whose early experience in the textile industry introduced him to fundamental problems which he studied throughout his life.
fields.body:
Henry Daniels, who has died aged 87, was a key figure in the development of statistical theory, practice and teaching in this country. He was an independent thinker with a natural mathematical and physical bent, whose early experience in the textile industry introduced him to fundamental problems which he studied throughout his life.

After university at Edinburgh and Cambridge, Daniels found his first employment at the wool industries research association (Wira) in Leeds. He worked there from 1935-46 with a wartime period at the ministry of aircraft production, where, as scientific officer, he specialised in position finding.

The period at Wira was probably the most formative of Daniels' career. His paper on the strength of bundles of threads (in which failure in one thread may be propagated through the bundle or may be arrested) laid the acknowledged basis for the study of composite and directed materials today, and "Daniels systems" bear his name. Likewise, his study of "stiff chains" provided an early study of the shape of polymer molecules. The methods he used for these problems were ones which he later applied in other contexts, for example in the treatment of mathematical models of epidemics and of the wave of advance of an advantageous gene.

Wira's laboratory nature gave full play to Daniels' mechanical bent; between mathematics he ran the fibre measurement laboratory and invented apparatus for it.

He returned to academic life in 1947, when he joined what was to become the statistical laboratory at the University of Cambridge. In an exciting pioneering atmosphere, he helped establish the group which came to set the standards for statistical research and teaching. Its very success brought about its dispersal, as in a bursting seed-head. In Henry's own case, that led to his appointment as the first professor of mathematical statistics at the University of Birmingham in 1957. He remained there until his retirement in 1978, returning to live in Cambridge until his death.

Daniels' other interests were mechanical and musical, somewhat combined. He was an expert watch-repairer and cooperated with a namesake, George Daniels, the doyen of British watchmakers. George was designing a very ambitious watch, one which would show both sidereal (stellar) and solar time, but the physical constraints on the gears meant that he could not achieve an accuracy of better than seven seconds per year. Henry used his mathematics and found three ways of attaining an accuracy of half a second per year.

He had a collection of musical instruments, but principally played the English concertina, which sounds as though it should be a folk instrument, but was designed on rational principles by the scientist Charles Wheatstone. It was in fact intended to take the viola part in chamber music, and Daniels dedicated himself to the fulfilment of this intention.

His ever-present sense of humour could vary from the impish to the dismissively sardonic; his many friends enjoyed the one and weathered the other. Always regarded with respect and affection by his colleagues, he became with time a treasured icon. He died while attending an annual event he much enjoyed, a conference at Gregynog, Powys.

Professor Daniels, president of the Royal Statistical Society for 1974-75, was awarded its Guy Medal in silver in 1957 and in gold in 1984. He was elected a fellow of the Royal Society in 1980. He valued at least equally the honour of being created a Liveryman of the Worshipful Company of Clockmakers in 1984, a recognition of his contributions to watch design.

He is survived by his wife Barbara and two children.

webTitle: Short blames OECD for lowest UK aid figures

fields.headline: Short blames OECD for lowest UK aid figures
fields.trailText: Britain last year donated a smaller slice of its income to overseas aid than at any previous time due to a series of one-off factors driving down spending, the government will announce today.
fields.body:
Britain last year donated a smaller slice of its income to overseas aid than at any previous time due to a series of one-off factors driving down spending, the government will announce today.

Figures from the department for international development show the UK aid budget dropping from £2.332bn in 1998 to £2.026bn in 1999.

As a percentage of gross national product, overseas development assistance last year stood at 0.23%, compared to 0.27% the previous year and 0.26% in 1997 - the last year of the Tory government.

The data is being submitted to the development assistance committee, or DAC, of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development - the Paris-based think tank that monitors how rich nations are shaping up against the UN target of spending 0.7% of their annual income on aid.

Clare Short, the international development secretary, said the figures did not reflect the hefty 8.5% increase in UK spending on developing countries and were the result of a series of statistical quirks.

"I'm very proud of the fact that this year saw the biggest ever increase in the British aid programme, and it is a mad anomaly that the way the DAC collects the figures by calendar year is showing such a low figure. It's not a real problem, it's a technical glitch. The figure will be way up next year."

Labour pledged to reverse the decline in the aid budget as a share of output so it reaches 0.3% by the end of this parliament. Ms Short said the target would be achieved in the 2001-02 financial year. The DfID said spending was artificially depressed by £432m last year.

This included £81m spent on Kosovo, which was only accounted for early this year, thus missing the cut-off for the DAC calculations which are based on calendar years.

In addition, a £133m payment to the World Bank was brought forward from last year to late 1998, while £30m to the African Development Bank was held up until 2000.

fields.standfirst:
Judges and lawyers on the benches

Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: Lord Sutherland, Presiding Judge Ranald Sutherland QC, 68, is one of the most experienced judges on the Scottish legal circuit. He was appointed to the bench in 1985 and has been an advocate, the Scottish equivalent of a barrister, since 1956. He frequently takes charge of the court of criminal appeal in Scotland and is used to high-profile cases.
fields.body:
Lord Sutherland, Presiding Judge Ranald Sutherland QC, 68, is one of the most experienced judges on the Scottish legal circuit. He was appointed to the bench in 1985 and has been an advocate, the Scottish equivalent of a barrister, since 1956. He frequently takes charge of the court of criminal appeal in Scotland and is used to high-profile cases.

Lord Coulsfield John Cameron QC, 66, was appointed to the bench in 1987 and first became an advocate in 1960. He took silk in 1973 and has had a long and varied career. He has lectured in law at Edinburgh University and was a judge in the courts of appeal of Jersey and Guernsey.

Lord MacLean Ranald MacLean QC, 61, is the newest of the judges to the Scottish bench. He was appointed to the bench in 1990, although he has been an advocate since 1964. In his advocate days he was most often a prosecutor.

William Taylor QC, Counsel for Al Megrahi Since the early 1980s, Bill Taylor has been one of the most prominent of Scotland's defence QCs. He has won a string of high-profile cases, helped by his good courtroom voice and what is generally regarded to be an extremely agile mind.

Richard Keen QC, Counsel for Fhimah Richard Keen's courtroom gifts are every bit as prominent as those of Bill Taylor. However his relative lack of experience in criminal cases made him, for many, a surprise choice as Fhimah's counsel.

The Lord Advocate, Colin Boyd QC Since Lord Hardie unexpectedly stepped down at the start of this year, Colin Boyd has led the prosecution team. As the former solicitor general for Scotland, he knows the case well. However, it is widely believed he will hand over the main prosecution role to one of his junior counsels - Alastair Campbell QC and Alan Turnbull QC - when the trial gets under way in earnest.

fields.headline: Fashion victims
fields.trailText: Something happened to TV fashion about eight years ago. Up till then it was a rather blowsy, mumsy affair, with snide sideways glances at what those nutters on the Milan catwalks were trying to force us into this season (for a curious survival of this kind of fashion journalism, see the rear pages of Hello!).
fields.body:
Something happened to TV fashion about eight years ago. Up till then it was a rather blowsy, mumsy affair, with snide sideways glances at what those nutters on the Milan catwalks were trying to force us into this season (for a curious survival of this kind of fashion journalism, see the rear pages of Hello!). Then along came Absolutely Fabulous, proving to discerning audiences the world over that fashion may well be completely ridiculous, but hey, it was funny too! Two painful years of people saying "Lacroix, darling, Lacroix" followed, and suddenly The Clothes Show looked very frumpy indeed.

Now, all these years later, TV fashion pundits still struggle to get the right mix of insider savvy and mainstream wearability. More often than not, BBC2's Looking Good misses, but Channel 4's She's Gotta Have It has proved to be a dependable standard, the broadcasting equivalent of a petite robe noire that'll take any amount of accessorising. Presenters and experts may come and go, but the basic model retains an enduring chic, largely because it stays firmly rooted in the British high street rather than disappearing up some designer's blanket-stitched fundament. There's nothing like your average British shopper to keep things real.

Last night She's Gotta Have It added one more to the seemingly endless roster of TV awards shows with its Top Of The Shops special, a light-hearted hour that collated viewer votes in various categories to find out who's winning the high-street war. While the collective impact may not seriously detract attention from, say, today's mayoral elections, there were enough friendly celebrity faces to keep things pepping along, and given that the other channels fielded a particularly diabolical prime-time schedule, it was a question of enjoy or switch off.

Jayne Middlemiss, a woman who knows how to carry off an outfit, swanned around a few shopping arcades introducing the categories, and it was comforting to discover that outside the Top Of The Pops studio she actually speaks English rather than the glottal Slavic dialect that she seems to reserve for that gig. Patsy Palmer bought an entire new outfit for £50 (that much!) and concluded (as if we didn't all know) that you really can't beat Top Shop when it comes to cheap glamour. Thenceforth the entire show turned into a kind of unofficial advert for Top Shop - or "To' Sho'" as nervous fashionistas allegedly call it. Little doubt, then, that even as you read this, there will be a mad rush to your nearest branch - the best all-round shopping experience, according to She's Gotta Have It viewers.

Lisa and Claire from Steps talked about shoes, and revealed that H sometimes walks around at home barefoot (yes, it was that kind of show). Dermot O'Leary claimed that men hate clothes shopping and would rather wear the same pair of denims until they've fallen apart. Has he actually been to the West End of London recently? Men in the provinces may choose to look like tramps, darling, but London boys can outshop the fairer sex any day of the week, and still have the energy to drink heavily and go out dancing all night.

Jennifer (Laurie Metcalfe), the madrigal-singing English professor in Third Rock From The Sun (BBC2), modelled some truly hideous ruffled collars and smock dresses in the first episode of the returning sitcom, proving that she could not possibly be the right woman for Dick (John Lithgow). Mary (Jane Curtin), on the other hand, bounded around in mannish designer duds, seemingly a sure-fire way to an alien's heart. Otherwise, Third Rock sloshed around in the usual sitcom mire of relationships, at the end of which the Solomons learned something about honesty. Time was when Third Rock was a breath of fresh air, a satire on American TV, a little subversive, even. Now back for its umpteenth series, it's run out of ideas. John Lithgow and Kristen Johnson still mug appealingly, but the thrill has gone. French Stewart as Harry seems to be stuck with just one facial expression and a dearth of decent lines. No reference was made to the Solomons actually being aliens - they just seemed like a more than usually cretinous comedy family. Perhaps things'll spark up later in the series, but on this showing it joins the ranks of American shows that should have been killed off while they were still funny.

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: The Avengers | Cry-Baby | Night On Earth | Desperate Measures
fields.body:
The Avengers (Jeremiah Chechik, 1998)
8pm, Sky Premier

Sadly flat Hollywood version of the bubbly TV series, though there are things to enjoy: Sean Connery's evil weatherman Sir August de Wynter (geddit?) holding the British climate to ransom, and Stuart Craig's design - a surreal blend of the 60s and 90s. But while Ralph Fiennes makes a decently furled umbrella of John Steed, Uma Thurman's cat-suited Emma Peel lacks claws. The fleeting presence of Patrick Macnee, the original Steed, is another reminder of what a classy, charming act the small screen version was.

Cry-Baby (John Waters, 1990)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Teen idol Johnny Depp dropped his good guy officer act on hit TV series 21 Jump Street to gain some cool cred as leather-clad lawbreaker Wade "Cry-Baby" Walker in this, the Sultan of Sleaze's song-strewn follow-up to Hairspray. Set in 1954 Baltimore, it's the rock'n'roll story of a prissy "square" (Amy Locane) who falls for the juvenile delinquent, nicknamed for his tear-stained cheek, when he introduces her to life on the wild side and his gang of "drapes".

Night On Earth (Jim Jarmusch, 1991)
10.10pm, FilmFour

A night in the lives of five cab drivers and their passengers: much of human life is there. LA cabbie Wynona Ryder is first away, talking movies with casting agent Gena Rowlands; in New York, Rome, Paris and Helsinki other taxi tales both strange and sad are interwoven. A mellow, moving comedy from the director whose enigmatic thriller, Ghost Dog: The Way of the Samurai, is now on release.

Desperate Measures (Barbet Schroeder, 1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

Another locked-up baddy reminiscent of Hannibal the Cannibal. Michael Keaton's multiple murderer McCabe is incredibly devious, intelligent, and pain-resistant, dislocating and replacing his thumb at will as part of his escape attempt. Thing is, tough cop Andy Garcia needs McCabe's bone marrow to save his sick son, and has to get him back before the rest of the force kills him. The clunking plot is almost rescued by the scenery-chewing performances and Schroeder's slick direction.

fields.headline: Step into another world
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle is disturbed, frightened and mesmerised by the biggest and best show of film and video art the UK has ever seen
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle is disturbed, frightened and mesmerised by the biggest and best show of film and video art the UK has ever seen
fields.body:
Since the 60s, film and video have become familiar media for artists. Go into any major art school and you'll find as many students working with video cameras as there are chasing oil paint around a canvas with a hairy stick. The suspicion is, of course, that anyone who grew up with TV can make a half-decent video, while painting and sculpture take time, struggle and application. Wrong: making art is a state of mind, never mind the medium.

With next week's opening of Tate Modern, London is gearing up for the arrival of the world's big-time museum directors, hot-shot curators and megabucks collectors, and the capital's commercial galleries are pulling out the stops to attract money and attention. The Lisson Gallery has taken over all five floors of a loft-style building in Covent Garden, filling 25,000 square feet of blacked-out emptiness with video and film work by 15 artists. This is the largest and best presented survey of such works ever seen in this country. No institution here - public or private - has ever attempted such an exhibition on this scale, nor cadged the space to do it properly. You wonder why not.

The show opens with a come-hither performance, shown on a monitor, staged by Vanessa Beecroft. Beecroft is best known for staging sexy catwalk performances in galleries, and she is providing the first show for the Gagosian Gallery, opening its doors in London next week. Beecroft has a glamorous model go through a routine of cliched poses. The Lisson may as well have employed a professional greeter. But it is a clever opening. Wander into the dark round the corner and there's a naked guy called Rocky, a hollow-chested, weak-kneed pugilist in a rubber mask and boxing gloves, belting himself to a punch-drunk pulp. Muttering, grunting and flailing about, this wretched, one-man orgy of abuse slathers jam over himself between rounds. The camera goes up close and all too personal. His bottom is all gooey and his willy does a miniature can-can as he lunges around. This is ghastly, frightening. This is Paul McCarthy.

McCarthy is one of the father-figures of contemporary video art, an inspiration and a stumbling-block for younger artists. Stumbling is the word - Rocky is a cruel, self-punishing and ultimately tragic work about masculinity, so filled with raging impotence and despairing testosterone that it has never been shown since it was made in 1976. A quarter century old, the piece could have been made yesterday, and it makes a lot of current younger British video art look pretty thin.

How about some real death, then? Douglas Gordon shows us the big-screen death of a fly. Super-glued to the spot, the fly elicits horror and empathy. Deeper in the darkness, Tony Oursler's giant eyeball is watching TV. You can see the screen reflected in the disembodied eyeball, itself a projection onto a free-standing orb. When the eye blinks, it is like a clam opening and closing.

Here, for perhaps the first time in Britain, we begin to get the measure of the medium, and how works, sensibilities, and generations of artists can have a dialogue. There are works which court outrage, are full of humour, which come close to pop-promo video, to pornography, to commercial film and TV. Others can only exist in the terms of the situation for which they were made.

A bell tolls on the second floor, the soundtrack to Belgian artist Francis Alÿs's 1997 Cuentos Patrióticos (Patriotic Tales), a film of a lone shepherd leading sheep around a flagpole in a public square. With each slow circuit of the pole, another sheep joins the flock. This is a mesmerising and beautiful video, filmed, like many of the artist's works, in Mexico. The shadow cast by the pole never moves, the shepherd follows his own steps exactly, and it slowly becomes apparent that each circuit is the same circuit, all the sheep the same sheep, digitally tweaked into a flock. The pace and enigma are perfect, the politics sly. If You Are a Typical Spectator, What You Are Really Doing is Waiting for the Accident to Happen" is the title of a second work here by Alÿs. I carry the words with me, a warning to critics everywhere.

Further up the building, fog drifts over the sea and over New York, in Igor and Svetlana Kopystiansky's new film, Fog. This is New York weather seen by two artists who left Moscow in the 70s, bringing their Russian lugubriousness with them. The fog rolls in on two screens. Watching one, you can't see the other. You turn and turn again, staring into the lustrous gloom for a break in the weather.

A lot of video and film work presents us with the dichotomy between being here - in this space, watching these images - and entering the fictive world presented on the screen. One of the best juxtapositions is the cinema-like presentation and commercial production values of Rodney Graham's Vexation Island (a work better known by reputation and the critical attention it has been given since its Venice Biennale premier in 1997), with Pierre Bismuth's Alternance, which fills a long wall with four abutted projections of a Paris street scene. Alternance almost demands that we walk alongside it, as though we ourselves were in that little square on the Left Bank. Mingling actors with passers-by, Bismuth repeats and repeats the same ordinary moments, in which people wait, are met, go about their daily lives. I feel as if I am on that street, walking through a moment of perpetual repetition and slippage, about to meet myself, like Dostoevsky's Double, adrift in Paris.

So it is for Graham's shipwrecked sailor, stranded on the beach with a squawking parrot while the surf thunders over the reef. This is RM Ballantyne's Coral Island revisited, but it is also a conundrum, a time-loop that makes us question beginnings and endings and narrative drive. It is a kind of fateful philosophical joke, and I could watch it all day.

For rather different reasons, I could also watch Juliao Sarmento's Faces longer than I ought. The camera watches two women, who eventually kiss. Sarmento made the film in 1976; the colour has since decayed into flaring magentas and raw reds, bleach-outs and grainy pulsations. This work belongs with Bismuth and Graham, in that it is about delay, withholding and has a disturbing acuity. Over time, the film has achieved a kind of porno-patina. Although better known as a painter, Sarmento's super-8 films describe the same psychological space as in his paintings. It is important to realise that hierarchies of media have irretrievably broken down. But it doesn't mean that values have ceased to prevail, that anything is as good, or bad, as everything else.

This is a great if uneven show. It includes works shown for the first time, including some ill-judged works by Mat Collishaw, along with works such as Jane and Louise Wilson's 1995 Crawl Space, which stands up extremely well. Flashy new technology guarantees nothing, while the use of the good old film loop, in Jonathan Monk's animation of the images in a catalogue of 100 cubes by Sol LeWitt, reminded me that 70s structuralist film-making really did a lot of the spadework in clearing new territory. It also makes you realise that movies are flicker-books. This is by no means a definitive show, and it certainly isn't a history show - there's no Bruce Nauman, no Warhol, no Vito Acconci - but it is a defining moment.

Up on the top floor, there is daylight once again, mirrored walls and the name Bruce Lee in free-standing Hollywood sign lettering. The soundtrack to the movie Enter the Dragon blasts the space. Simon Patterson's installation is about the movies, but it isn't a movie. Carlos Pazos did a much better installation on the theme of stardom, in Valencia, almost a decade ago. History and context matter, I thought, stumbling down the stairs, but so does space, room to breathe and to make your own connections. Who is Bruce Lee anyway? Where's Rocky? From now on, no one should put up with the paltriness of most survey or thematic shows dealing with video and film. More dark! More dark!

 Video Work is at Lisson Gallery in Covent Garden, London WC2, till May 26. Details: 020-7724 2739.

A lot of video and film work presents us with the dichotomy between being here - in this space, watching these images - and entering the fictive world presented on the screen. One of the best juxtapositions is the cinema-like presentation and commercial production values of Rodney Graham's Vexation Island (a work better known by reputation and the critical attention it has been given since its Venice Biennale premier in 1997), with Pierre Bismuth's Alternance, which fills a long wall with four abutted projections of a Paris street scene. Alternance almost demands that we walk alongside it, as though we ourselves were in that little square on the Left Bank. Mingling actors with passers-by, Bismuth repeats and repeats the same ordinary moments, in which people wait, are met, go about their daily lives. I feel as if I am on that street, walking through a moment of perpetual repetition and slippage, about to meet myself, like Dostoevsky's Double, adrift in Paris. So it is for Graham's shipwrecked sailor, stranded on the beach with a squawking parrot while the surf thunders over the reef. This is RM Ballantyne's Coral Island revisited, but it is also a conundrum, a time-loop that makes us question beginnings and endings and narrative drive. It is a kind of fateful philosophical joke, and I could watch it all day. For rather different reasons, I could also watch Juliao Sarmento's Faces longer than I ought. The camera watches two women, who eventually kiss. Sarmento made the film in 1976; the colour has since decayed into flaring magentas and raw reds, bleach-outs and grainy pulsations. This work belongs with Bismuth and Graham, in that it is about delay, withholding and has a disturbing acuity. Over time, the film has achieved a kind of porno-patina. Although better known as a painter, Sarmento's super-8 films describe the same psychological space as in his paintings. It is important to realise that hierarchies of media have irretrievably broken down. But it doesn't mean that values have ceased to prevail, that anything is as good, or bad, as everything else. This is a great if uneven show. It includes works shown for the first time, including some ill-judged works by Mat Collishaw, along with works such as Jane and Louise Wilson's 1995 Crawl Space, which stands up extremely well. Flashy new technology guarantees nothing, while the use of the good old film loop, in Jonathan Monk's animation of the images in a catalogue of 100 cubes by Sol LeWitt, reminded me that 70s structuralist film-making really did a lot of the spadework in clearing new territory. It also makes you realise that movies are flicker-books. This is by no means a definitive show, and it certainly isn't a history show - there's no Bruce Nauman, no Warhol, no Vito Acconci - but it is a defining moment. Up on the top floor, there is daylight once again, mirrored walls and the name Bruce Lee in free-standing Hollywood sign lettering. The soundtrack to the movie Enter the Dragon blasts the space. Simon Patterson's installation is about the movies, but it isn't a movie. Carlos Pazos did a much better installation on the theme of stardom, in Valencia, almost a decade ago. History and context matter, I thought, stumbling down the stairs, but so does space, room to breathe and to make your own connections. Who is Bruce Lee anyway? Where's Rocky? From now on, no one should put up with the paltriness of most survey or thematic shows dealing with video and film. More dark! More dark!  Video Work is at Lisson Gallery in Covent Garden, London WC2, till May 26. Details: 020-7724 2739.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Law In Action | Painting The Rainbow
fields.body:
Marcel Berlins starts the new season of Law In Action (4.0pm, Radio 4) with a report on American firearms. He visits a high school class in Brooklyn whose teacher was wounded during a mugging. Though Clinton's firearms policy seems reassuring, a Virginian women's group says that its members are never likely to abandon their weapons.

Ten years after Nelson Mandela's release from prison Julian O'Halloran gives a gripping account of the three-year secret negotiations to end apartheid. Painting The Rainbow (8.0pm, Radio 4) reveals how a Consolidated Goldfields director wangled himself into a party for ANC leaders at Anthony Sampson's house in 1986. Within days the firm had agreed to sponsor peace talks. Neil Barnard, director general of South African intelligence, soon heard about them but, instead of blowing the whistle, opened arms-length discussions with Thabo Mbeke.

webTitle: Farewell, dumb blonde and Essex girl

fields.headline: Farewell, dumb blonde and Essex girl
fields.standfirst: Use those words in an email, mister, and there'll be trouble...  Louisa Young explains why
fields.trailText: Use those words in an email, mister, and there'll be trouble...  Louisa Young explains why
fields.body:
Here's a poser. What do the words legs and equality have in common? Stuck? What if I add thick, and easy? Don't spend too much time on it. The answer becomes clearer when I give you some more from the list: lesbian, tart, sexy, dumb, arse.

Ah yes, now we're getting there. All these words are, according to business consultants Peapod UK, potentially sexist. It was revealed yesterday that the company is offering a service whereby employees' outgoing email can be scanned for potentially "offensive" terms: sexist or racist. The reason for doing this is not basic nosiness, prurience or nannying, nor to make the world a better place, but to protect employers from the charge of allowing a hostile working environment, which has become a popular tool at tribunals. When people can claim up to £50,000 for unfair dismissal, the anxieties of employers are easy to recognise. Local authorities, law firms, a government department and a university are signing up. The system works like this. Each suspect word or phrase gets a score: 30 points for Essex girl, 30 for dumb blonde, 20 for in the buff, 15 for blondie, 10 for lesbian, 5 for legs. The scanner picks up on the words, scores them and, if the overall score in a message is too high, it alerts a manager.

So God help the furniture designer concerned about the equality of thickness of his table legs and how easy it's going to be to get them in the van. Or anyone arsing about with an apple tart in their lunchbreak. We've already heard about the ornithologist getting into trouble with his Great Tits.

God help anyone with the natural British inclination towards the friendly insult, where bitch can be a term of affection. God help the journalist doing a piece on Elizabeth Wurtzel (author of The Bitch Rules) or Deborah Harry (formerly of Blondie), or the fashion stylist requesting the new Betty Jackson sweater in the taupe and in the buff, or the persecuted office junior emailing her friend about the horrid things her boss says - oh, it goes on.

Very few words are inherently sexist. Legs and equality at the top of this piece didn't start to look like a gender-political issue till I added thick, easy, lesbian and tart, did they? Context, and the intention of the writer, make them so. We all know this, surely. But we are humans with human brains, and clever as computers are, it seems they still cannot read context and human intention.

I feel for these words, innocent words judged grubby by a machine. It's not fair on them. Poor easy, that it becomes so limited and guilty in the mind of a computer. Blondie has often been aimed my way as a term of affection. I rather like it. Poor legs - we've all got them, they're nice, they walk us around the place. (Whoops, I just used "nice legs".)

It's not the computer programme's fault that pea-brains use these words in a sexist way, but it does seem to me that if bits of software have minds at all, they have the hopelessly innocent-yet-dirty minds of eight-year-olds, always getting it wrong. There's the apocryphal tale of a newspaper piece about Denis Thatcher about a million years ago - the spellcheck didn't recognise Denis, so changed it to Penis all the way through.

The most curious inclusion in this list, though, is equality. Why and how can equality be a bad word? Equality as in "That old cow, she's always banging on about equality"? It seems a hard price to pay for the word that is, you'd have thought, the whole point of anti-sexism and anti-racism; a word central to many reasonable discussions and the progress of human civilisation. A heroic, battle-scarred word, you'd have thought. Yet here it is, banded together with "dumb blonde" and branded potentially undesirable.

But this system is not about protecting equality, or even people's feelings. It's about protecting employers' backs from accusations of allowing offensive messages to move freely. (Offensive to whom, they don't say. Presumably people don't generally go sending "Look at the tits on that" messages to people from whom they would not expect a positive reaction.) But if Joe Colleague is emailing his opinions of Jane Colleague's breasts, is that any worse - for her - than his airing those opinions in the pub? The only difference is for the employer: when Jane comes to sue, an email could be produced as some kind of evidence, though given how very fakeable they are, even that is doubtful.

If anyone were serious about identifying sexism in office life, what they should look out for is those words that are patently sexist, yet widely accepted. Stand forward, totty: a term that portrays women as some great pile of non-individual stuff from which sniggering, puerile men help themselves, a word that is dispiritingly insulting to men and to women. Make the t-word unacceptable for a start and the world would be a better place. (Score: 540. Shocking! I shall call myself in and have strict words with myself.)

fields.headline: Talking dirty
fields.body:
 "The only problem I have got with Linda McCartney is that I never met her to say what a wonderful job she did with her man"
- Heather Mills, who is dating Paul McCartney, Sun

 "I'll be the first to tell you. Fifteen minutes of fame - not worth it. I have been poor and gotten money, been nobody and become somebody. You know what? I just want to do my job, take care of my kids"
- Erin Brockovich, Express

 "Britney Spears heads a flock of the music world's gorgeous young women at the Capital FM awards"
- Hello! gives the birds a big hand

 "I think that if you've got the right to vote it should be used. You shouldn't toss votes into the gutter - it's been too long fought for, especially for women"
- Novelist Margaret Forster on the mayoral election, Evening Standard

 "I'm going to vote for Steve Norris. Ken's a joke, I'd never vote for anyone with a beard and no one's heard of Mrs Kramer. I saw Emma Norris, Steve's new bride, eating lunch the other day and I thought she looked like quite a dish. She'd make a great mayoress"
- Nicholas Coleridge, British managing director of Condé Nast magazines, reveals the direction in which he'll toss his vote, Evening Standard

 "Women do it all rather than have it all. Men will be the new women only when they assume our elevated position. Contrary to the propaganda that 'It's all gone too far', women's position is this: fewer than 20% of executives are women. Women who work full-time earn on average only 80% of the hourly wage paid to men. Four out of five women with families still do most of the housework. And 45% of women have an individual income of less than £100 a week, compared with 20% of men"
- Suzanne Moore, Red

 "Every man enjoys feeling the power he has when it comes to sex. That's not a macho thing - but generally women expect men to be the aggressor in bed, although there are pleasant exceptions"
- Antonio Banderas, Hello!

 "Mind your own fucking business, ha ha. I'm a woman, at the end of the day, and don't wish to discuss things like that. You've got to have a bit of mystique about yourself"
- Kathy Burke on being asked about losing her virginity, FHM

 "You don't have to be a teenager to be sexy. The girls today are bones without muscles. They will be dogs by the time they are 29"
- Lauren Hutton, Sun

fields.headline: The good guy
fields.standfirst: If you think of Jerry Springer as your brash, trouble-making cousin then Maury Povich is best described as your doting uncle.  Lucy Barrick  meets the man who's trying to rescue US television from its own worst excesses
fields.trailText: If you think of Jerry Springer as your brash, trouble-making cousin then Maury Povich is best described as your doting uncle. Lucy Barrick meets the man who's trying to rescue US television from its own worst excesses
fields.body:
The daytime US talk show, as anyone with too much time on their hands will testify, is a deeply disturbing phenomenon, packed with celebrities and criminals, perverts and psychologists, all in equal measure. Against a backdrop of the American obsession with self-improvement and dirty laundry, the single-name hosts - Oprah, Jerry, Ricki, Jenny - make a nice living out of the misery and misfortune of others, while their audiences scream and whoop.

But there is an alternative, in the patrician form of former newsman Maury Povich. If Jerry Springer is the (self-proclaimed) ringmaster of his own sleazy circus, Povich is the kindly uncle who's there to make sure the kids get home safely afterwards.

After deciding not to follow in his journalist father's footsteps - "I knew I could never rival him" - Povich started out as an anchorman before turning to talk nine years ago. Povich Snr, he recalls, thought young Maury was perfectly suited to a TV career because he suffered from "what he called 'Big Shot-itis'...

"I definitely use the values I learned from my father," Povich exclaims. "My sense of fairness, honesty and truthfulness all came from him." But hang on, isn't all this talk of values and honesty somewhat at odds with Jerry Springer and his ilk? What's the moral message in the endless retinue of porn stars and educationally subnormal exhibitionists that fills those stages?

Povich - who simply says of his rivals' shows: "I don't watch them a lot" - claims he's more concerned with covering "family issues, the things that really interest me". Things, for example, like sending delinquent adolescents to boot camp, dissuading young girls from getting pregnant, or letting children confront their mothers about their outrageous behaviour. "As parents," remarks Povich - who has a four-year-old child with newscaster Connie Chung - "I think we're out there looking for the same answers that all parents are looking for."

According to the man himself, it's simply the recognition of his own foibles which took him away from traditional news journalism. "I became very frustrated. You're taught to be an observer, and I always got caught up in the stories too much." So a talk show enabled the caring, sharing, freshly surnameless Maury to "get more involved, to bring different viewpoints, maybe even my own viewpoint, to bear". And as well as being unashamedly tactile with his guests - "I've wiped away a few tears" - he isn't afraid of getting personally involved in the topics he covers. The subjects of adoption and children with Tourette's Syndrome are particularly close to his heart (he really does do a lot of good work for charity); his motivation, he says, is "a picture I have in my head of a kid going to school and getting teased unmercifully for something they can't control. I just hate it". Is that the voice of a 61-year-old bullied kid we can hear? "No. I was never bullied, but I was never a bully. If we can only make people realise how destructive it is, they might think twice."

But if you want destructive, you should look at the majority of US talk shows. Accused (justifiably in most cases) of parading dysfunctional people like freaks for cheap entertainment, the consequences were highlighted last year when the producers of the Jenny Jones show were forced to pay out $25 million to the family of a gay man who appeared on the show to reveal his desire for a straight man: a straight man who subsequently murdered him. So, what does a conscience-led liberal like Maury do to distance himself from the goings-on of the competition?

"We don't just forget people when the show ends," he explains. "We have an obligation - if we bring these very personal and intimate stories on the air, we owe it to the guests, and our audience, to follow up with people to see how they get on." He admits that anger and confrontation are an integral part of the show ("you do want the rage to come out because it's part of their lives") - so why does his show never seem to descend into violence? He looks momentarily pained.

"It does break out but I just won't air it. I hate it. On the Teen Paternity Test shows especially, when these guys find out they are the fathers of these kids, sometimes all hell breaks lose. Believe me, there's some classic out-takes where I've actually dived in between people to break up fights."

The anti-Jerry Springer indeed. So, what does he really make of his nemesis? A certain measured use of language follows...

"Well... that's just a whole different show. I mean, it's theatre with Jerry and he makes no bones about it." And, while Springer once did a show about a man who married a horse, Maury still has some taboos. "I wouldn't do a show on incest. I'm not big on doing shows on religion. And Sally [Jessy Raphaël] used to do a show about women with huge breasts, and I mean huge. I could never do that."

He returns to Springer. "You know, he does all that stuff, but I don't think he ever pretends to be anything different from what he is. That's just how he does things." He leaves a very long pause - long enough, in fact, to figure out that it's just not the way Maury Povich would do things.

 Maury Povich, weekdays, 11.40am & 4.40pm, Living

fields.headline: Mount Athos
fields.trailText: Appearance: Rocky Greek outpost, a popular destination for those seeking to abandon the stresses of daily life and find spiritual enlightenment.
fields.body:
Appearance: Rocky Greek outpost, a popular destination for those seeking to abandon the stresses of daily life and find spiritual enlightenment.

I see, Mount Athos Uncovered. This is no Ayia Napa. There's no clubbing here. No women either, come to think of it.

No women? They're not allowed within 550 yards of the place.

So who would want to go there? Prince Charles.

Without Camilla? He's currently escaping the daily grind for a week in a monastery on the peninsula, contemplating the new millennium.

In May? Look, he's been busy. Besides, Greece can be pretty cold in winter.

I thought a pilgrimage was supposed to involve a spot of hardship. Greek Orthodoxy isn't so puritanical, it seems; a pilgrimage is more to do with what you do once you arrive than how you get there.

How did Charles get there? On a luxury yacht, the Alexander, lent by the Greek tycoon John Latsis.

Hope he'll take a more spartan approach once he arrives, then. The Vatopedi monastery, where Charles will reside for the next few nights, has spectacular views over the Aegean Sea, and the monks refuse all payment for their hospitality. But in the hierarchy of 20 monasteries on Mount Athos, Vatopedi has been stuck in second place for more than 1,000 years, or perhaps I should say millennium, behind the indomitable mother church, Grand Lavra. Charles will feel right at home. Oh, there's plenty more to help him settle in. There are bound to be schooldays reminiscences when it's all boys together in the dorm. Then there are the tales of Prince Philip's visit to the mountain (royal aides were no doubt grateful for the ban on video cameras). And, of course, there's the famous Byzantine architecture.

Do say: "This monstrous carbuncle is disturbing my contemplation."

fields.bodyText: Appearance: Rocky Greek outpost, a popular destination for those seeking to abandon the stresses of daily life and find spiritual enlightenment. I see, Mount Athos Uncovered. This is no Ayia Napa. There's no clubbing here. No women either, come to think of it. No women? They're not allowed within 550 yards of the place. So who would want to go there? Prince Charles. Without Camilla? He's currently escaping the daily grind for a week in a monastery on the peninsula, contemplating the new millennium. In May? Look, he's been busy. Besides, Greece can be pretty cold in winter. I thought a pilgrimage was supposed to involve a spot of hardship. Greek Orthodoxy isn't so puritanical, it seems; a pilgrimage is more to do with what you do once you arrive than how you get there. How did Charles get there? On a luxury yacht, the Alexander, lent by the Greek tycoon John Latsis. Hope he'll take a more spartan approach once he arrives, then. The Vatopedi monastery, where Charles will reside for the next few nights, has spectacular views over the Aegean Sea, and the monks refuse all payment for their hospitality. But in the hierarchy of 20 monasteries on Mount Athos, Vatopedi has been stuck in second place for more than 1,000 years, or perhaps I should say millennium, behind the indomitable mother church, Grand Lavra. Charles will feel right at home. Oh, there's plenty more to help him settle in. There are bound to be schooldays reminiscences when it's all boys together in the dorm. Then there are the tales of Prince Philip's visit to the mountain (royal aides were no doubt grateful for the ban on video cameras). And, of course, there's the famous Byzantine architecture. Do say: "This monstrous carbuncle is disturbing my contemplation." Don't say: "We should try this no-women rule at Windsor." Not to be confused with: Porthos, Aramis, D'Artagnan.

webTitle: Court told how jet's radar blip broke up at 7.02pm

fields.headline: Court told how jet's radar blip broke up at 7.02pm
fields.standfirst:
Testimony Air controller tells historic court of final minutes of bombed Pan Am flight 103

Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: The final dramatic moments of Pan Am flight 103 before it exploded over Lockerbie nearly 12 years ago were recreated in a packed court yesterday at the start of the trial of two Libyans accused of murdering 270 people.
fields.byline: Ian Black  and Gerard Seenan  at Camp Zeist
fields.body:
The final dramatic moments of Pan Am flight 103 before it exploded over Lockerbie nearly 12 years ago were recreated in a packed court yesterday at the start of the trial of two Libyans accused of murdering 270 people.

On the first day of the historic trial, the Scottish court in the Netherlands heard how air traffic controllers watched the radar blip of the doomed Boeing 747 shatter into fragments before it finally disappeared off their screens.

Questioned by Colin Boyd, the Lord Advocate, Alan Topp, descirbed how on the night of December 21 1988 he tracked the path of the aircraft on his radar monitor in the Scottish air traffic control centre at Prestwick, as the plane headed from London Heathrow towards New York.

Mr Topp, 64, of Troon, Ayrshire, said that at about 7pm he made contact with the jumbo as it entered Scottish air space. "Good evening Scottish, Clipper one zero three," he was told by the pilot, according to a transcript introduced in evidence. "We are at level three one zero." Those words were the last ever heard from the plane.

Lord Sutherland, sitting with two other judges, listened as Mr Topp described how at 7.02pm he first noticed a radar abnormality with Pan Am flight 103.

Just a minute later, according to a video recording of the radar screen shown in evidence, flight 103's blip fragmented into first three and then five discrete signals. "I had my radar opened out and you could see that one big bright square is made of up of several squares very close to each other," said Mr Topp.

"I had never seen anything like this happen before. Nobody had."

Several attempts to contact the aircraft were made by the air traffic control centre, but with no success. A KLM aircraft nearby was also unable to make contact with the plane, despite repeated attempts.

The court heard how Mr Topp called over his boss, Adrian Ford, 66, from Ayr, after a British Airways pilot, Robin Chamberlain, told him he had spotted a fire on the ground near Lockerbie. Mr Chamberlain, 52, told the court: "The closest I could put it is that it looked as if a petrol storage tank had blown up. If you imagine the things you see in films, it was like that - like a large explosion or a bomb - something of that nature."

At the air traffic control centre, Mr Ford immediately informed search and rescue teams that the aircraft was missing. "I said to the control there that Clipper 103 has vanished."

Earlier, the two Libyans, described by the prosecution as intelligence agents, pleaded not guilty to murder, conspiracy to murder and contravention of the Aviation Security Act 1982. They also lodged a special defence of incrimination and blamed Palestinian terrorists for the bombing.

Surrendered

In a statement read by the clerk of the court, the defence claimed that members of two Syrian-backed Palestinian groups - one of them a prosecution witness - had planted the bomb on flight 103.

The defence was submitted moments after Lord Sutherland opened proceedings against Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah, who surrendered for trial last year. They claim to have been employees of Libyan Arab Airlines in Malta.

The defence statement also named Mohammed Abu Talb, a Palestinian, as one of 10 other alleged conspirators. He is serving a life sentence in Sweden for earlier bombings in Denmark and the Netherlands.

Abu Talb was an early suspect in the case, but investigators abandoned that line of inquiry. He is listed as one of more than 1,000 prosecution witnesses.

Seven other named Arab men, whose whereabouts are unknown, were described as formerly directors of a bakery in Malta,where the suitcase containing the bomb was allegedly loaded on to a feeder flight to Frankfurt, and from there to London.

The defence statement referred also to members of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command, and to Parviz Taheri, who is another crown witness.

First to testify was Richard Dawson, a civil aviation air traffic controller who was on duty at Heathrow airport on the night the plane crashed in flames on to the Scottish Borders town.

Mr Dawson, aged 52, described the routine procedures for departures from Heathrow, and radar control technology which allows the controllers to track the aircraft. He confirmed that the doomed flight made its first appearance in traffic control records at 6.18pm on December 21 1988, identified as Clipper 103, and that later it was cleared for takeoff, leaving the airport shortly afterwards.

Watching the trial throughout were the families of the Libyan accused. In total, 17 family members, including the children of the accused, witnessed the first day's proceedings - 10 of Mr Fhimah's relatives and seven of Mr al-Megrahi's. Mr Fhimah's uncle, Milad Fhimah, said: "We are Muslim, we look to Allah, we believe in God. We are not upset, because it is true that they are innocent."

Bruce Smith, a former Pan Am pilot whose wife, Ingrid, was killed in the crash, said: "This is the start of the trial and we welcome it, but there is a long way to go."

More air traffic control witnesses and police officers who were the first on the scene of the tragedy are expected to give evidence today.
