webTitle: The archaic grandeur of Scottish court proceedings. Behind bullet-proof glass

fields.headline: The archaic grandeur of Scottish court proceedings. Behind bullet-proof glass
fields.standfirst:
Courtroom sketch

Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: It could almost have been familiar. The judges, horsehair wigs, mace and court motto -the standard trappings of a Scottish court. But there was also the bullet-proof glass, the Libyan robes, and the infra-red technology of this most modern trial.
fields.body:
It could almost have been familiar. The judges, horsehair wigs, mace and court motto -the standard trappings of a Scottish court. But there was also the bullet-proof glass, the Libyan robes, and the infra-red technology of this most modern trial.

At 10.32 yesterday morning it began. Almost 12 years after the explosion above Lockerbie, Abdelbaset Ali Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah sat flanked by burly policemen in a Scots court in the Netherlands.

To the archaic grandeur of the court proceedings, the pair brought their own measure of dignified tradition. In the shashiya hats and arbaya robes worn by venerated Libyans, they appeared before judges bedecked in powdered wigs and silk gowns. They spoke only to confirm their names.

Then Lord Sutherland called on the court usher to read out the indictment. In an occasionally faltering Scottish burr, he began reading at 10.45am. He sat down at 11.05am. In those 20 minutes, his words travelled through Libya and Senegal, Malta and Germany, the complexity and detail turning the years of searching and investigation contained within them into courtroom filigree.

Only every so often did one phrase fall harshly on the court: "And you did murder them." The occasion, for all its ceremony and media attention, was captured in that simple phrase: 270 dead; two men forced to answer charges that they killed them. When the words came, the accused were impassive. Al Megrahi fiddled with one of the four water bottles in front of him; Fhimah pushed his spectacles further up his nose. On the other side of the glass, their families listened with similar calm.

Mohammed Ali Al Megrahi said he knew how his brother would feel at that moment. "This is the first time he has ever been on trial, it is very strange for him. I saw him yesterday and he was in very good spirits. He told us again that he will prove he is not guilty. He trusts the court and he said that where there is God there is justice."

Minutes later, William Taylor QC, counsel for Al Megrahi, set out what he believes will bring that justice to his client. He said his client was pleading not guilty; his special defence would be that of incrimination. Richard Keen QC entered the same plea and defence on behalf of Fhimah.

Over the next year, that will be the framework for battle. The crown says the Libyans blew up Pan Am flight 103, murdered and conspired to murder 270 people. The accused blame the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command, and Parviz Taheri, a man identified only as crown witness 996.

The first witness, Richard Dawson, an air traffic controller at Heathrow, spoke in rigorously technical detail of the mechanics of his craft. Charts were shown; definitions given. The first questions had been asked. There will be many more to come.

webTitle: Palestinians named by accused were the original suspects

fields.headline: Palestinians named by accused were the original suspects
fields.standfirst:
The defence Libyans seek to implicate witness for prosecution

Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: The finger of suspicion after the Lockerbie bombing was first pointed at Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command, the very group implicated yesterday, more than 11 years later, by the two Libyan defendants.
fields.body:
The finger of suspicion after the Lockerbie bombing was first pointed at Ahmed Jibril's Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command, the very group implicated yesterday, more than 11 years later, by the two Libyan defendants.

In another extraordinary twist, they also implicated Abu Talb, once regarded by the Scottish police as a prime suspect but now a prosecution witness.

For years, western intelligence agencies believed in a simple explanation. The bombing was funded by Iran in retaliation for the mistaken shooting down of an Iranian airliner by an American warship, the USS Vincennes, over the Persian Gulf in July 1988, five months before the Lockerbie bombing.

It was assumed that the Iranians paid Jibril's Syria-backed group to carry out a revenge attack. The assumption appeared to be backed up by the arrest a few months before the bombing of 17 people in Frankfurt, where the bag containing the bomb is alleged to have been placed on the Pan Am airliner. It was reported later that those arrested in the operation, called Autumn Leaves, included Hafez Dalkamoni, a prominent member of the PFLP-GC with links to Palestinians in Uppsala, Sweden.

They also included Marwan Kreeshat, a Jordanian, found with explosives and a Toshiba cassette player in his car similar to the one believed to have contained the bomb that destroyed the Pan Am airliner. British intelligence was later astonished to learn that he had been released for lack of evidence.

Iran appeared to be further implicated in the bombing when a US intelligence report referred to Ali Akbar Mohtashemi, a former Iranian interior minister who supervised Iranian funding of Middle East terror groups, paying out "10 million in dollars in cash and gold ... to bomb Pan Am flight 103 ... in retaliation for the US shoot-down of the Iranian Airbus".

The existence of the report, which was given to lawyers representing Pan Am, became known in 1995. This was after the two Libyans were indicted and officials in Washington and London played down its significance, describing it as low-grade information found to be incorrect.

The trail to Talb began when he was linked to a car belonging to to one of those arrested in Frankfurt. Talb was found guilty at Uppsala in December 1989 of planting a bomb at a synagogue in Copenhagen four years earlier.

Swedish police were reported to have found at Talb's Uppsala apartment an air ticket from Malta to Stockholm indicating that he was on the island at the time children's clothes - part of the evidence against the two Libyans - were bought.

British Lockerbie investigators were also alleged to have found clothes bought in Malta during a later raid on Talb's flat. Also found there was a diary with December 21 1988 - the date of the bombing - circled. He was named in the Uppsala court as being suspected in Scotland of murder or as an accessory to murder.

Yesterday, Egyptian-born Talb was described in the Camp Zeist court as a member of the Palestine Popular Struggle Front and witness number 963 for the Scottish prosecution. The PPSF was founded in 1969 with backing from Syria, and split in 1981. One of its two founders, Samir Ghosheh, left in 1981 to join the mainstream PLO and is now a minister in Yasser Arafat's Palestine Authority in Gaza.

Experts said last night that the PPSF was defunct and that little had been heard of it for at least two years.

According to Israel's Jaffee Centre for Strategic Studies, the PFLP-GC, which rejects a political settlement with Israel, has maintained links with Syria, Libya and Iran, serving as a proxy for those states in attacks in the international arena. It was suspected of carrying out the bombing of a French airliner in 1989 over Niger.

Ahmed Jibril declined to comment last night.

Some commentators say that attention over Lockerbie turned to Libya when the west wanted to improve relations with Iran and Syria after the Gulf war against Iraq. Washington and London dismiss this as conspiracy theory.

fields.headline: Terror ride
fields.standfirst: The hijacker with a 40cm blade
fields.trailText: A woman on a bus hijacked yesterday afternoon in south-western Japan died from stab wounds in hospital last night. Tatsuko Tsukamoto, 68, was one of three women released through a window after negotiations between the police and the hijacker in a parking area in Hiroshima.
fields.body:
A woman on a bus hijacked yesterday afternoon in south-western Japan died from stab wounds in hospital last night. Tatsuko Tsukamoto, 68, was one of three women released through a window after negotiations between the police and the hijacker in a parking area in Hiroshima.

The hijacker, a youth of 17, was holding a 10-year-old girl at knife-point late last night. Relatives were at the scene, trying to persuade him to give himself up.

Passengers said the hijacker was armed with a 40cm (16in) knife.

The police said the hijacker had demanded a gun, cash and a bulletproof jacket and said he wished to go to Tokyo.

They were alerted to the hijacking by a woman who escaped after persuading the hijacker to allow her off the bus to go to the toilet.

A second woman, Mikiko Matsuno, 29, escaped by jumping from the window of the moving bus and was taken to hospital. A 52-year-old man, Masayuki Kishikawa, suffered minor injuries in making a similar escape.

webTitle: Drive to get Syria on peace train

fields.headline: Drive to get Syria on peace train
fields.trailText: Efforts to revive the Syrian track of the Middle East peace process intensified yesterday as the foreign ministers of Syria, Egypt and Saudi Arabia gathered in the Syrian city of Palmyra for two days of talks.
fields.body:
Efforts to revive the Syrian track of the Middle East peace process intensified yesterday as the foreign ministers of Syria, Egypt and Saudi Arabia gathered in the Syrian city of Palmyra for two days of talks.

Meanwhile Israel pressed ahead with its plans to pull out of Lebanon, with or without a Syrian peace deal. It is dismantling border posts and, according to the Foreign Office in London, has stopped military flights in Lebanese airspace.

Observers suggested that these developments could be an attempt either to step up the pressure on Syria's ailing president, Hafez al-Assad, or to wrong-foot opponents in Lebanon by withdrawing earlier than expected.

The Syrian negotiations have been on hold since President Bill Clinton and President Assad, meeting in Geneva in March, failed to break the impasse.

Since then there has been growing concern in the Arab states, and some European capitals, that an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon could lead to more violence unless it was done within the framework of an overall deal with Syria.

The involvement of Egypt and Saudi Arabia at this stage appears to be an attempt to present a united Arab front to the Americans and Israelis.

The nub of the problem between Israel and Syria - and, by extension, the key to a comprehensive settlement in the region - is a small stretch of shoreline on the north-east corner of the Sea of Galilee.

The lake is an important source of water for Israel. Israel's claim to it is based on the border established between Palestine and Syria in 1923, at the time of the League of Nations mandate. This placed the whole of the lake in Palestine, together with a 10-metre strip around the water's edge.

Syria points out that Israel, from its establishment in 1948 until the war of 1967, had no access to the north-eastern part of the shore. The Syrians kept fishing boats there and their forces had control in that area, right down to the water's edge.

In the 1967 war the Israeli forces drove the Syrians back, occupied the Golan Heights, and gained control of the north-east shore. In the Syrians' view, Israel should withdraw from that part of the shore so as not to derive any benefit from its aggression. President Assad has made this an issue of principle and cannot budge now without serious loss of face.

The issue is further complicated by the fact that the Israelis, after occupying the Golan, built a road around the lake. At the failed meeting a Geneva, President Clinton is reported to have proposed extending the 10-metre strip of shoreline to several hundred metres - presumably to allow the Israelis to keep their road.

Several solutions have been proposed unofficially, most of them centred on either dual sovereignty or Syrian sovereignty over the north-east shore without actual control.

Syria has said it would not use the sovereignty issue to deprive Israel of the water it wants.

The nub of the problem between Israel and Syria - and, by extension, the key to a comprehensive settlement in the region - is a small stretch of shoreline on the north-east corner of the Sea of Galilee. The lake is an important source of water for Israel. Israel's claim to it is based on the border established between Palestine and Syria in 1923, at the time of the League of Nations mandate. This placed the whole of the lake in Palestine, together with a 10-metre strip around the water's edge. Syria points out that Israel, from its establishment in 1948 until the war of 1967, had no access to the north-eastern part of the shore. The Syrians kept fishing boats there and their forces had control in that area, right down to the water's edge. In the 1967 war the Israeli forces drove the Syrians back, occupied the Golan Heights, and gained control of the north-east shore. In the Syrians' view, Israel should withdraw from that part of the shore so as not to derive any benefit from its aggression. President Assad has made this an issue of principle and cannot budge now without serious loss of face. The issue is further complicated by the fact that the Israelis, after occupying the Golan, built a road around the lake. At the failed meeting a Geneva, President Clinton is reported to have proposed extending the 10-metre strip of shoreline to several hundred metres - presumably to allow the Israelis to keep their road. Several solutions have been proposed unofficially, most of them centred on either dual sovereignty or Syrian sovereignty over the north-east shore without actual control. Syria has said it would not use the sovereignty issue to deprive Israel of the water it wants.

fields.headline: The charges
fields.standfirst:
Murder and conspiracy

Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: Details of the charges faced by Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah are as intricate as would be expected of such a complex and involved case. They stretch the globe from Switzerland to Syria through Libya to Germany, taking in everything from the secret service agencies of various countries to a backstreet clothing store in Malta.
fields.body:
Details of the charges faced by Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah are as intricate as would be expected of such a complex and involved case. They stretch the globe from Switzerland to Syria through Libya to Germany, taking in everything from the secret service agencies of various countries to a backstreet clothing store in Malta.

But, in the end, the suspects face three stark charges. The first charge is conspiracy to murder. They are charged with conspiring to destroy Pan Am flight 103 using explosive devices to further the aims of the Libyan intelligence services, of which both men are alleged to be members. The Libyans are accused of placing a high-performance plastic explosive device hidden within a Toshiba Bombeat cassette recorder on to a plane at Luqa airport, Malta. The device was then transferred to Frankfurt and Heathrow before it caused the explosion over Lockerbie.

The relatively uncommon charge of conspiracy has been used so that, should the crown be unable to prove the second charge of murder, the accused may still be convicted of conspiring to murder - they could be found guilty whether it is proved they directly murdered the 270 people or not. Conspiracy carries no prescribed sentence in Scots law.

The second charge is murder. The indictment is similar to that of the first charge but the main difference lies in the fact that it refers to a completed crime, not just agreement to commit a crime. The crown has to prove, beyond reasonable doubt, that the suspects committed the act that resulted in the deaths of those on board the aircraft and the 11 who died on the ground. A higher degree of evidence is required here than for the first charge of conspiracy and punishment is a mandatory life sentence.

The third charge is contravention of the Aviation Security Act 1982. Under this act it is an offence to intentionally destroy an aircraft in service or to endanger its safety in flight.

For the crown to achieve a conviction it must show that the accused intended to destroy or damage Pan Am flight 103 or that they committed an act of violence on board the aircraft. If proven, the offence carries a mandatory life sentence.

webTitle: Meditations of an old hippy on the drugs trail

fields.headline: Meditations of an old hippy on the drugs trail
fields.standfirst: Phytopharm chief executive Richard Dixey on the hunt for natural remedies
fields.trailText: Unusually for a multi-millionaire pharmaceuticals executive, Richard Dixey is a bit of an old hippy. The chief executive of Phytopharm, the plant-based medicines specialist, is a devoted follower of Tibetan Buddhism. "I used to meditate every day, although now it depends on how busy I am," he says.
fields.body:
Unusually for a multi-millionaire pharmaceuticals executive, Richard Dixey is a bit of an old hippy. The chief executive of Phytopharm, the plant-based medicines specialist, is a devoted follower of Tibetan Buddhism. "I used to meditate every day, although now it depends on how busy I am," he says.

Dixey, 47, is hardly a typical new economy entrepreneur but then, Phytopharm is an unorthodox company. The chief executive keeps a collection of guitars behind his desk. "When I feel stressed, I have a quick twang," he says. "We have a bit of a sing-song in the office."

Despite its membership of Techmark - the stockmarket's hi-tech index - Phytopharm's focus is on the past. The company collects "anecdotes" from doctors about traditional herbal remedies, then goes to the world's jungles and deserts to see if they actually work.

Dixey says: "We're interested in hearing from trained clinicians who are impressed with what they have seen with their own eyes."

To the surprise of many in the pharmaceuticals industry, the approach is working. Phytopharm is developing products based on South African cactuses, Indian herbs and tropical lilies. Clinical trials are under way to treat eczema, baldness and irritable bowel syndrome; the results have been highly encouraging.

The City believes the Cambridge-based company can deliver - Phytopharm's shares have quadrupled in the last three years, and the business is worth £145m.

That means Dixey's 11% stake is worth £16m. He says he uses his money to support schooling projects for Tibetan refugees.

The son of a Berkshire doctor, Dixey studied biochemistry at Oxford and after a short period as a beef farmer, got a part-time post at St Bartholomew's hospital, London, researching into health implications of mobile phones.

While at Bart's, he met Jonathan Brostoff, an immunologist who noticed that his eczema patients were benefiting from an ancient Chinese medicine. Dixey and Brostoff spotted a potential business opportunity and teamed up with a wealthy German commodities broker, Klaus Heben, to create Phytopharm.

"At the time I didn't know anything about drug development," Dixey says. "I didn't realise how innovative the idea was."

Phytopharm's creation was well timed - it came at the beginning of a 1990s boom in self-administered medicine. "There was a genuine wish to create an alternative to single-chemical entities," says Dixey, who is critical of the race between other pharmaceuticals firms to create "magic bullet" drugs. "Before the war, virtually all medicines came from plants," he says. "Then there was a fashion that you could cure disease with magic bullets like penicillin and antibiotics. Ten of the world's top 20 drugs are still from plants but there's not much innovation in the field." Dixey believes the race to map the human genome has been wildly overhyped. "I don't see any obvious link between genes and drugs. Very few diseases are directly inheritable."

He points out that even when genes are linked with illness, proteins trigger the actual disease mechanism. "You've still got to do old-fashioned drug discovery. It's almost like the market has forgotten that."

Underlying Phytopharm's activities, Dixey says, is a kind of cultural relativism. He believes that the west is too dismissive of other traditions. "If you can show that ancient knowledge works, it shows that other cultures are valid," he says.

Dixey says that it is all too easy to assume that traditional medicines were all discovered through pure luck. "There are millions of plants out there - how did people stumble upon a particular one? It cannot have been through chance - it beggars belief.

"There is no evidence of ancient cultures doing clinical trials, so there must be another way of interrogating the world, not a scientific way."

As an example, he cites an Indian seed, mercuna puriens, which was recently "discovered" as a treatment for Parkinson's disease. "It's fully described in a fourth century Indian text. It shouldn't be called Parkinson's disease - it was around long before Parkinson."

Dixey is aware that it can be difficult to get Phytopharm's science taken seriously. In an effort to reach profitability more quickly, the company has a sideline in veterinary drugs - which require much shorter safety trials. He has to go round the City discussing herbal treatments for dog arthritis. "You can always put a funny angle on an aspidistra that does something weird," he says.

Dixey is a great believer in the fun side of life. Former girlfriends include the model Koo Stark; the pair stepped out together for a few months in the early 1990s. He quips: "Can you print my phone number? I'm always on the lookout for ladies."

At work, his favourite part of the job is the trips to obscure parts of the world, either to visit Phytopharm's vast plantations of shrubs or to evaluate potential new medicines.

One such journey led him to Mongolia, to look for a plant called the snow lotus. He says: "It is a very unusual plant - it grows at 12,000 feet (3,600m). It puts a long spike up over the snow, with a flower on the end."

He bought 25 kg of snow lotuses from a man in Ulan Bator for what he says was an astronomical sum, and carried the package home, via Bangkok. When he arrived back in Cambridge, he found that the contents had been replaced by grass.

The incident taught him the importance of finding a local partner who knows the territory. "It's naive to think you can go in like Crocodile Dundee all the time," he says.

fields.headline: France takes to les dot.coms
fields.standfirst: Establishment under threat as entrepreneurs wake up to possibilities of the internet
fields.trailText: This is a tale of two schools. One is housed in a frayed-at-the-edges concrete and glass affair on the wrong side of the Paris ring road. The other is in a cool and sumptuous old stone building in the heart of the chic sixth  arrondissement.
fields.body:
This is a tale of two schools. One is housed in a frayed-at-the-edges concrete and glass affair on the wrong side of the Paris ring road. The other is in a cool and sumptuous old stone building in the heart of the chic sixth arrondissement.

The first, the Ecole Pour l'Informatique et les Techniques Avancées (Epita), is open 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year. Its bleary-eyed graduates can choose from dozens of job offers, and half of them start their own companies before they leave.

They are not ashamed to say they plan to work a 90-hour week, make their million, and retire at 35. Epita's annual intake has trebled in the past three years.

The second, the Ecole Nationale d'Administration (ENA), is France's most prestigious school. Its graduates include two of the past three presidents, six of the past eight prime ministers, and half the top 17 ministers in the present government. A fast-breeder for bureaucrats, ENA virtually guarantees a job for life in the higher echelons of the civil service.

In the past two years, external applicants for the 100 places on offer at ENA - that is, those who are not already high-flying civil servants but are among the best and brightest of France's 20-somethings - have tumbled by a third.

It is, of course, unfair to compare the two. They are very different. ENA was founded by Charles de Gaulle in 1945 to be the high church of the technocratic and political classes, a super-elite state finishing school whose graduates would one day rule the country.

Epita was launched in 1984 as a computer and telecommunications college, and nearly went bust before the cellphone and internet revolutions finally got a hold on France, where resistance to change has been stiffened by the generations of the ENA graduates who administer it, govern it, and manage its state-run companies.

Things are changing. As Jean-Marie Messier, chief executive of the utilities and communications firm Vivendi, said: "At long last, this country is on the move. You can see it. You can almost touch it."

Statistics back him up. The French economy is expected to expand by 3.5% this year, and its rate of growth has been ahead of those in Germany, Italy and Britain for the past two years. Unemployment is falling, and the CAC 40 stock market index is outperforming New York's Dow Jones.

But perhaps more important is a change in mentality, a new perception of what is acceptable and achievable, a shift in young people's priorities. "Things really are moving," Joel Courtois, Epita's director, insisted, looking in on a classroom whose massed ranks of computers were all in use.

"France is surfing on the internet information technology wave, and I don't think it's a passing phase," Mr Courtois said. "A lot of things are suddenly different: it's OK to work enormously hard, to make lots of money, to prefer to be part of an informal team rather than some hierarchical elite. The youngsters at this school have completely outgrown the old French model."

Pascal Chevalier and Gilles Enguehard belong to the new breed. Recent graduates of Epita, they have formed On-net Services and Planet StartUp, two fast-growing firms providing technical, financial, legal and commercial help to young internet businesses.

Barely 30, they now sit on the boards of more companies than they can remember, and for want of space have moved out of Epita's e-business incubator, a suite of offices in a nearby building.

"The thing is, it's just not been part of French culture to start a company, and if you go to the chamber of commerce for advice you never will," said Mr Enguehard. "They'll tell you: take this course, fill in these forms, hire that lawyer, engage this accountant, sort out the social security - it's a nightmare and it's unnecessary."

To Mr Chevalier, there are now two Frances, moving at different speeds. "I love the 35 hours," he said, referring to the government's recent legislation to limit the working week. "So much, I do them twice."

Michel Wolff, 26, a dot.com millionaire, agreed. "It is a revolution," he said. "In the old France it was who you knew that counted. Now it's how good your idea is, how fast you can put it into action, and how many hours you put in to make it work."

Students and graduates of ENA do not quite know where that leaves them. This year's intake have demanded sweeping reforms to bring the school into the 21st century, and recent graduates bemoan a decline in interest in what used to be France's highest ideal - serving the state.

"Top minds are not turning to the administration any more as their first choice," said one, a civil servant. "Partly that's to do with a steadily deteriorating public image of the state, partly with the fact that business is now moving so fast - and it doesn't recruit from ENA. Before the new economy, ENA left all your options open. Now it closes a very big one off."

Another graduate was more damning. "Yes, France is changing," she said. "ENA is suffering because it is the emblem and the sum of French immobility, and suddenly France is becoming mobile.

"These days, the main satisfaction for the few brilliant students who go to ENA is the contemplation of so much mediocrity around them."

fields.headline: Three possible verdicts
fields.standfirst: Lockerbie: special report
fields.trailText: As in all Scottish criminal cases, a verdict will be by majority. Normally, eight of the 15 members of a Scottish jury would have to vote for a verdict for that to be entered. But, since the three judges in the Netherlands are sitting without a jury, the decision rests with them.
fields.body:
As in all Scottish criminal cases, a verdict will be by majority. Normally, eight of the 15 members of a Scottish jury would have to vote for a verdict for that to be entered. But, since the three judges in the Netherlands are sitting without a jury, the decision rests with them.

Under the rules set down for this unique trial, all decisions - including the verdict - must be taken by at least two of the three judges. (A fourth judge, Lord Abernethy, will be present throughout the trial in case one of the three be comes ill or cannot continue.)

When a verdict is given it could throw up the greatest oddity of Scottish criminal law. There are three possible outcomes on all three charges: guilty; not guilty and not proven. The first two are self-explanatory, but the third, not proven, is an acquittal. Should the charges against the Libyans be found not proven they will walk free, but without having their innocence vindicated.

If guilty, they are likely to serve their sentence at Glasgow's Barlinnie prison.

fields.headline: Bomb blasts rock casinos
fields.trailText: Three bombs exploded in France in the early hours of yesterday, one near the Crazy Horse cabaret in Paris and two at casinos on the Mediterranean coast, the police said. The explosions caused damage but no injuries.
fields.body:
Three bombs exploded in France in the early hours of yesterday, one near the Crazy Horse cabaret in Paris and two at casinos on the Mediterranean coast, the police said. The explosions caused damage but no injuries.

The first, around 3am, went off a stone's throw from the Crazy Horse in central Paris, showering the area with glass.

The second, two hours later, caused extensive damage to a casino in Carry-le-Rouet, near Marseille.

An hour later a third blast badly damaged a casino in Juan-les-Pins, near Antibes, which belongs to the company which had a casino in Aix-en-Province bombed in March.

Nobody has claimed responsibility for the explosions, which came two weeks after a bomb blast at a McDonald's in Brittany, northern France, killed a woman employee.

Investigators suspect that the separatist Breton Revolutionary Army was behind the McDonald's bomb.

The police questioned at least seven people yesterday in connection with the Brittany bomb - two Basques and five suspected Breton activists.

They said they had discovered bomb-making materials in the car of one of those detained.

"As you can see, the authors of these attacks are being actively sought," the interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, said.

Small groups of Breton separatists have long sought autonomy for the region, which has maintained a strong cultural identity reflecting the Bretons' Celtic origins.

The police have suspected links between the Bretons and the Basques in south-west France and Spain since tracking both Basques and Breton separatists to the theft in September of eight tonnes of dynamite in the Breton town of Plevin.

Five of the suspects questioned are members of Emgann, a small group believed to be the legal front for the Breton Revolutionary Army, known by its French initials ARB.

Emgann's spokesman, Gael Roblin, was among those detained.

An hour later a third blast badly damaged a casino in Juan-les-Pins, near Antibes, which belongs to the company which had a casino in Aix-en-Province bombed in March. Nobody has claimed responsibility for the explosions, which came two weeks after a bomb blast at a McDonald's in Brittany, northern France, killed a woman employee. Investigators suspect that the separatist Breton Revolutionary Army was behind the McDonald's bomb. The police questioned at least seven people yesterday in connection with the Brittany bomb - two Basques and five suspected Breton activists. They said they had discovered bomb-making materials in the car of one of those detained. "As you can see, the authors of these attacks are being actively sought," the interior minister, Jean-Pierre Chevènement, said. Small groups of Breton separatists have long sought autonomy for the region, which has maintained a strong cultural identity reflecting the Bretons' Celtic origins. The police have suspected links between the Bretons and the Basques in south-west France and Spain since tracking both Basques and Breton separatists to the theft in September of eight tonnes of dynamite in the Breton town of Plevin. Five of the suspects questioned are members of Emgann, a small group believed to be the legal front for the Breton Revolutionary Army, known by its French initials ARB. Emgann's spokesman, Gael Roblin, was among those detained.

webTitle: M5 gang preys on aged victims

fields.headline: M5 gang preys on aged victims
fields.standfirst: Death of pensioner is blamed on crime wave in west country that has seen robberies rise by 300%
fields.trailText: Police in the West Country are hunting a band of criminals dubbed the "M5 gang" which has been responsible for a huge rise in crime across two counties and have been involved in the death of a pensioner.
fields.body:
Police in the West Country are hunting a band of criminals dubbed the "M5 gang" which has been responsible for a huge rise in crime across two counties and have been involved in the death of a pensioner.

Since the start of the year 88 raids have been carried out on people in their 70s, 80s and 90s by a the group which targets towns easily accessible from the M5.

Destinations as far afield as Truro, Camborne, and Penryn in Cornwall and Exeter, Cullompton, and Honiton in Devon have been picked by the Bristol-based ring, believed to be a gang of travellers. They use children as young as four to gain entry to the pensioners' homes, and the motorway to beat a hasty retreat.

The level of this type of crime is unprecedented in the two counties, which have seen a 300% rise in "distraction burglaries" since the raids began in January.

Such attacks have traditionally been rife in central England, but Devon and Cornwall police believe the conmen have been shunted from the triangle between Bristol, London and Liverpool to the south-west as a result of successful crackdowns from Avon and Somerset and West Midlands forces.

The burglaries have led to tragedy.

Frances Blyth, an 81-year-old widow, answered the door of her terraced home in Launceston, Cornwall, to two young men claiming to be from the water board. She let them in but within minutes they had helped themselves to £1,000 - the majority of the great-grandmother's life savings - and forced her aside when she began to remonstrate.

She collapsed behind the door with a heart attack, and less than 12 hours later she was dead.

The outcome has been the most extreme in the series of burglaries.

"We haven't had a significant problem before now, and we think it is a question of their being displaced," said Detective Sergeant David Dale, heading the investigation.

Certainly the group, whom police believe could number anything from six to 12, now appreciate there are easy pickings to be had in the west country, where coastal towns such as Sidmouth and Torquay have evolved into meccas for people of retirement age.

Five or six raids a day have been reported with cash sums of up to £5,000 being taken. "As soon as the police are called out on one job you get a call from another pensioner a mile up the road - you can virtually trace their route," said Mr Dale.

"And, if you can imagine they are sometimes doing this five or six days a week, you can see how skilled they are at this offence."

The burglars' reasons for targeting the elderly reveal the extent of their cynicism.

Mr Dale said: "Elderly people are seen as more trusting, they are also unlikely to be willing to be witnesses if they are required to go to court.

"The burglars know that, even if court procedures go ahead, they can take 12 or 18 months, so their victims may well have passed away. They also know that, if they request an identity parade, which we must give them if they request it, there is a good chance they won't be recognised.

"And they know that elderly people are more likely to tend to have large amounts of money in their houses because they are less likely to trust banks."

After a month of intensive investigation Mr Dale believes he has "gone some way towards identifying the group involved" and is "reasonably close" to making arrests.

"What can I say about what they have done to my mum?" asked Mrs Blyth's daughter, Elizabeth Edwards, aged 54.

"Even if they go to prison, what is to stop them doing it again"?

webTitle: Aurora limps back to shipyard after aborted cruise

fields.headline: Aurora limps back to shipyard after aborted cruise
fields.trailText: P&O's stricken £200m cruise ship Aurora was last night slowly sailing back to Germany for repairs after limping to her home port of Southampton early yesterday to drop off 1,647 passengers.
fields.body:
P&O's stricken £200m cruise ship Aurora was last night slowly sailing back to Germany for repairs after limping to her home port of Southampton early yesterday to drop off 1,647 passengers.

Her maiden voyage to the Mediterranean was abandoned after a propeller shaft overheated 16 hours into the journey. The 76,000-tonne vessel is due to arrive at the Blohm and Voss shipyard in Hamburg on Friday. The cancelled two-week cruise will cost P&O's insurers an estimated £6m in compensation to passengers who will be offered a full refund plus a free cruise.

Some passengers expressed disappointment. Jill Turner, 37, from Bishop Auckland, Co Durham, said: "There was a general feeling that there should have been more rigorous sea trials before the voyage. People are disappointed but the compensation package is very generous."

Renee Tuftin, 70, from Southgate, London, said she knew the ship would be unlucky when the champagne bottle failed to break during the naming ceremony. She said the free alcohol offered by P&O had kept passengers' spirits up.

The ship's captain, Steve Burgoine, said the sea trials had been rigorous. "But who knows when you are going to get a flat tyre?"

Gwyn Hughes, managing director of P&O Cruises, said: "We are gutted. We are obviously disappointed, but not as disappointed as the passengers who were on board." He was confident that Aurora's next cruise, scheduled for May 15, will go ahead as planned.

webTitle: Sensor aid may reduce cot deaths

fields.headline: Sensor aid may reduce cot deaths
fields.trailText: A "smart" cot that can detect the signs leading to cot death has been developed by scientists. The cot can tell what position a baby is lying in, how it is breathing, and warn parents that their baby is in difficulty.
fields.body:
A "smart" cot that can detect the signs leading to cot death has been developed by scientists. The cot can tell what position a baby is lying in, how it is breathing, and warn parents that their baby is in difficulty.

The precise cause of sudden infant death syndrome (Sids) is not known but it is believed that changes in breathing and posture can be significant.

Tatsuya Harada, of the University of Tokyo, who led the research, said: "The respiratory movement preceding Sids is still not yet understood."

Hospitals already have pressure-sensor devices that monitor babies' positions and breathing but these are not suitable for home use.

Sensors usually have to be placed on the infant and this restricts their movement, this week's New Scientist reports.

The new system, developed by Dr Harada with help from paediatricians at the National Children's hospital in Tokyo, works with pressure sensors under the mattress. By analysing the pressure distribution from these 384 sensors the system determines whether the baby is lying face down or on its back and whether it is quiet, moving or crying.

Dr Harada said the other devices based on pressure sensors could only tell whether or not the infant was moving.

It is important to be able to recognise the movement of different parts of the body such as the head, abdomen and hips to build up an accurate picture of the infant's breathing and posture.

The system has been used with 50 infants under the age of one in preliminary tests designed to extract the algorithms the software needs to interpret data from the pressure sensors.

Dr Harada is trying to improve the system by increasing the number of sensors.

He said parents would not be able to buy the system for at least three years.

webTitle: Fears over safety in car parks

fields.headline: Fears over safety in car parks
fields.trailText: One in four motorists have had their cars broken into at, or stolen from, a car park, according to a study released today. And 10% of motorists know someone who has been attacked in a car park, the study from the Norwich Union revealed.
fields.body:
One in four motorists have had their cars broken into at, or stolen from, a car park, according to a study released today. And 10% of motorists know someone who has been attacked in a car park, the study from the Norwich Union revealed.

Three in four drivers prefer parking in an open air car park to a multi-storey one, it emerged.

The biggest worries about multi-storeys are dark corners, lack of security patrols and unsafe lifts and stairwells.

One in five female drivers fears for her personal safety in multi-storeys and only one in 10 would choose to park in one after dark.

The study of more than 500 British motorists showed: one in five drivers do not take any security measures, such as checking for signs of interference, when returning to their cars in a car park; when driving alone at night, five times more motorists feel safer parking on the street than in a multi-storey car park; one third of women have carried a personal attack alarm, compared with just 3% of men.

It also revealed that nearly half of motorists say that security guards are the most effective means of making car parks safer.

Norwich Union has now produced a guide to safe car parking in association with a safety group, the Suzy Lamplugh Trust.

webTitle: Food bug trauma 'led to job loss'

fields.headline: Food bug trauma 'led to job loss'
fields.trailText: A Sainsbury's employee suffered post traumatic stress disorder after shoppers contracted dysentery from the salad bar he managed, an industrial tribunal heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A Sainsbury's employee suffered post traumatic stress disorder after shoppers contracted dysentery from the salad bar he managed, an industrial tribunal heard yesterday.

Stephen Rickard, 53, was in charge of the salad bar in August 1998 when the outbreak was traced back to fruit at his store in Haywards Heath, West Sussex. More than 46 cases, including an 18-month-old baby and an 80-year-old woman, were recorded in what was the first food-borne outbreak of the bug in the UK.

Mr Rickard, who had worked for Sainsbury's from the age of 15, took four months off because of depression and stress, and was made redundant. He claims the supermarket discriminated against him because of his mental disability.

Sainsbury's had argued that Mr Rickard had not suffered from post traumatic stress disorder but a preliminary hearing at Brighton found in favour of Mr Rickard.

He said: "If anyone had died I don't know what I would have done. I had done nothing wrong and felt I was being made a scapegoat."

A doctor told the tribunal that Mr Rickard was suffering from depression and not post traumatic stress. But Douglas Morris, of Trauma Aftercare Trust, said he was certain Mr Rickard had the disorder. Because the panel ruled he had suffered post traumatic stress he qualifies as a disabled person and can claim unfair dismissal.

Mr Rickard, of Burgess Hill, West Sussex, now works in a Waitrose warehouse.

Most of the dysentery victims are believed to have received payouts from Sainsbury's.

webTitle: Dogs hit by unseasonal adder bites

fields.headline: Dogs hit by unseasonal adder bites
fields.trailText: Britons were put on adder alert yesterday as vets reported "unseasonal" snake bites in dogs and the RSPCA confirmed a rise in the number of poisoned pets during winter and spring.
fields.body:
Britons were put on adder alert yesterday as vets reported "unseasonal" snake bites in dogs and the RSPCA confirmed a rise in the number of poisoned pets during winter and spring.

There are many adders around now despite most people thinking July to September are their most dangerous months for getting bitten by Britain's only poisonous snake. Experts advised victims to seek immediate medical attention.

Earlier than usual adder appearances were reported in a letter to the Veterinary Record by Vicky Scarlett, a vet in Shrewsbury, Shropshire, who treated suspected snake bites in a lurcher dog in January and a greyhound in February. They appeared to have been bitten in woods several miles apart. The first died and the other had to be put down.

Louise Rayment, a spokeswoman for the British Veterinarian Zoological Society, who works in North Walsham, Norfolk, said a colleague had successfully treated a dog in March. "It is unusual but we do get the odd case in the summer months particularly. It seems to be more often dogs than anything else because they snuffle in the grass.

Dogs tend to get bitten around the nose, mouth, chest or paws. Symptoms include localised swelling and fluid under the skin. There may be puncture marks.

The RSPCA said there had been a "known rise" in cases over the past two years, but Jim Foster, reptile specialist with the conservation quango English Nature, warned against simply blaming global warming for the adder hazard. "They can be active almost any month of the year. They do come out of hibernation on sunny winter days."

Adders, which grow up to 30 inches and have a zig-zag pattern, are thought to be threatened by development of their favoured habitats of heathland, sandy soil or forestry plantation.

fields.headline: States of ignorance about US
fields.trailText: Britons know little about America, despite growing numbers now visiting the US, according to a survey by American Airlines.
fields.body:
Britons know little about America, despite growing numbers now visiting the US, according to a survey by American Airlines.

Fewer than one in six could correctly say how many American states there are and many confused towns with states. Some people even thought Mexico and Canada were US states.

The survey of 1,001 Britons revealed that: only 16% knew how many American states there are (50); 62% thought there were 52 states; 31% thought Hollywood was a state, 54% believed New Orleans was a state and 40% thought Las Vegas was one; 24% regarded Mexico as a state and 12% thought Canada was a state.

"It is surprising to see just how much more there is for we Britons to discover about America," said Matthew Hall, American Airlines' UK sales manager.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Traveller guilty of drugging
fields.body:
Traveller guilty of drugging

An unemployed Italian was convicted yesterday of drugging an air passenger into a coma at 35,000ft and stealing £135 from him.

Bruno Saputo, 32, was found guilty at Chichester crown court of slipping Flurazepam into a businessman's coffee during a flight from Rome to Gatwick. Saputo, diagnosed as having manic depression, was admitted to hospital under the Criminal Procedures (Insanity) Act.

Officer accused of bigamy

A police officer has been suspended from duty after his former partner accused him of bigamy. The 37-year-old constable from Middlesbrough was suspended last month pending an investigation by the crown prosecution service.

Rescuers move dogs to Spain

The search and rescue team Rapid UK is to move all its life-saving dogs to Spain to ensure they will never have to go through quarantine again.

The team, which is based in Devon, made the decision after the government refused to consider home quarantine for two hounds that were penned up for six months after helping to find earthquake victims in Turkey.

Women urged to pack pill

Female holidaymakers are being urged to pack the "morning after" pill when they go abroad this year in a bid to reduce the annual summer rise in unwanted pregnancies.

Family planning charity Marie Stopes International said women should take emergency contraception on holiday. It is offering a pack of the pill for £10 at its centres in London, Leeds, Manchester and Bristol.

webTitle: Row over drug tests on poor that leave some to die

fields.headline: Row over drug tests on poor that leave some to die
fields.trailText: Drug researchers are increasingly heading for the developing world to carry out trials on people with little understanding of their rights, some of whom are left without treatment for the disease under study, critics allege.
fields.body:
Drug researchers are increasingly heading for the developing world to carry out trials on people with little understanding of their rights, some of whom are left without treatment for the disease under study, critics allege.

They fear this practice will go on unchecked because, they suspect, the World Medical Association talks opening today may end up diluting the guidelines under which medical trials are meant to take place.

The issue has become highly contentious in the US, where public health doctors are privately agonising over the impossibility of reconciling President Clinton's call to help the millions dying of Aids in Africa with the fact that babies in Uganda and elsewhere have been left by researchers to contract HIV.

These are the babies of mothers in the section of a trial group that were not given drugs to stop HIV transmission. Such trials would not have been allowed in the US; in western countries the different test groups in a trial must each be given some form of treatment.

In a recent study of HIV and sexually transmitted diseases in Uganda antibiotics were given to half the subjects and nothing to the others. In China, people were deliberately infected with malaria to see whether this reduced the level of HIV infection - another study that would not have been permitted in the US.

The ethical battle has split the medical and scientific community, and today's WMA meeting in France is trying to reach a compromise by starting work on a new draft of the Declaration of Helsinki.

This contains the guidelines - drawn up between 1953 and 1964, in the light of Nazi medical experimentation - on how doctors should treat patients involved in clinical trials.

Public Citizen, the US watchdog leading the protests against the current test regime, says researchers are exploiting woolly wording in the Helsinki document.

It says: "In any medical study, every patient - including those of a control group, if any - should be assured of the best proven diagnostic and therapeutic method."

But in the developing world there is often nothing available to give those in the control group.

A row about the ethics of trials in the developing world on pregnant women with HIV, which broke out three years ago, led to the decision to rewrite not only the declaration but also the more detailed Cioms (Council for International Organisations of Medical Sciences) guidelines, which effectively interpret it.

But Peter Lurie and Sidney Wolfe of Public Citizen believe that the institutions are just moving the goalposts: "Rather than bringing their behaviour in line with the guidelines, they have set about changing the guidelines to conform to their behaviour," Dr Lurie said.

The controversy was stoked up in March by a study in 10 Ugandan villages to find out whether people who had sexually transmitted diseases such as syphilis were more likely to contract HIV.

Marcia Angell, editor in chief of the New England Journal of Medicine, wrote of her doubts about publishing the study's findings.

"It meant that for up to 30 months, several hundred people with HIV infection were observed but not treated," she wrote.

Five villages were supplied with antibiotics to cure any sexually transmitted diseases, but those in the other five got no treatment beyond being advised to go to a government clinic. The effects when it came to HIV were compared.

The uproar broke out in 1997, when Dr Lurie and Dr Wolfe denounced as unethical 15 US government-funded HIV studies in developing countries. Researchers wanted to find out if giving low doses of the drug AZT to pregnant women could reduce the chances of the baby being infected.

Half the women got the drug, the other half got nothing. In the US they would have been given longer courses of AZT and caesarian sections, and told to breastfeed - techniques known to reduce transmission.

Hundreds of infants needlessly contracted HIV, Dr Lurie and Dr Wolfe said.

The early stages of drafting new guidelines for the WMA, Cioms and Unaids - the World Health Organisation's Aids organisation - were directed by Robert Levine, a professor at Yale University School of Medicine, who takes the opposite view to the two men.

He says that research on what works best and most cheaply in developing countries cannot be done without comparing new drugs with what there is at the moment in such places - that is, no other treatments at all.

fields.headline: Snowballs of the gods
fields.standfirst: Hail from hell has dented a Spanish car and a number of scientific ideas, says  David Hambling
fields.trailText: Hail from hell has dented a Spanish car and a number of scientific ideas, says David Hambling
fields.body:
The Spanish motorist did not intend to challenge the laws of physics. He was just minding his own business when a 2kg chunk of ice dropped out of the sky and slammed into his car.

Such cases are usually blamed on ice falling from aircraft, either from a build-up of frost on the wings or from plumbing leaks. But the sky was empty, and there was more to follow. Dozens more blocks of ice fell around Spain in January and February, some weighing up to 6kg. But how can you claim on your insurance when scientists say your story is impossible?

Many people assumed the ice falls had to be a hoax. But then, scientists used to dismiss meteorites as a myth. The great French scientist Lavoisier, discover of oxygen, did not think they were worth investigating. "There are no stones in the heavens," he declared, "therefore it is impossible for stones to fall from the heavens."

Mysterious ice falls have been recorded for centuries and have generally been ignored. However, in Spain many of them fell over several weeks and more importantly, some were preserved for analysis. It seemed reasonable to assume that the ice falls were a kind of icy meteorite.

In 1986, satellite imagery of the upper atmosphere showed dark spots 20 kilometres across which appeared and faded in a few seconds. The general view was that the spots were caused by flaws in the imaging process. Then Louis Frank published a paper theorising that the spots were actually a stream of small comets or ice meteors vaporising in the upper atmosphere. He estimated that the Earth was bombarded by 20,000 house-sized snowballs a day.

This claim was not widely accepted, as scientists found it hard to believe that this barrage of meteors could have escaped their attention. However, more recent images have given some support to Frank's theory. It is now generally agreed that not all the spots are instrumental errors, and that something is striking the upper atmosphere - but exactly what, how many and how big are still matters of debate.

There is more evidence that ice meteors do exist. In 1996 a probe called Clementine found something unexpected on the moon: water. It was in the form of ice in the long shadows at the lunar poles, the only place where it could survive on the moon. From what we know of lunar geology, the ice can only have come from meteorites or mini-comets.

On a theoretical basis, it seemed most likely that the Spanish ice falls were ice meteorites. The biggest problem was understanding how ice could survive the intense heating by friction as it plunged through the atmosphere. When the chunks were analysed, a different story emerged. Traces of atmospheric dust were found, and the balance of isotopes was definitely terrestrial. The ice clearly came from Earth. This raised an entirely new set of questions.

Atmospheric ice falls are not particularly exotic: we call them hailstones. They are formed when ice particles are caught in an updraught within a raincloud. Supercooled water vapour condenses on the particles, laying down a new layer of ice. As it gains weight, the particle falls until it is caught by the updraught. The process is repeated and the hailstone gains layers like the growth rings of a tree. The hailstone eventually falls to earth when it is too heavy for the updraught to support.

How big can hail get? In Britain we rarely see hailstones more than two centimetres in diameter. In Texas, however, hailstones of 4cm are not uncommon and falls of 7cm hailstones have been recorded. The larger hailstones are not only heavier, they are also faster. It is a case of the bigger they are the harder they fall, which is why Texans prefer not to park outside during the storm season. Cars caught in giant hail are "waffled" - covered in small dents from dozens of impacts.

The law of physics that makes a bigger hailstone fall faster means that it takes a stronger updraught to keep it in the air. The most extreme air currents within stormclouds could not support a hailstone more than about a kilogram at most. Larger ice masses can form though, as shown by a grisly accident in Germany in 1938. Five glider pilots baled out in bad weather, but were caught in a powerful updraught and carried into a stormcloud. Their bodies became coated in layer after layer of ice, turning them into human hail. Four died, but the fifth, Guy Murchie, survived both the freezing and the fall. The layers of frost may even have cushioned his impact with the ground.

The chunks of ice from Spain do not have the characteristic onion layering of hailstones. Instead they consist of a dense mass of small crystals. This suggests that they were not formed inside clouds but higher in the stratosphere where temperatures are much lower.

At these altitudes there are jetstreams which can blow at hundreds of miles an hour, perhaps enough to support a large piece of ice if it was aerodynamically shaped. We do not know what the ice chunks looked like before they hit the ground; scientists believe that the pieces recovered are fragments of something larger. A piece of ice in the shape of a teardrop or a flattened disc might remain airborne at high altitude long enough to grow to several kilograms. Such objects would be a formidable hazard to aircraft.

It is now accepted that there is a phenomenon to be investigated, but much remains to be discovered. In the past ice falls have been very rare, whereas in Spain there seems to have been an epidemic. A study in Texas showed that giant hailstones are much commoner in hot El Nino years, when air currents are stronger.

If ice falls are linked to global warming, then we may be in for some heavy weather indeed - and insurance claims quoting "damage by unknown phenomenon" may become routine.

webTitle: Between a dot and an ad place

fields.headline: Between a dot and an ad place
fields.standfirst: The good, the bad and the hackneyed : Far from killing off advertising, the web has fuelled the biggest surge of new      business in years. But can it last, asks Jim McClellan
fields.trailText: The good, the bad and the hackneyed : Far from killing off advertising, the web has fuelled the biggest surge of new business in years. But can it last, asks Jim McClellan
fields.body:
In 1994, Wired magazine ran a cover that showed a couple of famous American ad men of the time, plus the US ad icon, the Pillsbury Doughboy, blindfolded and up against a wall. They were about to be finished off, firing squad style, by a series of TV remote controls. The accompanying blurb asked whether advertising was "finally dead?"

It went on to ponder whether the age of online interactivity would mean the end for traditional advertising. Fast-forward six years. Now you can't escape from traditional advertising taken out by companies whose business is the internet - either pure internet companies or so-called clicks and mortar operations.

The dot.coms fill up the commercial breaks on TV and radio. Buses and taxis inevitably feature a pitch for some new net company on their sides. Your daily newspaper is packed with dot.com ads. If you live in London and go to work on the tube, you'll see a few more. And if you buy sandwiches and coffee, your paper bags and cups may also feature "ambient" spots put there by the latest hot new net start-up looking to build brand awareness on a budget.

Perhaps the dot.com ads stand out because they weren't around a few years ago. And if you live inLondon, you see a lot more than you would in the rest of the country. "There are a few high spending dot.coms who are running regional as well as national TV and radio campaigns," says Caroline Sceats of net research firm Fletcher Research. "However, there isn't anything like the level of spending on outdoor advertising as you see in London."

That said, figures back up the general impression of a dot.com ad overload. According to Fletcher Research, spending on ads by companies involved in the net has been growing at an exponential rate, increasing four-fold over the past two years. Figures released by AC Nielsen show that in 1998 dot.com companies were spending £41.5m on traditional advertising in the UK. In 1999, that figure more than trebled, with around £140m being spent in total.

"The advertising industry does see it as a godsend because they were all worried about the impact of the web and thought they were going to lose out," says Patrick Burgoyne, editor of the advertising trade magazine, Creative Review. "In fact, dot.coms have been the most significant source of new business for advertising in years."

Six years is a long time on the net - an age if you believe the techno-gurus. But even so, there has obviously been a drastic turnaround since that Wired cover. Clearly, the net has woken up to commercial realities and abandoned the anti-ad attitudes it nurtured in the early 90s. More to the point, companies which work on the net have realised two things: first, that to survive they need to build brand identities consumers trust, and second, that traditional advertising is great for brand building.

Two or three years ago, dot.coms might have adver tised first on the net. Now, there's a growing scepticism about banner ads on web pages. They're seen as good for tactical campaigns: good, that is, for telling people who are already online about a particular promotion. But they are not so good for building brand awareness, and they are hopeless for reaching out to the mainstream. And that's what the dot.coms want to do. They want to establish themselves as the major players in their chosen areas as quickly as possible, so they gain first mover advantage and squeeze out potential competition.

To use the e-commerce jargon, there's a virtual land grab going on, and when it comes to staking a claim, traditional advertising (everything from TV and radio to print and outdoor posters) is seen as crucial. It's out there, in the real world, drilling home a tangible brand image to ordinary people who may not yet be online. Crucially, it gives the impression that you are a serious, reliable company like Coke, Ford, Virgin and all the other big names. It seems reassuring to consumers who are still slightly dubious about the net. That's why big dot.coms and clicks and mortar companies are prepared to spend as much as possible on advertising.

The biggest players (Freeserve, Egg and AOL) now spend £10-15m a year on advertising, enough to put them just outside the top 50 companies as far as UK ad budgets are concerned. According to Gordon Macmillan, internet editor at Campaign, everyone else is trying to keep up. "Typically, you're now seeing annual advertising budgets for a fair sized dot.com of around £5-10m." M uch of that money is going on high-profile TV campaigns. Among the more memorable dot.com ads of the last year were the spots produced by Red Handed for the online career agency monster.co.uk. Simon Parker, UK marketing director for Monster, says the company went for TV ads because it "wanted to be first out there to reach people who were getting to grips with the net".

The ads deliberately aimed for a universal appeal. "In the early days of establishing a brand, you're trying to be as inclusive as you can. We want to be that kind of brand. We're trying to appeal to people from all walks of life across the country - you have to be universal. As you grow and find out more about your customers, then you can become more targeted." Dot.coms using TV advertising is an admission, says Creative Review's Patrick Burgoyne, that "TV still reaches far wider audiences than the web, and will for some time to come". However, he argues that it would be sensible for more specialist sites to think carefully before splashing out on commercials. "With cable and satellite channels, you've got access to a more specialist audience. With general ITV slots, that isn't the case. It doesn't make as much sense spending a lot of money just to hit a very diverse audience, only a very small proportion of which are going to be interested in what you've got to say."

Indeed, some of the best known dot.coms have yet to advertise on television - lastminute.com, for example (though it could be argued that, given the amount of press it has received, it doesn't need to advertise). Instead, the company has produced a poster campaign, built around the slogan "do something lastminute.com". It was also one of a number of dot.coms to try ambient advertising. Lastminute.com put its ad messages on sandwich bags in the capital. Lunchtime is a prime time for internet use, when office workers get to do their own thing on the net. So the thinking was that it would help if the company's ad was on their desk with them, wrapped around their lunch.

Other well-known net brands have also eschewed TV in favour of other forms of traditional advertising, in particular outdoor posters. eToys concentrated on press ads and outdoor sites, says UK marketing manager James Bidwell. "We had an eToys ad on one in six London buses, which meant that people saw us on the high street. If you're a pure play internet brand, you don't have a shop front, so this was a way of us getting in front of shoppers, when they may not be having such a wonderful experience, in the rain, with lots of queues." Both Bidwell and Parker say their campaigns were very effective. Indeed, research from Fletcher Research indicates that big spenders such as Freeserve and Egg have achieved high levels of consumer awareness through traditional advertising.

Ad industry insiders are more critical. According to Campaign's Gordon Macmillan: "A lot of current campaigns miss the mark." Last year, dot.com ads were eye-catching because they were new. Now it's getting harder to stand out. Indeed, sometimes, these ads seem to blur into one big commercial for the net in general. It's hard to remember specific sites. To counter that, UK dot.coms may have to imitate their US counterparts.

In America, it's not unknown for start-ups to spend half their initial financing on TV ad campaigns. In January, dot.coms queued up to pay $2.2m for 30 seconds of airtime during the Super Bowl. They were following the example of job agency hotjobs.com, which received huge publicity from an ad during the Super Bowl in 1999. The only problem for hotjobs.com was that their ads generated too much traffic - some would-be users had to wait five days to access the site and post their CVs.

Many UK dot coms are beginning to devote a similarly large proportion of their revenue to advertising, to the potential detriment of their sites and the experience they offer. It's crucial to find a balance, says Fletcher's Caroline Sceats. "Dot.coms have to support the ad spending they need to make to grow, even if it's bankrupting them - because they have to attract customers. Their valuations are based on the number of customers they can get and their future value. To have any place in this market, they need to demonstrate they can get customers. Once they get that, they then have to put money into customer service and customer attention, to keep those customers."

According to Sceats, dot.coms will continue to have to spend highly on traditional advertising for the foreseeable future. As the UK net population increases (Fletcher predicts that 40% of the UK adult population will be online by 2004), so dot.coms will devote more of their ad budgets to online commercials. But the company also predicts that by then, the top 5% of dot.coms will need to spend at least £10m on advertising aimed at building and maintaining their brands. A sizeable share of that will still go on traditional advertising.

"Traditional advertising by the dot.coms won't go away," concludes Campaign's Gordon Macmillan. "These big companies are going to continue to need to build and develop their brands. Advertising is how you do that. If they don't do it, someone will sneak up behind them and take their space."

The good, the bad and the hackneyed
Top of the dots
Monster.co.uk
A series of glum kids talking about their dead-end future jobs. Very arresting, though a little depressing. Smile.co.uk
Contrasted the grey awfulness of traditional banking with the happy world of point and click transactions, helped by the chorus: "Smile, smile, smile." * Excite.co.uk
Men behaving strangely - breaking their car windows after overloading the boot, knocking down a glass of wine with a CD holder - alongside the slogan: "If he can, you can."

Commercial breakdown
Boo.com
Geeky guys attempting sporting activities and making fools of themselves. A well-made ad that failed to explain what boo.com does or even that it was a net company. Letsbuyit.com
Computer animated ants bring home the idea of aggregate buying. The idea explained the site well, but the execution was slated for being tacky and low-budget. AOL
The Oxo family for the new millennium ponder the costs of using the net and receives help from digital assistant Connie. Universally disliked in the ad world, though this may have much to do with creative snobbery.

Ad nauseum
 Making fun of geeks to make you feel superior. (Excite and Boo.com)
 I'd like to teach the world to click - visions of people from all round the world, usually children, delivering the same upbeat message about the net (Cisco Systems).
 Computer imagery: ads that rather unimaginatively show icons, cursors and trash cans (net bank First E), or those which mimic the point and click visuals of the net (Lloyds TSB).  Using the net to liberate the wacky inner you (Yahoo), or to escape from boring routine (IC 24).

Coming soon
 Short sharp shock ads designed to confuse and get you to check out the site to find out what's going on - used by outpost.com in the US; imitated by totalserve.com over here.
 Celebrities - new auction site Fired Up has an ad which features Bruce Willis, and LineOne is putting together a commercial featuring Malcolm McDowell. In the US, everyone from Whoopi Goldberg and Sophia Loren to Lee Majors has fronted dot.com ads.
